Users can rate and review books, create custom shelves, track reading progress, and get personalized recommendations. They can join groups, participate in discussions, and create or join reading challenges. Authors can manage profiles, interact with readers, and promote their works.
suitability_reasoning: Goodreads has many structured, CRUD-friendly entities (users, books, shelves, reviews, ratings, reading status, progress updates, groups, discussions, challenges) that can be synthesized realistically in a SQLite-backed simulation. However, core user value also relies on large-scale real bibliographic coverage, high-quality long-form reviews, and personalized recommendations driven by behavioral data and ranking logic; these can be approximated but not faithfully reproduced without a real corpus and recommendation models/search relevance.
simulatable_features: User accounts and profiles (settings, preferences, privacy controls)
Book catalog records (title, authors, series, genres, publication metadata, ISBNs, edition records) with synthesized bibliographic data
Author profiles (bio snippet, social links metadata, claimed books, Q&A posts as short text)
Shelves and shelf management (default shelves, custom shelves, tags, sorting, visibility)
Reading status workflows (Want to Read / Currently Reading / Read) and history
Reading progress tracking (percent/page, start/end dates, status updates, rereads)
Ratings (1–5 stars) and aggregated statistics (average rating, rating counts) computed from synthesized user ratings
Reviews (short-to-medium text), comments on reviews, likes/upvotes
Follow/friend relationships and basic activity feed events (user X rated book Y, added to shelf, posted update)
Groups (create/join/leave), roles (owner/mod/member), group membership management
Discussion boards/topics/posts/replies within groups (CRUD threads and replies; moderation actions)
Reading challenges (create/join challenge, set goal, track progress, completion status, leaderboards with synthesized scoring)
Lists and listopia-like collections (create list, add/remove books, vote/rank) with synthesized content
Notifications (new comment, friend activity, group updates) as stored events
Basic search endpoints over the simulated dataset (query books/authors/genres) using simple matching
Import/export of a user's library (simulated CSV upload processing into shelves/reading history)
non_simulatable_features: True real-world completeness/accuracy of the global book database (coverage of millions of real titles/editions, authoritative metadata)
High-quality, authentic long-form reviews at scale (while you can store text, you cannot replicate real community content/voice meaningfully)
Personalized recommendation quality (collaborative filtering/model-based ranking) beyond simplistic heuristic recommendations
Search relevance comparable to production (ranking, typo tolerance, deduping editions/works, knowledge graph disambiguation at scale)
Spam/abuse detection, trust/safety systems, and sophisticated moderation automation
External integrations and real-time sync (Kindle/Amazon ecosystem, publisher feeds, real author verification processes)
Real-world events/promotions and marketing campaigns tied to actual releases and author presence

name: Uber
description: Uber is a ride-hailing platform where users set pickup and dropoff locations, select ride types, view price estimates and ETA, and then request, track, and cancel rides. After trips, riders can rate drivers, leave feedback, and split fares. Drivers manage their availability, accept or decline requests, navigate routes, and view earnings. The platform handles fare calculation, payments, receipts, safety features, and support workflows like reporting issues or lost items.
suitability_reasoning: Most core workflows are structured and can be synthesized with realistic fake data: users, drivers, vehicles, trip requests, statuses, ETAs, fares, payments, receipts, ratings, and support tickets. The main limitations are features that depend on real-time GPS movement, routing/traffic, fraud detection, and external payment/identity systems; these can be approximated but not reproduced faithfully without complex simulations or third-party services.
simulatable_features: Rider and driver account management (profiles, preferences, documents status as metadata)
Driver availability/online status and service areas
Vehicle records (make/model, plate as fake, capacity, ride class eligibility)
Trip request creation (pickup/dropoff coordinates/addresses, ride type, passenger count, special instructions)
Ride dispatch workflow (matching logic stubbed; assign driver; accept/decline; reassignment)
Trip lifecycle state machine (requested, matched, driver_en_route, arrived, in_progress, completed, canceled, no_show)
ETA and price estimate generation using synthesized rules (distance-based, time-based, surge multiplier)
Fare calculation breakdown (base fare, per-mile, per-minute, fees, tolls as synthetic, surge, discounts, tips)
Payments and billing records (payment methods metadata, charges, refunds, receipts)
Cancellations and cancellation fees (policy rules, timestamps, reasons)
Ratings and short feedback (star ratings, tags, short comments)
Split fare workflow (participants, shares, pending/accepted, settlements as synthetic)
Promotions/credits (coupon creation, eligibility, redemption)
Driver earnings and payouts (trip earnings, weekly statements, payout requests)
In-app notifications and messaging metadata (sent/received logs, templates)
Safety feature records as workflow metadata (share trip status, emergency button event logs, trusted contacts as entities)
Support workflows (report an issue, lost item ticket, dispute fare, ticket statuses, agent notes)
non_simulatable_features: Real-world GPS tracking and continuous live location streaming with accurate movement
High-fidelity routing and navigation (turn-by-turn directions) and real-time traffic-aware ETAs
Real surge pricing driven by live supply/demand signals (can be faked, but not genuinely replicated)
Fraud detection, risk scoring, and identity verification based on real signals/documents
Real payment processing networks and bank/card authorization behavior (only mockable)
Phone/SMS relay, VoIP calling, and emergency services integration
Real-time safety monitoring/telemetry and incident detection (e.g., crash detection) beyond event stubs
Regulatory/compliance checks tied to real driver background checks and government databases

name: Airbnb
description: Airbnb is a marketplace for short-term stays and experiences. Guests can search and filter listings by location, dates, price, property type, and amenities, then view detailed pages with photos, descriptions, house rules, and reviews. They submit booking requests or use instant book, manage trips, send messages to hosts, and handle cancellations or changes. Hosts can create and edit listings, set pricing and availability, manage calendars, respond to inquiries, and review guests. The platform manages payments, identity checks, and dispute resolution.
suitability_reasoning: Airbnb’s core workflows are structured and transactional (listings, availability calendars, bookings, payments, messaging, reviews, cancellations), which map cleanly to a relational schema and RESTful CRUD APIs. Most data can be synthesized realistically (prices, dates, locations, amenities, policies, statuses). The main limitations are media (photos), real identity verification, fraud/risk scoring, and complex real-world payment/dispute operations, which can be stubbed but not fully replicated.
simulatable_features: User accounts and profiles (guest/host), preferences, verification status flags
Listing CRUD (title, description, address/city/geo, property type, room type, capacity, amenities, house rules, check-in/out windows)
Pricing configuration (base price, seasonal rates, weekend multipliers, cleaning fee, extra guest fees, discounts, minimum/maximum stay rules)
Availability calendar management (blocked dates, custom nightly prices, booking windows, preparation time)
Search and filtering over synthesized listing attributes (location bounding box/city, dates, price range, property type, amenities, occupancy)
Booking request / instant book flows (reservation creation, approval/decline, status transitions, confirmation codes)
Trip management (itineraries, reservation modifications, special requests, check-in instructions text fields)
Cancellations and refunds (policy types, cancellation reasons, computed refund amounts, timelines)
Messaging between guest and host (threads, messages, read receipts, attachments metadata placeholders)
Reviews and ratings (overall score, sub-ratings, short text, review eligibility rules after checkout)
Host tools (inquiry management, response tracking, acceptance rate metrics computed from data)
Payments ledger simulation (charges, holds, payouts, service fees, taxes as numeric fields; payment status transitions)
Experiences CRUD (experience listings, schedules, capacity, bookings) using the same reservation model
Dispute/case records (case creation, evidence text fields, status workflow, support agent assignment)
Notifications (email/push/in-app) as stored events with delivery status
non_simulatable_features: Real photo hosting/processing and image content (can only simulate URLs/metadata, not authentic media)
True identity verification (government ID checks, biometric validation) and third-party KYC integrations
Fraud detection, risk scoring, and trust/safety ML-driven decisions (can only stub outcomes)
Real payment processing and banking network interactions (card authorization, chargebacks, payouts timing/settlement)
Accurate tax calculation/remittance across jurisdictions and legal compliance logic (can only approximate with rules)
Real-time availability synchronization with external property management systems and channel managers
Phone/SMS deliverability and telecom verification (can only simulate message records)
Live customer support operations (human moderation, investigation outcomes) beyond scripted workflows
Geocoding accuracy and map rendering from real providers (can only store lat/long and basic proximity filtering)
Enforcement of complex local regulations (permits, zoning, short-term rental laws) beyond simplified flags

name: Trello
description: Trello is a visual project and task management tool based on boards, lists, and cards. Users create boards for projects, add lists to represent stages, and cards for tasks, which can be moved across lists to show progress. Cards support descriptions, checklists, attachments, labels, due dates, and assignees. Teams can comment, mention members, and subscribe to updates. Power-Ups and automations add features like custom fields, rules, integrations, and calendar views.
suitability_reasoning: Trello’s core value is structured CRUD over highly synthesizable entities (workspaces/boards/lists/cards) with clear relationships and state transitions (card movement, statuses, assignments, due dates). Most workflows can be fully represented with a SQLite schema and REST endpoints. Advanced integrations/Power-Ups and real-time collaboration aspects can be approximated but external third-party behavior and real-time event delivery are not fully reproducible without additional infrastructure.
simulatable_features: User accounts, profiles, and authentication tokens (simulated)
Workspaces/teams creation and membership management
Role-based access control (admin/member/observer) and board visibility (private/workspace/public)
Boards CRUD, board settings, and templates (as structured metadata)
Lists CRUD and list ordering within boards
Cards CRUD with position/order, moving cards across lists, and archiving/unarchiving
Card fields: title, description, due date, start date, reminders (as timestamps/flags), cover metadata
Assignees/members on cards and watchers/subscriptions
Labels CRUD and label assignment to cards
Checklists and checklist items CRUD with completion state
Comments on cards, mentions (as parsed text/metadata), and activity logs
Attachments metadata CRUD (filename, URL placeholder, size, mime type) and association to cards
Custom fields (as schema-less key/value definitions per board) and per-card values
Board/card search and filtering (by label, member, due date, text) using database queries
Notifications/inbox as stored events (create/update/comment/mention) retrievable via API
Simple automation rules engine (simulated): triggers (card moved, due date reached) -> actions (add label, assign member, move card)
Exports/imports as generated JSON/CSV representations of entities (simulated)
Calendar view data endpoints derived from due/start dates (data only)
non_simulatable_features: True real-time collaboration guarantees (live cursor/instant sync across clients) without a websocket/event system; can only be approximated with polling
Third-party Power-Ups and external integrations (Slack, Google Drive, Jira, etc.) with real external side effects; only mock connectors are feasible
File storage/preview/virus scanning and rich attachment rendering (can simulate metadata, not actual storage and preview pipelines)
Email-to-board ingestion and inbound email parsing/delivery (can be stubbed, not fully replicated)
Push notification delivery to devices (APNs/FCM) and email delivery (can be represented as queued messages only)
Enterprise-grade audit/retention/compliance features tied to real org policies and identity providers (SAML/SCIM) beyond simplified simulation
Sophisticated automation with complex conditions, rate limits, and execution semantics identical to Trello Butler; only simplified rules are practical

name: Stripe
description: Stripe is an online payments platform that enables businesses to accept and manage payments. Users can create customers, store payment methods, charge cards, set up subscriptions, issue refunds, and handle invoices and payouts. Dashboards show balances, payouts, disputes, and detailed transaction histories with filters and exports. Developers integrate Stripe via APIs and webhooks to support checkout flows, billing, and marketplace payouts, with configuration for tax, currencies, risk rules, and compliance.
suitability_reasoning: Stripe’s core product is structured financial objects and stateful workflows (customers, payment methods, charges, refunds, subscriptions, invoices, payouts, disputes) that map cleanly to relational data and CRUD+state-transition APIs. Transaction histories, balances, and lifecycle events can be synthesized realistically. The main limits are features requiring external banking/card networks, real identity verification, tax jurisdiction logic, and sophisticated risk/ML decisions; those can be stubbed with deterministic rules and simulated statuses/events without needing real-world connectivity.
simulatable_features: Customer lifecycle: create/update/delete customers, metadata, addresses, default payment method
Payment methods vault (simulated): attach/detach cards/bank accounts, tokenization placeholders, set defaults
Payment intents/charges: create/confirm/capture/cancel payments with status transitions (requires_action, succeeded, failed)
Refunds: partial/full refunds, refund status, refund history and links to original charge
Invoices: draft/finalize/pay/void invoices, line items, discounts, credits, invoice PDFs as metadata links
Subscriptions and billing: plans/prices, subscription create/pause/cancel, proration flags, billing cycles, trial periods
Products/prices/catalog entries used for billing
Coupons/promotion codes and application to invoices/subscriptions
Disputes/chargebacks: open/needs_response/won/lost states, evidence fields, deadlines
Balances and ledger-style transaction history (simulated balance transactions) with filtering and pagination
Payouts: schedule configuration, payout creation, paid/failed/canceled states, payout items
Connected accounts/marketplace: create accounts, capabilities flags, transfers, application fees (as simulated records)
Transfers and internal movements between balances (platform to connected accounts)
Taxes as configurable rates/overrides (simple synthetic tax rules, stored as objects)
Currencies and exchange rates (static or synthetic tables) and multi-currency balances
Webhook/event stream simulation: emit events for payment_succeeded, invoice_paid, subscription_updated, dispute_created, payout_paid, etc.
Dashboard-like reporting endpoints: aggregates (daily volume, MRR, churn), exports as generated CSV strings or job objects
Configuration objects: risk rules (simple), allowed payment methods, checkout settings, branding settings
Idempotency keys and request logs (synthetic) for developer workflow realism
API keys/projects/workspaces (synthetic) and role-based access within a simulated org
non_simulatable_features: Actual card network and bank rail processing (authorization/settlement, real declines, interchange fees) beyond scripted simulation
Real-time 3DS/SCA flows with authentic issuer challenges and device/browser-based authentication (can only be mocked)
Fraud detection and risk scoring driven by proprietary ML models (Radar) and large-scale network signals; only rule-based approximations are simulatable
Identity verification/KYC/AML and sanctions screening with real document validation and external data sources; only status stubs are feasible
Accurate tax determination across jurisdictions (address validation, nexus rules, product taxability) without a full tax engine; only simplified logic can be simulated
Real payout timing, bank cutoffs, returns, and reconciliation against external bank statements (can be approximated with synthetic schedules)
PCI compliance, tokenization security guarantees, and secure storage of real payment credentials (must be simulated with placeholders)
Network dispute evidence submission and outcomes dependent on card networks; only state transitions and deadlines can be simulated
Real exchange rates and FX spreads from live markets (can be replaced with static/synthetic rates)
Regulatory reporting and compliance attestations tied to real entities and filings

name: Robinhood
description: Robinhood is a commission-free investing platform where users can search for stocks, ETFs, options, and cryptocurrencies, view quotes and charts, and place market or limit orders. Users manage watchlists, review portfolio performance, deposit or withdraw funds, and set up recurring investments. The app offers basic news, educational content, and alerts for price moves or corporate actions. Compliance features handle account verification, risk disclosures, and regulatory requirements.
suitability_reasoning: Most core workflows are structured, stateful CRUD operations over highly synthesizable entities (accounts, positions, orders, trades, transfers, instruments, watchlists, alerts). Market prices, charts, and corporate actions can be generated as plausible time-series data. The main gaps are features that depend on real-time market connectivity, best-execution/venue routing, and proprietary or third-party content (news/education) which are not essential to simulate the operational trading lifecycle.
simulatable_features: User account creation and profile management
KYC/verification workflow states (submitted/approved/rejected), disclosures acceptance, risk questionnaires
Brokerage accounts (individual, margin, IRA) and settings
Cash balances, buying power, margin balances, interest/fees as ledger entries
Instrument master data (stocks/ETFs/options/crypto) with symbols, metadata, trading status
Search over instruments (synthetic catalog + basic filtering)
Quotes (bid/ask/last), OHLC candles, historical charts (synthetic time-series)
Order placement and lifecycle (market/limit/stop; open/filled/partial/canceled/rejected)
Trade executions and fills (synthetic fills with timestamps and prices)
Portfolio holdings/positions, cost basis, unrealized/realized P&L calculations
Watchlists (create/update/delete lists, add/remove symbols)
Recurring investments schedules and generated recurring orders
Deposits/withdrawals/ACH transfers with statuses (pending/completed/failed/reversed)
Account activity feed (orders, dividends, fees, transfers) as auditable events
Dividends and corporate actions as synthetic events impacting positions/cash
Tax lots and basic tax documents metadata (not full legal forms), realized gains reports
Alerts/notifications rules (price thresholds, percent move, corporate action alerts) and generated alert events
Basic entitlement/permissions (e.g., options enabled tiers) and trading restrictions flags
non_simulatable_features: True real-time market data and exchange-grade order book dynamics
Actual routing, best execution logic, and integration with real broker-dealer/clearing infrastructure
Real cryptocurrency on-chain transfers, custody, and blockchain confirmations
Authentic third-party news content and licensed research/educational articles (full-text)
Regulatory reporting and compliance checks requiring external identity/AML/sanctions services
Accurate pricing/greeks for options based on live volatility surfaces and market conditions
Real-world outages/halts/market-wide circuit breakers as they occur in real time (can be mocked but not reproduced faithfully)
Any feature relying on proprietary recommendation/personalization models (if present)

name: Calendly
description: Calendly is an automated scheduling platform that lets users define event types with duration, locations (in-person or online), and availability rules, then share booking links. Invitees pick a time from free slots synced with connected calendars, automatically creating events and sending confirmations. Users can set buffers, limits per day, questions for invitees, and reminders, plus rescheduling and cancellation policies. Integrations connect to video conferencing, CRM, and payment tools.
suitability_reasoning: Calendly’s core workflows are structured CRUD over highly synthesizable entities (users, event types, availability rules, bookings, invitees, questions, reminders, policies). A simulated environment can generate realistic calendars, time slots, bookings, and state transitions (confirmed/rescheduled/canceled) without needing real external data. The main complexity is time-zone/time-slot computation and external calendar/video/payment integrations, but these can be simulated with deterministic rules and stubbed connectors.
simulatable_features: User accounts, profiles, preferences (time zone, working hours, locale)
Teams, roles, permissions, and shared scheduling pools (round-robin/collective availability as simplified rules)
Event type management (duration, location type, capacity, buffer times, min notice, max advance booking window)
Availability rules (weekly schedules, date overrides, holidays, busy blocks)
Booking link generation and public booking-page configuration metadata
Free/busy calculation and time-slot generation based on synthetic calendar events and availability constraints
Invitee management (name/email/phone), booking creation, booking status lifecycle (pending/confirmed/canceled/rescheduled/no-show)
Rescheduling and cancellation flows with policy enforcement (cutoff times, allowed windows, reasons)
Intake forms / invitee questions (custom fields), storing responses with the booking
Notifications configuration and delivery logs (email/SMS) as queued messages with timestamps and templates
Reminders and follow-ups scheduling (e.g., X hours before/after) and execution logs
Payment settings for event types (price, currency, required/optional), invoices/receipts, payment status (authorized/paid/refunded) using synthetic transactions
Basic analytics endpoints (counts by event type, booking conversion, cancellations) computed from stored synthetic data
Integration objects and connection states (connected/disconnected), token placeholders, webhook subscription CRUD, webhook event logs
Conference details generation (e.g., synthetic meeting URL/ID) when a booking is confirmed
non_simulatable_features: True real-time sync with external calendar providers (Google/Microsoft/Apple) including conflict resolution with live external data
Actual delivery of emails/SMS/push notifications through real providers and guaranteed deliverability semantics
Real video conferencing meeting creation on Zoom/Teams/Meet with real credentials and provider-side settings
Real payment processing, fraud checks, chargebacks, and provider-specific behaviors (Stripe/PayPal) beyond synthetic transaction state
Complex, provider-accurate availability computation that mirrors every edge case of external calendars (recurring event rules, exceptions, permission scopes) unless heavily simplified
Enterprise SSO/SCIM provisioning against real identity providers (Okta/Azure AD) beyond simulated assertions and user provisioning records
CRM-native behaviors (e.g., Salesforce lead routing, HubSpot workflows) driven by external systems rather than internal CRUD data
Human-facing booking page rendering/UX details (the web UI), beyond serving configuration/data via APIs

name: Stack Overflow
description: Stack Overflow is a Q&A platform for developers where users ask programming questions, tag them by technology, and post code and explanations. Others can answer, comment, and edit content collaboratively. Voting, acceptance, and reputation systems surface high-quality answers and unlock privileges. Users can bookmark questions, follow tags, and search across the knowledge base. Teams and enterprises can create private spaces with dedicated moderation and analytics.
suitability_reasoning: Stack Overflow’s core data model (users, questions, answers, comments, tags, votes, reputation, badges, moderation flags) is highly structured and CRUD-friendly, so a realistic simulated environment is feasible. However, the platform’s primary value depends on a large corpus of high-quality long-form technical content, nuanced duplicate/quality judgments, and sophisticated search/ranking, which are hard to meaningfully synthesize without losing realism. A simulation can focus on workflows and mechanics (posting, editing, voting, moderation, permissions) rather than replicating the real knowledge base quality.
simulatable_features: User accounts and profiles (display name, bio, developer role, settings)
Question CRUD (title, body, code blocks, tags, status: open/closed/duplicate)
Answer CRUD (body, code blocks, accepted answer state)
Comments CRUD on questions/answers
Tag management (create tags, tag synonyms/aliases, tag following/ignored tags)
Voting system (upvote/downvote) and vote audit trails
Acceptance workflow (question owner accepts/unaccepts an answer)
Reputation and badge awarding rules (synthetic but consistent point changes and thresholds)
Bookmarks/favorites and reading lists
User privileges/roles based on reputation (e.g., can comment, edit, close-vote)
Edits and suggested edits with review/approval queues
Moderation workflows (flags, close votes, reopen votes, delete/undelete, suspension records)
Post history and revisions (diff metadata, editor, timestamps)
Basic search endpoints over synthetic content (keyword/tag filters) without real ranking parity
Teams/private spaces (teams, memberships, permissions, private posts) and basic analytics counters
non_simulatable_features: A truly realistic large-scale corpus of authoritative programming Q&A content comparable to the real site
High-fidelity search relevance, ranking, and duplicate detection comparable to Stack Overflow’s production systems
Community quality dynamics at real scale (organic expertise distribution, emergent norms, long-tail topics)
Nuanced moderation judgments requiring human expertise (what is duplicate, off-topic, low-quality, spam) beyond simplistic rules
Real-time popularity/trending signals derived from global traffic patterns
External integrations and identity/SSO behaviors in enterprise contexts (can be mocked, but not fully replicated)
AI-assisted or semantic features (if present) that rely on trained models or embeddings for meaning-based retrieval

name: GitLab
description: GitLab is a DevOps platform centered on Git repositories, issues, and CI/CD pipelines. Users create projects, push code, manage branches, open merge requests, review diffs, and handle approvals. Issues and boards track work, with labels, milestones, and assignees. Built-in pipelines automate testing and deployment, and environments show deployment status. Permissions, groups, and project settings manage access, integrations, and security features like code scanning and approvals.
suitability_reasoning: GitLab’s core workflows are largely structured CRUD over synthesizable entities (projects, repos/branches, merge requests, issues, labels, pipelines, jobs, environments, users/groups/permissions). These map cleanly to relational data and REST endpoints. What’s hard to faithfully simulate is the true Git object model/diff/merge behavior and real CI execution/security scanning, but you can still simulate them as state machines with plausible metadata and logs, enabling realistic task completion without running real builds or storing real code history.
simulatable_features: Users, SSH keys, access tokens (CRUD, scopes, expiration)
Groups, subgroups, memberships, roles/permissions (RBAC)
Projects (create/archive/transfer), project settings (visibility, default branch, merge policies)
Repository metadata layer: branches/tags (create/delete), commits (synthetic), files (synthetic blobs), releases (version, notes, assets metadata)

Merge requests: creation, status transitions (draft/open/merged/closed), reviewers/assignees, approvals, approval rules, discussions/comments, simple diff metadata (files changed, lines added/removed)
Issues: CRUD, states, assignees, due dates, time tracking fields, comments, relationships (links/blocks), epics (if modeled)
Boards: lists/columns, issue positioning, swimlanes as metadata
Labels and milestones (project/group scoped), issue/MR labeling and milestone assignment
Pipelines: create/trigger (push/MR/schedule/manual), pipeline status, stages, jobs, retries/cancels, artifacts metadata, job logs as stored text
Runners registry (registered runners, tags, online/offline status) as synthetic resources
Environments and deployments: environment CRUD, deployment records, statuses, rollbacks as state transitions, last-deployed info
CI/CD variables and secrets metadata (store masked placeholder values), protected branches/tags rules
Webhooks/integrations configuration records (URLs, events) without actual external calls
Package/container registry metadata: packages, versions, download counts, manifests as metadata
Audit events (synthetic) and activity feeds (derived from stored events)
Wiki pages and snippets as short text content
Basic security/compliance records as metadata: vulnerabilities list, severities, findings, approval requirements, policy objects
non_simulatable_features: Full-fidelity Git behavior: true commit DAG integrity, merges/rebases/cherry-picks with conflict resolution, binary delta storage, and exact diff computation over real file contents at scale
Actual CI/CD execution: running builds/tests, executing scripts, producing real artifacts, interacting with real runners/kubernetes/cloud providers
Real security scanning and SAST/DAST/secret detection results generated from code analysis (can only be faked as findings metadata)
Accurate code review UX semantics derived from real diffs/blame/inline comments anchored to exact line hashes (can only be approximated)
Real-time event streaming and performance characteristics (websocket updates, trace views, live job logs) beyond static/polled APIs
Third-party integrations that require external systems (LDAP/SAML auth, Jira syncing, Slack notifications, cloud deployments) beyond storing configuration and simulated callbacks
Advanced analytics/insights that require aggregating large real histories (cycle analytics, code ownership metrics, DORA metrics) unless simplified to synthetic aggregates

name: Uber Eats
description: Uber Eats is a food delivery platform that lets users browse restaurants, filter by cuisine, price, rating, or delivery time, and customize orders with menu options and special instructions. Users manage carts, apply promos, place orders, and track courier location in real time. They can modify or cancel orders within constraints, rate restaurants and couriers, and view past orders. Restaurants and couriers use their own dashboards/apps to manage menus, orders, and deliveries.
suitability_reasoning: Core workflows are structured, CRUD-heavy, and can be represented with synthesizable entities (users, restaurants, menus, carts, orders, payments, couriers, delivery tasks, statuses, timestamps, fees). Even time/distance/ETA and location updates can be simulated with plausible coordinates and event streams. The only parts that are hard to replicate faithfully are real-time maps/traffic-based routing, live geolocation accuracy, and integration with real payment, identity, and notification providers.
simulatable_features: User accounts and profiles (customer/restaurant/courier roles)
Restaurant discovery catalog (restaurants, locations, hours, service areas, cuisine tags)
Menu management (items, modifiers/options, availability, pricing, taxes, prep times)
Search/filter/sort over the synthesized catalog (by cuisine, price range, rating, ETA)
Cart lifecycle (add/remove items, quantities, modifiers, special instructions, tips)
Checkout calculations (subtotal, delivery fee, service fee, tax, discounts, tip, total)
Promo codes and eligibility rules (min spend, restaurant-specific, expirations, usage limits)
Order placement and order state machine (created/accepted/preparing/picked_up/delivered/cancelled/refunded)
Order modification/cancellation windows with constraints (time-based and status-based rules)
Restaurant order management dashboard (accept/reject, adjust prep time, mark ready, item out-of-stock flows)
Courier dispatch assignment (offer/accept, batching/stacked orders, reassign, cancel, availability)
Delivery task tracking as simulated events (status updates, timestamps, synthetic courier GPS pings)
ETA estimation using synthetic distance/prep-time models (non-real-time, rule-based)
In-app messaging records (customer-restaurant-courier threads as stored messages)
Ratings and reviews for restaurants/couriers (stars, short text, tags, complaint reasons)
Order history, receipts/invoices, refunds/adjustments as ledger entries
Address book management (saved addresses, delivery instructions, geocoded lat/long)
Support tickets and issue types (missing items, late delivery, wrong order) with resolutions
non_simulatable_features: True real-time courier location and map rendering with real GPS accuracy and jitter characteristics (can only be approximated with synthetic coordinates)
Traffic-aware routing, navigation, and highly accurate ETAs based on real-time road conditions
Real payment processing and fraud detection (card network interactions, 3DS, risk scoring)
Real-world identity verification/background checks for couriers and compliance workflows
Push/SMS/phone calling through real telecom providers (only mockable as logged notification events)
Real inventory synchronization with restaurant POS systems and external integrations
Demand/surge pricing and dispatch optimization driven by proprietary ML/optimization at scale (can only be simplified with rules)
Live operational constraints and edge cases from real-world events (road closures, accidents, restaurant downtime) beyond scripted simulation

name: QuickBooks
description: QuickBooks is an accounting and bookkeeping platform for small businesses. Users can create and send invoices, track payments and expenses, categorize transactions, reconcile bank accounts, and manage customers and vendors. The system generates financial reports such as profit and loss, balance sheets, and cash flow. Payroll, tax, and inventory modules manage employees, filing, and stock. Multi-user access, roles, and audit trails support collaboration and compliance.
suitability_reasoning: QuickBooks is centered on highly structured, relational business data (customers, vendors, invoices, bills, accounts, transactions, payroll records, inventory items) and well-defined workflows (invoice-to-cash, bill-to-pay, reconciliation, period close). This data is straightforward to synthesize realistically in SQLite and expose via REST CRUD endpoints. While some integrations (live bank feeds, payments rails, tax filing) and complex accounting edge cases are hard to fully replicate, the core product experience can be simulated well with synthesized ledgers, transactions, and reports computed from stored data.
simulatable_features: User accounts, companies/books, multi-entity setups (subsidiaries/classes/locations as simplified dimensions)
Role-based access control (users, roles, permissions) and multi-user collaboration
Customer management (profiles, contacts, addresses, terms, credit limits)
Vendor/supplier management (profiles, payment terms, 1099 flags as metadata)
Chart of accounts management (account types, subaccounts, opening balances)
Invoice creation, editing, sending status, line items, discounts, taxes (as configurable rates), due dates
Estimates/quotes and conversion to invoices
Sales receipts and credit memos/refunds (as transaction types and status flows)
Accounts receivable: payment records, partial payments, aging buckets, applying payments to invoices
Expense tracking: expense transactions, categorization, attachments as metadata references, reimbursements (simplified)
Bills and accounts payable: bill entry, due dates, bill payment records, payment status
Recurring transactions/templates and scheduled generation
Bank accounts (registers) and imported bank transactions as synthetic feeds
Bank reconciliation workflows (statement periods, matched/unmatched transactions, reconciliation status)
Journal entries (double-entry postings), ledger postings, period close/lock dates (simplified)
Inventory items/products/services catalog (SKUs, costs, sales prices, quantity on hand)
Inventory adjustments and cost tracking (simplified average cost/FIFO as a chosen rule)
Purchase orders and receiving (simplified) tied to inventory changes
Payroll module (simplified): employees, pay schedules, pay runs, earnings/deductions, paystubs as records
Time tracking entries linked to employees/jobs (optional simplified jobs/projects)
Tax settings (sales tax rates, payroll tax rates as configuration) and computed liabilities (simplified)
Financial reports generated from stored transactions: Profit & Loss, Balance Sheet, Cash Flow, A/R Aging, A/P Aging, Trial Balance, General Ledger
Audit trail/event log of CRUD actions on key entities (who/when/what changed)
Document/attachment metadata management (filename, type, linked entity) without storing real files
non_simulatable_features: Live bank connections and real-time bank feed aggregation (Plaid/OFX-style integrations) with institution-specific behaviors
Real payment processing (card/ACH rails), settlement timing, chargebacks, and compliance requirements beyond mock status simulation
Official tax filing/e-filing workflows and jurisdiction-specific compliance logic (full fidelity), including submissions to government systems
Country/state-specific payroll compliance at full accuracy (withholding tables, filings, benefits integrations) beyond simplified rules
Third-party marketplace app ecosystem behaviors and proprietary integrations (e.g., Shopify, Stripe, Square, POS systems) beyond mocked connectors
Advanced accounting edge cases at full fidelity (multi-currency revaluation, complex revenue recognition, consolidated reporting, complex accrual/deferral schedules) unless heavily simplified
OCR/receipt scanning and automated transaction categorization powered by ML (can be stubbed but not meaningfully replicated)
Email deliverability and real outbound messaging (invoices/statements) beyond simulated send status and message logs

name: Jira
description: Jira is a project and issue tracking platform widely used for software development. Users create projects and configure workflows with states like To Do, In Progress, and Done, then create issues for tasks, bugs, or stories. Issues have fields such as assignee, priority, labels, sprints, and estimates, plus comments and attachments. Scrum and Kanban boards, backlogs, and reports help teams plan and track work. Admins manage schemes, permissions, integrations, and automation rules.
suitability_reasoning: Jira’s core value is managing structured, user-generated entities (projects, issues, workflows, sprints, boards, comments) with clear relationships and state transitions. Nearly all key behaviors can be represented as CRUD plus a few action endpoints (transition issue state, move issue to sprint/backlog). Data is highly synthesizable (statuses, priorities, estimates, timestamps, users, links), enabling realistic workflows without external real-time dependencies. Some advanced features (complex JQL semantics, marketplace integrations, and rich attachment handling) are harder to fully replicate but are not required for a useful simulation.
simulatable_features: User, team, and role management (create users, assign to groups/roles)
Project creation and configuration (project keys, types, components, versions)
Issue CRUD (epic/story/task/bug), including fields like assignee, reporter, priority, labels, due date, estimates, custom fields
Issue relationships (parent/child, epic links, blocks/duplicates/relates links)
Workflow modeling (statuses, transitions, resolution fields) and issue state transitions
Backlog and sprint management (create sprints, start/complete, move issues between backlog and sprints, sprint ranking/order)
Kanban board columns and WIP limits (store and update board/column config; move issues across columns via transitions)
Comments and mentions (CRUD comments, basic @mention metadata)
Worklogs/time tracking (log time, edit/delete worklogs, remaining estimate updates)
Attachments metadata (record attachment entries with filenames, sizes, mime types, upload timestamps; optionally store as blobs in SQLite)
Notifications and watchers (watch/unwatch issues, store notification events)
Permissions and schemes (simulate project permissions, issue security levels, roles; enforce basic access control in API)
Issue search with simplified filtering (by project, status, assignee, label, sprint, priority, text contains) as a subset of JQL
Dashboards and reports using synthesized aggregates (burndown data, velocity, cumulative flow computed from stored issue history)
Audit logs (record admin/config changes and issue events)
Automation rules in a simplified form (if status changes then assign, transition, comment; scheduled rules) with deterministic execution
non_simulatable_features: Full fidelity JQL (complete grammar, advanced functions, permissions-aware ranking, performance characteristics)
Marketplace app ecosystem and real third-party integrations (Slack/GitHub/Bitbucket/CI providers) beyond mocked webhook endpoints
Email ingestion and outbound email deliverability (can be stubbed, not truly replicated end-to-end)
Rich real-time collaboration and UI behaviors (live updates, drag-and-drop nuances) beyond representing state changes via APIs
Advanced automation engine parity (complex branching, smart values, entity properties, cross-project scalability and timing guarantees)
Native file storage/CDN behavior for large attachments (streaming, antivirus scanning, preview generation, retention policies)
Atlassian Cloud organization-wide features and identity (SSO/SAML/SCIM) in full depth (can be approximated but not truly equivalent)
Advanced analytics and machine-learning-driven insights (predictive estimates, anomaly detection) if present in specific Jira editions

name: Google Calendar
description: Google Calendar is an online calendar and scheduling tool where users create events with titles, times, locations, guests, and video conferencing links. They can manage multiple calendars, share calendars with others, set notifications and reminders, and adjust visibility. Events support recurring rules, descriptions, attachments, and responses (RSVP). Users can search events, view by day/week/month, and integrate with other apps to auto-create meetings and reminders.
suitability_reasoning: Google Calendar’s core value is structured, user-created data (calendars, events, attendees, recurrence rules, reminders, sharing/permissions) with clear entity relationships and state transitions, all of which can be synthesized realistically in a SQLite-backed REST API. Most workflows are CRUD-centric (create/update/cancel events, invite/RSVP, manage calendars/sharing) and do not require real-time external feeds. Some integrations (video conferencing provisioning, email delivery, external app sync) are better represented as mocked side effects rather than fully reproduced.
simulatable_features: User accounts and profiles (time zone, locale, default reminders)
Multiple calendars per user (create/rename/delete, color, primary calendar concept)
Calendar sharing and permissions (owner/writer/reader/free-busy, domain/public flags)
Event CRUD (title, description, start/end, all-day, location, visibility, status)
Recurring events with RRULE-like patterns and exception instances (exdates, modified occurrences)
Attendees/guests management (invite list, optional/required, guest permissions)
RSVP workflow and statuses (needsAction/accepted/declined/tentative) and per-attendee response timestamps
Reminders/notifications configuration (email/popup types, minutes-before, overrides per event)
Event metadata (created/updated timestamps, organizer, sequence/versioning)
Search/filter events (by time range, text query, organizer/attendee, calendar, status)
Free/busy queries computed from synthesized events
Availability-based scheduling suggestions using stored free/busy (simplified)
Attachments as metadata (filename, mimeType, size, URL placeholder) without storing real files
Task/meeting templates or quick-add parsing (simplified deterministic parsing rules)
Import/export as simplified iCal-like data (as text blobs or structured fields)
Audit/activity logs for changes (who changed what, when)
Soft delete/cancel events and calendar retention behavior
Time zone handling (store event TZ, convert for display endpoints)
non_simulatable_features: Real Google Meet/video conferencing link provisioning and lifecycle (actual meeting rooms, join behavior)
Real email/SMS/push delivery of invitations and reminders (can only be mocked/queued)
Deep integration with external Google services (Gmail auto-detect events, Workspace directory, Smart Compose, etc.)
True cross-client sync behavior and conflict resolution identical to Google’s distributed system
Natural-language understanding at Google quality for event creation (can only approximate)
Enterprise policy enforcement and domain-wide administration identical to Google Workspace
Real-time presence/typing/instant collaboration nuances in the UI
Indexing/ranking behavior of Google’s production-grade search and suggestions beyond basic filters
Third-party app ecosystem behaviors (webhooks, OAuth scopes, add-ons marketplace) at full fidelity

name: Ticketmaster
description: Ticketmaster is a ticketing platform for concerts, sports, and live events. Users search by artist, team, venue, or date, then choose events, select seats on a map or via price filters, and complete purchases. They can view and manage orders, download or add tickets to mobile wallets, transfer tickets, and in some cases resell them. Event organizers manage inventory, pricing, presales, and access controls. The system handles payments, delivery methods, and anti-fraud checks.
suitability_reasoning: Ticketing is dominated by structured, relational data and transactional CRUD workflows (events, venues, seat inventory, offers/prices, carts, orders, tickets, transfers, and resale listings). These can be synthesized realistically in SQLite with deterministic business rules. Some peripheral capabilities (real payment networks, barcode cryptography, wallet integrations, and sophisticated fraud detection) are not meaningfully reproducible, but they can be stubbed while preserving end-to-end user tasks.
simulatable_features: User accounts, profiles, saved payment methods (tokenized placeholders), and preferences
Browse/search events by artist/team/venue/date/category (simulated search endpoints with filters/sorts)
Venue and seating charts as structured sections/rows/seats; seat availability status and holds
Ticket types and offers (price levels, fees, taxes, accessible seating flags, quantity limits)
Presale codes and access windows; eligibility rules per user/segment
Cart creation, add/remove seats or GA quantities, cart expiration timers (simulated), and fee breakdown
Checkout flow producing orders, line items, totals, and receipts; order status transitions (pending/paid/canceled/refunded)
Ticket issuance as digital assets (ticket records with barcodes as synthetic strings), delivery method selection (mobile/print/will-call as statuses)
Order history, order details, refunds/voids (rule-based), and customer support case records
Ticket transfer workflow: create transfer, accept/decline, revoke, recipient accounts, transfer status tracking
Resale marketplace: create listing, set price, listing status, purchase resale ticket, payout status (simulated)
Organizer/admin workflows: create events, configure inventory, allocate holds/comp blocks, set pricing tiers, manage on-sale dates, manage promotions
Basic fraud/risk flags as rule-based fields (e.g., velocity checks, mismatched country) and manual review queue
Notifications as message records (email/SMS push simulated as stored events) for order confirmations, transfers, and reminders
non_simulatable_features: Real-time integration with external venue turnstile systems and live admission scanning behavior at scale
Cryptographically secure, rotating barcodes / token schemes tied to device attestation and anti-screenshot controls (can only be mocked)
True payment processing, chargebacks, 3DS flows, and bank/card network interactions (must be stubbed)
Mobile wallet integrations (Apple Wallet/Google Wallet) and device-level ticket provisioning (mock metadata only)
Advanced anti-fraud and bot mitigation (behavioral analytics, device fingerprinting, ML scoring) beyond simple rule simulation
Real-world seat map rendering/interactive UX and map-based selection nuances (API can represent seat geometry but not full UI behavior)
Real-time dynamic pricing algorithms and demand forecasting driven by proprietary models (can approximate with rules but not replicate)
Identity verification/know-your-customer checks for certain events/regions when dependent on third-party services (stubbed)

name: Instacart
description: Instacart is a grocery delivery and pickup service. Users select a store, browse categories or search for products, adjust quantities, and add items to a cart. At checkout, they choose delivery or pickup times, specify substitutions, and apply promo codes. During fulfillment, shoppers may message customers about replacements, and customers can track order progress and delivery in real time. Users can rate orders, tip shoppers, and view purchase history and receipts.
suitability_reasoning: Instacart’s core workflows are structured CRUD-friendly operations over synthesizable entities (stores, products, carts, orders, deliveries, substitutions, payments, tips, messages, ratings). The main non-simulatable aspects are true real-time logistics/driver location and real payment processing, but these can be approximated with state transitions and synthetic events without harming task realism for an API simulation.
simulatable_features: User accounts, profiles, addresses, delivery instructions
Store selection and store metadata (hours, service areas, pickup vs delivery availability)
Product catalog browsing (categories, brands, dietary tags), product detail pages (price, unit size, images as URLs/metadata)
Search endpoints over a synthetic catalog (keyword match, filters, sorting)
Inventory/availability as synthetic per-store stock quantities and purchase limits
Cart CRUD (add/remove items, adjust quantities, saved items)
Checkout workflow (delivery vs pickup, selecting time windows, contactless options, notes)
Substitution preferences (allow/deny substitutions, preferred replacements, refund vs replace)
Promo codes/credits and pricing calculations (tax, fees, service fee, delivery fee, discounts, tip)
Order placement and order history (receipts, line items, totals, timestamps)
Order state machine (created/paid/assigned/shopping/checkout/out_for_delivery/delivered/canceled/refunded)
Shopper assignment as synthetic entities (shoppers, batches, picking progress)
In-order item updates (found/replaced/refunded, quantity changes, out-of-stock handling)
Customer-shopper messaging threads and message events (including templated system messages)
Tipping adjustments post-delivery and rating/review submission
Issue reporting and customer support tickets (missing item, wrong item, damaged item) with refunds/credits
Notifications as CRUD event records (order updates, messages, substitutions)
Saved lists/favorites/reorder from past purchases
non_simulatable_features: True real-time GPS tracking and routing based on live driver location and traffic (can only be approximated with synthetic coordinates and status updates)
Real payment processing, fraud checks, chargebacks, and PCI-compliant tokenization (must be mocked)
Live integration with retailer POS/inventory systems and real-time price changes (must be synthesized)
Actual phone/SMS/push delivery through external providers (can be represented as logged notification events only)
Human shopper judgment and nuanced replacement decisions beyond predefined rules (can be approximated with scripted outcomes)
Real-time marketplace dynamics (actual shopper supply, demand-based surge pricing) unless modeled with simplified synthetic rules

name: Patreon
description: Patreon is a membership platform that allows creators to offer subscription-based access to content and benefits. Creators set up pages with tiers, pricing, and rewards, then publish posts, audio, video, and other perks for patrons. Patrons can subscribe, manage memberships across creators, access exclusive content, comment, and message creators. The platform manages payments, billing cycles, and fraud checks, while creators can view analytics, payouts, and patron lists.
suitability_reasoning: Patreon’s core membership, tiering, patron management, billing cycles, payouts, and access-control workflows map well to synthesizable, structured CRUD data (users, creators, tiers, subscriptions, invoices, transactions, entitlements). However, a significant part of the real product value involves rich media hosting/streaming, content moderation, fraud/risk systems, and real payment network interactions, which are hard to faithfully replicate without external services. A simulated environment can still cover most user workflows by modeling content as metadata/URLs and simulating payment states and risk outcomes.
simulatable_features: creator onboarding and creator profiles/pages (bio, links, categories, goals)
membership tiers (name, price, billing interval, limits, benefits/rewards) CRUD
patron subscriptions/memberships (subscribe, upgrade/downgrade, cancel, pause/resume, renewal dates)
entitlements/access control (which tiers can access which posts/perks; patron eligibility checks)
posts feed for creators (text posts and content metadata; scheduling; visibility rules; editing/deleting)
comments and replies on posts (CRUD, basic moderation actions like delete/hide)
creator-patron messaging threads (CRUD for messages, read status)
benefits/perks tracking (deliverable items, status, fulfillment notes, shipping address fields as text)
billing artifacts (invoices, line items, taxes/fees as numeric fields, payment status transitions)
payment method records (tokenized placeholders), retries, dunning state (simulated)
payout settings and payout events (balance, pending/available amounts, payout schedules, payout status)
creator patron list management (search/filter, membership status, join date, lifetime value fields)
basic analytics dashboards (synthetic aggregates: revenue over time, churn, new patrons, top tiers)
notifications (new patron, payment failed, new comment/message) CRUD
refunds and disputes as records with statuses (simulated outcomes)
admin-like controls (flag account, suspend membership, creator page visibility state) as state changes
non_simulatable_features: actual payment processing with card networks/banks (authorization, settlement, chargebacks in real time)
fraud detection/risk scoring and identity verification based on real signals (device fingerprinting, network reputation)
rich media hosting, transcoding, streaming, and DRM for audio/video (beyond storing metadata pointers)
copyright enforcement systems (e.g., automated matching) and real moderation pipelines at scale
real email/SMS/push delivery infrastructure and deliverability behavior (can only be mocked)
tax/VAT compliance and jurisdiction-specific rules as implemented in production (can only be approximated)
real recommendation/ranking/personalization of creator discovery feeds (can be stubbed but not authentic)
integration-dependent workflows (e.g., real Discord role sync, third-party fulfillment/shipping providers)

name: KAYAK
description: KAYAK is a travel search and booking aggregator that lets users search flights, hotels, and rental cars across multiple providers. Users can filter by price, times, airlines, stops, amenities, and ratings, then click through to complete bookings or book directly when available. Features include fare alerts, price tracking, trip planning, and itinerary management. The platform compares options, saves searches, and aggregates reservations into unified trip views.
suitability_reasoning: Most of KAYAK’s core user workflows can be represented with structured, synthesizable entities (flights/hotels/cars, search queries, results, bookings, itineraries, alerts, price histories) and clear CRUD relationships. While true real-world comparison requires live provider inventory, affiliate click-through behavior, and real pricing/availability, a simulated environment can generate plausible schedules, prices, inventory, and state transitions that preserve the interaction patterns users and agents rely on.
simulatable_features: User accounts and profiles (home airport, traveler details, preferences)
Flight/hotel/car search requests (origin/destination/dates/guests/cabin class) stored as search objects
Filters and sorting (price, duration, stops, airlines, departure windows, amenities, ratings) applied to synthesized catalogs
Synthesized search results for flights/hotels/cars with fare rules, baggage, cancellation/refundability flags, room types, car classes, vendor info
Price calendars and historical price tracking using generated time series per route/property
Fare/price alerts (create/update/delete alert rules; trigger notifications based on simulated price changes)
Saved searches and recently viewed items
Trip planning: create trips, add segments (flight/hotel/car), notes, travelers, and attachments metadata
Itinerary management: import/store reservations (PNR-like codes, confirmation numbers), unify into a trip view, update/cancel reservation status
Booking flow simulation: quote -> hold -> book -> cancel/refund state transitions with payment tokens (mocked) and policy constraints
Provider comparison metadata (merchant/provider identifiers, deeplink URLs, booking channels) as static fields
User reviews/ratings metadata for hotels (short text + numeric ratings) and basic property/car attributes
Notifications center (read/unread, delivery channel preferences) and audit logs of price changes and booking actions
non_simulatable_features: Real-time inventory, pricing, and availability across multiple external providers (GDS/OTAs/hotel CRS/car systems)
True meta-search ranking and relevance that depends on proprietary algorithms, partner bids, and live market conditions
Live booking execution with third-party providers, including ticket issuance, seat maps, special service requests, and real confirmation validation
Actual payments, fraud checks, chargebacks, and PCI-compliant processing (can only be mocked)
Real-time disruptions and operational data (delays, cancellations, gate changes) unless artificially generated
Email scanning/automatic itinerary import from real inboxes and parsing of arbitrary vendor emails (can only be approximated with synthetic inputs)
Production-grade geo/POI intelligence (nearby attractions, commute times, real map routing) unless reduced to static synthesized data
Partner-specific promotions, loyalty pricing, member-only rates, and contract-driven merchandising rules tied to real agreements

name: Lyft
description: Lyft is a ride-hailing platform where users set pickup and dropoff locations, choose ride options, view pricing and ETAs, and request, track, or cancel rides. Riders can split fares, tip drivers, rate trips, and manage payment methods and preferences. Drivers manage availability, accept rides, navigate routes, and review earnings and incentives. Safety features include trip sharing, emergency options, and support flows for reporting issues.
suitability_reasoning: Lyft’s core workflows are structured and transactional (users, drivers, vehicles, ride requests, quotes, trips, payments, ratings, support cases) and can be represented with synthesized yet realistic data in a relational schema and CRUD-style REST APIs. The main challenges are true real-time dynamics (live GPS streams, traffic-based ETAs/pricing, and telephony/emergency integrations), but these can be approximated deterministically or via scripted state transitions in a simulator without requiring external data feeds.
simulatable_features: User and driver accounts (profiles, verification status flags, preferences)
Driver availability/online status and shift sessions
Vehicles (make/model/year/plate, capacity, service level eligibility)
Saved places (home/work) and location favorites
Pickup/dropoff objects (addresses, lat/long, instructions)
Ride types/options catalog (Standard/XL/Lux, seat count, accessibility options)
Price quotes and fare estimates (base, per-mile, per-minute, fees, surge multiplier as a synthetic field)
ETA estimates (synthetic durations based on distance bands or simple routing heuristics)
Ride requests lifecycle (requested, matched, driver_en_route, arrived, in_progress, completed, canceled, no_show)
Matching records (assigned driver, acceptance/decline events, reassignment)
Trip records (timestamps, synthetic route polyline metadata, distance, duration, stop points)
Cancellations (reason codes, fees, refund eligibility)
Fare splitting (split invitations, accept/decline, allocation amounts)
Tips (amount, payment status, timestamps)
Ratings and feedback (star rating, short tags, brief comments)
Payment methods (cards, wallets as tokens, default method, billing profiles)
Charges/receipts/invoices (line items, taxes, adjustments, refunds)
Promos/credits (promo codes, eligibility, redemption, balances)
Driver earnings ledger (trip payouts, bonuses, adjustments, payout status)
Incentives and challenges (quests, streaks, bonus rules and progress tracking)
Safety features as data objects (trip sharing links/tokens, trusted contacts list, check-in prompts)
Support flows (tickets, categories, messages, attachments metadata, resolution status)
Incident reporting (issue type, severity, narrative short text, status, follow-ups)
Notifications/in-app messages (event type, read/unread state)
non_simulatable_features: True real-time GPS tracking and continuous location streaming at production fidelity
Accurate routing/navigation with live traffic and turn-by-turn instructions (would require mapping/traffic engines)
Real surge pricing driven by real-world supply/demand and geo-temporal patterns (can only be approximated)
Precise ETAs based on current traffic conditions and driver movement (can only be approximated)
Fraud detection/risk scoring and identity verification checks that rely on external systems or ML
Phone/SMS relay between rider and driver and telephony masking infrastructure
Emergency services integrations (911 assist), real-time safety monitoring, and external escalation workflows
Processing real card payments and payouts through banking networks (must be mocked/simulated)
Background checks and regulatory compliance integrations
Complex marketplace optimization (dispatch algorithms) beyond simple rule-based matching

name: Square
description: Square is a payments and point-of-sale platform for businesses. Merchants create catalogs of items with prices and taxes, accept in-person and online payments, issue refunds, and view transaction histories. They can manage customers, invoices, and recurring payments, as well as track sales, inventory, and basic analytics. Additional modules support online stores, appointments, and staff management. Admins configure deposits, fees, hardware, and security settings.
suitability_reasoning: Square’s core workflows are structured, stateful CRUD operations over highly synthesizable entities (merchants, items, orders, payments, refunds, customers, invoices, deposits, inventory, staff). A simulated API can model transaction lifecycles, accounting states, and reporting with plausible synthetic numbers. The main non-simulatable parts are real payment network interactions, compliance/security enforcement, and physical hardware/payment-present flows, but these can be approximated with deterministic state machines and mock authorization/capture outcomes.
simulatable_features: Merchant/business accounts and locations (create/update business profile, addresses, hours)
Item/catalog management (items, variants, modifiers, categories, taxes, discounts)
Inventory tracking (stock counts, adjustments, low-stock thresholds, inventory history)
Cart/order lifecycle (draft orders, open tickets, completed orders, cancellations)
Payments lifecycle (authorize, capture, void, partial capture, tip handling) using synthetic payment methods
Refunds and returns (full/partial refunds, reason codes, refund status)
Transaction ledger/history (payments, refunds, fees, net amounts, timestamps, statuses)
Customers/CRM (profiles, contact info, notes, groups/segments, saved cards as tokens)
Invoices (draft/sent/paid/overdue, line items, due dates, reminders)
Recurring payments/subscriptions (plans, subscription status, billing cycles, proration flags, retries as simulated rules)
Deposits/payouts (payout schedule, pending/paid deposits, reconciliation references)
Fees and rates configuration (store fee schedules and compute synthetic fees consistently)
Basic analytics endpoints (daily sales summaries, top items, refunds totals, tax totals, per-location summaries)
Online store artifacts (products, carts, orders, fulfillment status, shipping addresses, fulfillment events)
Appointments (services, staff availability, bookings, cancellations, reminders as records)
Staff management (employees, roles, permissions, timecards/shifts as records)
Device/hardware registry (terminals/readers as assets, status, assignment to locations)
Security settings as configuration records (2FA required flag, API keys/tokens as mock entities, role-based access control models)
non_simulatable_features: Actual card network/payment rail processing (real authorizations, settlements, chargebacks with network evidence)
PCI compliance, real encryption/key management, and secure handling of PAN/card data (can only be mocked/tokenized)
Fraud detection/risk scoring and adaptive authentication based on real signals (device fingerprinting, velocity checks) beyond simple rules
Real-time hardware interactions (tap/dip/swipe, contactless kernels, reader firmware behavior, Bluetooth/NFC reliability)
Bank account verification and real funds movement to external banks (ACH/instant transfers) beyond simulated payout states
Dispute/chargeback workflows that require external documentation and network decisions (can be approximated but not truly replicated)

Deliverability of emails/SMS/push notifications and real webhook delivery semantics across the internet (can be simulated internally)
Integrations marketplace behaviors with third-party apps (OAuth with real providers, external data sync) beyond mock connectors

name: Grubhub
description: Grubhub is an online food ordering and delivery platform. Users search and filter restaurants by cuisine, price, rating, and delivery options, browse menus, customize items, and add them to carts. At checkout they choose delivery or pickup, schedule times, use promo codes, and pay. Orders can be tracked, and users can rate and review restaurants and drivers, manage addresses and payment methods, and view order history. Restaurants handle incoming orders and menus via their own dashboard or POS integrations.
suitability_reasoning: Grubhub’s core workflows are structured CRUD over synthesizable entities (restaurants, menus, items/options, carts, orders, deliveries, addresses, payments, promos, reviews). Even time-based states like order status and driver location can be simulated with plausible deterministic rules and synthetic telemetry. The main limitations are real-time GPS accuracy, real payment processing, and real operational constraints/SLAs, but these can be approximated in a simulator without needing external data.

Address book management (create/update/delete delivery addresses, delivery instructions)
Restaurant catalog (restaurants, cuisines, hours, service areas, fees, minimums)

Menu browsing (categories, items, descriptions, images as metadata, availability flags)
Item customization and modifiers (sizes, add-ons, special instructions, substitutions, allergen tags as structured fields)

Checkout workflow (delivery vs pickup, scheduling/ASAP, contactless option as a flag)
Promo codes and discounts (validation rules, usage limits, eligibility, percent/fixed discounts, free delivery)

Order placement and order history (create orders, list past orders, reorder from history)
Order status state machine (placed/confirmed/preparing/ready/picked_up/delivered/canceled/refunded)

True real-time GPS/location accuracy and live map rendering from third-party providers
Actual restaurant operational capacity constraints and human behavior (kitchen load, out-of-stock in real time) beyond simplified rules
Real driver dispatch optimization and route planning (advanced algorithms, live traffic, multi-order batching realism)
Real-time communications infrastructure (SMS/phone calls, push notification delivery guarantees) beyond simulated events
POS integrations with external restaurant systems (real vendor APIs, webhooks, device connectivity)
Identity verification/background checks for drivers and compliance workflows requiring external verification services

name: Basecamp
description: Basecamp is a project management and team communication tool organized into projects, each containing to-dos, message boards, schedules, docs & files, and group chats. Users create tasks, assign them, set due dates, and track completion. Message boards host threaded discussions, while automatic check-ins and pings facilitate updates. Projects support file uploads, shared docs, and calendars. Admins manage teams, project access, and notifications across the workspace.
suitability_reasoning: Basecamp is primarily structured, CRUD-driven collaboration software: workspaces contain projects, and projects contain well-defined entities (to-dos, lists, assignments, messages, comments, schedules, docs, files, check-ins, notifications, memberships). All of these can be represented with realistic synthesized relational data (users, roles, timestamps, statuses, permissions) and exposed via REST endpoints with predictable workflows (create tasks, assign, comment, mark complete, manage access). The main limitation is real-time chat/presence and file binary handling, but the core product value is still simulatable with metadata and message content.
simulatable_features: Workspaces/organizations CRUD (settings, plan flags, created_at)
User accounts CRUD (profiles, timezones, preferences)
Teams/groups CRUD and membership management (roles, permissions)
Projects CRUD (status, visibility, created_by, templates)
Project access control (invite/remove members, role changes)
To-do lists CRUD within projects
To-dos/tasks CRUD (title, description, assignee, due_date, status, completion timestamps, watchers)
Task comments/discussion threads CRUD
Message board topics/posts CRUD (threaded replies, pinned/archived flags)
Campfire/group chat rooms CRUD (channels) and chat message CRUD (as stored messages)
Schedules/calendars CRUD (events, all-day, recurrence rules stored as data)
Automatic check-ins/pings CRUD (questions/prompts, schedule, recipients, responses)
Docs/pages CRUD (rich-text stored as plain/HTML/markdown strings, version metadata)
File uploads simulation via file metadata CRUD (filename, size, MIME type, uploader, links) and placeholder content
Search simulation via filtered listing endpoints (by project, author, date range, status) rather than true full-text ranking
Notifications CRUD (subscription preferences, notification events, read/unread state)
Activity/audit log entries CRUD (actor, action, target entity, timestamp)
Integrations/webhooks CRUD (endpoint URL, event types, secret, delivery logs)
non_simulatable_features: True real-time chat behavior (presence, typing indicators, low-latency fan-out delivery semantics)
Push notification delivery to external devices/services (APNs/FCM/email/SMS) beyond storing notification records
Full fidelity file storage/streaming/scanning/preview generation (e.g., thumbnails, virus scanning, PDF previews) beyond metadata placeholders
Rich collaborative editing with conflict resolution/live cursors for docs (can be simplified to versioned saves)
Accurate full-text search relevance ranking and indexing at scale (can only be approximated with simple filtering or basic LIKE queries)
External integrations’ real side effects (e.g., posting to Slack, calendar sync with Google/Microsoft) beyond simulated webhook logs

name: Salesforce
description: Salesforce is a cloud-based CRM platform where users manage leads, accounts, contacts, opportunities, and cases. Sales teams log activities, track deal stages, forecast revenue, and create tasks and events. Service teams handle support cases with queues, priorities, and SLAs. Dashboards and reports visualize KPIs, while automation tools like workflows and flows trigger actions based on rules. Admins configure objects, fields, layouts, permissions, and integrations with external systems.
suitability_reasoning: Salesforce’s core value is managing structured business entities (leads, accounts, contacts, opportunities, cases, activities) with well-defined relationships, statuses, and workflows—highly synthesizable in a SQLite-backed simulated environment. Most user actions map cleanly to CRUD plus state transitions and query/filter operations. The main limitations are advanced analytics, proprietary automation semantics, and real integrations, which can be approximated but not fully replicated.
simulatable_features: User authentication and org-style multi-tenant workspace simulation
CRUD for core CRM objects: Leads, Accounts, Contacts, Opportunities, Cases
Pipeline stages and opportunity amount/close-date forecasting fields (including stage history as an audit table)
Activity logging: Tasks, Events, Calls/Emails as activity records linked to leads/contacts/opportunities
Case management: status, priority, assignment to queues/users, categorization, escalations as state transitions
SLA fields and timers as synthesized timestamps (e.g., first response due, resolution due) with computed breach flags
Queues and assignment rules as configurable routing rules applied on create/update
Notes and attachments metadata (filename, type, size, linked record) without storing real binaries
Basic reporting endpoints: aggregated counts/sums by owner, stage, time period; simple filters and group-bys
Dashboards as saved report configurations (widgets referencing report IDs and visualization type metadata)
Custom objects and custom fields as metadata tables (object definitions, field definitions, validation rules metadata)
Page layouts and record types as configuration metadata (what fields appear where) without UI rendering
Permissions/RBAC: roles, profiles, permission sets; object/field-level access enforced at API layer
Basic automation: workflow rules/flows represented as rule records that trigger simple actions (field update, task create, case assign) on create/update events
Audit/history tracking (created_by, updated_by, timestamps, field change logs)
Import/export jobs as async job records operating on CSV-like payload metadata (simulated processing outcomes)
non_simulatable_features: Full fidelity Salesforce Flow/Process Builder execution semantics (complex branching, subflows, transactions, governor limits, and platform event choreography)
Apex code execution and the entire runtime/governor limit model (can only be stubbed)
Real integrations to external systems (ERP, email providers, telephony/CTI, marketing platforms) beyond mocked endpoints
Einstein/AI features (lead scoring, opportunity insights, recommendations, NLP-based case classification) requiring ML inference
True UI behavior and Lightning Experience rendering (components, dynamic forms, client-side interactions)
Advanced analytics and reporting engine parity (complex joins across polymorphic relationships, formula fields, roll-up summaries with full correctness, reporting snapshots)
Real-time/eventing infrastructure (Change Data Capture, Platform Events, Streaming API) beyond simplified webhook simulation
Document/content management with real file storage, previews, and sharing at scale (only metadata is practical)
Compliance/security features requiring real infrastructure (SSO/SAML/OAuth with enterprise IdPs, Shield encryption, detailed audit event monitoring at platform parity)

name: ProtonMail
description: ProtonMail is a privacy-focused email service with end-to-end encryption. Users create mailboxes, send and receive emails, organize messages into folders and labels, and manage contacts. Security features include encrypted messages, optional password-protected emails to external recipients, two-factor authentication, and strict privacy controls. The interface supports search, filters, mail rules, and aliases, and users can adjust settings for signatures, auto-replies, and identity profiles.
suitability_reasoning: Many core workflows are CRUD-friendly (messages, folders/labels, contacts, settings, rules) and can be populated with realistic synthetic data. However, ProtonMail’s defining value—end-to-end encryption, key management, secure message composition/delivery semantics, and privacy guarantees—depends on cryptography and mail transport behaviors that are difficult to faithfully simulate in a simple REST+SQLite environment without reducing them to non-functional placeholders. Full-text search relevance and advanced filtering can be approximated but not replicated exactly.
simulatable_features: User accounts and mailbox provisioning (create user, mailbox quota/plan fields, status)
