Message objects CRUD (drafts, sent items, inbox, archived, trashed) with metadata (from/to/cc/bcc, subject, timestamps, flags, size)
Thread/conversation modeling (link messages by thread_id, read/unread state, starred/important flags)
Folder management CRUD (system and custom folders, nesting)
Labels/tags CRUD and applying/removing labels to messages
Contact management CRUD (contacts, groups, multiple emails/phones, notes)
Email aliases/identities CRUD (addresses, display names, enabled/disabled, default identity)
Signatures per identity and other mail preferences (display settings, default composer options)
Auto-reply/vacation responder settings CRUD (enabled, date range, message)
Mail rules/filters CRUD (conditions, actions like move to folder/apply label/mark read/delete)
Block/allow lists CRUD (sender domains/addresses)
Basic search endpoints over message metadata (subject, participants, date range, folder/label filters) using simple SQL queries
Two-factor authentication state modeling (enabled/disabled, recovery codes stored as synthetic tokens, last_used timestamps) as data/state only
Session/token management simulation (login, refresh, revoke sessions) as application state
Message attachments as metadata CRUD (filename, mime type, size, attachment_id) with optional dummy blob storage references
Password-protected external message feature as a workflow/state (create 'secure link' record, expiration, access attempts) without real cryptography
non_simulatable_features: Real end-to-end encryption behavior (PGP-like key generation/storage, client-side encryption, cryptographic verification, forward secrecy)
True privacy/security guarantees (zero-access architecture, tamper resistance, threat model enforcement)
Real email delivery via SMTP and interoperability with the global email network (MX routing, bounces, spam scoring, DKIM/DMARC validation) beyond mocked status fields
Accurate full-text search over encrypted content (Proton’s approach to searchable encrypted mail) and relevance ranking comparable to production
Cryptographically sound password-protected emails to external recipients (encryption, secure key exchange) beyond placeholder links/password checks
Advanced anti-abuse systems (spam/phishing detection, reputation systems) that rely on real signals/models
Secure attachment handling (content scanning, true encrypted storage) beyond metadata simulation
Client-specific behaviors (desktop/mobile apps, offline caches, local encryption) outside a server-side CRUD API

name: Coinbase
description: Coinbase is a cryptocurrency exchange and wallet platform. Users verify identities, link payment methods, and buy, sell, and convert cryptocurrencies at market or recurring intervals. They can track portfolio balances and performance, view detailed transaction history, and transfer assets to and from external addresses. Watchlists and price alerts help monitor markets, while educational modules reward learning. Security settings include two-factor authentication, address whitelists, and withdrawal controls.
suitability_reasoning: Most core Coinbase workflows are structured CRUD over synthesizable entities (users, KYC status, payment methods, orders, trades, balances, transfers, addresses, alerts). Market data and execution can be simulated with plausible price series and deterministic matching/quote rules. The main non-simulatable aspects are real blockchain interaction, real-time market microstructure/liquidity, and regulatory/third-party integrations; however these can be mocked without breaking typical task flows.
simulatable_features: User accounts and profiles (email, region, preferences)
KYC/identity verification workflow states (submitted/reviewing/approved/rejected) and document metadata
Payment methods CRUD (bank accounts, cards) and verification states
Fiat wallets and crypto wallets (accounts, balances, holds, available vs pending)
Address book and address whitelists (saved withdrawal addresses, tags/memos, allowlists)
Security settings (2FA enabled/disabled, device/session lists, withdrawal limits, withdrawal holds, login history records)
Spot trading flows: quote endpoint, market/limit orders, order status lifecycle (open/filled/partially_filled/canceled), trade fills
Convert trades (asset-to-asset conversions) with fee modeling
Recurring buys (schedules, next run time, paused/resumed, execution history)
Deposits/withdrawals (fiat and crypto) with statuses (created/pending/confirmed/completed/failed) and timestamps
Internal transfers between user portfolios/wallets (e.g., main vs vault) with approvals and delays
Transaction history and statements (ledger entries, fees, references to orders/transfers)
Portfolio performance snapshots (time-series balances, P&L calculations from synthetic price history)
Watchlists (asset lists) and custom price alerts (thresholds, triggers, delivery preferences)
Asset catalog (supported coins, networks, precision, min sizes, trading pairs) and account-specific availability flags
Fees configuration (maker/taker tiers, spread/commission models) and receipts/invoices metadata
Learning modules CRUD (courses, lessons, quiz attempts) and reward payout records (earn program ledger entries)
Customer support tickets (issue types, status, messages) as a supporting workflow
API keys creation/rotation and permissions (read/trade/transfer) with audit logs
non_simulatable_features: Real blockchain network behavior (true mempool dynamics, confirmations, reorgs, gas/fee market, on-chain contract execution)
Real-time market prices, depth, and liquidity/venue routing; true slippage and best-execution across exchanges
Actual custody and signing infrastructure (HSMs, cold storage operations) beyond representing states/controls
Bank/card network integrations (ACH/wire/card authorization, chargebacks, settlement) and real fraud scoring
Regulatory/compliance integrations (sanctions screening, PEP checks, third-party identity verification results) beyond mocked outcomes
Real-time push notification delivery and SMS/email provider behavior (can be recorded as events but not truly delivered)
Tax reporting accuracy tied to real jurisdictions and evolving rules (can be approximated but not authoritative)
Institutional features dependent on external counterparties (OTC desk pricing, real borrowing/lending markets) if included

name: Greenhouse
description: Greenhouse is an applicant tracking and recruiting operations platform used by hiring teams to manage the full hiring lifecycle. Users can create job requisitions, define interview plans and scorecards, publish openings to job boards, and manage candidate pipelines through stages (applied, phone screen, onsite, offer). Core entities include jobs, departments, locations, candidates, applications, interviewers, interviews, feedback forms, offers, and approvals. Recruiters can schedule interviews, send templated emails, request referrals, attach resumes and notes, and log activities for compliance. Hiring managers can review candidates, submit structured feedback, and approve offers. The platform supports role-based permissions, audit trails, and custom fields for EEO/OFCCP reporting. Workflows include creating an opening, assigning a hiring team, moving candidates through stages, collecting feedback, generating offer letters, and onboarding handoff. API-friendly actions include CRUD for jobs/candidates/interviews, status transitions, webhook events (stage changed, interview scheduled), and integrations with HRIS and background checks.

name: BambooHR (ATS + HRIS hub)
description: BambooHR is an HR platform that combines lightweight recruiting with employee records management. Teams can post jobs, collect applications, and move candidates through a simple pipeline, then convert a hired candidate into an employee profile. Key entities are job postings, applicants, interview notes, hiring tasks, employee profiles, departments, positions, managers, documents, time-off requests, benefits enrollments, and company assets. Typical workflows include opening a requisition, collecting candidate data via forms, scheduling interviews, marking a candidate as hired, and triggering onboarding checklists (equipment assignment, document signing, policy acknowledgments). HR admins can manage custom fields, upload files, track e-signatures, and run headcount/turnover reports. Employees can update personal info, request PTO, view approval status, and download pay-related documents (metadata). This scenario is highly synthesizable because all records are structured (people, dates, statuses, documents, tasks). APIs can support CRUD for employees and applicants, approval flows for time-off, document metadata, and event-driven updates when an applicant becomes an employee.

name: Gusto (Payroll + Benefits)
description: Gusto is a payroll and benefits platform for small businesses that manages employees, contractors, pay schedules, and tax filings. Businesses can onboard workers, collect W-4 details, set compensation, run recurring payroll, and issue off-cycle payments. Core entities include companies, employees, contractors, pay periods, time entries, earnings/deductions, reimbursements, benefits plans, payroll runs, tax forms, bank accounts (tokenized), and pay stubs (records). Workflows include adding a worker, verifying eligibility, configuring pay schedule, importing hours, approving a payroll run, generating payment transactions, and marking payroll as paid/failed with reconciliation. Admins can manage deductions, garnishments, and employer contributions, while employees can update profiles, download stubs, and change withholding elections. Everything is database-driven with clear status transitions (draft payroll → approved → submitted → paid). For simulation, realistic data can be generated for hours, salaries, tax withholdings, benefit premiums, and payment statuses. APIs can expose CRUD for employees and payroll items, payroll-run creation/approval, webhooks for payroll completion, and reporting endpoints.

name: Workday Recruiting (Enterprise ATS)
description: Workday Recruiting is an enterprise-grade recruiting suite integrated with workforce planning and requisition approvals. Organizations can create requisitions tied to cost centers and headcount plans, route them through multi-step approvals, and manage candidate pipelines at scale. Entities include requisitions, positions, job profiles, candidates, applications, interview loops, assessments, offers, compensation packages, approval tasks, and compliance questionnaires. Recruiters can source candidates, record referrals, schedule interview panels, collect structured feedback, and manage offer negotiations with versioned offer documents. Hiring teams operate through task inboxes (approve req, review candidate, submit feedback), and every action is auditable with timestamps and role-based access. Workflows emphasize governance: requisition creation → budget approval → posting → candidate screening → interview scheduling → offer approvals → hire conversion → onboarding handoff. The platform suits API simulation because it is highly structured and stateful, with many entities and transitions. Synthetic data can cover salary bands, requisition statuses, interview outcomes, and time-to-hire metrics. APIs can model CRUD plus complex actions like submitting approvals, moving stages, generating offers, and emitting events for downstream HRIS/payroll.

name: Indeed Employer (Job Board + Employer Console)
description: Indeed’s employer-facing tools support posting jobs, managing applicants, and tracking hiring performance for each listing. Employers can create job posts with location, compensation, schedule, and required qualifications; choose sponsored budgets; and manage applicant pipelines with statuses (new, reviewed, contacted, interview, hired, rejected). Key entities include employer accounts, job listings, screening questions, applicants, messages, interview requests, and spend/billing records for sponsored postings. Workflows include drafting a post, publishing, reviewing incoming applications, sending messages or interview invitations, collecting availability, and recording outcomes. The system can also manage multiple locations and roles, assign recruiter seats, and export hiring reports such as applicant volume and time-to-contact. This is suitable for synthesis because listings, applicants, and communications are structured records; ranking/search quality isn’t required to simulate the core CRUD experience. API interactions can include creating/updating job posts, retrieving applicant feeds, updating applicant status, sending templated messages, recording interview events, and tracking ad spend and invoice statuses.

name: Lever (Recruiting CRM + ATS)
description: Lever combines an applicant tracking system with a recruiting CRM for managing both active applicants and passive talent pools. Teams can create job postings and also build pipelines for prospects sourced from events, referrals, or outbound campaigns. Entities include prospects, candidates, opportunities (candidate-to-job), tags, talent pools, email sequences, interview schedules, feedback, offers, and user roles. Recruiters can import profiles, deduplicate records, apply tags, add notes, and launch outreach campaigns with templates and tracking (sent, opened, replied). Candidates can be linked to multiple opportunities over time, enabling realistic relational data modeling. Hiring managers can review candidate packets, submit feedback, and approve offers. Workflows include sourcing → outreach → conversion to applicant → interview loop → offer → hire, as well as re-engagement campaigns for silver-medalist candidates. The platform is highly suitable for API simulation because it’s centered on CRUD, relationships, and event logs. Synthetic data can represent response rates, stage durations, interviewer availability, and offer outcomes. APIs can expose endpoints for candidate/prospect CRUD, opportunity stage transitions, scheduled interviews, bulk tagging, and webhooks for status changes and email events.

name: DonorPerfect (Nonprofit CRM + Donations)
description: DonorPerfect is a nonprofit donor management platform focused on tracking constituents, gifts, campaigns, and fundraising performance. Organizations can maintain constituent profiles (individuals, households, companies), record donations (one-time, recurring, pledges), generate receipts, and segment supporters for mail/email outreach. Core entities include donors, addresses, communication preferences, gifts, soft credits, campaigns, funds, appeals, events, tickets, memberships, and interactions (calls, meetings, notes). Workflows include importing donor lists, creating a campaign with goals, processing online/offline gifts, allocating a gift to one or more funds, generating acknowledgments, and producing reports (retention, LYBUNT/SYBUNT, campaign ROI). Staff can assign tasks to gift officers, log stewardship steps, and manage pledge schedules with installment statuses. Everything is synthesize-friendly: amounts, dates, donor demographics, campaign targets, receipt numbers, and statuses (pledged, paid, lapsed). APIs can support CRUD for constituents and gifts, batch gift entry, recurring payment schedules, receipt generation metadata, and webhook events for new donations or failed recurring charges.

name: VolunteerHub (Volunteer Management)
description: VolunteerHub is a volunteer scheduling and engagement platform for nonprofits, schools, and community programs. Admins can create events and shifts with capacity limits, required skills, minimum age, check-in windows, and waiver requirements. Key entities include volunteer profiles, groups/teams, events, shifts, signups, waitlists, check-in records, service hours, communications, and documents (waivers/certifications metadata). Workflows include publishing opportunities, volunteers registering and signing up for shifts, automated confirmations and reminders, waitlist promotion when spots open, and day-of check-in/out via QR or roster. Coordinators can approve or correct logged hours, track attendance, and run reports by program, date range, or volunteer. The platform also supports recurring events, role-based permissions for team leaders, and integration exports for grant reporting. This scenario is ideal for synthesis because it’s structured scheduling data: people, time slots, capacity, statuses (signed up, canceled, attended, no-show), and hour totals. APIs can implement CRUD for events/shifts, signup/cancel actions, waitlist operations, check-in endpoints, and reporting queries for hours and participation metrics.

name: Chewy Autoship (Pet Supplies Subscription Commerce)
description: Chewy is a pet supplies e-commerce platform with a strong subscription (Autoship) and fulfillment workflow. Users can manage pet profiles (species, breed, allergies), browse products (food, treats, meds metadata), add items to cart, and configure Autoship plans with delivery cadence, quantities, and substitutions. Core entities include customers, pets, products, inventory by warehouse, carts, orders, shipments, returns, promotions, subscriptions, payment methods (tokenized), and customer service cases. Workflows include placing an order, tracking shipping statuses, initiating returns/refunds, editing subscriptions (skip, pause, change frequency), and handling out-of-stock substitutions. Customer support agents can view order history, issue replacements, approve refunds, and record interaction notes. This is highly synthesizable: product catalogs, prices, stock counts, order/shipping timelines, and subscription schedules can all be generated realistically. APIs can cover CRUD for pets and addresses, order creation, shipment tracking updates, subscription management actions, return authorizations, and event notifications (shipment delivered, payment failed, item backordered).

name: Rover (Pet Sitting & Walking Marketplace)
description: Rover is a marketplace connecting pet owners with sitters and dog walkers, centered on bookings, availability, and service fulfillment. Owners can create pet profiles, request services (boarding, house sitting, drop-in visits, walks) for specific dates and times, and message providers. Sitters manage profiles, service offerings, rates, service areas, availability calendars, and booking preferences. Key entities include users, pets, listings, availability blocks, booking requests, bookings, messages, payments, payouts, cancellations, reviews/ratings, and incident reports. Workflows include searching/filtering providers (can be simplified to structured queries), sending a booking request, sitter acceptance/decline, payment authorization, service check-in/out, optional “visit cards” as structured logs (time, notes, photos metadata), and post-service reviews. Dispute and cancellation policies can be modeled with fees and refund statuses. This scenario is API-friendly because it’s a state machine around bookings with clear transitions and timestamps. Synthetic data can represent service durations, rates, distances, sitter capacity, and booking outcomes. APIs can support CRUD for pet and listing profiles, availability management, booking lifecycle actions, messaging threads, payment/payout records, and review submission.

name: Vetstoria (Veterinary Appointment & Practice Scheduling)
description: Vetstoria is an online booking and practice management-facing scheduling layer for veterinary clinics. Pet owners can register accounts, manage multiple pets, upload vaccination document metadata, and request appointments by service type (wellness exam, vaccine, dental, urgent visit) with preferred clinicians and time windows. Clinics manage providers, rooms, appointment types, slot templates, and capacity rules, as well as client records. Core entities include clinics, staff/providers, clients, pets, medical record summaries (structured fields), appointment requests, confirmed appointments, reminders, invoices, and follow-up tasks. Workflows include searching available slots, booking, automated SMS/email reminders, check-in, appointment completion, invoice creation, and scheduling follow-ups (recheck, booster shots) with due dates and statuses. Staff can reschedule, cancel with policy reasons, and flag no-shows. This scenario is well suited to synthesis because the data is structured and operational (schedules, services, pet demographics, billing line items), not content-heavy. APIs can implement CRUD for clients/pets, availability queries, appointment booking/reschedule/cancel, reminder events, invoice endpoints, and reporting (appointment volume, no-show rates, revenue by service).

name: GivePulse (Volunteer & Event Management for Nonprofits)
description: GivePulse is a volunteer engagement platform where nonprofits and community groups create opportunities and manage participation end-to-end. Core entities include organizations, programs, volunteer opportunities, shifts, locations, volunteer profiles, hours logs, waivers, announcements, and impact tags (skills, causes). Admins can CRUD events and recurring shifts, set capacity rules, create waitlists, and publish sign-up forms. Volunteers browse opportunities, register for shifts, complete digital waivers, check in/out (QR or manual), and submit hours for approval. Workflows include approval queues for new volunteers, automated reminders, shift cancellations with reassignments, and hour verification by supervisors. The system supports group registrations for corporate volunteer days, plus attendance rosters and volunteer history transcripts. Nonprofits can segment contacts, message volunteers, and generate reports by program, date range, location, and total hours. Optional modules include donation campaigns tied to events, in-kind needs lists, and badge/recognition records. All data is easily synthesized: names, shifts, capacities, check-ins, hours, skills, and engagement metrics.

name: Classy (Online Fundraising Campaigns & Donor CRM)
description: Classy is a fundraising platform focused on donation flows and campaign management. Key entities include nonprofits, fundraising campaigns, donation pages, donors, gifts, recurring plans, peer-to-peer fundraisers, teams, event registrations, and receipts. Admins can create campaigns with goals, tiers, and suggested giving amounts, configure recurring donation options, and manage payment methods and processing settings. Donors can give one-time or monthly, manage their profile, update cards, download receipts, and opt into communications. Peer-to-peer workflows allow supporters to create personal fundraising pages, join teams, track progress against goals, and post short updates. Back-office workflows include gift reconciliation, refund and cancellation handling, pledge tracking, soft credit attribution, and exporting transactions to accounting. The system supports segmentation (donation frequency, campaign source), automated emails (thank-you, failed payment dunning), and basic reporting (totals by campaign, cohort retention, average gift). Data can be synthesized realistically: donor records, gift amounts, plans, statuses, timestamps, and campaign performance.

name: Benevity (Employee Giving & Matching Programs)
description: Benevity is a corporate giving portal where employees donate, volunteer, and request matching from their employer. Core entities include companies, employees, nonprofits, donation transactions, match requests, volunteer events, volunteer hours, grant budgets, approval rules, and payout batches. Company admins configure giving campaigns (e.g., disaster relief), match policies (ratio, caps, eligibility), volunteering incentives, and payroll deduction schedules. Employees can browse nonprofits, submit one-time or recurring donations, allocate donations across multiple charities, and file match requests with supporting documents. Volunteer workflows include signing up for company-organized events, logging individual hours, manager verification, and converting hours to grants. Finance workflows include approvals, exception handling, chargeback/refund records, and generating payout batches to nonprofits. Reporting covers participation rates, total giving, match liabilities, and department-level engagement. Synthesizable data includes employee profiles, donation amounts, match statuses, policy limits, approval timestamps, and payout summaries—ideal for CRUD-heavy API simulations without relying on content-heavy features.

name: Charity Auctions (Silent Auction & Gala Fundraising)
description: Charity Auctions is an event-based fundraising platform for silent auctions, raffles, and ticketed galas. Key entities include events, ticket types, attendees, tables, auction items, item categories, bid increments, bidder numbers, bids, buy-it-now purchases, raffles, invoices, and payment records. Organizers can CRUD auction catalogs (items, images metadata, starting bids, donor acknowledgments), configure auction rules (closing times, auto-extend, bid increments), and manage attendee check-in. Guests register, purchase tickets, receive bidder IDs, place bids, watch lists, and settle invoices after the event. Workflows include item procurement intake (donor contact, fair market value, restrictions), bid monitoring with outbid notifications, checkout queues, tax-deductible receipt generation, and item fulfillment tracking (pickup/shipping status). Staff can reconcile payments, mark items as paid/collected, handle refunds, and export final results. Reporting includes top items, bidder activity, revenue by category, and sponsor performance. All entities (items, bids, attendees, invoices, statuses) are easily synthesized for robust database-driven simulations.

name: ShelterLuv (Animal Shelter Intake, Adoptions & Medical Records)
description: ShelterLuv is a shelter management system focused on animal intakes, care, and adoption workflows. Core entities include animals, intakes, microchips, kennels, fosters, adopters, applications, appointments, vaccinations, treatments, medications, behavior notes, and adoption contracts/fees. Staff can create animal profiles, assign IDs, track species/breed/age, upload document metadata, and manage location changes (kennel, foster home, medical hold). Medical workflows include scheduling vaccines, logging treatments, tracking medication courses with start/end dates, and recording outcomes. Adoption workflows include application submission, screening statuses, meet-and-greet appointments, contract generation, fee collection, and post-adoption follow-ups. Foster workflows include assigning animals to foster caregivers, tracking supplies, check-ins, and return dates. Inventory features can track food and medication stock by lot and expiration. Reporting supports capacity, length of stay, adoption conversion, and medical costs. All records—animals, events, appointments, statuses, fees—can be synthesized while preserving realistic shelter operations and API CRUD complexity.

name: Pawfinity (Pet Sitting & Dog Walking Marketplace)
description: Pawfinity is a pet care booking platform connecting pet owners with sitters and walkers. Key entities include users (owners/sitters), pets, service offerings, availability calendars, bookings, visit schedules, addresses, checklists, visit reports, payments, and reviews/ratings. Sitters create profiles, set service types (walks, drop-ins, overnight), pricing rules, service areas, and blackout dates. Owners create pet profiles (species, weight, medication notes, feeding instructions), request bookings, and approve quotes. Booking workflows include request → acceptance/decline → payment authorization → scheduled visits → completion → review. During visits, sitters can submit a structured visit report (start/end timestamps, potty/meal checkboxes, short notes) and attach media metadata if needed, without requiring actual media content. The system supports recurring bookings, cancellation policies, dispute tickets, and payout schedules. Admin tools include sitter verification status, incident logs, and customer support case management. All entities—calendars, bookings, pets, pricing, statuses—are highly synthesizable and ideal for API simulation.

name: VetConnect (Veterinary Clinic Scheduling, SOAP Notes & Billing)
description: VetConnect is a practice management platform for veterinary clinics, centered on appointments, clinical records, and invoicing. Entities include clinics, staff, clients, pets, appointments, visit reasons, SOAP notes, diagnoses, lab orders/results (structured), vaccines, prescriptions, treatment plans, invoices, line items, and payments. Receptionists manage schedules (providers, rooms), create appointments, confirm via reminders, and handle cancellations and waitlists. During a visit, clinicians record structured SOAP notes, create lab orders, administer vaccines, and generate prescriptions with dosage and refill rules. Billing workflows generate invoices from performed services and products, apply discounts, accept payments, and track balances/refunds. Inventory modules manage medications and consumables by SKU, on-hand quantity, reorder points, and lot/expiration. Referral workflows can create outgoing referrals and attach document metadata. Reporting includes appointment utilization, revenue by service category, vaccine compliance, and inventory valuation. The system is CRUD-heavy and database-driven; all data (clients, pets, codes, timestamps, invoice totals, statuses) can be synthesized realistically.

name: PawMart Wholesale (Pet Supplies B2B Ordering & Inventory)
description: PawMart Wholesale is a B2B pet supply ordering portal for groomers, shelters, and independent pet stores. Key entities include business accounts, users/roles, product catalog (SKUs, variants, case packs), price lists, contracts, carts, purchase orders, invoices, warehouses, inventory levels, shipments, and returns (RMA). Admins manage product data, supplier records, tiered pricing, customer-specific catalogs, and minimum order rules. Buyers build carts, submit purchase orders with requested ship dates, choose shipping methods, and track fulfillment statuses (picked, packed, shipped, delivered). Warehouse workflows include pick lists, backorders, substitutions, partial shipments, and cycle counts to adjust inventory. Returns workflows create RMAs, validate eligibility windows, receive items, and issue credits. The platform supports recurring replenishment orders, low-stock alerts for customers, and basic analytics dashboards (top SKUs, reorder frequency, fill rate). This scenario is ideal for synthesized API environments: create realistic SKUs, quantities, lead times, warehouse bins, and order lifecycles without any reliance on non-synthesizable content.

name: AutoNation-Style Dealer Portal (Vehicle Listings, Leads & Financing)
description: A car dealership web platform focused on inventory, leads, and deal workflows. Core entities include dealerships, vehicles (VIN, trim, mileage, options), photos metadata, pricing rules, promotions, customer leads, test-drive appointments, trade-in appraisals, finance applications (structured fields), offers, and sales pipeline stages. Staff can import vehicles, set prices, mark availability (in transit, on lot, sold), and manage add-ons (warranty packages, accessories). Customers can browse listings, save vehicles, request quotes, schedule test drives, and submit trade-in details. Sales workflows include lead assignment, contact logs, offer negotiation records, document checklist statuses, and final sale closure with deposit/payment tracking. Finance workflows capture application status (submitted, pending docs, approved/declined), lender offers, and APR/term options as structured data. Post-sale workflows track delivery appointments, DMV paperwork status, and CSI survey requests (short ratings). All data—VIN-like identifiers, vehicle attributes, lead statuses, prices, timestamps—can be synthesized for robust CRUD and relational database simulations.

name: ShopKey-Style Service Shop (Repair Orders, Scheduling & Parts Inventory)
description: An automotive service management platform for independent repair shops, combining appointment booking, repair orders, and parts inventory. Entities include customers, vehicles, service appointments, technicians, bays, repair orders (RO), labor operations, parts line items, suppliers, purchase orders, inventory bins, invoices, payments, warranties, and service history. Front desk staff schedule appointments by bay/technician availability, capture customer concerns, and create estimates. Once approved, the estimate converts to an RO with assigned technician tasks and timestamps (check-in, diagnosis, parts ordered, repair complete, QC). Parts workflows include searching a parts catalog (internal SKUs), reserving stock to an RO, generating supplier POs for out-of-stock items, receiving parts into inventory, and tracking returns/cores. Billing workflows invoice labor and parts, apply coupons/tax, accept payments, and track A/R for fleet accounts. Customer notifications track approval requests and status updates. Reporting covers technician productivity, parts margin, comeback rates, and inventory turnover. This scenario is highly synthesizable with rich CRUD operations across schedules, orders, and stock.

name: PawCare Veterinary EMR & Appointment Portal
description: PawCare is a veterinary clinic management platform that combines online booking with a full practice database. Pet owners create accounts, add multiple pets (species, breed, weight, vaccines, allergies), upload insurance details, request appointments, and complete digital intake forms. Clinics manage provider schedules, exam rooms, and appointment types (wellness, surgery consult, vaccines), with workflows for confirmations, reminders, cancellations, and waitlists. Staff maintain medical records: problem lists, visit notes (SOAP), diagnoses, lab orders/results, imaging orders, prescribed medications, and vaccination certificates. Billing workflows support invoices, itemized services, payment collection, refunds, and statements, plus estimates for procedures. Inventory entities include medications, vaccines, consumables, lot numbers, expiration dates, and reorder thresholds, linked to administered items. The platform supports referrals and document sharing (export visit summaries, rabies certificates). Reports cover appointments, revenue by service category, vaccine compliance, and inventory usage. All data (clients, pets, appointments, treatments, invoices, inventory) is database-driven and can be fully synthesized for API simulations.

name: TeleVet Video Visits & Prescription Requests
description: TeleVet is a telehealth-style platform for veterinary remote consultations. Pet owners register, create pet profiles, submit visit requests with symptoms (structured fields), photos as metadata (optional), and preferred times. Clinics configure clinician availability, service regions, pricing, and triage rules. The core workflow includes triage status (new, pending info, scheduled, completed, escalated), appointment scheduling, and visit records with structured outcomes (assessment codes, recommended care plan, follow-up date). Providers can create prescriptions and refills, issue home-care instructions templates, and generate discharge summaries. Payments can be captured per consult, with invoices and receipts stored in the ledger. Messaging is handled as threaded conversations per case with attachments metadata and read receipts. Integration-ready entities include “cases,” “visit notes,” “tasks” (e.g., request vaccination record), and “referral orders” to in-person clinics. Admins manage users/roles, clinic locations, service catalogs, and audit logs. This is well-suited to synthetic APIs because the platform relies on CRUD for users, pets, cases, schedules, billing, prescriptions, and statuses—without requiring real video/audio content.

name: SitStay Pet Sitting Marketplace & Scheduling
description: SitStay is a pet sitting and dog walking marketplace that focuses on bookings, availability, and transaction workflows. Pet owners create profiles, add pets (care instructions, feeding schedule, medications, vet contacts), and request services (walks, overnight stays, drop-ins) with dates, location, and special requirements. Sitters maintain listings with service areas, rates, capacity limits, background-check status, and weekly availability calendars. The booking pipeline includes request, counteroffer, confirmed, in-progress, completed, and canceled states, with automated deposits, payout calculations, and refund rules. Sitters can build visit reports as structured checklists (walk duration, feeding done, water refreshed, medication administered) and upload photo metadata and timestamps. Messaging is tied to each booking with system events (schedule change, address updates). The platform supports recurring bookings, coupons, add-ons (extra pet, holiday rate), and dispute tickets. Admin tools include sitter verification, performance metrics, cancellation monitoring, and fee configuration. Core entities (owners, sitters, pets, listings, availability slots, bookings, payments, visit reports, support tickets) are fully synthesizable and ideal for API testing around scheduling, status changes, and billing.

name: PawMart Pet Supplies Subscription Store
description: PawMart is an e-commerce platform specialized in pet supplies with both one-time purchases and subscriptions. Customers manage accounts, multiple shipping addresses, pets (to personalize recommendations as stored preferences), carts, and wishlists. The product catalog includes SKUs with variants (size, flavor), pricing tiers, tax classes, stock levels by warehouse, and compliance flags (prescription required, age restrictions). Subscriptions are first-class entities: cadence (weekly/monthly), next shipment date, quantity, skip/pause/resume actions, and payment method tokens. Order workflows include authorization, pick/pack/ship statuses, tracking numbers, returns, refunds, and exchanges. Admins manage promotions (coupon codes, bundles, buy-one-get-one), supplier records, purchase orders, and replenishment rules based on reorder points. Customer service workflows include RMA creation, replacement shipments, and issue tagging. Reporting covers subscription churn, average order value, and inventory turnover. All records are structured (products, customers, inventory, orders, shipments, returns, subscriptions, payments), making it highly suitable for synthesized API environments without needing real product media beyond metadata.

name: AutoLane Dealership Inventory & Sales CRM
description: AutoLane is a car dealership platform combining vehicle inventory, lead management, and sales paperwork tracking. Dealers import or create vehicle records (VIN, trim, mileage, condition, price, options, photos metadata, reconditioning status) and manage availability across lots. Shoppers can save vehicles, request quotes, schedule test drives, and submit trade-in details (vehicle info, photos metadata, payoff amount). Sales staff manage leads, contact attempts, pipeline stages (new, contacted, appointment set, test drive, negotiating, won, lost), and tasks. The deal desk workflow supports offers, discounts, finance terms, lender applications as structured records, and document checklists (ID, insurance, proof of income). Once sold, the system generates a “deal” entity linking the buyer, vehicle, trade-in, add-ons (warranty, GAP), and payment schedule. Post-sale workflows include delivery appointments, title/registration status, and customer follow-ups. Admins manage user roles, commission rules, and reporting. The platform is database-heavy and API-friendly: vehicles, leads, appointments, deals, documents status, and financing terms can all be synthesized realistically.

name: QuickBay Auto Service Scheduling & Shop Management
description: QuickBay is a service scheduling and work order system for automotive repair shops. Customers create accounts, register vehicles (VIN, mileage, service history), request appointments, and approve estimates online. Shops configure technicians, bays, business hours, service menus (oil change, brakes, diagnostics), and labor rates. The primary workflow is a repair order: intake checklist, symptom notes, inspection items, recommended services, parts needed, labor lines, and estimate approvals (pending/approved/declined). Status transitions track the job lifecycle (scheduled, checked-in, in progress, waiting on parts, QA, ready for pickup, closed). Invoicing supports taxes, discounts, coupons, partial payments, refunds, and receipts. Messaging is linked to each repair order for customer updates and authorization prompts. Shops can record photos metadata (inspection findings) and store warranty terms per line item. Reports cover technician utilization, average ticket size, and comeback rates. Core entities include customers, vehicles, appointments, repair orders, inspection items, labor/parts lines, invoices, payments, and statuses—ideal for CRUD-focused API simulation.

name: PartsHub OEM/Aftermarket Parts Inventory Network
description: PartsHub is a parts inventory and procurement platform for auto shops and small dealerships. Businesses manage catalogs of parts (SKU, OEM cross-references, fitment attributes, brand, cost, MSRP), on-hand quantities by location/bin, and serialized/lot-tracked items when needed. Purchase workflows include supplier records, purchase orders, backorders, expected delivery dates, receiving, and discrepancy handling (short shipment, damaged, returned). Sales workflows support internal part requests linked to repair orders, counter sales invoices, and returns to stock. Fitment matching is implemented as structured filters (make/model/year/engine) backed by database tables rather than real-time search ranking. The platform can generate quotes, reserve stock, and allocate inventory to jobs. Pricing rules (markup matrices by category, customer tier pricing) and audit logs are included. Admins manage user permissions, multi-location transfers, cycle counts, and reorder suggestions based on min/max. Entities (parts, suppliers, POs, receipts, inventory bins, transfers, reservations, invoices, returns) are fully synthesizable and create rich API interactions around inventory integrity and workflow states.

name: MediConnect Patient Portal & Scheduling
description: MediConnect is a healthcare patient portal for clinics and outpatient practices. Patients register, manage profiles, insurance coverage, dependents, and preferred pharmacies. They can search provider availability (specialty, location), book appointments, complete pre-visit questionnaires, and upload documents as metadata (ID, insurance card). The clinical side manages provider schedules, appointment types, rooming status, and visit records with diagnoses codes, vitals, orders, and after-visit summaries. Patients can view lab results as structured values (test name, value, range, flag), request refills, message care teams, and pay bills. Billing workflows include statements, invoices, copays, payment plans, and refunds. Admin tools cover role-based access, consent forms, audit trails, and notification templates. The data model is highly database-driven: patients, encounters, appointments, providers, locations, insurance policies, messages, lab results, prescriptions, and billing records can all be synthesized. The portal emphasizes CRUD operations and status transitions (scheduled/checked-in/completed, results pending/final, refill requested/approved/denied) suitable for realistic API environment simulations without relying on medical content generation.

name: CareNow Telehealth Triage & Visit Management
description: CareNow is a telehealth platform focused on structured triage, scheduling, and visit documentation for primary care or urgent care groups. Patients create accounts, add medical history (conditions, allergies, medications), and submit a visit request via symptom checklists and severity fields. Staff manage a triage queue with categories, routing rules, and SLA timers. Appointments can be on-demand or scheduled; the system tracks clinician availability, licensing regions, and visit types. Each visit generates an encounter record with vitals (patient-reported), assessment codes, treatment plan templates, follow-up tasks, and referral orders. Prescriptions and lab orders are created as structured entities and can be routed to partner pharmacies/labs as outbound requests. Billing supports insurance eligibility checks as stored responses, copay collection, invoice generation, and claim status tracking (created/submitted/accepted/denied/paid). Messaging and document exchange are tied to the encounter with strict audit logs. The platform is suited to synthesis because the key objects—patients, triage tickets, appointments, encounters, orders, prescriptions, claims, payments, and statuses—are all realistic CRUD records without needing actual clinical audio/video.

name: RxFlow Pharmacy Fulfillment & Refills
description: RxFlow is a pharmacy management and patient-facing refill platform. Patients maintain profiles, insurance details, medication lists, and preferred pickup/delivery options. They can request refills, track fulfillment status, and manage reminders. Pharmacy staff manage prescription records (drug, dosage, quantity, refills remaining, prescriber, expiration), prior authorization tickets, and substitution rules (generic allowed). The fulfillment workflow includes intake, insurance adjudication result as structured fields, fill queue, verification, packaging, pickup/delivery scheduling, and completion. Inventory tracks NDC-like identifiers, on-hand counts, lot numbers, expiration dates, controlled substance flags, and reorder points. Delivery features include address validation fields, courier assignments, routes as simple stop lists, and proof-of-delivery metadata. Billing entities include copays, reversals, refunds, and reconciliation reports. Admin roles manage pharmacists/techs, store locations, operating hours, and audit logs for compliance. The entire system is database-centric and easy to synthesize: patients, prescriptions, refill requests, insurance responses, inventory lots, fulfillment steps, deliveries, and payments provide rich API CRUD and state-machine testing.

name: AutoNation
description: AutoNation is a large automotive retail platform that supports end-to-end dealership workflows across new/used inventory, financing, and after-sales service. Users can browse and filter vehicle listings by make/model/trim, mileage, price, and location; save searches; favorite vehicles; and request quotes or test drives. A customer account can manage personal info, driver’s license/insurance documents, trade-in details, and communication preferences. Core entities include vehicles (VIN, photos, options, pricing), dealer locations, leads, offers, trade-in appraisals, credit applications, appointments, and purchase orders. Buyers can start a deal online: reserve a vehicle, submit a finance application, select protection products, upload documents, and track deal status through stages (lead → quote → deposit → paperwork → delivery). Dealership staff workflows include updating pricing, marking vehicles as sold/hold, managing inbound leads, scheduling test drives, and generating buyer’s orders. Post-sale, users can schedule service appointments, view service history, approve estimates, and pay invoices. APIs can simulate inventory feeds, lead lifecycle events, appointment availability, and transactional artifacts like invoices and contracts (metadata only).

name: CarGurus Dealer Portal
description: CarGurus Dealer Portal is a dealership management interface focused on listing syndication, lead handling, and pricing intelligence. The platform revolves around CRUD on vehicles and leads: dealers create and maintain listings with VIN decoding, trim/options, photos, price, mileage, disclosure fields, and merchandising notes; then publish to marketplace channels. Users manage multiple rooftops/locations, assign roles to staff, and set business rules like pricing strategies, contact routing, and response templates. Lead workflows include capturing inquiries (email/call/chat), tracking status (new → contacted → appointment set → closed won/lost), scheduling follow-ups, attaching notes, and logging communications. Inventory workflows include bulk imports, mapping stock numbers, setting promotions, managing availability (in stock, in transit, on hold), and auditing price changes with timestamps. Reporting dashboards summarize KPIs such as lead response time, conversion rate, days-to-turn, and listing performance metrics (views, saves) that can be synthesized. API simulation is strong: vehicles, photos (URLs), lead events, tasks, staff assignments, and price history are all structured data; integrations can emulate DMS sync, webhooks for new leads, and export endpoints for inventory feeds.

name: Shopmonkey (Auto Repair Shop Management)
description: Shopmonkey is a service scheduling and shop management platform for independent auto repair businesses. It supports the full workflow from appointment booking to repair orders, parts, labor, and invoicing. Key entities include customers, vehicles (VIN, mileage, service intervals), appointments, inspections, estimates, repair orders, labor lines, parts lines, vendors, purchase orders, payments, and shop employees. Advisors can create appointments with concerns, assign technicians, and convert appointments into repair orders. Digital vehicle inspections allow adding checklist items, photos (metadata/URLs), recommended services, and approvals; customers can approve/decline line items and receive status updates (waiting, in progress, ready). Inventory and procurement workflows include adding parts to jobs, checking stock, creating purchase orders to vendors, receiving items, and reconciling invoices. The system tracks labor time, technician productivity, and job profitability via synthesized rates and cost fields. Customers can view estimates, pay invoices, and access service history. APIs can simulate multi-bay calendars, work order state transitions, parts catalog references, taxes/fees, payment transactions (non-real), and automated reminders. This scenario is database-heavy with rich CRUD and realistic stateful processes.

name: PartsTech (Auto Parts Ordering & Inventory)
description: PartsTech is a parts procurement and inventory coordination platform used by repair shops to source and order auto parts from multiple suppliers. Users manage shop profiles, delivery preferences, technician/advisor roles, and supplier connections. Core entities include vehicles and fitment details (VIN, year/make/model/engine), parts searches (queries, results metadata), quotes, carts, purchase orders, order confirmations, deliveries, returns, and inventory bins. A typical workflow starts with a repair order requesting parts: the user enters vehicle fitment, searches for a component, compares supplier pricing/availability/ETA, and generates a quote. Approved items are added to a cart and submitted as purchase orders to selected suppliers. Orders move through statuses (submitted → accepted → shipped → delivered → closed), with line-level tracking, backorders, and substitutions. Receiving workflows include scanning/marking items received, updating on-hand inventory counts, and linking parts to specific repair orders. Returns and core charges are modeled with RMA numbers, return reasons, and refund status. All data is synthesizable: SKUs, interchange numbers, prices, quantities, ETA timestamps, supplier IDs, and delivery events. API simulations can emphasize quoting endpoints, PO lifecycle, inventory adjustments, and webhook notifications for shipment/delivery updates.

name: MyChart (Patient Portal)
description: MyChart is a patient portal used by healthcare systems to let patients manage appointments, records, billing, and secure messaging. The platform’s entities are highly structured: patients, providers, departments, appointment slots, visit summaries, lab results (values/units/ranges), medications, allergies, immunizations, documents, messages, billing statements, insurance coverage, and payment methods. Patients can create and manage profiles, add dependents/proxies, update demographics, and set notification preferences. Scheduling workflows include searching for appointment types (primary care, specialty), viewing available time slots, booking/rescheduling/canceling visits, completing pre-visit questionnaires, and checking in online. Clinical record workflows include viewing test results, downloading visit summaries, requesting medical records, and tracking care plans. Medication workflows include refill requests, medication history, and preferred pharmacy settings. Communication workflows include composing messages to care teams, receiving replies, and attaching documents (metadata). Billing workflows include viewing charges, setting up payment plans, paying balances, and downloading receipts. APIs can simulate HL7/FHIR-like resources (patients, encounters, observations), portal message threads, and appointment state transitions without requiring real clinical content beyond numeric/short-text fields.

name: Teladoc Health (Telehealth Visits)
description: Teladoc Health is a telehealth platform centered on scheduling and conducting virtual medical visits with structured intake and post-visit documentation. Users manage accounts, dependent profiles, insurance details, preferred pharmacies, and communication settings. The core workflow starts with selecting a visit type (general medical, dermatology, mental health), completing a symptom intake form (structured fields, onset dates, severity scales), uploading photos (URLs/metadata), and choosing an on-demand or scheduled appointment. Entities include patients, providers, provider availability, appointment sessions, intake questionnaires, triage outcomes, visit notes (short structured summaries), diagnoses codes (optional), prescriptions (medication, dosage, quantity, refills), care instructions, and billing claims (metadata). During the visit, status moves through queued → connected → completed; after completion, users can view visit summaries, download receipts, and message the care team for follow-up within a defined window. Operational workflows include provider credential profiles, licensing regions, shift scheduling, and routing rules. API simulation is strong: you can synthesize provider schedules, appointment availability, intake answers, claim statuses, and prescription records without AI inference. Real-time video is not required; sessions can be modeled as tokens and timestamps, with audit logs and event streams.

name: CVS Pharmacy (Prescription & Refill Management)
description: CVS Pharmacy’s digital platform supports prescription lifecycle management, refill workflows, immunization appointments, and store services. Users manage profiles, household members, insurance, preferred store, and notification preferences. Key entities include prescriptions (Rx number, medication, dosage, quantity, refills remaining), prescribers, refill orders, pickup/delivery options, payment methods, coupons (codes/eligibility metadata), immunization appointments, and order tracking events. Prescription workflows include requesting refills, enrolling in auto-refill, transferring prescriptions between pharmacies, managing prior authorization status (metadata), and choosing pickup windows or home delivery. Users can track prescription status (requested → in process → ready → picked up), receive alerts, and view medication history. Pharmacy shopping workflows (optional) include adding OTC items to cart and combining with prescriptions for pickup. Clinical service workflows include booking vaccine appointments, completing consent forms, and viewing appointment confirmations and reminders. APIs can simulate Rx records, refill eligibility rules, fulfillment status updates, store inventory availability (boolean/quantity), and delivery tracking events without real medication counseling content. This scenario provides rich CRUD across prescriptions, orders, appointments, and customer communications with realistic state changes.

name: Mindbody (Wellness Studio & Gym Management)
description: Mindbody is a management platform for gyms, yoga studios, and wellness businesses to run classes, appointments, memberships, and payments. Businesses manage locations, staff, services, class schedules, capacity, waitlists, pricing, and policies. Core entities include clients, memberships, class sessions, appointments (e.g., massage, personal training), packages/credits, check-ins, retail products, payments, promotions, and attendance records. Workflows include creating classes with recurring schedules, assigning instructors, setting capacity and cancellation windows, and managing waitlists with automated promotion rules. Client-facing workflows include browsing schedules, booking/canceling, purchasing memberships or class packs, storing cards on file, and receiving reminders. Staff workflows include roster management, timeclock (optional), commission settings, and viewing client notes and contraindications (short structured fields). Reporting includes revenue, utilization, retention, and attendance metrics that can be synthesized. APIs can simulate booking endpoints, membership billing cycles, credit consumption, check-in events, and capacity constraints. The platform is highly database-driven and well-suited for environment simulation: you can create realistic studios with calendars, thousands of bookings, payment records (non-real), and membership state transitions (trial → active → frozen → canceled).

name: Strava (Workout Tracking & Activity Log)
description: Strava is a fitness tracking platform focused on logging activities and analyzing performance over time. Users manage profiles, privacy settings, connected devices, and activity preferences. Core entities include activities (run/ride/swim), GPS tracks (coordinate arrays), splits/laps, heart rate samples, elevation, gear (shoes/bikes), routes, segments (defined paths), goals, and challenges (metadata). The primary workflow is creating or importing an activity: users upload a file or sync from a device, then the system stores timestamps, distances, pace, elevation gain, and derived summaries. Users can edit activity titles, descriptions, visibility, tags, and gear assignment; they can delete activities or correct data (e.g., trimming start/end). Social features like followers and kudos/comments can be simulated as structured interactions without requiring content-heavy posts. Training workflows include weekly mileage goals, comparing performance trends, and viewing personal records—all numeric and synthesizable. APIs can simulate device sync, activity CRUD, route creation, segment efforts, and leaderboard-like aggregates using synthetic users and tracks. This scenario is ideal for time-series data modeling (samples per second) and database queries (date ranges, aggregates, PR detection) without relying on AI recommendations.

name: Cronometer (Nutrition & Macro Tracking)
description: Cronometer is a nutrition tracking app centered on structured food logs, nutrient targets, and biometrics. Users manage profiles (age, weight, goals), dietary settings, custom nutrient targets, and connected devices. Core entities include foods (database items and custom foods), recipes, servings, diary entries by meal/time, supplements, biometrics (weight, body fat, blood pressure), and targets (calories, macros, micronutrients). The workflow involves searching/selecting foods, logging quantities with units, saving frequent foods, and building recipes from ingredients with computed nutrition totals. Users can create custom foods with label data, manage barcodes (metadata), and adjust serving sizes. Reporting features summarize daily/weekly intake versus targets, nutrient deficiencies/excesses, and trends over time—all synthesizable numeric outputs. For coaching or group use, additional entities can include clients, shared diaries, and review notes. APIs can simulate food catalog endpoints, diary CRUD, recipe composition, nutrient calculations (deterministic), and export/report queries. This platform avoids content-heavy requirements while providing rich relational and time-series data: meals, nutrients, goals, and biometrics, plus clear workflows for editing, deleting, copying days, and handling compliance streaks.

name: Asana
description: Asana is a work management platform used by teams to plan, assign, and track projects. Users create workspaces and teams, then manage projects as lists, boards, or timelines. Core entities include projects, tasks, subtasks, sections/columns, assignees, due dates, priorities, dependencies, tags, and custom fields. Typical workflows involve creating a project template, adding tasks, assigning owners, setting deadlines, attaching files/links, and moving tasks through statuses (e.g., To Do/In Progress/Done). Users can comment on tasks, @mention teammates, log time or estimates, and update progress with status updates. Administrators manage members, roles, permissions, and guest access, and can configure project privacy and approval steps. Reporting entities include saved searches, dashboards, and portfolios that aggregate task metrics across projects. Notification and automation rules can be configured (e.g., when a task moves columns, assign a reviewer; when due date changes, alert watchers). All data is highly synthesizable: users, tasks, dates, statuses, and activity logs; CRUD operations map naturally to API interactions for creating tasks, updating fields, listing by filters, and auditing changes.

name: ServiceNow (IT Service Management)
description: ServiceNow is an enterprise ITSM platform for managing service requests and operational workflows. Users interact through a service catalog to submit requests (software access, new equipment, onboarding), while IT teams handle incidents, problems, and change requests. Key entities include users, groups, configuration items (CMDB assets like laptops, servers, applications), tickets (incident/request/problem/change), SLAs, approvals, assignments, and knowledge base metadata (titles, tags, links). Common workflows include intake (create ticket), categorization and prioritization, assignment to a queue, status transitions (New/Assigned/In Progress/On Hold/Resolved/Closed), and resolution with root-cause notes and time worked. Change management adds entities like change plans, risk level, maintenance windows, impacted services, and approval chains. Asset workflows include procurement records, assignment to employees, warranty dates, and retirement/disposal status. Administrators configure forms, fields, routing rules, and escalation policies; auditing and reporting track backlog, SLA breaches, and agent performance. This is ideal for synthesis because tickets, assets, statuses, timestamps, relationships (CI impacted by ticket), and approval logs can all be realistically generated and exercised via CRUD-heavy APIs.

name: DocuSign
description: DocuSign is an e-signature and agreement workflow platform centered on preparing, sending, signing, and storing documents. Users manage templates, envelopes (a send instance), recipients, signing order, and fields (signature, initials, date, checkbox, text input). Typical workflows include uploading a document, placing fields, selecting recipients/roles (signer, approver, carbon copy), setting authentication requirements, and sending for signature. As recipients complete steps, the envelope progresses through statuses (Created/Sent/Delivered/Signed/Completed/Declined/Void). Users can resend, correct recipient emails, set reminders, define expiration dates, and track audit trails with timestamps and IP metadata. Organizations manage address books, branding, permissions, and shared template libraries. Advanced flows include conditional routing, parallel signing, attachment requirements, and payment collection at signing (modeled as payment intent records). APIs naturally map to CRUD operations on templates, envelopes, recipients, and documents, plus event webhooks for status updates. Data is fully synthesizable: names, emails, documents as placeholders, field definitions, routing rules, and audit events. This makes it suitable for database-driven simulations of approval chains, compliance logging, and lifecycle transitions without needing content-heavy document text.

name: Stripe Billing (Subscriptions)
description: Stripe Billing is a subscription and invoicing platform used by SaaS and online businesses. Users define products and prices (recurring or one-time), create customers, attach payment methods, and manage subscriptions with billing cycles and proration rules. Core entities include customers, payment methods, invoices, invoice line items, subscriptions, subscription items, coupons, discounts, tax rates, usage records (metered billing), credit notes, and payment intents. Typical workflows: sign up a customer, start a trial, upgrade/downgrade plans, apply promo codes, generate invoices, retry failed payments, and cancel or pause subscriptions. Finance operations include issuing refunds, voiding invoices, writing off bad debt, and exporting reports. Businesses also manage dunning settings, email reminders, invoice branding, and revenue recognition metadata. Webhooks emit events for invoice.created, payment_failed, subscription.updated, and dispute outcomes, enabling event-driven simulations. All data is synthesizable (amounts, currencies, dates, statuses, line items, tax calculations) and supports rich CRUD/API interaction: create subscription, update quantity, post usage, finalize invoice, pay, refund, and reconcile. This scenario exercises relational data modeling and stateful billing lifecycles without relying on non-synthesizable content.

name: Twilio Console (Messaging/Voice)
description: Twilio is a communications platform where developers and operations teams manage phone numbers, messaging services, voice applications, and usage. Users procure and configure phone numbers, set webhooks, manage sender pools, and create messaging campaigns with templates and compliance attributes. Core entities include accounts/subaccounts, phone numbers, messaging services, sender IDs, message records (to/from, body length, segments), call records, webhook endpoints, API keys, rate limits, and logs. Typical workflows: buy a number, assign it to a service, send SMS/WhatsApp messages, receive inbound messages routed to a webhook, and review delivery outcomes (queued/sent/delivered/failed). Voice workflows include configuring a call flow, recording calls, and tracking call status (initiated/ringing/in-progress/completed) with duration and costs. Administration includes rotating credentials, managing permissions, and setting alerts for spend thresholds. For synthesis, message content can be short placeholders while metadata is realistic: timestamps, status codes, error reasons, carrier, and pricing fields. This scenario supports CRUD and event-driven patterns (webhooks, callbacks), log querying, and cost reporting—ideal for API environment simulation without requiring real telecom media content.

name: GitHub (Issues & Pull Requests)
description: GitHub is a developer collaboration platform; a highly synthesizable subset focuses on repository management, issues, and pull requests rather than code content. Users create organizations, repositories, teams, and manage access permissions. Core entities include repositories, branches (metadata), issues, labels, milestones, assignees, comments, pull requests, reviews, checks/statuses, releases (metadata), and webhooks. Workflows include opening an issue, triaging with labels and priority, assigning owners, linking issues to milestones, and closing with resolution reasons. Pull request workflows include creating a PR, requesting reviewers, posting review comments, approving/changes-requested states, and merging with merge methods and required checks. Automation includes configuring webhooks for issue and PR events, and enforcing branch protection rules (required reviewers, status checks). Audit and analytics entities include events, timelines, and contribution summaries. All of this can be synthesized: users, repos, issue titles, timestamps, states, and review decisions; even commit IDs can be fake hashes. CRUD operations map cleanly to APIs for creating/updating issues, listing by filters, updating labels, posting comments, and simulating CI check runs. This supports realistic relational workflows and event streams without depending on long-form content or real code execution.

name: Zendesk (Customer Support Helpdesk)
description: Zendesk is a customer support platform centered on ticketing, customer identity, and agent workflows. Users (customers) submit requests via email, web forms, or chat; agents triage and resolve them. Key entities include end users, organizations, tickets, ticket fields (custom forms), groups, agents, macros, SLA policies, priority, tags, and knowledge base metadata (article titles/categories). Ticket workflows involve creation, assignment, internal notes vs public replies, status transitions (New/Open/Pending/On-hold/Solved/Closed), and escalation based on SLAs. Agents can merge duplicates, link related tickets, create follow-up tickets, and attach files (as metadata). Automation rules and triggers perform actions like auto-tagging, routing to a group, notifying customers, and reopening when a reply arrives. Reporting entities include views/queues, satisfaction ratings, time-to-first-response, backlog by channel, and agent activity logs. Data is straightforward to synthesize: customer profiles, ticket subjects, categories, timestamps, and statuses, enabling database-driven simulations of queues, SLA timers, and audit trails. APIs support full CRUD across tickets and users plus incremental exports and webhook events, making it ideal for practicing integrations and workflow engines.

name: Upkeep (CMMS Maintenance Management)
description: Upkeep is a computerized maintenance management system (CMMS) for facilities and equipment maintenance. Organizations manage assets and work orders, track preventive maintenance, parts inventory, and technician activity. Key entities include facilities, assets (machines, HVAC units, vehicles), asset hierarchy, meters/readings, work orders, tasks/checklists, priorities, statuses (Requested/Assigned/In Progress/Waiting/Completed), technicians, vendors, purchase orders, parts, and stock locations. Typical workflows: an operator submits a maintenance request, a supervisor triages and converts it into a work order, assigns a technician, and schedules it. Technicians log labor time, add notes/photos (metadata), record meter readings, and consume parts from inventory. Preventive maintenance schedules generate recurring work orders based on time or meter thresholds. Inventory workflows include receiving parts, setting reorder points, transferring stock between locations, and linking parts usage to work orders for cost tracking. Reporting covers downtime, mean time to repair, maintenance costs by asset, and compliance completion. Data is highly synthesizable (asset IDs, readings, timestamps, costs, statuses) and supports rich relational CRUD and event patterns. This scenario is ideal for simulating operational systems where state transitions, scheduling, and inventory constraints drive realistic database interactions.

name: Shopify (Merchant Admin for Online Stores)
description: Shopify is an e-commerce store management platform focused on merchant operations rather than a marketplace. Store owners manage products (variants, SKUs, prices, inventory), collections, discounts, and customer accounts. Orders progress through fulfillment, shipping, and returns/refunds workflows with statuses such as paid, partially fulfilled, fulfilled, canceled, and refunded. Merchants can create draft orders, apply promotions, issue refunds, and manage shipping rates and tax settings. Inventory is tracked across locations, with adjustments, transfers, and reorder thresholds. Customers, addresses, and marketing consent settings can be managed as entities, along with gift cards, subscriptions (via apps), and abandoned checkouts. For simulation, product descriptions can be short and synthetic, while prices, stock levels, and order timelines are fully synthesizable. APIs naturally cover CRUD for products, variants, inventory levels, customers, carts/checkouts, orders, fulfillments, returns, discounts, and webhooks. This scenario supports realistic integration testing for storefront events, back-office operations, and reporting (sales totals, conversion, top products) without relying on content-heavy assets.

name: GitHub Issues & Project Management (Repository Operations)
description: GitHub is a developer collaboration platform, but a highly synthesizable subset is repository project management: issues, pull requests metadata, milestones, labels, and boards. Teams create issues with titles, descriptions (short), labels, assignees, priorities, and due dates; they triage, comment, close/reopen, and link issues to milestones or projects. Pull requests can be simulated via metadata: branches, reviewers, review states (approved/changes requested), checks status, and merge outcomes, without needing real code diffs. Workflows include sprint planning with project boards (columns or status fields), automated transitions based on events, and release planning using milestones and versions. User and team permissions, repository settings, webhooks, and audit events provide additional CRUD targets. Metrics like cycle time, throughput, and backlog size can be generated from timestamps and state changes. APIs map cleanly to CRUD for repos (metadata), issues, comments, labels, milestones, projects, pull request metadata, reviews, and webhooks, enabling simulations of team coordination, integrations, and event-driven automations without needing content-heavy artifacts.

name: Chargebee Subscription Billing
description: Chargebee is a subscription management and recurring billing platform commonly used by SaaS businesses. Core entities include customers, subscriptions, plans, add-ons, coupons, invoices, payments, and credits. Users create products and pricing models (monthly/annual, tiers, usage-based), onboard customers, start trials, and manage upgrades/downgrades with proration rules. Subscriptions progress through states like trialing, active, past_due, canceled, and non_renewing. Billing workflows generate invoices on schedules, apply discounts, calculate taxes, and handle dunning for failed payments with retries and notifications. Teams can manage payment methods, refunds, chargebacks metadata, and revenue recognition schedules (as structured records). For simulation, payment outcomes can be deterministic or randomized while remaining realistic (authorization success rates, failure codes, retry windows). APIs support CRUD for catalogs, customers, subscriptions, usage records, invoices, payments, refunds, coupons, and webhook events. This scenario provides rich database interactions and event-driven patterns, ideal for testing lifecycle transitions, scheduled jobs, and financial reporting without requiring any content-heavy assets.

name: Salesforce Sales Cloud (CRM Pipeline)
description: Salesforce Sales Cloud is a CRM for managing B2B sales pipelines. Users create and maintain accounts, contacts, leads, opportunities, and activities (tasks, calls, meetings). Leads are qualified and converted into accounts/contacts/opportunities, capturing structured fields like industry, company size, source, and consent. Opportunities move through customizable stages (prospecting, proposal, negotiation, closed won/lost) with probability, expected close date, and line items (products, quantities, prices). Sales reps log interactions, attach files as metadata, add notes, and create follow-up tasks. Teams can manage territories, assignment rules, approval processes (discount approvals), and forecasts aggregated by owner or region. Reporting dashboards rely on synthesizable metrics: pipeline value, win rates, aging, and activity counts. APIs map cleanly to CRUD for accounts, contacts, leads, opportunities, products, price books, line items, tasks, events, notes, and workflow/approval records. This scenario enables realistic simulations of multi-step conversions, role-based access, and audit history while keeping the data fully synthetic and operationally meaningful.

name: Samsara Fleet Telematics & Maintenance (Fleet Management)
description: Samsara is a fleet operations platform that tracks vehicles, drivers, and maintenance workflows using structured telemetry and events. Core entities include vehicles (VIN, make/model, assigned depot), drivers, trips, routes, geofence locations, and sensor readings (speed, fuel level, odometer, engine fault codes). Dispatchers can assign routes or jobs, monitor trip status, and generate alerts for harsh braking, idling, speeding, or unauthorized movement. Maintenance teams manage service schedules, work orders, inspection reports, and parts usage, linking them to vehicles and timestamps. Compliance workflows can include driver logs (duty status changes), document uploads as metadata, and audit-ready event histories. For simulation, GPS traces, event streams, and maintenance intervals can be synthesized realistically using coordinates, timestamps, and rule-based thresholds. APIs can expose CRUD for fleets, vehicles, drivers, devices, trips, locations/geofences, alerts, maintenance work orders, inspection forms, and telemetry samples. This scenario is strong for testing time-series ingestion, status transitions, and operational dashboards without requiring any real-world media or content generation.

name: Ironclad
description: Ironclad is a contract lifecycle management (CLM) platform for creating, negotiating, approving, and storing contracts. Users generate contracts from clause libraries and templates, fill structured intake forms, and collaborate on redlines and comments. Key entities include organizations, contract requests, templates, clauses, contract records, versions, parties/counterparties, approvals, tasks, obligations, and metadata (term dates, renewal windows, governing law, spend). Workflows route contracts through configurable approval chains (legal, finance, security), with status changes such as requested, drafted, under review, approved, executed, active, renewing, expired. Teams can assign tasks, set reminders for renewals, and track obligations like delivering insurance certificates or reporting requirements. Searchable repositories support filtering by tags and metadata, plus access controls by team/role. API simulations can synthesize counterparties, clause text snippets, version history, negotiation events, and renewal schedules. Useful CRUD operations include creating contract records, updating versions, adding counterparties, recording approval decisions, and posting execution timestamps and signed-file references.

name: OneTrust
description: OneTrust is a privacy, compliance, and risk management platform for handling regulatory workflows like GDPR/CCPA requests, consent management, vendor risk, and policy documentation.
