Users configure compliance programs, create data inventories, define processing activities, and map systems to data categories and legal bases. Core entities include data subjects, DSAR cases, consent records, cookies/trackers, vendors, assessments, control frameworks, evidence items, remediation tasks, and audit logs. Workflows include intake (web form/email/API), identity verification steps, task assignment to system owners, response drafting, deadline tracking, and closure with exportable reports. Vendor risk modules manage questionnaires, scoring, findings, and follow-up actions, while governance modules manage policies, attestations, and training completion. Everything can be synthesized: fake data subjects, vendors, systems, risk scores, SLA deadlines, and status transitions (new/in review/awaiting info/fulfilled/denied). CRUD and database interactions are rich: create DSARs, attach evidence, update case status, assign tasks, record consents, and generate compliance dashboards without needing real personal data.

name: LeaseQuery
description: LeaseQuery is a lease accounting and lease administration platform that centralizes lease portfolios for compliance and financial reporting. Users enter lease agreements for real estate or equipment, capturing terms like commencement date, lease payments, escalation schedules, options, and renewal clauses. Key entities include lessors, lessees, properties/assets, leases, payment schedules, amendments, journal entries, approvals, and supporting documents. Workflows support onboarding leases, validating data, generating amortization schedules, tracking modifications (rent changes, term extensions), and producing reports for accounting standards. Users can manage notifications for renewals and critical dates, attach documents, and track approvals for changes. Simulated data is straightforward: you can generate realistic lease portfolios, payment histories, status values (draft/active/modified/terminated), and financial outputs. APIs would support CRUD on leases, amendments, schedules, and attachments, plus queries for upcoming payments, expiring leases, and reporting snapshots—ideal for database-driven interactions without relying on external content or real-time feeds.

name: Buildium
description: Buildium is a property management platform for residential rentals and HOA communities. Property managers create properties and units, onboard owners and tenants, and manage leases, rent schedules, and maintenance. Primary entities include properties, units, owners, tenants, leases, rent charges, payments, late fees, work orders, vendors, inspections, documents, and communications. Workflows cover listing vacancies, processing applications (screening status can be simulated), moving tenants in/out, generating recurring charges, recording payments, reconciling accounts, and handling maintenance requests from tenants through to vendor assignment and completion. Managers can track ledgers per unit, issue notices, store lease documents, and schedule inspections with checklists. Portals allow tenants to submit tickets and pay rent, and owners to view statements and reports. All data can be synthesized: fake units, tenants, ledger entries, maintenance statuses, and timestamps. The platform’s CRUD richness includes creating leases, updating balances, adding work orders, changing ticket status, and exporting reports—ideal for an API simulation of property operations.

name: Apartments.com (Rental Listings & Applications)
description: Apartments.com is a rentals marketplace focused on property listings, lead management, and online applications. Property owners/managers create listings with unit availability, pricing, fees, pet policies, lease terms, and amenity tags, then publish/unpublish and update inventory over time. Key entities include properties, units, floor plans, availability calendars, applicants, applications, screening results (mockable), messages/leads, tours, and application fees/payments (simulated). Workflows include responding to inquiries, scheduling tours, collecting applications, reviewing applicant status, approving/declining, and converting an approved applicant into a lease-ready tenant record. Managers can track listing performance metrics (views, inquiries), manage photos/attachments, and maintain saved templates for unit descriptions and policies. Data is highly synthesizable: realistic addresses, unit mixes, pricing histories, applicant profiles, and status transitions (new lead/contacted/tour scheduled/applied/approved/leased). An API environment can support CRUD on listings and applications, plus queries for vacancy, leads by source, and application pipeline stages without needing content-heavy components.

name: Intercom
description: Intercom is a customer messaging and support platform combining live chat, inbox workflows, and help-desk style ticketing. Companies manage contacts (users/leads), conversations, teams, assignment rules, and automation. Entities include customers, companies/accounts, conversations, messages, tags, custom attributes, support tickets, SLA timers, macros, and event timelines. Workflows include inbound chat, email-to-ticket, routing by topic/priority, internal notes, collaboration, escalation, and closure with satisfaction ratings. Automation can be modeled via rules that tag conversations, assign to teams, and send templated replies based on customer attributes or product events. Agents manage queues, update status (open/pending/snoozed/closed), and track response times. Customer profiles contain synthetic metadata like plan tier, device, last login, and billing status to power segmentation and routing. API simulations can create and update contacts, post messages, assign conversations, manage ticket fields, and generate activity events. This yields realistic CRUD operations and stateful interactions without requiring AI-generated content or external search.

name: Freshservice (ITSM Service Desk)
description: Freshservice is an IT service management (ITSM) platform for internal support, asset tracking, and change management. Users submit service requests and incidents, while IT teams manage triage, assignment, and resolution. Key entities include requesters, agents, tickets (incidents/requests/problems), categories, SLAs, assets (devices, software licenses), CMDB relationships, changes, approvals, and releases. Workflows include onboarding requests (new laptop, access provisioning), incident escalation, linking incidents to known problems, scheduling changes with CAB approvals, and documenting resolutions. Asset management tracks lifecycle states (in stock/assigned/repair/retired), ownership, warranties, and audit history. Automated rules can route tickets by category, set priorities based on impact/urgency, and generate tasks/subtasks for fulfillment. All data can be synthesized: mock employees, devices with serials, ticket queues, maintenance windows, and change calendars. APIs enable CRUD across tickets, assets, and changes, plus queries for open incidents by service, upcoming changes, and compliance-friendly audit logs.

name: Clio (Legal Practice Management)
description: Clio is a legal practice management platform for law firms to organize matters, clients, documents, time tracking, billing, and intake. Core entities include contacts (clients, opposing counsel), matters/cases, practice areas, tasks, calendar events, documents, notes, time entries, expenses, invoices, payments, trust/operating accounts, and staff permissions. Workflows cover client intake (lead -> consultation -> retained), matter creation, document assembly and filing checklists, assigning tasks with deadlines, recording billable time, generating invoices, accepting payments, and producing account statements. Document management includes uploading, tagging, versioning, and linking documents to matters, with access control by role. Firms can manage court dates and reminders, and maintain audit trails for billing and account activity. Data is highly synthesizable: fake clients, case types, time entries, invoice line items, payment statuses, and event schedules. An API simulation can demonstrate CRUD on matters, time entries, invoices, and documents, plus workflow state transitions (open/pending/closed) without requiring real legal content.

name: AppFolio Property Manager
description: AppFolio Property Manager supports end-to-end operations for property management companies across residential, student, and commercial portfolios. Key entities include portfolios, properties, units, prospects, showings, applications, tenants, leases, rent/fee rules, inspections, work orders, vendors, payments, and accounting records. Workflows include prospect inquiry capture, scheduling showings, converting prospects to applicants, screening (score/status), lease generation, and move-in checklists. Ongoing management covers posting recurring charges, recording payments, enforcing late fees, generating notices, handling renewals, and processing move-outs with deposit accounting. Maintenance modules create service requests, triage/assign, track ETAs, store photos/notes (metadata), and capture vendor bills. Communication can be represented via threads, templates, and delivery status. Reporting can expose occupancy, rent roll, delinquency, maintenance backlog, and owner statements. An API simulation can support CRUD for all objects plus permissioned roles (manager, leasing agent, tenant, owner) and audit logs. The system is well-suited because it is structured, transactional, and stateful—ideal for realistic test data: leases with dates, unit availability, payment schedules, ticket SLAs, and vendor performance metrics.

name: CoStar LoopNet (Commercial Listings)
description: A LoopNet-style commercial real estate listings and deal workflow platform lets brokers and landlords publish and manage office/retail/industrial listings. Synthesizable entities include properties, spaces/suites, floor plans (metadata), asking rents, CAM estimates, availability dates, broker contacts, marketing packages, leads, tours, offers, LOIs, and deal stages. Users create listings with structured attributes (building class, square footage, zoning, amenities), publish/unpublish, manage price changes, and track inquiries. Lead management includes capturing inbound messages, assigning to agents, logging calls/emails, scheduling tours, and converting leads to opportunities. Deal workflows track proposals, document requests, counter-offers, and status changes (new → qualified → toured → LOI → lease out). Permissions and teams can be modeled for brokerages with multiple agents and portfolios. Analytics endpoints can return listing views, lead response times, and conversion rates from synthesized events. The platform avoids content-heavy requirements because the core value is structured inventory + pipeline management rather than long-form content; descriptions are short fields and the rest is attributes, timestamps, and status. It is highly suitable for API simulation with clear CRUD operations and realistic commercial leasing lifecycles.

name: Furnished Finder (Mid-term Rental Marketplace)
description: A Furnished Finder-like marketplace focuses on 30+ day furnished rentals for traveling professionals. Hosts manage listings, units/rooms, pricing by month, availability calendars, house rules, deposits, utilities included flags, and photos (metadata). Renters manage profiles, verification status, saved searches (stored filters), inquiries, bookings, leases/agreements, and payment schedules. Workflows include inquiry → host response → viewing/virtual tour scheduling → booking request → approval/decline → deposit collection → lease signing → check-in/out. The platform can support messaging threads, template responses, and notification delivery statuses. Reviews are structured: ratings, categories (cleanliness, accuracy), and short comments. Dispute/claim handling is also synthesizable via cases, evidence metadata, and resolution statuses. Admin tools cover moderation (listing status, flags), identity checks (status + timestamps), and fraud/risk rules (scores). Because pricing, availability, and booking states are all database-driven, an API simulator can generate realistic inventory, seasonal pricing, overlapping calendar constraints, and funnel metrics. The marketplace is well-scoped for CRUD and transactional flows without requiring real content feeds or complex recommendation engines.

name: Turo (Peer-to-Peer Car Rental Marketplace)
description: Turo is a peer-to-peer vehicle rental marketplace where hosts list cars and renters book trips. Synthesizable entities include vehicles (VIN-like IDs, make/model/year, features), listing photos (metadata), daily pricing, discounts, delivery options, availability calendars, trip requests, insurance/protection plans, add-ons, driver profiles, verification statuses, messages, trip checklists, incident reports, and reviews. Core workflows: host creates/updates a vehicle listing, sets rules (mileage limits, fuel policy), blocks calendar dates, and approves/declines booking requests. Renters search using filters (stored query parameters), request trips, pay, and manage trip modifications/cancellations with policy-driven fees. Trip lifecycle states (requested → approved → checked-in → in-progress → completed) are ideal for state machines. Damage handling can be modeled with claims, photos metadata, estimates, and payout statuses. Support operations include disputes, refunds, and account holds. For API simulation, the platform offers rich CRUD plus validations (availability conflicts, age/verification requirements, pricing calculations) while remaining fully synthesizable: no need for real GPS traces or media beyond metadata, and search ranking can be simplified to filtering/sorting.

name: ServiceNow Customer Service Management (Case/Ticketing)
description: ServiceNow CSM is an enterprise customer support and ticketing system centered on case management and omnichannel communication. Entities include customers/organizations, contacts, products/assets, entitlements/SLAs, cases, tasks, knowledge article references (titles/IDs only), attachments metadata, communications (emails/chats), escalation rules, and resolution codes. Workflows are highly structured: create case via portal/email/API, auto-categorize (simulated), route to queues/agents, assign tasks, track SLA timers, add internal/external notes, request information, and close with outcome and customer satisfaction ratings. Integrations can be simulated with webhooks/events for status changes and inbound messages. Admin operations cover queue configuration, macros/templates, role-based access, and audit history. Reporting endpoints can return volumes by category, agent performance, first response time, backlog aging, and SLA breach rates. This scenario is ideal for API environment synthesis because all objects are transactional, have clear lifecycle states, and rely on short text + structured fields rather than long content. It also supports realistic multi-tenant data models (accounts, contacts, entitlements) and complex relational queries suitable for database-driven testing.

name: eBay (Auction + Fixed-Price Marketplace)
description: eBay is a marketplace supporting both auctions and fixed-price listings. Synthesizable entities include sellers, buyer accounts, listings (item SKU-like IDs), categories, item conditions, photos metadata, shipping services, inventory quantities, auction parameters (start/end time, reserve, bid increment), bids, watchlists, offers, carts, orders, payments, refunds, disputes, and feedback ratings. Workflows cover seller listing creation, revisions, scheduling, promotions, and fulfillment; buyers search via structured filters, place bids, set max bids, make offers, purchase instantly, and track shipments. Auctions have a clear state machine (scheduled → live → ended → paid/awaiting payment → shipped → completed) and bid history is ideal for event logs. Returns and disputes can be modeled with reason codes, timelines, and status transitions. Admin/moderation workflows include listing policy checks, counterfeit flags, and seller performance metrics. For API simulation, pricing, bid activity, shipping times, and ratings can all be generated realistically without any need for content-heavy pages. The marketplace model provides rich relational data and transactional integrity scenarios (concurrency in bids, inventory decrements, payment status).

name: Faire (B2B Wholesale Marketplace)
description: Faire is a B2B wholesale marketplace connecting independent retailers with brands. Entities include brands/suppliers, retailer accounts, catalogs/products, wholesale price lists, minimum order quantities, terms (net payment days), samples, purchase orders, line items, shipments, invoices, returns, promotions, and messaging between buyers and brands. Retailers browse catalogs with structured attributes, build carts, submit POs, request terms, and reorder from past purchases. Brands manage product catalogs, inventory availability, lead times, order acceptance, fulfillment, and wholesale customer relationships. Payment workflows can include invoicing, partial shipments, refunds, and chargebacks—each with status values and timestamps. A CRM-like layer can track retailer outreach, notes, tasks, and deal stages (prospect → active account). For API simulation, the platform is excellent: it’s largely CRUD and transactional with clear constraints (MOQ, case packs, pricing tiers, shipping windows), and the text fields can be short descriptions. Reporting endpoints can provide GMV by period, repeat rate, fulfillment performance, and aging invoices. This scenario offers a different e-commerce niche (wholesale) with distinct workflows from consumer retail.

name: Twilio Conversations
description: Twilio Conversations (or a similar CPaaS messaging layer) provides programmable chat across SMS, WhatsApp, and in-app channels. The platform is built around services, conversations, participants, messages, media attachments, delivery receipts, and webhooks. Developers and operators can create a conversation, add participants (by identity or phone number), send messages, update message attributes (metadata), and manage participant state (muted, removed, last-read index). Workflows include onboarding a customer into a support chat, escalating to a group conversation with agents, and closing/archiving conversations with an outcome status. From an API simulation standpoint, all data is synthesizable: message bodies, timestamps, sender identities, delivery/read events, and status transitions (queued/sent/delivered/read/failed). Admin features can include opt-in/opt-out management, templates, rate limits, and compliance flags. Reporting endpoints can aggregate conversation volumes, agent response times, and channel mix without requiring real-world content beyond short text. Webhooks can drive realistic event streams for integration testing (message added, participant joined/left, conversation updated).

name: Jira Service Management
description: Jira Service Management is an ITSM/helpdesk platform for managing service requests, incidents, problems, and changes. Core entities include projects, request types, forms, tickets/issues, queues, workflows, approvals, assets/CMDB items, SLAs, knowledge links, and change calendars. Users submit requests through a portal; agents triage, categorize, and assign; and tickets progress through configurable states (reported, in progress, waiting for approval, resolved). Approvers can approve/decline changes, and automation rules can create subtasks, notify stakeholders, or escalate when SLA targets are breached. The system is well-suited for API simulation because data is structured and synthesizable: issue fields, custom fields, priorities, components, linked issues, comments, worklogs, and audit trails. Asset entities (laptops, servers, software licenses) can be CRUD-managed and associated to tickets, enabling realistic scenarios like “replace device,” “grant access,” or “outage incident.” Metrics (mean time to acknowledge/resolve, SLA compliance) can be computed from synthetic timestamps. Integrations can be represented via webhooks and external references to monitoring alerts or deployment records.

name: StockX (Marketplace for Sneakers/Collectibles)
description: StockX-style marketplaces facilitate buying and selling authenticated goods using listings and bids/asks. Core entities include products (with attributes like size/condition), users, listings (asks), bids, matches/trades, orders, payouts, fees, shipping labels, authentication status, and dispute cases. Sellers create listings with price and quantity; buyers place bids; the system matches bids and asks into an order. Workflows include seller ship-to-authentication, verification results (pass/fail/needs review), buyer shipment, and final settlement. All data is synthesizable and database-driven: price histories, order timelines, fee breakdowns, shipment events, and status states (listed, matched, shipped to auth, authenticated, shipped to buyer, delivered, completed). Admin operations can include listing moderation, authentication outcomes, user risk flags, and dispute resolution with message threads. APIs can expose market data endpoints (last sale, bid/ask depth) based on generated transactions, enabling realistic testing of pricing dashboards, notifications, and settlement pipelines without requiring content-heavy media.

name: eBay Auctions
description: An eBay-like auction platform supports time-bound listings where buyers place bids and sellers manage fulfillment after auctions close. Key entities include sellers, buyers, listings, item catalog entries, photos (metadata), auction schedules, bids, watchlists, messages, payments, shipping options, orders, returns, and feedback ratings. Sellers create listings with starting price, reserve, buy-it-now option, quantity, and shipping policies; buyers bid, retract bids (with rules), set maximum proxy bids, and receive outbid notifications. When auctions end, winning bids convert into orders with payment capture, shipping label purchase, and tracking updates. Disputes and returns can be initiated with statuses and resolution outcomes. Everything is API-suitable for synthesis: short descriptions, categories, bid increments, timestamps, bidder identities, order status changes, and feedback scores. Admin tools can include fraud flags, account limits, listing takedowns, and audit logs. Event streams (bid placed, auction ended, payment confirmed, delivered) make it ideal for integration and workflow testing.

name: ShipBob (3PL Fulfillment & Shipping Portal)
description: ShipBob-style 3PL platforms let merchants store inventory in warehouses and outsource picking, packing, and shipping. Core entities include merchants, warehouses, SKUs, inventory lots, inbound shipments (receiving), storage locations, orders, pick lists, packing slips, shipping labels, carriers/services, tracking events, returns (RMA), and billing line items. Merchants create SKUs, define carton/case configurations, and submit inbound shipments with expected quantities. Once received, inventory levels update per warehouse. Orders can be imported via API, created manually, or batched; the system allocates inventory, generates pick/pack tasks, and purchases labels. Status workflows include order received, allocated, picked, packed, shipped, delivered, exception, and returned/restocked. All data is synthesizable: warehouse IDs, stock counts, shipment ETAs, carrier codes, tracking numbers, and event timelines. APIs support CRUD for inventory, inbound shipments, orders, and returns, plus webhooks for shipping events. This scenario is ideal for database-driven simulation of fulfillment SLAs, partial shipments, backorders, and cost reconciliation.

name: Toast POS (Restaurant Operations)
description: Toast is a restaurant point-of-sale and operations platform that supports ordering, menu management, payments, and front/back-of-house workflows. Users can manage menu entities (items, modifiers, combos, pricing rules, daypart availability), tables/floor plans, employee profiles, roles/permissions, and shift schedules. Orders flow through states—open, fired, ready, paid, voided/refunded—with line-item updates, special instructions, discounts, taxes, and tips. Operational CRUD includes opening/closing checks, splitting/merging checks, transferring tables, issuing comps, and recording refunds. Inventory and prep can be modeled via ingredient counts, low-stock alerts, and item 86’ing (mark unavailable). Customers can be stored as profiles with visit history, loyalty points, and saved payment tokens (simulated). Reporting is database-driven: sales summaries, server performance, labor costs, and payout reconciliation. API simulation is strong for order creation/updating, payment intent/capture/refund flows, menu publishing, shift clock-in/out, and event webhooks to kitchen display systems or delivery aggregators.

name: Airtable (Team Database & Workflow)
description: Airtable is a spreadsheet-like database platform where teams build apps on top of structured tables and relationships. Users create bases, tables, fields (text, number, single select, attachments metadata, links to records), views (grid, kanban, calendar), and automations. Core entities are workspaces, bases, tables, fields, records, linked records, comments, and collaborators/roles. CRUD interactions are rich: insert/update/delete records, bulk imports, filtering/sorting views, linking records across tables (e.g., Projects ↔ Tasks ↔ People), and maintaining computed fields (formulas, rollups). Workflows include intake via forms, review/approval columns, assignment and due dates, and automations that trigger on record changes to create follow-up tasks or send notifications. Permissions (read-only, editor, owner) shape what operations are allowed. For API simulation, you can model endpoints for metadata management (schema changes), record-level CRUD, pagination, webhook change events, and audit logs. Data is straightforward to synthesize across many domains (content calendars, asset trackers, QA logs, vendor lists) while remaining realistic and operationally meaningful.

name: Twilio (Messaging & Voice Communication)
description: Twilio is a communications platform providing APIs for SMS, WhatsApp messaging (metadata), voice calls, and phone number management. Users manage accounts, API keys, phone numbers, messaging services, sender pools, verified caller IDs, and application configurations (webhooks for inbound/outbound events). Key entities include messages, conversations, call records, recordings metadata (not media), delivery statuses, error codes, opt-in/opt-out lists, and templates for notifications. Workflows include provisioning numbers, configuring callback URLs, sending messages, receiving delivery receipts, handling failures/retries, and maintaining compliance artifacts (consent records, stop keywords, geographic restrictions). For voice, you can simulate call initiation, call status transitions (queued, ringing, in-progress, completed), and basic call logs with durations and cost estimates. API simulations can cover CRUD on numbers and configuration, create/read message logs, filter by date/status, and process webhooks that update message/call states. All data is synthesizable (phone numbers, timestamps, statuses, costs) and supports realistic integration testing for appointment reminders, two-factor codes, support hotlines, and notification pipelines without requiring actual carrier delivery.

name: Fleetio (Fleet Maintenance Management)
description: Fleetio is a fleet management platform for tracking vehicles, maintenance, inspections, and fuel/expense logs. Users manage vehicles (VIN, make/model, odometer), drivers, assignments, locations, service schedules, work orders, parts inventory, vendors/shops, and documents (registration/insurance metadata). CRUD operations include adding vehicles, updating mileage, assigning drivers, creating preventive maintenance schedules (every X miles/days), logging service events, and recording costs. Workflows include inspection checklists with pass/fail items, generating maintenance reminders, opening a work order, adding labor/parts line items, setting statuses (requested, approved, in_progress, completed), and attaching receipts metadata. Fuel tracking can be synthesized via fill-ups with gallons, price per gallon, and station location to generate MPG and cost reports. API simulations can cover vehicle lifecycle updates, event timelines, work order state transitions, and report endpoints (maintenance cost per mile, downtime, upcoming services). Data is straightforward to fake yet realistic, and it supports complex relational queries across vehicles, drivers, vendors, and maintenance history.

name: Klaviyo (Email/SMS Marketing Automation)
description: Klaviyo is a marketing automation platform centered on customer profiles, events, segments, and messaging campaigns. Users manage contacts (profiles with attributes), lists, consent/preferences, custom properties, and event streams (checkout started, purchase completed, email opened) that drive segmentation. Core entities include segments, campaigns, flows (automations), templates, message variants, send schedules, metrics, and webhooks/integrations. CRUD operations include importing/updating profiles, creating segments with rules, building campaigns, editing templates (short content/metadata), scheduling sends, and pausing/resuming flows. Workflow patterns include triggered sequences (welcome series, abandoned cart), conditional branching by attributes, A/B tests, and suppression lists. Analytics is database-driven: delivery status, open/click rates, conversion attribution, revenue per campaign, and cohort retention—fully synthesizable as numeric metrics linked to events and timestamps. API simulation can cover profile CRUD, event ingestion, segment evaluation (returning synthesized membership), campaign creation/scheduling, and retrieving reporting aggregates. This scenario is excellent for testing event-driven pipelines, idempotency of event writes, and large-scale list/segment queries without requiring real message delivery.

name: PlayStation Store (Console Digital Marketplace)
description: PlayStation Store is a console-first marketplace for purchasing digital games, add-ons, and subscriptions. Users manage PSN-like accounts, consoles/devices, wallets, payment instruments, parental controls, and region settings. Key entities include product SKUs (games, DLC, season passes), editions, entitlements/licenses, subscription plans (Plus tiers), renewal status, download queues, pre-orders, and refund cases. Typical workflows include browsing a catalog, saving items to a wishlist, placing pre-orders (with release-date fulfillment), purchasing and immediately provisioning entitlements, and initiating remote downloads to a registered device. Users can also manage recurring subscriptions (upgrade/downgrade tier, pause, cancel), redeem promo codes, and view purchase history/receipts. Social features can be modeled as structured data: user ratings, short reviews, and content warnings. For API simulation, you can synthesize storefront inventory, dynamic price rules, discount campaigns, age ratings, device compatibility matrices, and entitlement validation checks used by client apps.

name: Twitch (Streaming Channels + Subscriptions + Bits)
description: Twitch is a live streaming platform centered on channels, subscriptions, and creator monetization. A simulation focuses on channel management and transactional metadata rather than video. Core entities include users, channels, stream sessions (start/end, category, title), VOD metadata (IDs, durations), followers, subscriptions (tier, renewal date), gifted subs, cheers/bits transactions, emotes (catalog, ownership), chat messages (short text), moderation actions, and reports/appeals. Streamers manage channel settings, schedule upcoming broadcasts, create panels and tags, and configure moderation rules (banned words, timeouts). Viewers follow/unfollow, subscribe/unsubscribe, buy bits, cheer, and manage notifications. Workflows include going live (creating a stream session), updating stream title/category mid-session, ending a session, generating analytics summaries (viewer counts, revenue totals), and handling moderation queues (review report → action → log). APIs can realistically synthesize viewer metrics, monetization events, and chat volume while keeping media out of scope.

name: Roblox (UGC Game Platform + Virtual Economy)
description: Roblox is a user-generated game platform where creators publish experiences and sell virtual goods. Users manage accounts, avatars, friend lists, groups, and safety settings. Creators manage experiences (place IDs), versions, access controls, game passes, developer products, in-experience catalogs, and payout settings. Economy entities include virtual currency balances, purchases, receipts, refunds/chargebacks, limited items, marketplace listings, price history (synthetic), and inventory ownership. Core workflows: create an experience record, upload a new version (metadata + build ID), configure monetization items, publish updates, and manage moderation states (pending/approved/rejected). Players browse experiences by genre, join sessions (session IDs), favorite/like, report content, and purchase avatar items or passes. Group operations include membership requests, role assignments, group funds (synthetic), and audit logs. For API simulation, you can generate believable item catalogs, scarcity rules, transaction ledgers, and engagement counters without needing actual 3D assets.

name: GOG.com (DRM-Free Game Store + Download Library)
description: GOG.com is a DRM-free marketplace where customers buy games and manage offline installers. Users manage profiles, addresses, payment methods, carts, wishlists, and libraries. Key entities include products (game IDs), editions, downloadable files (installer IDs, platform, checksum, size), patches, bonus content (soundtrack/artbook metadata), order records, invoices, refund requests, and support messages. Workflows include browsing the catalog, tracking price drops on wishlisted items, purchasing bundles during promotions, receiving entitlements, and selecting which installers to download (Windows/macOS/Linux). Users can also manage optional updates (latest version vs. pinned), verify file integrity via hashes, and export purchase history for accounting. Community features can be represented as structured content: ratings, short reviews, and forum thread metadata (titles/IDs only). For simulation, generate a realistic product catalog, file manifests, release timelines, discount schedules, and library states (owned/not owned, downloaded/not downloaded) to drive extensive CRUD and reporting APIs.

name: Reverb (Musical Instruments Marketplace)
description: Reverb is an e-commerce marketplace focused on new and used musical instruments and gear. Sellers manage shops, product listings (condition, year, brand/model, serial-like IDs), pricing, inventory quantity, shipping profiles, and offer settings (accept offers, minimum offer). Buyers manage saved searches, watchlists, carts, payments, and shipping addresses. Order entities include line items, negotiated offers, taxes, shipping labels, tracking events, returns, refunds, and feedback ratings. Workflows include listing creation with variations (e.g., color/finish), enabling local pickup vs. shipping, handling inbound questions/messages, negotiating offers (offer → counteroffer → acceptance), and fulfilling orders with carrier selection and label generation. Post-sale operations include partial refunds for issues, return authorizations, dispute resolution, and seller performance metrics (ship time, cancellation rate). For simulation, you can synthesize catalogs, realistic condition grading, price ranges, shipping zones, and message threads, making it rich for CRUD, search/filter, and stateful commerce APIs.

name: Depop (Peer-to-Peer Fashion Resale + Social Shop)
description: Depop is a social-first peer-to-peer marketplace for secondhand fashion. Users manage profiles, closets (listings), followers/following, likes, saved items, carts, and payment/shipping settings. Listings include structured attributes (category, size, brand, condition, color, price, quantity), photo metadata, hashtags/tags, and visibility states (draft/published/sold). Buyers browse feeds and categories, message sellers, make offers, and purchase items; sellers accept/decline offers, reserve items, and fulfill orders with tracking. Order entities cover payment status, shipment status, cancellations, refunds, and disputes. Social CRUD includes commenting (short text), liking, reposting, and reporting listings. Workflows: create listing → publish → receive messages/offers → accept offer → payment capture → shipping label creation → mark shipped → delivery confirmation → leave feedback. For simulation, generate fashion catalogs, user closets, offer negotiations, and shipping timelines. The platform is highly suitable because most interactions are structured transactions and short text, not long-form content.

name: Back Market (Refurbished Electronics Retail)
description: Back Market is a retail marketplace for refurbished electronics sold by vetted refurbishers. Users manage accounts, addresses, payment methods, and warranty preferences; browse products by model, storage, color, grade, and carrier compatibility. Key entities include product models, SKU variants, refurbisher storefronts, grading tiers (Fair/Good/Excellent), warranty plans, inventory availability, carts, orders, invoices, returns, replacements, and customer support cases. Workflows include selecting a device variant, comparing grades and sellers, purchasing with optional warranty, and receiving shipment tracking updates. After delivery, users can open return requests within a window, choose reasons (DOA, cosmetic mismatch, battery health), and request refund or replacement; the seller processes RMA states (approved → shipped back → inspected → refunded/replaced). Sellers manage stock uploads, pricing rules, lead times, and quality metrics. This scenario is strong for synthesis: you can generate device catalogs, grade-based pricing, warranty SKUs, inventory counts, and end-to-end return logistics without needing any real-time external data.

name: Fat Llama (Peer-to-Peer Equipment Rental Marketplace)
description: Fat Llama is a rental marketplace for borrowing and lending equipment like cameras, drones, tools, and AV gear. Lenders manage listings (item type, replacement value, daily rate, deposit), availability calendars, pickup/delivery options, location radius, and house rules. Renters manage profiles, verification status, saved lists, booking requests, and payment methods. Core entities include listings, quotes, booking requests, rental agreements, messages, pickup appointments, check-in/check-out inspections (condition notes), deposits, late fees, extensions, cancellations, and damage claims. Workflows: renter submits a booking request for dates → lender approves/declines or counters with a quote → payment authorization + deposit hold → scheduled handoff → rental active → return + condition verification → deposit release. Extensions and late returns trigger recalculated charges; disputes create claim cases with evidence metadata. For simulation, synthesize calendars, location coordinates, pricing, state transitions, and ledger entries. It provides rich CRUD and transactional APIs without requiring any content-heavy media.

name: Poshmark (Fashion Resale Marketplace)
description: Poshmark is a peer-to-peer fashion resale marketplace where sellers create listings and buyers purchase secondhand items. Core entities are users, closets (storefront profiles), listings (brand, size, condition, price, SKU, photo metadata), offers, bundles, shipping labels, orders, payouts, returns, and ratings. Sellers can draft, publish, edit, and delist items; set price drops; manage inventory quantity (single-item vs multi-qty lots); and track order fulfillment milestones (sold → shipped → delivered → complete). Buyers can browse categories and filters, like items, add to bundles, submit offers, and check out with shipping options. The platform supports messaging threads tied to a listing or order, dispute/return requests with structured reason codes, and review workflows (buyer rates seller; seller rates buyer). Admin-like operations include moderation flags, category/brand dictionaries, fee rules, and promotional campaigns. All data is highly synthesizable (prices, statuses, sizes, brands, timestamps, shipping events), making it suitable for API simulations of listing lifecycle, purchase flows, and marketplace trust signals.

name: Chairish-Style Curated Home Decor Consignment
description: A Chairish-style platform blends curated listings with consignment-like workflows for home furniture and decor. Entities include sellers, consignor agreements, listings (category, dimensions, materials, condition, era/style tags, price, delivery methods, photo metadata), pickup/delivery quotes, offers, orders, shipping providers, damage claims, returns (if allowed), and payouts. Sellers can create and edit listings with structured attributes, request pricing guidance (stored as recommended price records), and choose fulfillment options (ship, local delivery, white-glove). Buyers can favorite items, create room “boards” (curation collections), request shipping quotes by ZIP, submit offers, and complete checkout. Order workflows involve scheduling pickup, carrier assignment, tracking milestones (scheduled → picked up → in transit → delivered), and post-delivery confirmation. The platform supports commissions and tiered fees, plus promotional discounts applied at checkout. Moderation and curation features are database-friendly: featured collections, tag vocabularies, and listing quality flags. This scenario is well-suited to synthetic API simulation because dimensions, pricing, delivery windows, statuses, and claims reasons are all structured and realistic without requiring long-form content.

name: Raindrop.io-Style Bookmark Manager (Team + Tags)
description: A Raindrop.io-style bookmark manager helps users save, organize, and share web links with strong CRUD and collection workflows. Key entities are users, workspaces/teams, collections (nested folders), bookmarks (URL, title, excerpt, favicon/preview metadata), tags, highlights/notes (short snippets), attachments metadata, and sharing permissions. Users can create/edit/delete bookmarks, move items between collections, bulk-tag, deduplicate by URL hash, and import/export lists. Collections can be private, shared via link, or shared to a team with role-based permissions (owner/editor/viewer). The system supports smart collections stored as saved filters (tag contains, domain equals, date range), plus read/unread status and reminder dates. Collaboration workflows include comment threads on bookmarks, change history logs, and moderation controls for shared spaces. APIs can model URL normalization, tag dictionaries, pagination, full-text search over short fields (titles/notes), and webhook events (bookmark.created, collection.updated). All stored data is synthesizable and structured, making it ideal for database-driven simulations of personal knowledge organization without needing to fetch real page content.

name: Goodreads-Style Reading Lists & Wishlists (Metadata-Only)
description: A Goodreads-style platform centered on reading lists can be simulated without long-form reviews by focusing on metadata and list management. Entities include users, books (ISBN-like IDs, title, author, genres, publication year), editions (format, language), shelves/lists (want-to-read, currently-reading, custom), reading status updates (pages, percent, timestamps), ratings (1–5), short reviews (optional, brief), and recommendations settings (rule-based, not AI). Users add books to shelves, reorder list items, set reading goals, log progress entries, and rate books upon completion. The system can support follow relationships, activity feeds (event records), and group reading challenges with join/leave membership and milestone tracking. Admin operations manage the book catalog, genre taxonomy, and duplicate-merge tools. APIs exercise CRUD on shelves, list items, and progress logs; enforce constraints (a book can be “currently reading” once); and generate summaries (books read this year, average rating). Because the platform’s value can be simulated via structured metadata and short text fields, it works well for API environment testing of collections, wishlists, and lightweight social graph features.

name: Khan Academy-Style Learning Platform (Courses + Mastery)
description: A Khan Academy-style learning platform can be modeled around structured learning objects and progress tracking. Entities include users (learners, guardians, coaches), courses, units, lessons, exercises, quizzes, skill tags, attempts, mastery states (not started/practicing/mastered), badges, and assignments. Learners enroll in courses, complete lessons, submit exercise attempts (answers stored as structured fields), and receive scores and mastery updates based on rule thresholds. Coaches create classes, invite students, assign lessons/exercises with due dates, and monitor dashboards showing completion and performance summaries. The platform supports content sequencing rules (prerequisites), accommodations (extra time), and notifications (assignment due, mastery achieved). Admin-like tools include course authoring (CRUD on units/lessons), versioning (draft/published), and question banks (items with correct-answer keys and difficulty). This scenario is highly synthesizable because questions can be template-based, scores numeric, and progress timestamps realistic. APIs can cover enrollment flows, assignment lifecycles, gradebook exports, and analytics aggregates (time spent, accuracy by skill) without needing media or long content.

name: Teachable-Style Course Storefront (Creator + Checkout)
description: A Teachable-style platform lets creators build and sell online courses using structured modules and commerce primitives. Entities include creators, schools/sites, courses, modules, lessons (text metadata, downloadable file metadata), pricing plans (one-time, subscription, installments), coupons, students, enrollments, progress, quizzes (question bank + attempts), certificates, orders, invoices, refunds, and affiliate links. Creators CRUD course content, publish/unpublish, set access rules (drip schedule by day), and configure checkout (tax, currency, payment methods). Students browse the course catalog, purchase, enroll, and track progress; they can update profiles, manage subscriptions, and download receipts. Workflows include lead capture forms, email sequences (stored templates + send logs), coupon redemption, and refund requests with structured reasons. Admin operations cover user roles, payout schedules, and compliance settings. This is ideal for API simulation because it includes realistic multi-tenant data (schools), transactional integrity (orders → enrollments), and time-based access controls (drip). All lesson content can remain short/metadata-based while still enabling meaningful CRUD and reporting endpoints.

name: Wyzant-Style Tutoring Marketplace (Scheduling + Packages)
description: A Wyzant-style tutoring marketplace connects students with tutors and supports booking and billing workflows. Entities include tutor profiles (subjects, hourly rates, availability slots, verification status), student profiles, lesson requests, messages, bookings (date/time, duration, modality), lesson packages (prepaid credits), invoices, payments, cancellations, reschedule events, and ratings. Tutors manage availability calendars, set rates per subject, create custom offers (discounted packages), and track earnings. Students search by subject (using structured tags), request sessions, book times, and pay; they can upload assignment metadata (file references), track upcoming sessions, and leave reviews after completion. The platform enforces policies like cancellation windows, no-show statuses, and dispute flows with resolution codes. Group tutoring can be represented with session capacity and attendee records. APIs can simulate scheduling constraints (timezone handling, slot conflicts), lifecycle transitions (requested → confirmed → completed), and payout calculations (platform fees, taxes). All data is synthesizable: profiles, rates, schedules, and transactional logs—useful for testing calendar-heavy CRUD and marketplace interactions without relying on content generation.

name: Rubric-Based Assignment Marketplace (Teacher Resource Wishlists)
description: A platform for educators to curate and purchase classroom resources focuses on lists, wishlists, and structured content metadata rather than long documents. Entities include sellers (teachers/creators), resource listings (grade level, subject, standards tags, file metadata, preview thumbnails metadata, price), bundles, carts, orders, licenses (single classroom/school-wide), ratings, and buyer libraries. Buyers can create wishlists and “unit plan” collections, add resources, reorder items, and share lists with team members for approval. Schools can be modeled with organizations, budgets, purchase approvals, and PO numbers; workflows include request → manager approval → purchase → access granted. Sellers manage inventory (digital download limits via license rules), update versions (v1/v2), and send announcements to past buyers (send logs only). The platform supports coupons, district-wide pricing tiers, and refund requests with reason codes. APIs cover CRUD on collections and resource metadata, checkout with licenses, entitlement checks when downloading, and audit logs for organizational purchasing—highly suitable for synthetic database simulation while staying away from content-heavy artifacts.

name: Grailed
description: Grailed is a fashion resale marketplace focused on menswear and designer streetwear, with strong CRUD-driven interactions. Sellers manage closets/wardrobes, create listings with size, brand, condition, measurements, price, shipping options, and availability status. Buyers follow brands and sellers, save searches (stored filter criteria), send offers, message sellers, and pay through integrated checkout. Key entities include users, seller profiles, listings, price drops, offers, messages, orders, payments, shipping labels, tracking scans, returns, refunds, and moderation decisions (approved/removed with reasons). Workflows are highly structured: create listing → moderation queue → publish → offer negotiation → payment captured → seller ships within SLA → delivery → rating/review. API simulations can include automated price-drop campaigns, bundle orders (multiple listings in one checkout), and seller performance metrics (ship time, cancellation rate). The platform can realistically synthesize catalog taxonomies (brands/categories), sizing systems, address books, and fee schedules, enabling meaningful database interactions without depending on any long-form content.

name: Kiva (Microloan Marketplace)
description: Kiva is a crowdfunding-style microloan platform where lenders fund borrower loans through structured contributions. Users create lender accounts, manage wallets/balances, browse loan profiles represented as structured records (country, sector, amount requested, amount funded, repayment schedule, risk tier), and fund loans in increments. Core entities include lenders, borrowers (anonymized profiles), loan postings, field partners, funding transactions, repayment schedules, repayments, wallet movements, donations/tips, tax receipts, and portfolio summaries. Workflows include loan posting creation (admin/partner) → funding open → fully funded → disbursement recorded → periodic repayments credited back to lenders → re-lend or withdraw balance. Portfolio features include auto-lending rules (saved preferences), watchlists, and impact reporting (loans by region/sector, repayment rates). All data can be synthesized: loan terms, payment dates, repayment statuses, delinquency flags, and exchange-rate adjustments as predefined numeric series. This scenario supports rich CRUD APIs for loans, funding, repayment events, and user preferences.

name: Affirm (Buy Now, Pay Later)
description: Affirm is a BNPL platform embedded in merchant checkouts, centered on underwriting decisions, installment plans, and repayment tracking. Shoppers create accounts, link payment methods, view prequalification, choose a payment plan at checkout, and manage upcoming payments and autopay. Merchants integrate APIs to create financing offers, confirm captures, issue refunds, and reconcile settlements. Core entities include consumers, merchants, applications, decision outcomes (approved/declined with reason codes), loans, payment schedules, installments, payments, late fees, refunds, disputes, chargebacks, settlements, and reporting exports. Workflows include: merchant creates checkout session → consumer applies → offer presented (APR/term) → loan originated → merchant capture/ship confirmation → scheduled payments post over time → delinquencies/collections statuses (simulated). Admin functionality includes risk rules, credit limits, merchant rate tables, and customer support adjustments (deferrals, plan changes, goodwill credits). All data—amounts, APR, dates, statuses—can be realistically synthesized to drive complex CRUD and state-machine testing.

name: Outschool
description: Outschool is a live online learning marketplace where educators publish classes and learners enroll, providing structured entities ideal for API simulation. Teachers create class listings with title, age range, schedule times, price, capacity, and session count; manage rosters and cancellations; and issue refunds per policy. Parents/students manage profiles, enrollments, saved classes, payment methods, and attendance. Entities include teachers, students, guardians, classes, class sessions (dated events), enrollments, waitlists, coupons, payments, payouts, messaging threads, attendance records, and reviews/ratings. Workflows: teacher drafts class → publishes → students enroll or join waitlist → automatic reminders → session attendance updates → class completion → review window → payout release. Support/admin workflows can handle reschedules, partial refunds, teacher verification, and policy enforcement flags. The content itself can remain short (titles/descriptions), while the meaningful interactions occur around schedules, capacity management, refunds, and marketplace payouts—highly database-driven and fully synthesizable.

name: Coursera
description: Coursera is an online course and credential platform emphasizing enrollment, progress tracking, assessments, and certificates. Learners browse a course catalog (structured metadata), enroll in courses or specializations, pay for subscriptions, and complete graded items with deadlines. Entities include users, organizations (for enterprise learning), courses, modules, lessons, assignments (quiz IDs, attempt limits), submissions (scores/status), discussion posts (short), deadlines, enrollment records, subscriptions, invoices, certificates, and learning paths. CRUD operations include creating/updating learner profiles, enrolling/unenrolling, starting attempts, submitting assignments, resetting deadlines, and downloading certificates. Instructor/admin APIs can manage course runs (cohorts), update schedules, publish/unpublish content units (metadata), and view analytics (completion rates, average scores, churn). Workflows support free trials → subscription active → progress events logged → graded completion checks → certificate issuance. All assessment items and results can be synthetic numeric data while preserving realistic platform behavior, making this scenario strong for simulating stateful learning systems.

name: Wyzant
description: Wyzant is a tutoring marketplace connecting students with tutors, centered on profiles, availability, booking, and billing workflows. Tutors create profiles with subjects, hourly rates, service areas/online modality, availability calendars, and policies; they manage lesson requests, confirm sessions, and submit invoices. Students manage profiles, search with filters (subject, price, rating, availability), message tutors, request lessons, and pay for completed sessions. Key entities include tutors, students, subjects taxonomy, availability slots, lesson requests, bookings, session logs (start/end time), invoices, payments, refunds, promo credits, reviews, and dispute cases (no-show, charge disagreements). Workflows: student inquiry → tutor responds → booking scheduled → session occurs (attendance status) → tutor invoices → payment captured → review enabled. Platform operations can include background-check status flags, messaging moderation tags, and tutor performance metrics (response time, completion rate). All necessary data—schedules, rates, statuses, invoices—can be synthesized for robust CRUD and transactional testing.

name: Canvas (LMS)
description: Canvas is a learning management system used by schools and universities to run courses and track student progress. In a simulated environment, admins and instructors can create terms, courses, sections, and enrollments (students, TAs, teachers) with roles and permissions. Instructors manage modules, assignments, quizzes (question banks, time limits, attempts), rubrics, gradebook columns, and due-date overrides by section. Students submit assignments (file/URL metadata), take quizzes, view feedback, and manage to-do lists. Core workflows include course provisioning (create course -> add section -> enroll users), content release (draft -> publish -> schedule availability windows), assessment lifecycle (create assignment -> accept submissions -> grade -> post grades -> handle regrades), and academic integrity flags (status, notes). Discussion boards and announcements are CRUD-managed as short posts with moderation states. Support entities include calendar events, late policies, accommodations, outcomes/standards mapping, and API-driven SIS imports/exports (user/course/roster sync jobs with run logs). Reporting endpoints can return synthesized analytics such as submission counts, grade distributions, and activity timestamps without requiring content-heavy artifacts.

name: Teachable (Creator Course Platform)
description: Teachable is a platform for creators to sell and deliver online courses and digital products. A realistic simulation can model schools (tenants), course catalogs, lectures (metadata), pricing plans, coupons, checkout sessions, enrollments, and progress tracking. Creators CRUD-manage courses, sections, drip schedules, bundles, and upsells; set pricing (one-time, payment plan, subscription), taxes, and payout settings; and configure custom domains and email templates (metadata). Students create accounts, purchase courses, access lectures, complete quizzes, and download resources (file metadata). Transactions can be synthesized with invoices, refunds, chargeback statuses, and payout batches to creators. Workflows include funnel setup (landing page -> checkout -> enrollment), discount campaigns (create coupon -> set rules -> track redemptions), cohort launches (open enrollment window -> enforce seat limits -> close sales), and customer support actions (grant comped access, extend access expiration, switch plans). Admin reporting can return revenue by course, churn, conversion rates, and affiliate tracking via affiliate profiles, links, commissions, and payout approvals.

name: Moodle Workplace (Enterprise Training LMS)
description: Moodle Workplace is an enterprise-focused LMS for internal training, compliance, and multi-department learning. A simulation can model organizations, departments, positions, managers, and users; then assign learning programs composed of courses, certifications, and recurring compliance. Admins CRUD-manage programs, enrollment rules (by department/role), completion criteria, re-certification intervals, and learning paths. Courses can include activities like quizzes, SCORM package metadata, attendance sessions, and acknowledgements. Workflows include onboarding (create user -> assign department -> auto-enroll in program), compliance tracking (due dates -> reminders -> overdue escalations), and manager approvals for elective enrollments. Assessment workflows include attempts, grading states, feedback, and retake rules. Reporting endpoints can generate synthesized audit-friendly records: completion timestamps, scores, credit hours, exemptions, and attestations. Additional entities include learning plans, cohorts, event logs, notification templates, and integration jobs to HRIS systems (import users, update job roles). This scenario is highly suitable for CRUD-heavy API testing because it involves structured rules, time-based schedules, and many relational entities without relying on content-heavy materials.

name: Wise (International Money Transfer Wallet)
description: Wise is a multi-currency wallet and money transfer platform. A simulated environment can include customers (personal/business), profiles, KYC verification checks (status, documents metadata), balances by currency, bank accounts, cards, beneficiaries, exchange rates (synthetic), and transfers. Users CRUD-manage recipients, saved payout methods (IBAN, SWIFT, local rails), and transfer templates. Workflows cover quote creation (source/target currency, fees, delivery estimate), funding (bank transfer/card), compliance screening (pending -> cleared/blocked), and transfer execution (created -> processing -> completed/failed) with tracking events. Businesses can manage batch payouts, approvals, role-based access, and reconciliation reports. Disputes and refunds can be modeled as cases linked to transfers with outcomes and ledger adjustments. Ledger-style entities include transactions, balance holds, charge items, and payout batches. Admin features can simulate limits, risk flags, and manual review queues. The platform supports meaningful API interactions across CRUD, state machines, idempotent payment requests, and audit logs while keeping all monetary amounts, timestamps, and identities synthesizable.

name: Zapier (Workflow Automation Platform)
description: Zapier is a no-code automation platform that connects apps via triggers and actions. A simulation can model users, connected app accounts, credentials metadata, app definitions, triggers, actions, zaps (workflows), steps, filters, formatters, and run histories. Users CRUD-manage zaps: choose a trigger (e.g., “new row”), map fields into actions (e.g., “create record”), set schedules, and configure error handling (retries, fallback paths). Each run produces execution records with input/output payloads (synthetic JSON), timestamps, step statuses, and error codes. Workflows include testing a zap, publishing/unpublishing, cloning, versioning, and rolling back to previous revisions. Team features can include shared folders, role-based permissions, and approval gates for publishing automations. Rate limits, task usage counters, and billing plans can be represented for realistic constraints. Admin endpoints can provide audit logs, run analytics (success rate, average duration), and replay capabilities. This platform is highly suitable because it’s fundamentally database-driven orchestration with synthesizable entities and deterministic execution traces.

name: Revolut (Digital Banking + Cards)
description: Revolut is a mobile-first digital banking platform for managing multi-currency money, cards, and everyday spending. Users can create profiles, pass verification status (simulated), open sub-accounts/wallets per currency, and manage balances. Core entities include customers, accounts, cards (virtual/physical metadata), merchants, transactions, FX exchanges, beneficiaries, transfers, recurring payments, budgets, vaults/savings goals, and notifications. Workflows include onboarding → account creation → add funding source (bank account/card token) → top up → convert currency → send transfer to beneficiary → track status (pending/complete/failed) → generate statements. Card controls are highly CRUD-friendly: freeze/unfreeze, set limits, toggle online/magstripe/ATM settings, and create disposable virtual cards. Additional flows include chargeback/dispute creation, document uploads (metadata), and alerts for spend thresholds. Admin and compliance views can manage risk flags, KYC review queues, and account restrictions with audit logs. All data can be synthesized (amounts, exchange rates, timestamps, merchant categories) while preserving realistic ledger behavior and idempotent payment APIs.

name: Coinbase Exchange (Spot Trading + Custody)
description: Coinbase Exchange is a cryptocurrency trading and custody platform supporting deposits, withdrawals, orders, and portfolios. Synthesizable entities include users, wallets by asset, addresses (metadata), deposit/withdrawal requests, transfer approvals, markets (trading pairs), order books (simplified), orders (limit/market/stop), fills, fees, holds, balances, and compliance flags. Workflows: user onboarding → create wallets → generate deposit address → record deposit confirmations (simulated) → place order → match and create fills → update balances and trade history → withdraw to external address with review steps. Users can manage price alerts, API keys/permissions, whitelisted addresses, and withdrawal limits. For businesses, custody sub-accounts and internal transfers can be modeled: create sub-account → move funds between sub-accounts → generate audit logs and approvals. Admin operations include freezing accounts, marking deposits as reversed, investigating suspicious activity, and exporting transaction records for tax reporting (metadata). Even without real market data, realistic trading can be simulated with synthetic price feeds, deterministic matching rules, and immutable fill records.

name: Aave (DeFi Lending/Borrowing Dashboard)
description: Aave-style DeFi dashboard enables users to supply assets, borrow against collateral, and manage positions with transparent health metrics. Entities are fully synthesizable: users, wallets, supported assets, reserve parameters (LTV, liquidation threshold, interest model), supply positions, borrow positions, collateral toggles, interest accrual snapshots, liquidation events, and governance proposals (metadata). Workflows: connect wallet (session metadata) → deposit asset into a reserve → receive a position record → enable collateral → borrow another asset within limits → accrue interest per block/time interval (simulated) → repay partially or fully → withdraw collateral subject to health factor constraints. The platform can include automation rules: set a target health factor, schedule auto-repay from a stablecoin balance, or alert thresholds. Liquidation is a clean state machine for simulation: if health factor drops below threshold (via synthetic price changes), create liquidation event(s), update collateral/borrow balances, and record fees. Users can manage transaction history, export CSV reports, and configure notification channels. This scenario is highly API-friendly because every action is a deterministic update to positions and event logs.

name: Monday.com (Boards + Workflow Automation)
description: Monday.com is a board-based collaboration platform where teams model processes as tables with columns and automations. Entities include accounts, workspaces, boards, groups, items (rows), subitems, columns (text, status, date, number, people, dropdown), updates/comments, files (metadata), views (kanban/timeline/calendar), automations, integrations (metadata), and permissions. Workflows: create a board for a process (e.g., sales pipeline or onboarding) → define columns → add items → assign owners → update statuses → trigger automations like “when status changes to Done, set completion date” or “when date arrives, notify assignee.” The platform supports cross-board linking: connect items, mirror fields, and roll up metrics. Teams can create forms that submit directly into a board (stored submissions), then triage items via status and priority. API simulation is straightforward: CRUD on items and column values, batch updates, pagination, webhooks for change events, and audit logs. You can also model approval flows using status + person columns, and generate predictable analytics (cycle times, throughput) from timestamps captured during state transitions.

name: OpenTable for Garages (Service Scheduling + Bay Management)
description: A service-scheduling platform for auto repair shops that combines consumer booking with shop-floor capacity planning. Entities include shops, service bays, technicians, service catalogs (oil change, brakes), labor time estimates, parts requirements, customer vehicles, appointments, work orders, inspection checklists, and customer approvals. Customer workflows: create a profile, add vehicles, view available time slots, book services, upload symptoms/photos (metadata), and approve/decline recommended work with price breakdowns. Shop workflows: configure business hours, bay capacity, technician skills, service durations, and blackout dates; create/update appointments; convert appointments into work orders; assign technicians; track statuses (checked-in → diagnosing → awaiting approval → in progress → ready). The system supports reminders, rescheduling, and waitlists. All data can be synthesized (slots, labor hours, quotes, status transitions). APIs can simulate scheduling constraints, conflict detection, multi-vehicle households, and event streams for appointment lifecycle changes and customer authorization.

name: PartsTech-like B2B Auto Parts Ordering Network
description: A B2B parts procurement and inventory platform connecting repair shops with multiple distributors. Key entities: suppliers, catalogs/parts (SKU, fitment attributes, interchange numbers), pricing tiers, shop locations, on-hand inventory, purchase orders, quotes, backorders, shipments, returns (RMA), and invoices. Shop workflows: search parts by vehicle (year/make/model/engine), compare supplier availability and delivery windows, build carts, submit POs, track fulfillment, and process returns/credits. Supplier workflows: manage catalog items, publish price updates, confirm allocations, update shipment tracking, and handle substitutions. Inventory workflows include receiving shipments (increase stock), cycle counts, reorder points, and transfer between shop locations. This scenario is ideal for API simulation: realistic catalogs and pricing can be synthesized, fitment matrices are structured, and lifecycle states (quoted → ordered → picked → shipped → delivered) are deterministic. Useful endpoints include bulk price updates, PO line-item status updates, webhook notifications, and reconciliation reports for invoices vs received quantities.

name: CDK-style Dealer Service Lane (RO + Warranty Claims)
description: A dealer service-lane management system focused on repair orders (ROs), technician dispatch, and warranty/recall workflows. Entities include customers, vehicles, service history, appointment requests, repair orders, labor operations, parts lines, technician assignments, warranty policies, recalls/campaigns (static data tables), approvals, and invoices. Front-desk workflows: check in a vehicle, capture concerns, create an RO with recommended packages, estimate labor/parts, and obtain customer authorization (signature metadata). Dispatch workflows: assign operations to technicians based on skill and workload, track time punches, and update RO status (diagnosis, waiting parts, complete). Warranty workflows: validate eligibility, attach required codes, submit claims, and manage claim statuses (submitted → pending → approved/denied) with supporting document checklists. The data is structured and synthesizable: operation codes, labor times, prices, and claim states. APIs can cover RO CRUD, line-item adjustments, approval events, and integrations to parts inventory and customer notification systems.

name: Kaiser Permanente-style Patient Portal (Appointments + Results Metadata)
description: A patient portal for managing healthcare interactions and records without requiring real clinical content. Entities include patients, dependents, providers, clinics, appointment slots, visits, encounter summaries (structured fields), lab orders/results metadata (test name, date, status, reference ranges), medications, refill requests, immunizations, allergies, insurance plans, billing statements, and messages. Patient workflows: register, verify identity (simulated), choose a PCP, schedule/cancel appointments, request refills, view upcoming visits, pay bills, and download visit summaries. Provider workflows: manage schedules, approve refill requests, send message replies, and update encounter statuses (scheduled → checked-in → completed). The portal can also manage referrals and prior authorization requests with step-based statuses. Data is highly synthesizable because most items are structured codes, timestamps, and status fields. API simulations can include role-based access (patient vs proxy), consent records, notification preferences, and audit trails for record access.

name: Teladoc-style Telehealth Clinic (Virtual Visit Operations)
description: A telehealth platform centered on intake, scheduling, and visit management, focusing on operational data rather than real video or AI. Entities include patients, providers, state licenses, appointment slots, intake forms (symptoms checklists), triage queues, encounters, prescriptions (medication, dosage, quantity), pharmacy destinations, visit notes metadata (templates/sections), and billing claims. Patient workflow: create account, complete intake questionnaire, upload insurance, choose visit type (urgent care, dermatology async), schedule or join a queue, and receive a care plan summary. Provider workflow: view queue, accept an encounter, request more info, issue an e-prescription, and close the encounter with a disposition code. Admin workflow: manage provider availability, pricing, cancellation rules, and compliance flags. Status transitions are explicit (intake submitted → queued → provider assigned → completed). This is ideal for API simulation with CRUD on encounters, forms, prescriptions, and billing events; webhooks for queue/assignment changes; and realistic synthetic timestamps, states, and medications lists.

name: CVS-style Pharmacy (Refills + Inventory + Pickup Scheduling)
description: A pharmacy platform that supports patient refills and store-level fulfillment operations. Entities include patients, prescribers, prescriptions (Rx number, refills remaining, directions), refill requests, prior authorizations (status), drug catalog (NDC-like codes), store inventory, lot/expiration records, fulfillment tasks, pickup/delivery orders, payments, and notifications. Patient workflows: link prescriptions, request refills, choose pickup time windows, switch pharmacies, set reminders, and manage family members. Store workflows: intake refill requests, verify eligibility, perform adjudication status (simulated), allocate inventory, fill/label tasks, mark ready for pickup, handle partial fills/backorders, and process returns to stock. Controlled substances can be represented by extra flags and stricter status gates. All data is structured and synthesizable: drug codes, quantities, insurance response codes, and timestamps. APIs can simulate inventory decrements, task queues, exception handling (out of stock, PA required), and event-driven updates to the patient portal.

name: Toast-style Restaurant POS + Online Ordering Admin
description: A restaurant platform combining menu management, online ordering, and POS operations. Entities include restaurant locations, menus, categories, items, modifier groups (sizes, add-ons), taxes/fees, service hours, tables, tickets, orders, payments, discounts, customers, delivery zones, and staff roles. Admin workflows: create/update menu items, set availability (86 items), configure combos, schedule daypart menus, and publish changes across locations. Order workflows: customers place pickup/delivery orders, apply promos, pay, and track order status (received → preparing → ready → completed). Kitchen workflows: KDS-style ticket routing by station (grill, salad), bump/re-fire items, and track prep times. Manager workflows: void/refund payments, reopen checks, manage tips, and run sales reports (aggregated numbers). This scenario is highly synthesizeable: item data, orders, payments, and status changes are deterministic. API simulation can cover menu versioning, multi-location inheritance, concurrency (two devices editing menus), and webhooks for order events and payment settlement.

name: Back-of-House Kitchen Ops (Inventory + Prep + Waste Tracking)
description: A kitchen operations system focused on ingredients, prep production, and waste—designed for restaurants and commissaries. Entities include ingredient items, vendors, purchase orders, receiving logs, recipes (bill of materials), prep batches, par levels, storage locations, temperature logs (numbers), waste events, and production schedules. Workflows: create ingredients and units, define recipes with yields, generate prep plans based on forecasted sales (input numbers), issue batch tasks to staff, decrement inventory through usage, record waste/spoilage with reason codes, and perform weekly counts with variance reporting. Receiving workflows: create POs, record deliveries, manage substitutions, and track lot/expiration where relevant. Managers can set reorder points and view cost-of-goods snapshots. Everything can be synthesized: quantities, costs, timestamps, and structured reason codes. APIs can simulate inventory movements, idempotent receiving events, permissions (prep cook vs manager), and reconciliation reports that tie purchases to usage and waste.

name: DoorDash for Catering (Corporate Lunch Ordering + Dispatch)
description: A catering ordering and dispatch platform that handles large, scheduled food orders for offices and events. Entities include corporate accounts, users, budgets/allowances, vendors/restaurants, catering menus, quotes, orders, delivery windows, drivers/couriers, pickup tasks, routing stops, proof-of-delivery metadata, invoices, and satisfaction ratings. Customer workflows: request a quote, select menu packages, set headcount and dietary flags, schedule delivery, add delivery instructions, and approve final totals. Vendor workflows: accept/decline orders, propose substitutions, manage prep schedules, and mark orders ready. Dispatch workflows: assign drivers, generate pickup/dropoff tasks, update statuses (confirmed → in prep → picked up → delivered), and handle exceptions (late, missing items) with resolution codes and credits. Corporate admin workflows: manage allowed vendors, spending limits, approval rules, and monthly invoicing. Data is fully synthesizable: menus, headcounts, delivery windows, routes (coordinates), and status events. APIs can model SLA timers, webhooks for status changes, and multi-party messaging threads (short text).

name: Teladoc (Virtual Care Platform)
