description: A Teladoc-like telehealth platform centers on appointment booking, eligibility, and visit lifecycle management. Synthesizable entities include patient accounts, dependents, providers, specialties, licenses/regions, availability blocks, visit requests, triage questionnaires (structured answers), appointments, virtual room sessions (metadata), chat messages, attachments metadata (photos/docs), prescriptions (drug, dose, quantity), care plans (structured tasks), clinical notes metadata, invoices, insurance eligibility checks (status + coverage fields), and post-visit surveys. Patients CRUD their profiles, medical history fields, preferred pharmacy, and payment methods; they search providers by specialty/region and book time slots; upload images; and receive prescriptions and follow-up tasks. Providers manage calendars, accept/decline visit requests, document vitals and assessments as structured fields, issue e-prescriptions, and close visits with disposition codes. Operations include rescheduling, cancellation with policy enforcement, refunds, and dispute handling. Key workflows: patient intake → eligibility verification → provider matching → visit start/complete → prescription sent → billing captured → follow-up scheduled. This is highly API-simulatable via states (requested/confirmed/in-session/completed) and structured clinical data placeholders.

name: Capsule (Modern Delivery Pharmacy)
description: A Capsule-style delivery pharmacy platform emphasizes logistics coordination and patient experience around medication delivery. Core entities: patient profiles, delivery addresses, delivery zones, prescriptions, refill requests, insurance benefits (deductible/copay), payment authorizations, delivery orders, delivery time windows, courier routes/stops, shipment status events, temperature-sensitive handling flags, ID verification steps, support tickets (non-Intercom style), and satisfaction ratings. Patients CRUD delivery preferences (doorman notes, contactless rules), address book entries, insurance details, and preferred communication channels; they approve copay amounts, choose delivery windows, and track orders. Pharmacists and operations teams manage intake queues, insurance verification tasks, substitutions, fill status, and release-to-courier events. Couriers update stop statuses (en route/arrived/delivered/failed) with timestamps and proof-of-delivery metadata. Workflows: transfer Rx → benefits check → patient copay approval → schedule delivery → route optimization (simulated) → delivery completion → post-delivery follow-up. This scenario is API-friendly because it uses structured statuses, numeric pricing, and event streams rather than content-heavy medical notes.

name: DoorDash Drive (Restaurant Delivery Dispatch)
description: A DoorDash Drive-style dispatch platform lets merchants outsource delivery while controlling order intake and customer experience. Synthesizable entities include merchant stores, delivery zones, quoted delivery fees, orders, pickup readiness times, driver assignments (courier IDs), delivery tasks, route legs, status updates, cancellation reasons, tips, proof-of-delivery metadata, customer support cases (structured), and reconciliation payouts. Merchants CRUD store settings, pickup instructions, hours, and throttling limits; create delivery orders via API (recipient, address, items summary, value, requested window); and monitor fulfillment statuses (created/driver-assigned/picked-up/delivered/failed). Drivers update pickup/dropoff events with timestamps and geolocation pings. Finance workflows include delivery fee invoicing, refunds for failures, and weekly payout reports. Operational workflows: order created → quote accepted → courier dispatched → pickup scan → live tracking updates → delivered with POD → exception handling (wrong address, no answer). This is strongly database-driven, with realistic synthetic items/prices, addresses, and event timelines.

name: Olo (Enterprise Restaurant Ordering API)
description: An Olo-style enterprise ordering platform exposes APIs for brands with many locations and complex menus. Entities include brands, locations, menus, items, modifier groups, fulfillment methods (pickup, curbside, delivery), service windows, pricing overrides per store, taxes/fees, promotions, customers, orders, payment authorizations, loyalty identifiers, and integration events to POS systems (acknowledged/failed/retried). Operators CRUD menu catalogs, publish schedules, item availability, and store hours; configure promotion rules and throttling; and manage integration credentials and webhooks. Consumers place orders through brand apps/websites powered by the API, selecting modifiers, scheduling pickup times, applying rewards, and receiving order status callbacks. Workflows include catalog sync → order creation → POS injection → kitchen acceptance → ready notification → pickup verification → post-order refund/adjustment if needed. This is highly suitable for synthesis because menus, prices, and order flows are structured, and integration states can be emulated without real POS hardware.

name: Home Assistant Cloud (Smart Home Device & Automation Hub)
description: A Home Assistant Cloud-like platform manages smart-home devices, sensor telemetry, and automations. Entities include households, users, rooms, devices, integrations/connectors, entities (lights, locks, thermostats), sensor readings (numeric + timestamps), scenes, automations, triggers/conditions/actions, schedules, notification channels, firmware versions, and audit logs. Users CRUD devices (pair/unpair), assign rooms, set friendly names, create automations (e.g., if motion detected then turn on lights), manage scenes, and configure access (guest users). Device operations include command dispatch (on/off/set temperature/lock/unlock) and state reporting (online/offline/battery). Workflows: onboard hub → discover devices → map entities → create automation → run history charts → troubleshoot offline device → firmware update rollout (simulated) with status tracking. APIs can synthesize realistic telemetry streams, geofences, and event logs, enabling database-driven simulations of smart home behavior without requiring actual hardware.

name: Mosquitto/EMQX-Backed IoT Device Management Console
description: An IoT device management console built around MQTT (like EMQX dashboards plus device registry) supports fleets of sensors/actuators with provisioning and telemetry. Entities include tenants, device registries, device identities/certificates, product types, firmware artifacts (metadata), configuration profiles, topics, message payload schemas, telemetry readings, command jobs, job executions, alerts, rules, and webhooks. Operators CRUD devices, assign them to products, rotate credentials, apply configuration templates, and schedule OTA updates. They also define rules (if temperature > threshold then alert) and manage alert acknowledgements and incident states. Devices publish synthetic telemetry (temperature, humidity, GPS, voltage) and receive commands (reboot, set sampling rate). Workflows: provision device → activate → start publishing → alert triggers → operator acknowledges → command job dispatched → device reports success/failure → firmware update staged and rolled back if error rate exceeds threshold. This scenario is ideal for API simulation because all core artifacts are structured, timestamped, and stateful.

name: BlueCart (Restaurant Supply Ordering Marketplace)
description: A BlueCart-like B2B ordering platform connects restaurants with local distributors for recurring supply purchases. Entities include buyers (restaurants), supplier accounts, catalogs, products (pack sizes, UOM, allergens/attributes), price lists, contract terms, minimums, delivery schedules, and warehouse locations. Buyers create carts, purchase orders, standing orders, and approval workflows (request → manager approval → submit). Orders have line items, substitutions, backorders, invoices, credit notes, and payment terms (net-7/net-30). Suppliers manage inventory snapshots, lead times, delivery routes, and fulfillment statuses (confirmed/picked/shipped/delivered). The platform supports receiving workflows: buyers record deliveries, discrepancies (short/over/damaged), attach photos metadata, and create claims/returns with reason codes. Admins manage user roles, budget limits, and vendor onboarding. Reporting is database-driven: spend by category, price variance over time, fill rate, and top SKUs. API simulation is strong: CRUD on catalogs, orders, invoices, and disputes; webhook events for “po.submitted,” “invoice.issued,” “delivery.completed,” and “claim.opened.” Product content is structured and synthesizable, avoiding long-form content dependencies.

name: 7shifts (Restaurant Scheduling + Task Checklists)
description: A 7shifts-style workforce platform helps restaurants schedule staff, manage availability, and run shift-based task execution. Entities include locations, departments (FOH/BOH), roles, employees, availability blocks, time-off requests, shift templates, published schedules, and time clock punches. Tasking entities include checklists, tasks, due times, recurrence rules, assignments, completion logs, photo/temperature-check metadata, and manager sign-offs. Workflows cover creating schedules from templates, detecting conflicts (overtime, minor labor rules, double-booking), offering open shifts for pickup, shift swaps with approvals, and last-minute callouts. Daily operations include pre-shift sidework lists, end-of-day closing procedures, and weekly deep-clean tasks with audit trails. Messaging can be modeled as threads, announcements, and read receipts. The platform can also track labor targets with synthetic sales inputs and forecasted staffing needs (stored numbers, not ML). APIs suit CRUD: employees, shifts, time-off, tasks, and completion events. Managers generate reports (hours by role, lateness counts, task compliance rates) and maintain permissions/locations. All data is structured, timestamped, and easy to synthesize for realistic simulations.

name: IFTTT (Consumer Workflow Automation for Apps + Devices)
description: An IFTTT-like automation platform connects apps and smart devices via user-defined rules (“applets”). Entities include users, connected services (channels), OAuth connections (synthetic tokens), triggers, actions, applets, filter conditions, schedules, locations (geofences), device endpoints, and execution logs. Users browse a catalog of triggers/actions (structured metadata), create applets, set parameters (e.g., thermostat setpoint, light color, webhook URL), and define conditions (time window, days of week, device state). Runs generate events with timestamps, input payloads, action outcomes, retries, and error codes. The platform supports enabling/disabling applets, cloning templates, rate limits, and notification settings. Service providers manage app schemas, field types, validation rules, and versioning (deprecate a trigger, migrate applets). A developer console can simulate webhook triggers (incoming JSON) and outgoing webhooks to external endpoints, plus test harnesses for action execution results. All data is synthesizable: device states, event payloads, schedules, and logs. CRUD is extensive across applets, connections, and execution history, making it ideal for integration testing and database-driven simulations.

name: Ubiquiti UniFi Network (SMB Network + Device Management)
description: A UniFi-like controller manages networks and hardware devices across one or many sites. Entities include organizations, sites, networks/VLANs, SSIDs, firewall rules, user groups, captive portal profiles, devices (APs, switches, gateways), firmware versions, clients (devices on the network), DPI categories, and alerts. Operational data includes device adoption status, configuration profiles, port settings (PoE on/off, speed), DHCP leases, and client connection sessions with timestamps. Workflows cover onboarding a new site, adopting devices, pushing configuration changes, scheduling firmware updates, and responding to alerts (high latency, device offline, rogue AP detected). Admins manage roles, API keys, and audit logs. Troubleshooting actions include restarting a device, blocking/unblocking a client, moving a client to a VLAN, and exporting support bundles (metadata). Reporting dashboards summarize uptime, throughput (synthetic), and client counts. APIs can expose CRUD for sites, networks, SSIDs, and devices, plus event streams for device state changes and client connect/disconnect events. This is highly suitable for synthesized simulations because metrics and inventories are structured and can be generated deterministically.

name: Philips Hue (Smart Lighting + Scenes + Rooms)
description: A Hue-like smart lighting platform manages bulbs, rooms, zones, and scenes for home automation. Entities include households, bridges/hubs, lights, groups (rooms/zones), scenes, schedules, sensors (motion/ambient light), switches, and firmware. Each device has capabilities (dimmable, color, color temperature), current state (on/off, brightness, hue/sat/ct), health (reachable, battery), and last-seen timestamps. Users create rooms, assign devices, build scenes (saved states), and set automations: time-based schedules, sunrise/sunset rules, motion-triggered actions, and presence simulations. Workflows include onboarding devices (pairing), renaming/reorganizing, sharing access with household members, and creating “away mode” schedules. The system tracks command history, failures (device unreachable), and retries. APIs support CRUD for devices, groups, scenes, schedules, and sensor rules, plus real-time-ish event endpoints for state changes (simulated). Because device telemetry and states are numeric/enum-heavy, it’s straightforward to synthesize realistic sequences like evening routines, sensor triggers, and intermittent connectivity while keeping interactions fully database-driven.

name: Kitchen Display System (KDS) for Multi-Station Kitchens
description: A KDS-style platform coordinates kitchen operations by turning orders into station-specific tickets and timing performance. Entities include restaurants, prep stations (grill/fry/salad/bar), screens/devices, menus, routing rules (item → station), tickets, ticket items, modifiers, coursing (appetizer/entrée/dessert), and timers. Orders enter from POS/online channels and are split into station queues with priority logic (rush orders, promised pickup time). Cooks perform actions: accept, start, bump/complete, recall, and mark items as delayed or out-of-stock (86). Expo users can coordinate “all day” counts, fire courses, and hold items until others are ready. The system logs every event with timestamps (created/printed/started/bumped) to compute prep times and SLA breaches. Managers configure screen layouts, sound/alert rules, and staffing modes (merge stations during slow periods). Additional entities include waste logs, remake reasons, and quality checks. APIs naturally support CRUD for routing config, station devices, tickets, and event logs, plus webhook notifications to POS/customer messaging when orders move to “ready for pickup.” All data is structured and highly synthesizable.

name: Smart Energy Device Manager (Solar + Battery + EV Charger Fleet)
description: A portal for managing residential and small-commercial energy devices: solar inverters, home batteries, smart meters, and EV chargers. Organizations manage sites, electrical assets, tariffs, and users. Entities include devices, firmware, connectivity status, meters, measurement streams (kWh, voltage, current), charge sessions, schedules, demand-response events, and maintenance tickets. Workflows cover provisioning devices to a site, configuring rate plans, setting charge rules (time-of-use windows, max power, reserve SOC), and monitoring performance with alerts for anomalies (over-temperature, grid outage, low production). APIs support CRUD for sites/devices, starting/stopping charger sessions, setting inverter modes, creating schedules, and posting periodic telemetry batches. The database model is strong: assets link to locations, sessions link to vehicles/drivers, and readings link to devices with timestamps. A billing module can synthesize invoices based on energy usage and tariff tables, including line items, taxes, and payment status. Operators can export reports and manage SLA policies for different customer tiers. This scenario yields realistic state machines (charging -> paused -> completed), reconciliations (meter vs session totals), and audit logs for configuration changes.

name: Industrial IoT Sensor Fleet Console (Factories & Warehouses)
description: A multi-tenant console to manage industrial sensors and gateways deployed across facilities. Companies create plants, zones, and asset hierarchies (lines, machines). Devices include gateways and sensors (vibration, temperature, pressure, humidity), each with calibration profiles, sampling rates, and connectivity metadata. Core entities: device inventory, sensor channels, telemetry streams, thresholds, alerts/incidents, maintenance work orders, parts inventory, and technician assignments. Workflows include onboarding (register device -> assign to asset -> configure sampling -> start ingestion), incident handling (alert -> triage -> create work order -> close with resolution codes), and scheduled calibration cycles with due dates. APIs provide CRUD for assets/devices, bulk configuration pushes, ingestion endpoints for timestamped readings, and query endpoints for aggregated metrics (min/max/avg) by time window. Everything is synthesizable: readings, anomaly flags, downtime durations, and maintenance logs. The system can track firmware rollouts and device certificates/keys (as metadata), with rotation schedules and revocation status. Role-based access separates operators, maintenance, and administrators. This creates a realistic database-driven environment with time-series plus transactional workflows.

name: No-Code Workflow Automation Builder (Zapier-like)
description: A no-code automation platform where users connect apps and build multi-step workflows. Entities include accounts, connected apps, credentials (token metadata), triggers, actions, workflows, steps, mappings, filters, schedules, run histories, retries, and error logs. Users create a workflow by selecting a trigger (e.g., “new form submission”), mapping fields into actions (e.g., “create task”, “send email”), adding conditional branches, and enabling the automation. CRUD operations cover creating/editing workflows, versioning drafts, enabling/disabling, and managing reusable components like field mappings and templates. Execution is recorded as runs with step-by-step statuses (queued/running/succeeded/failed), timestamps, input/output payload metadata, and retry policies. A testing mode can create synthetic trigger events and store them as sample data. The platform supports rate limits and quotas as configurable entities, plus team collaboration with shared folders, role-based permissions, and audit trails. Everything can be synthesized: event payloads, delays, errors, and throughput metrics. This scenario provides rich API simulation opportunities including pagination, webhooks, idempotency keys, and asynchronous job handling without depending on external search or AI.

name: Miro-style Collaborative Whiteboard (Structured Collaboration)
description: A collaboration platform focused on shared boards with structured objects rather than content-heavy documents. Teams manage organizations, workspaces, boards, board members, permissions, and templates. On each board, entities include frames, sticky notes (short text), shapes, connectors, comments, tags, and version snapshots. Workflows: create a board from a template, invite collaborators, add objects, group items, lock/unlock sections, and run facilitation sessions with timers and voting. CRUD operations involve creating/updating objects with coordinates, sizes, colors, z-index, and parent-child relationships; moving items between frames; and maintaining an activity log of edits. A voting feature is highly synthesizable: vote sessions with participants, vote counts per item, and outcomes. Boards can have export jobs (PDF/image) represented as job metadata rather than media content. APIs can simulate real-time collaboration via append-only events or change sets, plus conflict-free updates using revision numbers. Access control supports public links, guest editors, and team roles. The data model is spatial and relational, making it excellent for database-driven interactions and realistic multi-user workflows without requiring long-form content.

name: Veterinary Clinic Practice Portal (Appointments + Medical Records)
description: A veterinary clinic system for managing clients, patients, appointments, and clinical workflows. Entities include clinics, staff, pet owners, pets, vaccinations, allergies, conditions, medications, lab orders (structured results), visit notes (short fields), treatment plans, invoices, payments, and reminders. Workflows cover intake (create client + pet -> capture history), scheduling (appointment slots, providers, room assignment), check-in, exam documentation, prescribing medications, generating an invoice, and closing the visit with follow-up reminders. CRUD operations include updating pet profiles, recording vaccine administrations with lot numbers and expiration dates, creating lab orders and posting results, and managing medication refills with approval status. Inventory for clinic supplies (vaccines, meds) can be tracked with quantities, reorder thresholds, and suppliers. The system also supports consent forms as form metadata, and communications as templated messages (appointment reminders, refill ready) with delivery status. All data is synthesizable and structured, enabling realistic API simulations for permissions (front desk vs clinician), audit trails, and billing reconciliation without requiring long narrative content.

name: Pet Supplies Subscription Store (Consumables + Auto-Ship)
description: An e-commerce platform specialized in recurring pet essentials (food, litter, supplements) with subscription and inventory logic. Entities include customers, pets (to personalize sizing), products, variants, pricing tiers, warehouses, inventory levels, carts, orders, shipments, returns, and subscriptions (frequency, next ship date, pause/resume, swap item). Workflows: customer browses products, adds to cart, chooses one-time vs subscription, checks out, tracks shipment, and manages subscription changes (skip next, change address, adjust quantity). Admins manage product catalogs, bundle offers, coupons, tax/shipping rules, and replenishment settings. The subscription engine creates scheduled orders, attempts payment, and transitions states (scheduled -> processing -> shipped -> delivered; subscription active -> paused -> cancelled). APIs support CRUD for products/variants, inventory adjustments, subscription updates, and order fulfillment events. A loyalty module can track points, tiers, redemptions, and referral codes—all synthesizable. Customer support can create return authorizations and refunds. This scenario is database-driven with strong transactional requirements and recurring billing logic, while avoiding content-heavy needs beyond short descriptions and structured attributes.

name: Zendesk Sell (Sales CRM)
description: Zendesk Sell is a sales-focused CRM for managing pipelines and customer interactions. Key entities include accounts/companies, contacts, leads, deals/opportunities, pipelines, stages, activities (calls, emails, tasks, meetings), products, quotes, and notes. Users create and enrich leads, convert them to contacts/accounts, and associate deals with expected close dates, amounts, and probability. CRUD operations cover pipeline configuration (custom stages, required fields), deal updates, bulk imports, tagging, and custom fields. Workflows include lead assignment rules, activity scheduling, follow-up cadences, and moving deals across stages (qualified → proposal → negotiation → closed won/lost). Communication logs can be simulated as structured records (direction, timestamps, outcome codes) rather than real email content. Reporting includes forecast snapshots, stage conversion metrics, and rep performance dashboards based on synthesized deal histories. This scenario supports realistic database-driven interactions like deduplication, ownership transfer, multi-entity relationships (one account to many contacts/deals), and audit trails for changes.

name: Notion (Workspace Database & Docs)
description: Notion is a workspace platform combining documents with structured databases. For synthesis-focused simulation, emphasize database-like features: workspaces, pages, databases (tables), properties (text, select, multi-select, number, date, person, relation), rows/records, views (kanban/calendar/table), and permissions. Users create databases for projects, inventories, meeting logs, or content calendars using short fields rather than long articles. CRUD operations include adding/editing records, changing property schemas, creating filtered/sorted views, linking records via relations, and rolling up aggregates (e.g., project → tasks completion). Workflows include onboarding templates, assigning tasks to people, tracking statuses, and generating weekly reports from views. Version history can be simulated as page revisions with diff metadata and timestamps. Sharing models (public link vs team-only) and access roles (owner/editor/commenter) provide realistic permission tests. Because the “content” can remain short structured fields, this scenario avoids long-form generation while offering rich API interactions: schema evolution, migrations, nested pages, and cross-database relationships.

name: Workday (HR & Time Tracking)
description: Workday is an enterprise HR system covering employee records and workforce operations. Synthesizable entities include organizations, positions, employees, job profiles, compensation plans, benefits enrollments, time clocks, timesheets, leave requests, approvals, and payroll periods (without needing real payroll calculations). Users manage employee lifecycle workflows: requisition → hire (create worker profile, assign manager, set start date), changes (promotion, transfer, compensation update), and offboarding (termination date, equipment return checklist). Time and attendance workflows include submitting weekly timesheets, manager approvals, corrections, and audit logs of edits. Leave management adds balances, accrual rules, leave types, and request statuses (submitted/approved/denied/cancelled). Security is central: roles, permission groups, and data domains (who can read comp vs contact details). Reporting entities include headcount snapshots, turnover metrics, and labor distribution summaries based on synthetic timesheet lines. This scenario is suitable for API simulation of complex approvals, effective-dated records, and strict RBAC across many related tables.

name: Verizon Connect (Fleet Telematics & Dispatch)
description: Verizon Connect is a fleet management and telematics platform for tracking vehicles and dispatching jobs. Synthesizable entities include fleets, vehicles, devices, drivers, GPS pings, trips, geofences, maintenance schedules, fuel logs, alerts, jobs/work orders, routes, and status updates. Users register vehicles and tracking devices, assign drivers, configure geofences (warehouses, customer sites), and set alert rules (speeding threshold, idling time, unauthorized after-hours movement). Dispatch workflows include creating jobs with addresses, time windows, required skills, assigning them to drivers, sequencing stops into routes, and monitoring job statuses (assigned → en route → on site → completed). Telemetry data can be generated as time-series records (lat/long, speed, ignition, odometer) and summarized into trip reports and compliance logs. Maintenance modules track service events, upcoming inspections, and parts costs. This scenario supports high-volume ingestion APIs, aggregation queries, and role-based access across dispatchers, drivers, and admins, without relying on any non-synthesizable content.

name: SurveyMonkey (Forms & Survey Data Collection)
description: SurveyMonkey is a survey and forms platform centered on creating questionnaires and collecting structured responses. Synthesizable entities include organizations, users, surveys, pages, questions, answer choices, logic rules (skip/display piping as IDs), collectors (web link, email invite), contacts, responses, response items, completion statuses, and export jobs. Users perform CRUD on survey structure (add questions, reorder pages, edit choices), configure validation rules, and launch collectors with quotas and close dates. Distribution workflows include importing contact lists, sending invites (message metadata), tracking opens/clicks (event logs), and sending reminders to non-respondents. Response workflows store partial vs completed responses, timestamps, device metadata, and anonymization settings. Analysis features can be simulated via computed aggregates: question summaries, cross-tabs by segment, NPS score calculations, and filters based on synthetic demographic fields. The platform is ideal for API simulation of schema changes over time (survey versions), large response datasets, permissions for team collaboration, and data exports, all without generating long-form content.

name: Typeform (Advanced Forms + Lead Capture)
description: A Typeform-style platform lets teams build multi-step forms for lead capture, registrations, quizzes, and internal requests. Core entities are workspaces, users/roles, forms, question blocks (types, validation rules, logic jumps), themes, translations, variables/hidden fields, and share links/embeds. Operators CRUD forms, reorder questions, define required fields, set branching logic, and configure completion screens. Submissions are first-class records with answers, metadata (UTM, referrer, device), timestamps, and spam scores; admins can review, tag, export, or delete submissions and manage retention policies. Workflows include draft → publish, versioning/duplication of forms, A/B testing of intros, and automated routing via webhooks/integrations (e.g., create a CRM lead when a submission meets conditions). Teams manage notification rules (email/Slack), responder limits, scheduling windows, and payment-collection settings (metadata-only transaction intent). Analytics entities include views, starts, completion rates, drop-off by question, and attribution; these can be synthesized from event logs. The API supports embedding tokens, listing forms, posting submissions, bulk export, and audit logs for changes and access.

name: Qualtrics XM (Survey Research + Panel Management)
description: A Qualtrics-like experience management platform focuses on structured survey design and respondent operations. Entities include organizations, projects, surveys, question libraries, blocks, randomizers, quotas, scoring rules, and distribution lists (contacts, segments). Admins CRUD contacts and attributes, create surveys from templates, apply skip/display logic, and set quota limits (e.g., stop collecting when 200 completes in a segment). Distribution workflows cover email invites, unique links, reminders, and anonymous links with rate limiting; all are synthesizeable as events and tokens. Response entities store answers, timing per question, completion status, IP/device metadata, and quality flags (speeders, straight-liners). Analysis entities include crosstabs, filters, weights, and dashboards configured from saved queries; the system can generate synthetic charts from the response table without real content. Governance features include role-based access, approval workflows for publishing, data retention settings, and audit trails. APIs support creating surveys, importing contacts, distributing links, collecting responses, exporting datasets, and managing dashboards—ideal for CRUD-heavy simulation and database-driven interactions.

name: UserVoice (Product Feedback + Roadmap Voting)
description: A UserVoice-style feedback portal collects structured feature requests and prioritizes them via voting and internal triage. Entities include products/portals, user accounts, customer organizations, feedback posts (title, category, status), comments, votes, tags, internal notes, and roadmap items/boards. End users can submit new ideas, upvote, subscribe to updates, and comment; moderators can merge duplicates, edit categories, apply tags, and change statuses (Under Review, Planned, In Progress, Shipped, Won’t Do). Workflows include intake queues, SLA rules for first response, automatic duplicate detection via simple similarity (configurable but can be mocked), and escalation to internal teams. Roadmap entities track planned releases, themes, and visibility settings; admins map feedback posts to roadmap items and send status-change notifications to subscribers. Reporting entities include vote counts by customer segment, trend lines over time, and top requests by tag/category. Integration points include webhooks for new posts/status changes, linking to tickets in external issue trackers, and exporting prioritized lists. All data is short text + counters + timestamps, making it straightforward to synthesize realistically.

name: Zendesk Customer Satisfaction (CSAT/NPS Feedback Hub)
description: A Zendesk-style feedback module collects CSAT and NPS surveys tied to support interactions, then aggregates results for operations teams. Entities include accounts, agents, end users, tickets, satisfaction surveys (CSAT, NPS, CES), delivery rules, survey instances, responses, and follow-up tasks. Admins CRUD survey templates (questions, scales, localization), configure triggers (send after ticket solved, after chat ends), set sampling rates, and define suppression rules (don’t survey VIPs, cooldown windows). Each response stores rating, optional short comment, ticket linkage, timestamps, channel metadata, and agent/team attribution. Workflows include alerting on low scores, auto-creating follow-up tickets/tasks, assigning to managers, and tracking resolution outcomes (contacted, recovered, closed). Analytics entities include score distributions, rolling averages, driver tags, and leaderboards by agent/team; these are generated from response tables and event logs. APIs support ticket creation/updates, survey dispatch, response ingestion, exporting datasets, and managing user/team hierarchies. The scenario is CRUD-heavy and synthesizable without needing long-form content or external real-time data.

name: DocuSign Agreements (Applications + eSignature Packets)
description: A DocuSign-like platform manages structured applications and agreements as reusable templates that become signature packets. Entities include organizations, users/roles, templates, documents (metadata), fields (text, checkbox, date, numeric), recipients (signers, CCs), routing order, envelopes/packets, signing events, and status history. Admins CRUD templates, define field placement and validation rules, create recipient roles, and set conditional fields (show if applicant selects a specific option). Workflows cover generating an envelope from a template, pre-filling applicant data, sending for signature, reminders, expirations, and completion certificates. The system records audit events (opened, viewed, signed), IP/user-agent metadata, and timestamps, plus optional attachments. Teams manage versions of templates, access policies, and retention. APIs support creating templates, sending envelopes, embedding signing sessions, downloading completed PDFs (can be mocked as metadata), and retrieving event logs. This scenario simulates real database interactions around applications/registrations and approval chains while keeping all content short, structured, and synthesizable.

name: Eventbrite Organizer (Registrations + Ticketing Check-in)
description: An Eventbrite-style registration platform lets organizers create events and sell/manage tickets with attendee check-in. Entities include organizer accounts, venues, events, ticket classes (price, quantity, sales windows), promo codes, orders, attendees, refunds, check-in devices, and scan logs. Organizers CRUD events, set schedules, capacity limits, ticket tiers, add-ons, and policies; publish/unpublish events and duplicate past events. Buyers create orders with line items and attendee details; each attendee has a unique QR code token and status (valid, checked-in, canceled, transferred). Workflows include waitlists, automated confirmation emails, partial refunds, ticket transfers, and onsite check-in using device sessions that upload scan events. Analytics entities include sales by day, conversion funnels, attendance rates, and revenue breakdowns by ticket class/promo code. Access control includes staff roles (box office, check-in only) and audit logs. APIs support event creation, inventory adjustments, order queries, attendee check-in endpoints, webhook notifications for purchases/refunds, and exports. All objects are structured records with timestamps and counters, making realistic synthesis straightforward.

name: Steamworks Publisher Portal (Game Platform + Virtual Goods)
description: A Steamworks-like publisher portal manages game releases, entitlements, DLC, and virtual items without requiring real gameplay or media. Entities include publishers, games/apps, builds (version, branch, changelog metadata), depots, release channels, pricing regions, discounts, user accounts, ownership entitlements, achievements (metadata), inventory items (SKUs), item grants, trades (optional), and transaction records. Publishers CRUD store metadata (short descriptions, tags, supported languages), configure release dates, manage build rollout (beta → staged → public), and set pricing rules and sale schedules. Virtual goods workflows include defining item SKUs, drop tables (probabilities), bundle offers, and grant rules (purchase grants starter pack, seasonal event grants cosmetics). Support ops can reconcile purchases, issue refunds (synthetic), revoke entitlements, and review fraud flags. APIs include querying catalog, purchasing items (creating transactions), granting/revoking inventory, listing owned items, and retrieving audit logs. This scenario is rich in CRUD and state transitions while remaining fully synthesizable through structured data and event histories.

name: Twitch Creator Dashboard (Streaming Channel Ops + Subscriptions)
description: A Twitch-style creator dashboard focuses on channel operations, monetization settings, and viewer engagement metadata without needing actual video. Entities include creators/channels, streams (sessions with start/end timestamps), categories/tags, schedules, VOD metadata (no media), chat messages (short), moderation actions, subscriptions, bits/cheers transactions (numeric), emotes (metadata), and payouts. Creators CRUD stream schedules, titles, category tags, and moderation settings (blocked terms, roles, VIP/mod lists). Workflows include going live (create a session record), updating stream info mid-session, running polls/predictions (options, votes), and managing subscriber tiers/benefits (badge metadata, emote slots). Moderation workflows cover timeouts/bans, message deletion, and appeals; all can be modeled as event logs. Analytics entities include concurrent viewers time series, chat rate, follower/sub growth, and revenue breakdowns, synthesized from session events and transaction tables. APIs support channel configuration, schedule endpoints, subscriptions/payout queries, and event webhooks for follows/subs. It’s database-driven with clear CRUD patterns and realistic state transitions.

name: Twitch-Like Creator Dashboard for Live Streams (Metadata-First)
description: A creator and channel management console for a live-streaming service where the core simulation focuses on stream/session metadata rather than video. Entities include channels, creators, stream sessions (start/end timestamps), categories/games, titles, tags, scheduled broadcasts, VOD records (metadata only), clips (timestamps + IDs), and moderation policies. Creators CRUD stream schedules, update titles/categories mid-session, configure chat rules (slow mode, followers-only), manage moderators, and set monetization features such as subscriptions tiers, bits/cheers equivalents, and ad-break schedules. Audience entities include viewers, follows, subscriptions, gift subs, and purchases of channel perks; admins can issue refunds, revoke perks, or apply sanctions. Safety workflows include user reports, timeouts/bans, appeal tickets, and audit logs of moderation actions. Analytics is synthesizable: concurrent viewers time series, chat message counts, conversion funnels for subs, and revenue summaries by day. APIs support creating sessions, updating stream state, listing followers/subscribers, emitting webhook events (stream.online/offline, subscription.created), and pulling channel analytics dashboards.

name: App Store for Game Mods & UGC Packages (Curated Repository)
description: A mod distribution platform for games (similar to mod hubs) centered on structured packages rather than content-heavy posts. Entities include games, mod projects, versions/releases, dependency graphs, compatibility ranges (game version, platform), file artifacts (hashes, sizes), install manifests, tags/categories, authors/teams, and download mirrors. Authors CRUD mod metadata, upload new versions, deprecate releases, manage changelog entries (short text), and set visibility (public/unlisted/private). Users can create collections/modpacks by selecting specific versions, pin dependencies, and export install profiles; collections support collaboration via roles and change requests. Quality workflows include virus-scan status, automated validation checks, and moderation queues (DMCA report, policy violation) with actions like takedown, reinstate, or region restrict. Engagement entities are synthesizable: ratings, favorites, download counts, issue tickets, and support requests (templated forms). Monetization can be simulated via creator donations, paid “premium” downloads, or subscription tiers with entitlements. APIs provide search/filter over metadata, resolve dependency trees, generate signed download URLs, and post webhooks for new release published or collection updated.

name: Virtual Goods Marketplace for Game Skins & Items (Primary + Resale)
description: A virtual item marketplace for cosmetic skins, emotes, and game collectibles with both primary sales and peer-to-peer resale. Entities include item definitions (rarity, series, attributes), editions, listings, price history (numeric), inventory holdings, wallets, orders, escrow records, settlement payouts, and trade offers. Publishers/admins CRUD item catalogs, mint supply (finite or unlimited), set drop tables for events, and define marketplace rules (fees, minimum price, cooldowns). Users CRUD listings (create, update price, cancel), manage watchlists, place bids, accept trade offers, and transfer items between accounts (subject to trade locks). Risk workflows include KYC status flags (synthetic), fraud rules, chargeback cases, dispute tickets, and account holds. Promotions include coupons, seasonal events, and bundles; reporting includes revenue by item, GMV, fee breakdowns, and suspicious activity alerts. APIs expose inventory queries, create checkout sessions, post-sale fulfillment (grant entitlement), and webhook notifications (listing.created, order.completed, payout.sent). All data—items, prices, timestamps, statuses—can be synthesized while remaining realistic.

name: Esports Tournament Operations & Bracket Management Suite
description: An esports tournament platform for organizers, teams, and referees. Entities include organizers, events, seasons, tournaments, game titles, rulesets, venues/servers, teams, players, rosters, eligibility documents (metadata), matches, brackets, lobbies, maps, score submissions, and dispute cases. Organizers CRUD tournament configurations (format, seeding, check-in windows), publish schedules, invite teams, and manage registration approvals. Match workflows include auto-generating brackets, creating match instances, assigning referees, issuing lobby codes, recording results, handling forfeit/no-show statuses, and advancing winners. Teams manage rosters, substitute requests, availability, and check-in actions; referees validate scores, attach evidence references (IDs), and resolve disputes via structured outcomes. Sponsorship and payments can be simulated with prize pools, payout splits, invoices, and payout statuses. Analytics include match duration, participation rates, and rule violation counts. APIs support registering teams, pulling match schedules, reporting results, webhooking status transitions (match.started/completed), and integrating with game server provisioning systems (synthetic endpoints).

name: Applicant Tracking System (ATS) for Mid-Market Recruiting
description: An ATS for managing hiring pipelines from job creation through offer and onboarding. Entities include companies, departments, requisitions/jobs, hiring teams, candidates, applications, resume files (metadata), interview stages, scorecards, interview schedules, tasks, notes, email templates, and compliance fields (EEO/OFCCP-style synthetic). Recruiters CRUD job postings, define pipelines, add candidates manually or via imports, and move applications through stages with reason codes. Interview workflows include scheduling (time slots, interviewers, rooms/video links metadata), collecting structured feedback, and triggering reminders. Offer workflows include generating offers from templates, approval chains, compensation bands, and acceptance/decline statuses; onboarding workflows include document checklists, equipment requests, and start-date tracking. Collaboration features include @mentions, task assignments, and activity timelines. Reporting is synthesizable: time-to-fill, source effectiveness, stage conversion rates, and diversity metrics. APIs provide endpoints for posting jobs, ingesting candidates, updating stage transitions, exporting analytics, and webhooks for offer accepted, background check initiated, or candidate hired.

name: Job Board + Employer Branding Portal for Niche Industries
description: A niche job board (e.g., healthcare IT, green energy, logistics) focused on structured listings and employer tools rather than content publishing. Entities include employers, company profiles, locations, job posts, screening questions, compensation ranges, application forms, candidate profiles, saved searches, alerts, and subscription plans. Employers CRUD job posts with structured attributes (role type, seniority, skills, remote policy), purchase posting credits, sponsor listings, and manage inbound applications with status labels (new, screened, shortlisted, rejected). Candidates CRUD profiles, resumes (metadata), preferences, and applications; workflows include applying with form answers, scheduling screening calls, and receiving status notifications. Admin workflows include fraud review of employers, content moderation for job posts, refund/cancellation, and plan upgrades/downgrades with proration. Analytics includes impressions, clicks, apply conversion, and spend per applicant. APIs enable programmatic job posting, applicant export to an ATS, webhook notifications on new applications, and partner integrations for single sign-on. The dataset is fully synthesizable: roles, skills, salaries, locations, timestamps, and application states.

name: Global Payroll & Contractor Payments Platform (Multi-Country)
description: A payroll system supporting employees and contractors across countries with configurable pay rules. Entities include organizations, legal entities, workers, employment types, contracts, pay schedules, timesheets, earnings/deductions, benefits (metadata), tax profiles (synthetic), payroll runs, payslips, funding wallets, payouts, and reconciliation records. Admins CRUD worker profiles, compensation (salary/hourly), bank details tokens (synthetic), and country-specific configurations (pay periods, holiday calendars). Payroll workflows include collecting timesheets, approvals, calculating gross-to-net (simulated), generating payroll runs, handling exceptions (missing hours, invalid banking), and producing payslips and accounting exports. Contractor workflows include invoicing, milestone payments, approvals, and payment status tracking. Compliance workflows include document requests, audit logs, role-based access controls, and approval chains for payroll runs. Reporting includes labor cost by department, variance vs prior periods, and payout status dashboards. APIs cover worker onboarding, timesheet submission, payroll run creation, payout initiation, webhooks for payout.failed/succeeded, and integration with HRIS/accounting systems.

name: Asana/ClickUp-Style Work Management for Cross-Functional Teams
description: A project and task management platform with configurable workspaces and views. Entities include organizations, workspaces, teams, users, projects, tasks, subtasks, custom fields, statuses, priorities, dependencies, sprints, milestones, comments (short), attachments (metadata), and activity logs. Users CRUD projects and tasks, assign owners, set due dates, create templates, and track progress via Kanban, list, calendar, and timeline views. Workflow features include automations (when status changes, create task; when due date approaches, notify), approval tasks, and recurring tasks. Collaboration includes mentions, watchers, and task-level permissions; governance includes roles, guest access, and audit trails. Reporting is synthesizable: burndown charts, cycle time, workload by assignee, and SLA breach counts. Integrations are API-first: create/update tasks, bulk import, webhook events (task.created/updated), and outbound connectors to Slack/email (simulated). This scenario is database-rich with realistic CRUD and state transitions, yet independent of long-form content or AI-generated outputs.

name: Smartsheet (Collaborative Work & Resource Scheduling)
description: A Smartsheet-like platform blends spreadsheets with project tracking, approvals, and resource management. Entities include organizations, users, sheets, columns (typed), rows, attachments metadata, comments, forms, reports (cross-sheet views), dashboards (widget configs), automation rules, and approval requests. Users CRUD sheets and columns, create rows representing tasks or line items, assign owners, set due dates, and update status fields (not started/in progress/blocked/done). Workflow features include requesting updates, routing approvals (pending/approved/rejected) with audit logs, and generating reports that aggregate rows across sheets based on filters. Resource management can be simulated with people, allocations (percent), project calendars, and utilization summaries. Integrations are modeled via webhooks when rows change and import/export jobs. Data is synthesizable: tasks, dates, dependencies (optional), and approval histories create realistic project operations without content-heavy artifacts. This scenario exercises pagination, bulk updates, concurrency/locking concerns, and permissioned sharing links.

name: Chargebee (B2B Subscription Management & Entitlements)
description: A Chargebee-style platform manages complex B2B subscriptions with contracts, add-ons, entitlements, and invoicing. Core entities include sites/tenants, customers, accounts, billing addresses, products, plans, addons, price points, subscriptions, subscription items, contract terms, ramp deals, coupons, usage events, invoices, payments, credits, quotes, checkout sessions, and entitlement records (feature flags/limits). Workflows include quoting a deal, converting quote to subscription, configuring billing cycles, mid-cycle upgrades/downgrades with prorations, pausing service, and renewing contracts. Entitlements are crucial: admins define features (API calls/month, seats, storage GB) and link them to plans; product systems query entitlements at runtime. Collections can be simulated with payment retries, dunning steps, and account holds. APIs support CRUD plus event streams/webhooks (invoice_generated, payment_failed, subscription_changed). All data can be synthetic: contracts, seat counts, usage quantities, and invoice schedules enable rich integration testing for SaaS backends without requiring real payment rail connectivity.

name: Procore (Construction Project Management)
description: A Procore-like construction management platform coordinates projects, budgets, documents, and field execution through structured records. Core entities include companies, projects, users, roles, cost codes, budgets, commitments (subcontracts/POs), change orders, invoices/pay applications, RFIs, submittals, drawings metadata (sheet numbers/revisions), specifications sections (metadata), daily logs, inspections, punch lists, issues, photos metadata, meetings, and action items. Workflows include setting up a project, defining budget line items, issuing a subcontract, submitting and approving change orders, collecting pay apps, and reconciling costs. Field workflows cover creating RFIs, routing for answers, managing submittals with review cycles, logging daily manpower/equipment quantities, and tracking punch items to completion with assignments and due dates. Permissions and audit logs are central for compliance. APIs support CRUD with rich filtering (by project, status, trade, date range) and webhooks for approvals and status transitions. Synthetic data works well: fabricate projects, cost structures, status progressions, and schedule dates to simulate real operations without relying on document-heavy artifacts.

name: DocuSign CLM (Contract Lifecycle Management)
description: A DocuSign CLM-like platform manages contracts as structured records with approvals, redlines, and e-sign workflows (without needing real document content). Entities include organizations, users, roles, templates, clause libraries (short text), contract records, parties/counterparties, contacts, metadata fields (term, renewal date, value), tasks, approval steps, signers, envelopes, signature requests, reminders, audit trails, and status states (draft → review → approved → sent → signed → archived). Users create contracts from templates, populate metadata, route for internal review, assign redline tasks, and send for signature to external parties. The system tracks events: viewed, signed, declined, expired, voided, with timestamps and IP/device metadata (synthetic). Renewal workflows create alerts and tasks as deadlines approach, and reporting endpoints summarize cycle time, pending approvals, and contract value by category. CRUD operations cover templates, clause sets, counterparties, and approval policies. Because the platform’s value is in structured metadata, states, and logs, it is highly suitable for synthesized data while still enabling meaningful API testing around permissions, workflow engines, and compliance-grade auditing.

name: Plaid-Style Open Banking Aggregator (Accounts & Transactions API)
description: A Plaid-like platform provides APIs to link financial institutions and normalize account data for apps. Entities include end users, link sessions, institutions, items/connections, accounts (checking/savings/credit), balances, transactions, categories, merchants, recurring transactions, identity profiles, and webhooks. Workflows include creating a link token, exchanging a public token for an access token (synthetic), refreshing transactions, handling error states (MFA required, login reset), and receiving webhook events when new transactions arrive. CRUD is meaningful for managing users, linked institutions, account enablement, transaction sync cursors, and category mappings. The system can also model bank transfer features: transfer authorizations, transfers, returns, and reconciliation events. Data is fully synthesizable: realistic transaction amounts, timestamps, descriptions, merchant names, pending→posted transitions, and balance changes. This scenario is excellent for API simulation because it emphasizes pagination, idempotency keys, webhook delivery/retry, and multi-account aggregation logic without relying on any real external content.

name: Robinhood-Style Brokerage (Trading, Portfolio, Orders)
description: A retail brokerage platform models investing workflows including market/limit orders and portfolio accounting using synthesized quotes. Entities include users, KYC profiles, brokerage accounts, cash balances, positions, instruments (stocks/ETFs/options metadata), quotes (synthetic time series), watchlists, orders, order legs (for options), executions/fills, transfers (ACH/wire), dividends, corporate actions (splits), tax lots, and statements (metadata). Users CRUD watchlists, place orders, cancel/replace orders, deposit/withdraw cash, and view position performance. Order workflows cover states such as created → queued → partially filled → filled/canceled/rejected, with fill price/quantity events and timestamps. Risk checks can be simulated (insufficient buying power, pattern day trading flags), along with margin settings and interest accrual. Reporting endpoints can generate realized/unrealized P&L, cost basis, and performance by period from synthesized trade history. This scenario is highly suitable for database-driven simulation: it’s structured, stateful, and rich in transactions and audit trails, without requiring real market connectivity.

name: Coinbase-Style Crypto Exchange & Wallet (Spot Trading + Transfers)
description: A crypto exchange and wallet platform supports deposits, withdrawals, and spot trading with synthetic price feeds. Entities include users, wallets, blockchain addresses (synthetic), assets (BTC/ETH/USDC), networks, balances, deposit/withdrawal transactions, confirmations (counts), internal transfers, spot markets, order books (simulated snapshots), orders, fills, fees, holds, and compliance flags. Users CRUD address books, withdrawal whitelists, API keys, and notifications. Trading workflows include creating limit/market orders, reserving funds (holds), partial fills, cancellations, and fee calculation by tier. Transfer workflows include creating a withdrawal request, applying 2FA, moving through states (requested → queued → broadcast → confirmed/failed), and recording network fees and tx metadata. Admin/compliance workflows can include travel-rule info, account freezes, and suspicious activity case records. This scenario is ideal for API simulation because all data types are synthesizable (amounts, timestamps, confirmations, states), and the platform exercises complex ledger consistency, idempotency, and event-driven updates.

name: AutoTrader Dealer Portal (Listings, Leads, Financing, Trade-Ins)
description: A car dealership marketplace portal lets dealers manage inventory listings and respond to buyer leads. Entities include dealer groups, rooftops (locations), users/roles, vehicles (VIN, make/model/trim, mileage, condition), photos (metadata), pricing, incentives, listing status (draft/published/sold), buyer leads, chat/messages, test-drive appointments, trade-in appraisals, financing applications (structured fields), and follow-up tasks. Dealers CRUD vehicle records, publish/unpublish listings, update pricing, mark vehicles reserved/sold, and manage reconditioning status. Lead workflows include capturing inquiries, assigning to sales reps, logging call/email outcomes, scheduling appointments, and tracking conversion stages. Trade-in workflows create appraisal records with offer values, expiration dates, and counteroffers. Financing workflows collect applicant data, run synthetic decision outcomes (approved/conditional/declined), and generate required-document checklists. This is a strong API simulation scenario because all entities are synthesizable, the operations are transactional and multi-step, and it supports role permissions, auditing, and integration-style webhooks for CRM handoff.

name: Auto Repair Shop Management (Service Scheduling + Parts Inventory)
description: A shop management platform coordinates appointments, repair orders, technician schedules, and parts inventory. Entities include shops, service bays, customers, vehicles (VIN, odometer), appointments, work orders/ROs, inspections (checklists), labor line items, parts line items, estimates, approvals, technician assignments, time entries, vendors, purchase orders, inventory locations/bins, stock levels, reorders, invoices, payments, and warranty claims. Users CRUD customers and vehicles, book services by time slot, convert appointments into work orders, add recommended services, and request customer approval (pending/approved/declined). Parts workflows include reserving parts to a work order, decrementing stock on install, ordering from vendors via POs, receiving into inventory with lot/cost fields, and handling backorders/substitutions. Scheduling workflows assign technicians based on skills, capacity, and bay availability; statuses track job progress (checked-in → diagnosing → waiting parts → in repair → QC → complete). Reporting can synthesize KPIs like labor utilization, average ticket, parts margin, and comeback rate. This scenario is highly suitable for database-driven API simulation with realistic CRUD, state transitions, and inventory consistency.

name: ServiceNow-style ITSM (Tickets, Change, CMDB)
description: An IT service management platform supports incident, request, problem, and change workflows with a configuration management database (CMDB). Entities include tenants, departments, users, groups, SLAs, service catalogs, catalog items, incidents, service requests, tasks, problems, changes, approvals, knowledge article stubs (short summaries), CI records (servers, apps, databases, network devices), relationships (depends-on/hosted-on), outages, maintenance windows, and audit logs. Users CRUD tickets, assign/transfer ownership, add comments and attachments metadata, classify impact/urgency, and link incidents to CIs or changes. Change management covers change types (standard/normal/emergency), risk scoring, implementation plans, CAB approvals, and scheduled windows. The CMDB supports discovery-like imports (synthetic), lifecycle states, and relationship graphs. Dashboards expose SLA timers, backlog counts, mean time to resolve, and change success rate. APIs can simulate inbound email-to-ticket creation, webhook updates from monitoring tools, and downstream task creation for teams. This is highly synthesizeable because it relies on structured records, status transitions, timestamps, and relationship data rather than content-heavy assets.

name: Etsy-style Handmade Marketplace (Creator Shops)
description: A handmade/creative goods marketplace focuses on seller-managed storefronts, unique listings, and order fulfillment. Entities include buyers, sellers/shops, shop policies, listings, variants (size/color), materials/tags, inventory quantities, photos (metadata), shipping profiles, zones/rates, carts, orders, order line items, payment records (status only), messages, reviews/ratings, returns, refunds, coupons, and dispute cases. Sellers CRUD listings, set processing times, configure shipping rates, and manage stock by variant. Buyers browse categories, favorite shops/items, add to cart, checkout, and track shipment statuses. Workflows include order confirmation, packing slips, label purchase (simulated), fulfillment, delivery, review submission, and return authorization. Messaging threads support buyer-seller communication with status (unread/archived). Admin tools include shop verification status, policy violations, and case resolution actions. Data is easily synthesized: product metadata, prices, shipping timelines, and review scores can be generated realistically, enabling API tests for catalog management, multi-seller orders, and post-purchase support without relying on content-heavy assets.

name: Toast-style POS Back Office (Menu, Tables, Cash, Shifts)
description: A restaurant POS back-office system manages menu configuration, pricing, table service, and operational closeout. Entities include restaurant groups, locations, users/roles, menus, menu groups, items, modifiers, taxes/fees, discounts, table maps, tables, dining areas, orders, checks, payments (cash/card status), tips, voids/comp comps, gift cards (balances), customers, loyalty points (optional), employees, schedules, time punches, cash drawers, deposits, and end-of-day reports. Managers CRUD menus, enable/disable items, set daypart availability, and configure modifiers (add-ons, cooking temps). Front-of-house workflows include creating orders by table, splitting/merging checks, applying discounts, recording payments, and closing checks. Operational workflows include clock-in/out, declaring tips, drawer open/close, cash reconciliation, and daily sales summaries. APIs can simulate high-volume order traffic, partial payments, refunds, and void reasons while keeping all values synthetic. The system is database-driven with clear state transitions (open check → paid → closed) and supports rich CRUD interactions across catalog, staffing, and accounting-like records without relying on external real-time data.

name: Veeva Vault-style Regulated Document & Quality Management (QMS)
description: A regulated content and quality management platform supports controlled documents, training, deviations, and CAPA in life sciences/manufacturing settings. Entities include organizations, sites, users, roles, controlled documents, versions, document types, change controls, approvals, effective dates, training curricula, training assignments, acknowledgements, deviations, nonconformances, investigations, CAPAs, corrective/preventive tasks, e-signature events (metadata), audit trails, and retention rules. Users CRUD documents, create new versions, route for review/approval with required signers, and manage lifecycle states (draft/in-review/approved/effective/obsolete). Quality workflows include logging deviations, assigning investigations, determining root cause categories, creating CAPA plans, tracking task completion, and verifying effectiveness. Training workflows auto-assign courses when documents become effective and record completion/overdue status. Reporting endpoints provide compliance metrics (on-time training rate, open CAPAs aging, deviation closure times) and full traceability links among records. This scenario is highly synthesizeable because it relies on structured metadata, workflows, timestamps, and role-based approvals; actual document content can be stubbed while keeping realistic versioning and audit requirements.

name: Verkada-style Physical Security Admin (Access Control + Cameras Metadata)
description: A physical security management console administers sites, doors, credentials, and camera device fleets, focusing on configuration and event logs rather than video content. Entities include organizations, sites/buildings, floors, doors, access controllers, cameras (metadata), device health status, firmware versions, users, visitor profiles, credential types (badge/mobile PIN), access groups, schedules, holiday calendars, door events (unlock/forced/held-open), access attempts (granted/denied with reason), incidents, alerts, and maintenance tickets. Admins CRUD doors and camera inventory, assign devices to locations, define access policies by group and schedule, issue/revoke credentials, and create visitor passes with expiration windows. Workflows include provisioning devices, applying firmware updates, responding to alerts, investigating incidents via event timelines, and exporting access logs for audits. APIs can simulate high-frequency event generation, policy changes, and device offline/online transitions with timestamps. This is suitable for synthesis because the valuable data is structured (events, policies, users, schedules, device status) and video can be excluded entirely or represented as clip metadata IDs, enabling realistic security operations without media handling.

name: GitHub Actions-like CI/CD Pipeline Manager
description: A CI/CD platform manages code repositories as metadata and orchestrates build/test/deploy pipelines. Entities include organizations, repositories, branches, commits (hash + author metadata), workflow definitions (YAML stored as text), pipeline runs, jobs, steps, runners/agents, artifacts (metadata), environment targets (dev/stage/prod), secrets (placeholder), approvals, and logs (structured line events). Users CRUD repos and workflow configs, register runners, and define triggers (push, schedule, manual). A workflow run creates a run record, expands into jobs/steps, transitions through queued → running → success/failure/canceled, and writes timestamps, exit codes, and summary metrics (duration, retries). Deployments create deployment records with environment gates and required reviewers; approvals are separate entities with audit trails. Additional capabilities include caching keys, artifact retention policies, and notifications/webhooks for run completion. This is synthesizable because code and logs can be stubbed; the value is in workflow state transitions and relationships. API tests cover reruns, concurrency limits, secret scoping, artifact downloads, and querying run histories per branch/environment.

name: App Store Connect (Mobile App Release & TestFlight Management)
description: An App Store Connect-like portal manages mobile app metadata, builds, testers, and release workflows. Entities include developer accounts, teams, apps (bundle IDs), app versions, localized metadata (short fields: name/subtitle/keywords), screenshots (metadata), builds, build processing statuses, test groups, testers, beta invitations, release tracks (internal/beta/production), phased release settings, and compliance questionnaires as structured fields. Users CRUD apps, register devices (IDs), upload builds (represented as build records), assign builds to TestFlight groups, collect tester feedback (short text + rating), and promote a build to a release candidate. Release workflows include submitting for review, tracking review statuses (waiting for review/in review/rejected/approved), scheduling release dates, and rolling back to a prior build. Additional operations include managing certificates/profiles as metadata, setting age ratings, and configuring in-app purchase items (SKUs, prices, availability). This scenario emphasizes state machines, approvals, and versioning—highly suitable for synthesized API environments because artifacts can be placeholders while operational metadata remains realistic.

name: One Medical-like Clinic Scheduling & Patient Portal
description: A patient portal for a clinic network manages appointments, patient profiles, providers, and billing metadata (not full EHR narratives). Entities include clinics/locations, providers, specialties, appointment slots, patients, insurance policies (plan metadata), appointments, intake forms (structured questions/answers), visit summaries (coded fields), prescriptions (med name/dose/refills), lab orders/results (numeric values + reference ranges), messages, and invoices/payments. Patients CRUD profiles, insurance info, preferred pharmacy, and communication preferences; they book, reschedule, or cancel appointments based on slot availability rules and cancellation windows. Staff workflows include opening schedules, blocking provider time, triaging patient messages, issuing prescription renewals, ordering labs, and releasing results. Appointment states transition requested → confirmed → checked-in → completed/no-show. Data is synthesizable because clinical content can be represented via codes, checklists, and numeric results rather than long free-text notes. APIs support eligibility checks (simulated), appointment search by location/specialty/date, messaging threads, and reporting on utilization and no-show rates. This offers rich CRUD with constraints (availability, policy rules, and permissions) while avoiding content-heavy medical documentation.

name: Toast/Shopify POS-like Retail Point-of-Sale + Inventory
description: A POS platform for multi-location retailers manages catalogs, inventory, register sessions, and sales transactions across stores. Entities include merchants, locations, registers/devices, cash drawers, employees, roles, products/SKUs, variants, barcodes, price books, promotions, customers, carts, orders/sales, payments (cash/card metadata), returns, exchanges, gift cards, inventory items, stock counts, purchase orders, vendors, and transfer shipments between locations. Users CRUD product catalogs, set location-specific pricing, receive inventory via purchase orders, perform cycle counts, and adjust stock with reason codes. Front-of-house workflows include opening a register session, creating a cart, scanning items, applying discounts, capturing payment, printing receipts (metadata), and closing the drawer with counted cash variance. Post-sale workflows include returns with restocking rules, exchanges, and refund issuance. Inventory workflows include low-stock alerts, transfers, and reconciliation reports. All data is synthesizable (SKUs, quantities, totals, taxes, timestamps) and offers complex state transitions and constraints—ideal for API simulation involving concurrency (stock decrements), idempotent order creation, and audit logs.

name: Fleetio-like Fleet Maintenance & Vehicle Telematics Metadata
description: A fleet management platform tracks vehicles, maintenance schedules, fuel, and driver assignments, optionally ingesting telematics readings as simple numeric streams. Entities include organizations, vehicles (VIN metadata), vehicle groups, drivers, assignments, odometer readings, GPS points (optional), maintenance schedules, service reminders, work orders, inspections (checklists), parts inventory, vendors/shops, fuel transactions, expense records, and compliance documents (metadata). Users CRUD vehicles and driver profiles, assign drivers to vehicles, log trips or mileage, and create work orders for repairs with labor/parts line items and statuses (open → approved → in progress → completed). Automated workflows generate service reminders based on time or mileage, escalate overdue items, and track downtime. Fuel logs and expenses aggregate into cost-per-mile reports. Inspections capture pass/fail items with photos as metadata and create follow-up work orders. This scenario is synthesizable because telematics can be random but realistic (miles, engine hours), and all operational data is structured. APIs cover bulk imports, reminder generation, work order approvals, parts stock decrements, and reporting endpoints for utilization, maintenance compliance, and total cost of ownership by vehicle.

name: ComplianceHub (Policy & Training Compliance Manager)
description: ComplianceHub is a policy and training compliance platform for SMBs and regulated teams. Admins CRUD organizations, departments, locations, users, roles, and permission sets. Compliance content is managed as structured entities: policies (title, version, effective date, owner), procedures, attestations, training courses, quizzes, and required acknowledgements by role. Workflows include policy drafting → review → approval → publish, with version history, read receipts, and acknowledgement deadlines. Training workflows support assignment rules (by role/location), enrollment, completion tracking, retakes, and certificate issuance (metadata only). Evidence management includes uploading artifacts (file metadata + links), tagging to controls, and building audit-ready “evidence packs.” The system tracks incidents/nonconformities with status, severity, corrective actions, due dates, and assignees. Reporting endpoints provide compliance posture by policy, department, user, and timeframe. Integrations can simulate HRIS user sync, SSO provisioning, and webhook events when policies are published, attestations are overdue, or corrective actions change state.

name: CaseLedger (Ethics Hotline & Investigation Case Management)
description: CaseLedger is an ethics hotline intake and investigation management platform. It supports multi-channel report intake via web form, phone agent entry, or API, creating cases with structured fields (category, allegations, parties involved, location, risk level). Teams CRUD cases, people/subjects, investigators, tasks, interviews, evidence items (metadata), and communications logs. Workflows include triage (new → screening → accepted/rejected), investigation planning, task assignment, evidence collection, findings, and closure with outcome codes and remediation actions. Role-based access controls restrict visibility by case sensitivity. Chain-of-custody is modeled as immutable event logs attached to evidence items (who accessed what, when). The system includes SLA timers, reminders, and escalation rules. It supports anonymous reporter portals via case tokens, enabling Q&A threads and file uploads (metadata) without revealing identity. Reporting endpoints provide trends by allegation type, business unit, time-to-close, substantiation rate, and remediation completion.

name: ClauseCraft (Contract Lifecycle Management for Teams)
description: ClauseCraft is a contract lifecycle management (CLM) platform for creating, negotiating, and renewing agreements. Users CRUD counterparties, contacts, contract records, templates, clause library items, and playbooks (fallback language + approval rules). Contracts include structured fields (term dates, auto-renew, payment schedule fields, governing law, risk score) and attachments (document metadata + storage links). Workflows cover intake request → template selection → redline rounds → internal approvals → signature routing → post-signature obligations tracking. Redlines are represented as revisions with comments, status, and authorship; clause deviations can be flagged against playbook rules. Approval routing supports multi-step chains based on thresholds (e.g., spend amount, liability cap), with audit logs and timestamps. Obligations are tracked as tasks/milestones (deliverables, renewal notice dates, compliance certificates due) with owners and reminders. APIs enable searching by structured fields, generating renewal pipelines, syncing counterparty data to CRM, and emitting webhooks when a contract moves stages or nears renewal.

name: SignFlow (Document Signing & Notary-Ready Envelope System)
description: SignFlow is an e-signature platform centered on “envelopes” and signing workflows. Admins CRUD users, teams, sender identities, templates, fields (signature, initials, date, checkbox, text), and brand settings. Senders create envelopes with recipients, signing order, authentication requirements, reminders, and expiration dates; each envelope tracks status (draft, sent, viewed, signed, declined, expired). Documents are represented by file metadata and field placements (page, coordinates). Recipients complete signing sessions, with event logs for view/sign actions and IP/device metadata (synthetic). Advanced flows include conditional routing (if checkbox set, add approver), carbon copies, and bulk send from CSV-like recipient lists. The platform stores completed envelope artifacts (combined PDF metadata, certificate of completion metadata) and supports download/void/reassign operations.
