APIs manage templates, create envelopes, fetch signing URLs, list recipient statuses, and receive webhooks on status changes. Optional “notary mode” models appointment scheduling and identity verification steps as structured checklists without requiring real media.

name: GrantSpring (Nonprofit Grant & Program Management)
description: GrantSpring is a nonprofit platform for managing programs, grant applications, and award lifecycles. Staff CRUD programs, funding rounds, eligibility rules, application forms (sections, questions, validation), applicants (organizations/individuals), budgets (line items), and supporting documents (metadata). Intake workflows include application submission, completeness checks, reviewer assignment, scoring rubrics, panel deliberation notes, and award decisions. Award management tracks grant agreements, payment schedules (tranches), reporting requirements, and compliance flags. Grantees submit progress reports using structured forms, outcomes metrics, and expense reports tied to budget categories; staff review and request revisions. The system supports site visits as scheduled events with checklists and findings. Accounting-friendly exports provide payments, vendor/grantee master records, and restricted/unrestricted tagging. APIs enable listing open rounds, submitting applications, pulling reviewer queues, updating award status, and generating dashboards for pipeline, award totals by program, reporting timeliness, and outcomes over time.

name: DonorPulse (Donations, Recurring Giving & Receipting)
description: DonorPulse is a donation management system for nonprofits handling one-time and recurring gifts. Admins CRUD donors (people/organizations), households, communication preferences, campaigns, funds/designations, appeals, and donation forms. Donations track amount, currency, payment method token (synthetic), fees, soft credits, tribute gifts, and tax-deductible amounts. Workflows include pledge creation, recurring schedule setup, failed payment retries, refunds, and issuing receipts/acknowledgement letters (template + merge fields). The platform manages employer matching as a structured process (match request → verification → received). Donor engagement is modeled via interactions: calls, emails, meetings, tasks, and notes. Segmentation uses structured filters (last gift date, total giving, campaign participation), enabling targeted mail-merge exports and suppression lists. APIs support creating donations, updating recurring plans, generating year-end statements, and webhooks for donation succeeded/failed/refunded events. Reporting endpoints provide campaign performance, retention/cohort analysis, and fund balances without relying on external content.

name: VolunteerRoster (Volunteer Scheduling & Hours Tracking)
description: VolunteerRoster is a volunteer management platform for charities and community programs. Coordinators CRUD volunteer profiles, skills, certifications, background-check status (flag + dates), availability blocks, and emergency contacts. Programs define opportunities, shifts, capacity limits, locations, and role requirements (e.g., must have “Food Handler” cert). Volunteers browse and sign up for shifts, join waitlists, cancel, and check in/out to record hours. Workflows include approval-required shifts, automated reminders, no-show handling, and substitution requests. The system tracks service hours by program, grant code, and date range; supervisors can approve hours, add adjustments, and attach notes. Group volunteering is supported via team signups and roster imports. Messaging features include broadcast announcements to shift rosters and targeted messages by skill or location. APIs enable syncing opportunities to a public website, creating shifts, listing attendance, issuing service letters (metadata), and exporting hours to payroll or grant reporting. Audit logs capture who edited schedules, capacities, and attendance.

name: CampaignForge (Peer-to-Peer Fundraising & Event Pages)
description: CampaignForge is a peer-to-peer fundraising platform where organizations run campaigns and supporters create personal fundraising pages. Admins CRUD organizations, campaigns, teams, participants, fundraising pages, goals, incentives, and donation configurations. Participants manage page content as structured fields (headline, story snippet, photos metadata, progress goal) and can invite team members. Donation flows create donation records tied to campaign/page/team with optional dedication messages (short text). Workflows include participant onboarding, pledge tracking, matching gift challenges, leaderboard snapshots (computed from donation totals), and milestone notifications. Event fundraising supports ticket types, registrations, check-in lists, and add-ons (e.g., t-shirt size as a field). Compliance needs are modeled with consent checkboxes, donor anonymity options, and exportable receipts. APIs allow creating campaigns, registering participants, posting offline donations, generating share links, and pulling real-time totals for dashboards. Webhooks notify when a page hits a goal, a donation is made, or a participant completes registration.

name: HelpDeskAtlas (Customer Support Ticketing & SLA Console)
description: HelpDeskAtlas is a customer support ticketing system for product teams and service desks. Admins CRUD customers/companies, contacts, agents, groups, inboxes, categories, macros, and SLA policies. Tickets store subject, description, requester, priority, channel, status (new/open/pending/solved), tags, custom fields, and time tracking. Workflows include assignment rules, triage queues, internal notes vs public replies, collision detection, and escalation when SLA timers breach. The platform supports knowledge base articles as short structured entries (title, summary, steps) but keeps content lightweight and optional. Multi-channel messaging is represented as conversations with message objects (sender, timestamp, body) and attachments metadata. Automations include triggers (on status change, on tag added), scheduled jobs (follow-up after 3 days), and satisfaction surveys (rating + short comment). APIs support creating/updating tickets, bulk tagging, searching by structured fields, exporting audit logs, and webhooks for ticket created/updated/assigned events. Analytics endpoints provide first response time, resolution time, backlog, and agent workload.

name: CommunityLine (Omnichannel Messaging & Contact Center Lite)
description: CommunityLine is an omnichannel messaging platform for nonprofits and service organizations to communicate with constituents. Admins CRUD contact profiles, phone numbers/email identities (synthetic), segments, opt-in/opt-out consent records, message templates, and conversation routing rules. Agents handle inbound/outbound conversations across SMS, email, and web chat as unified threads with message events, statuses (queued/sent/delivered/failed), and assignment to agents or queues. Workflows include campaign broadcasts with throttling, keyword-based automations (e.g., “FOOD” replies create a case), and appointment scheduling via structured availability slots. Contact enrichment is modeled via custom fields (preferred language, service eligibility, location) and interaction history. The platform maintains suppression lists, quiet hours, and compliance logs for consent and message delivery attempts. APIs enable importing contacts, sending templated messages, managing opt-outs, retrieving conversation transcripts (message objects), and receiving webhooks for inbound messages and delivery updates. Reporting covers reach, response rates, queue performance, and constituent engagement over time.

name: Greenhouse (Recruiting ATS + Hiring Pipeline)
description: An applicant tracking system (ATS) manages recruiting from job creation through offer and onboarding handoff. Entities include organizations, departments, job openings, requisitions, candidates, applications, sources, stages, interview kits, scorecards, interviewers, schedules, feedback, offers, and attachments (file metadata). Recruiters CRUD jobs, define pipeline stages, publish openings, and manage candidate profiles with tags and custom fields. Workflows include ingesting applications, moving candidates through stages, scheduling interviews (time slots, calendars as synthetic), collecting structured feedback, initiating background-check placeholders, and generating offer letters with compensation fields and approval routing. The platform supports email templates, tasks and reminders, candidate status transitions (applied/phone screen/onsite/offer/hired/rejected), and compliance reporting (EEO fields as optional synthetic). Admins manage roles/permissions, user accounts, and integrations (webhooks for “candidate hired”). Reporting endpoints summarize time-to-fill, stage conversion rates, interviewer load, and source performance. Everything is synthesizable: candidates, interviews, feedback scores, offers, and timestamps that create a credible hiring pipeline simulation.

name: QuickBooks Online (SMB Accounting + Invoicing)
description: An SMB accounting platform manages core bookkeeping records with clear CRUD patterns and auditability. Entities include companies, chart of accounts, customers, vendors, items/services, invoices, estimates, bills, payments, bank transactions (imported feed as synthetic), journal entries, attachments (metadata), and recurring transactions. Users CRUD customers and items, create invoices and bills, apply payments, reconcile bank lines, and categorize expenses with tax codes. Workflows include invoice approval, partial payments, overdue reminders, vendor bill pay scheduling, and month-end close with locked periods. The system supports multi-location or class tracking, basic inventory counts for items, and sales tax setup by jurisdiction. Admin roles manage users, permissions, and connections to “banks” via token placeholders. Reporting endpoints generate balance sheets, P&L, cash flow, AR/AP aging, and audit logs of edits. Synthetic data can cover realistic transaction histories, invoice sequences, reconciliation states, and ledger balances without requiring real bank connectivity, making it excellent for API and database-driven simulations.

name: Workday-style HRIS (Employee Records + Time Off + Org Structure)
description: An HRIS manages employee master data, organizational hierarchy, and HR workflows. Entities include tenants, employees, positions, departments, cost centers, locations, managers, compensation records, benefits enrollments (metadata), time-off policies, accrual balances, time-off requests, approvals, and lifecycle events (hire, promotion, transfer, termination). HR admins CRUD employee profiles (addresses, emergency contacts, job details), define org structures, and assign positions with effective dates. Workflows include onboarding tasks (equipment, training, paperwork checklists), manager approvals for time off, policy-based accrual calculations, and job changes with multi-step approvals and effective-date scheduling. The system tracks documents (metadata), acknowledgements, and audit logs for sensitive changes. Optional modules can simulate performance reviews with goals, rating scales, and review cycles. Reporting endpoints provide headcount snapshots, turnover, PTO liability, and org charts. All fields are synthesizable: identities, dates, payroll-related numbers (without real payouts), approvals, and historical effective-dated records suitable for robust API testing.

name: ArcGIS Online-style Field Data Collection (Maps + Assets + Inspections)
description: A GIS-backed field operations platform manages spatial assets and inspection records without requiring real map tiles. Entities include organizations, users, feature layers, assets (hydrants, poles, valves, parcels), coordinates/geometry, inspection forms, submissions, photos (metadata), work orders, statuses, and assignment routes. Admins CRUD layers, define schemas (fields, domains, required attributes), and set permissions. Field users create and update asset attributes, submit inspections with timestamps and GPS points, attach notes, and change asset condition/status. Workflows include assigning inspection batches to crews, offline sync simulation (queued edits), QA review of submissions, and escalation when thresholds are exceeded (e.g., condition = “critical”). The platform can generate exports (CSV/GeoJSON), webhooks for new submissions, and dashboards summarizing counts by status and area. Synthetic data is natural: coordinates, asset IDs, condition ratings, photos as URLs, and time series of inspection events. It supports diverse API interactions: spatial queries by bounding box, pagination, filtering, and bulk updates.

name: Asana-style Creative Review & Approval (Proofing + Versioning)
description: A creative proofing platform coordinates asset reviews with structured feedback and approvals. Entities include organizations, projects, folders, assets (images/PDF/video as metadata), versions, reviewers, comments (anchored to page/timecode coordinates), annotations, approval states, tasks, due dates, and notification rules. Users CRUD projects and assets, upload new versions, assign reviewers, and set deadlines. Review workflows include collecting threaded comments, resolving annotations, requesting changes, and capturing formal approvals or rejections with reasons. Version comparison is represented as metadata (version numbers, diff links), enabling realistic iteration without hosting real media. Admins manage teams, permissions, watermark/branding settings, and integrations (webhooks for “asset approved” to trigger downstream tasks). The system maintains activity logs and SLA-like reminders to chase overdue reviews. Reporting endpoints summarize cycle time per asset, number of revisions, reviewer responsiveness, and approval rates by project. All data is synthesizable: assets as records, annotations as coordinates, statuses, timestamps, and user actions—ideal for simulating database-driven workflows in an API environment.

name: FarmLogs-style Farm Management (Fields + Crop Plans + Input Tracking)
description: A farm management system tracks field operations, crop plans, and inventory of agricultural inputs. Entities include farms, fields (polygons or acreage), seasons, crop plans, planting events, scouting observations, equipment, labor crews, input products (seed, fertilizer, chemicals), inventory lots, application logs, irrigation events, and yield records. Users CRUD fields, define crop rotations, record activities with dates, quantities, and costs, and attach notes/photos (metadata). Inventory workflows manage receiving input lots, allocating quantities to applications, tracking remaining stock, and alerting on reorder thresholds or restricted-use compliance flags. Scouting workflows log pest/disease observations with severity ratings and recommended actions (structured). Harvest workflows record yields by field and moisture/quality metrics, enabling profitability reports per crop and season. The platform also supports task scheduling for crews and equipment maintenance reminders. Reporting endpoints provide cost per acre, input usage, yield trends, and activity timelines. All information is naturally synthesizable—numbers, timestamps, geographies, and entities—creating a realistic CRUD-heavy domain distinct from generic e-commerce or travel.

name: Twilio Flex-Style Contact Center (Omnichannel Messaging + Routing)
description: A Flex-style contact center platform lets businesses handle customer conversations across SMS, WhatsApp, web chat, and email with agent routing and case context. Core entities include organizations, queues, agents, skills, schedules, channels, phone numbers/senders, conversation threads, messages, attachments (metadata), contacts, cases/tickets, dispositions, tags, SLAs, and audit logs. Admins CRUD queues, skill rules, routing strategies (priority/round-robin/skills-based), working hours, canned responses, and compliance settings (retention, redaction flags). Agents work conversations: accept/transfer/escalate, send messages, add internal notes, link/unlink tickets, set status (open/pending/solved), and schedule follow-ups. Supervisors manage monitoring sessions, coaching notes, and QA evaluations with scorecards. Automation workflows include auto-triage based on keywords (synthetic), auto-creation of tickets on first contact, outbound notifications, and webhooks to CRM/billing systems. Reporting endpoints provide synthetic metrics (handle time, first response time, queue depth) and exports by date range. The platform supports multi-tenant API keys, role-based access, and sandbox-friendly message simulators for inbound events.

name: Slack Connect-Style Shared Channels for Vendor/Client Collaboration
description: A shared-channel collaboration platform provides cross-organization workspaces where companies can communicate with partners while maintaining admin controls. Entities include organizations, workspaces, users, user groups, shared channels, invitations, memberships, threads, messages, reactions, file objects (metadata only), pinned items, bookmarks, integration apps, OAuth installs, webhook subscriptions, and retention policies. Admins CRUD external connection policies, approve/deny shared-channel requests, set channel-level permissions (who can post, invite, mention), and configure data retention and eDiscovery exports. Users create channels, invite partner orgs, post messages, start threads, attach files, and manage channel settings (topic, purpose). Moderation workflows include message reporting, content takedown actions, and audit trails of edits/deletions. API workflows are rich for simulation: provisioning users via SCIM-like endpoints, lifecycle events (user suspended, channel archived), channel membership changes, and webhook-driven message ingestion. Search is limited to structured filters (channel, sender, date range, tags) rather than relevance ranking. Synthetic datasets can model realistic collaboration patterns: project channels per client, onboarding checklists, approval threads, and incident coordination.

name: Zendesk-Style Customer Support Helpdesk + Knowledge Base Metadata
description: A helpdesk platform manages customer support tickets with workflows, SLAs, and agent productivity tooling. Entities include accounts, brands, users/customers, agents, groups, ticket forms, custom fields, tickets, comments (public/internal), attachments (metadata), macros, triggers, automations, SLAs, tags, satisfaction ratings, and escalation policies. Admins CRUD forms, fields, business rules (if priority=high then route to Tier 2), and status pipelines (new/open/pending/on-hold/solved). Agents triage queues, assign/claim tickets, request info, merge duplicates, set due dates, apply macros, and log time entries. Customers can submit requests via portal/email and track status; the system creates and links user profiles and organizations. Reporting endpoints expose synthetic KPIs (backlog, resolution time, SLA breaches) and allow exports by group/date. Optional knowledge base support focuses on article metadata and short summaries (title, category, visibility, last updated) without requiring long-form content. Integration workflows include webhooks for ticket events, syncing contacts from CRM, and posting updates to messaging channels.

name: VetConnect-Style Veterinary Clinic Management (Appointments + Records + Billing)
description: A veterinary practice platform manages clients, patients, scheduling, medical records, and invoicing across one or multiple clinic locations. Entities include clinics, staff, roles, clients, pets/patients, species/breed tables, appointments, appointment types, exam notes (structured fields), diagnoses codes (synthetic), vaccinations, lab orders/results (numeric + status), prescriptions, treatment plans, reminders, inventory items (medications/supplies), invoices, payments, and insurance claims (metadata). Staff CRUD schedules, availability, appointment slots, and waitlists; clients request appointments and receive confirmations and reminders. During visits, clinicians update patient records, add vaccines, create prescription orders, and generate follow-up tasks. Billing workflow supports estimate → invoice → payment (cash/card token metadata) → receipt; inventory decrements on dispensed items and triggers reorder thresholds. The system can also manage referral letters as short templates and attach documents as metadata. API simulation is strong: state transitions (scheduled → checked-in → in-exam → completed), recurring reminders, and reporting (revenue by service, vaccine compliance, inventory turns) with purely synthesized data.

name: Indeed-Style Job Board + Employer Hiring Console
description: A job marketplace combines a public job listing directory with an employer console for posting, screening, and managing applicants. Entities include employers, company profiles, job posts, locations, salary ranges, employment types, screening questions, applications, candidate profiles, resumes (metadata), status states (new/shortlisted/interview/offer/rejected), messaging threads, interview events, and billing objects (sponsored job budgets, clicks/applications counters). Employers CRUD job posts, set screening questions, define knockout rules (yes/no), manage applicant stages, and communicate with candidates using templates. Candidates CRUD profiles, saved jobs, alerts (filters by title/location/salary), and applications. The platform supports straightforward filter search (location radius, category, pay range, remote flag) without modeling relevance ranking. Sponsored posting workflows include budget setup, pacing rules, invoice generation, and refund adjustments; all are numeric and synthesizable. Admin tooling manages fraud flags, duplicate postings, and moderation actions. APIs can simulate high-volume ingestion (bulk job posting), applicant pipelines, and event callbacks for application submitted and interview scheduled.

name: GitHub Issues (Project Issue & Release Tracker)
description: A GitHub Issues-style tracker manages software work items and lightweight release planning without needing real code content. Entities include organizations, repositories, users, teams, issues, comments, labels, milestones, assignees, projects/boards, columns, pull request references (metadata only), releases, and notifications. Users create issues with titles, short descriptions, labels (bug/feature), priority, and due dates; they assign owners, link related issues, and add checklists. Teams triage using filters, move issues across board columns (backlog → in progress → review → done), and close/reopen issues with resolution reasons. Milestones group work with start/end dates and completion metrics. Release entities track version tags, release dates, and a generated changelog built from linked issues (short text). Admin workflows include managing repository settings, label taxonomy, team access permissions, and automation rules (e.g., auto-assign based on label; auto-close on milestone completion). APIs expose CRUD for issues, labels, milestones, boards, and comments, plus actions like add/remove assignees, transfer issues between repos, and subscribe/unsubscribe to notifications. All content can be synthesized as short text, IDs, timestamps, and status transitions.

name: Figma (Design File, Component Library & Review System - Metadata Focus)
description: A Figma-like collaboration platform can be simulated by focusing on file structure, permissions, versioning, and review workflows rather than real vector graphics. Entities include organizations, teams, projects, files, pages, frames (metadata: size, position), components, component sets/variants, styles (color/text tokens), libraries, users, roles, comments, mentions, review sessions, version history, and share links. Designers create projects and files, add pages and frames, define components and publish them to shared libraries with semantic names and version numbers. Consumers of the library update dependencies in their files, track which files use which components, and manage upgrade status (up-to-date/outdated/conflicted). Collaboration workflows include inviting users, setting permissions (viewer/editor), creating comment threads anchored to frames, resolving comments, and requesting reviews with assigned reviewers and due dates. Versioning workflows allow saving named versions, restoring prior versions, and auditing changes at the metadata level (who/when/what changed). APIs provide CRUD for org/team/project/file objects, component/library catalogs, comments, and permissions; actions include publish library, accept updates, resolve comments, and generate activity feeds. All fields—names, IDs, coordinates, timestamps, statuses—are synthesizable and database-friendly.

name: ServiceNow (IT Asset + Change + Incident Operations)
description: ServiceNow-style IT operations platforms are highly suitable for synthetic API simulation because the core value is structured records and workflows. Admins CRUD users, groups, roles, CMDB configuration items (servers, laptops, apps, dependencies), locations, vendors, contracts, and service catalogs. IT staff create and manage incidents, problems, service requests, changes, and tasks with priorities, SLAs, status transitions, approvals, and assignment rules. Change workflows include risk scoring fields, implementation plans (short text), scheduled windows (timestamps), CAB approvals, and post-implementation reviews. Asset workflows track procurement, check-out to employees, warranty dates, software installs (metadata), and decommissioning. Integrations can be simulated with webhook events (incident created, CI updated, change approved), audit logs, and notification preferences. Reporting endpoints query tickets by queue, aging, SLA breaches, CI relationship impact, and technician performance. All data—IDs, timestamps, statuses, relationship graphs, and short descriptions—can be generated realistically while still supporting meaningful CRUD, permissions, and lifecycle state machines.

name: Shopify (Merchant Admin + Catalog + Fulfillment)
description: Shopify’s merchant admin model is ideal for synthesizable database-driven interactions focused on commerce operations rather than marketplace browsing. Merchants CRUD stores, staff accounts, roles, products, variants (SKU, price, weight), collections, inventory levels by location, customers, addresses, discount codes, gift cards (tokens), tax/shipping settings, and basic theme settings (structured fields). Order workflows cover checkout creation (cart lines), payment status (authorized/paid/refunded), fulfillment status (unfulfilled/partial/fulfilled), returns/RMA records, and shipment tracking numbers (synthetic). Merchants manage fulfillment locations, purchase shipping labels (metadata), and handle cancellations, partial refunds, and inventory adjustments with reason codes. Additional entities include subscriptions (recurring orders), draft orders, abandoned checkouts, and customer segments. APIs can simulate webhooks for order created, paid, fulfilled, refunded, and inventory updated. Analytics endpoints summarize GMV, AOV, conversion counts, and fulfillment lead times using generated numeric metrics. The platform supports realistic permissioning, audit trails, and idempotent operations for order/fulfillment updates.

name: UpKeep (CMMS Maintenance Requests + Work Orders)
description: A CMMS like UpKeep is highly suitable for API simulation because it revolves around assets, preventive maintenance, and work order lifecycles. Admins CRUD sites, buildings, asset hierarchies (equipment, components), meters (runtime/odometer), parts inventory, vendors, technicians, and permission roles. Users submit maintenance requests with category, priority, photos (metadata), and location; requests can be approved, converted into work orders, assigned, and scheduled. Work orders track checklists, labor time entries, parts consumed, downtime windows, safety notes, and completion codes. Preventive maintenance workflows generate recurring work orders based on schedules or meter thresholds; meter readings can be synthesized as time-series numbers. The system supports SLA fields, status transitions (open/assigned/in-progress/on-hold/completed/closed), and audit logs. Inventory workflows include stock transfers, reorder points, purchase orders, and receiving. Reporting endpoints query MTTR, uptime percentages, technician utilization, and cost by asset. Mobile-style interactions can be simulated with offline sync endpoints and conflict resolution (last-updated timestamps), making it valuable for realistic CRUD and workflow testing.

name: Chargebee (Subscription Billing + Dunning + Entitlements)
description: Chargebee-style subscription management platforms are ideal for API simulations centered on plans, subscriptions, invoices, and lifecycle events. Admins CRUD products, plans, add-ons, pricing tiers, coupons, tax rules, customers, payment methods (tokens), and entitlement features. Subscription workflows include signup, trial periods, upgrades/downgrades (proration), renewals, pauses, cancellations, and reactivations with effective dates. Billing entities cover invoices, line items, credits, payments, refunds, and credit notes with synthetic amounts and currencies. Dunning workflows track failed payments, retry schedules, grace periods, and account status changes (active/past_due/canceled). The platform can expose metered usage records (counts, timestamps) and generate overage charges. Entitlement APIs manage which features a customer has access to based on subscription state, supporting realistic gating tests. Reporting endpoints summarize MRR/ARR, churn, cohort retention, and AR aging. Webhooks simulate invoice generated, payment succeeded/failed, subscription renewed, and chargeback events. Everything is structured, auditable, and synthesizable without needing real payment rails.

name: Mixpanel (Product Analytics Events + Funnels + Cohorts)
description: A Mixpanel-like analytics platform can be simulated without real user content by focusing on event ingestion, identity management, and computed aggregates. Admins CRUD projects, data schemas (event types, properties), API keys (synthetic), user roles, and retention/funnel definitions. Client apps send events (event name, timestamp, user/device IDs, properties like plan, region, price) and user profile updates (traits). The platform manages identity merges (anonymous to known), device mappings, and consent flags. Analytical workflows create funnels (step sequences), cohorts (property filters and behavioral conditions), and dashboards composed of queries. Query APIs return aggregate counts, unique users, conversion rates, time-to-convert distributions, and retention curves based on stored events—fully synthesizable. Data governance endpoints validate schema changes, property cardinality limits, and sampling settings. Export APIs provide paginated event streams or batch jobs. While it resembles “data,” it’s still CRUD + query: manage definitions, ingest records, compute results, and audit changes. Webhooks can simulate threshold alerts (e.g., conversion drop) based on generated metrics, enabling realistic integration testing.

name: Buildium (Property Management for Rentals + Accounting)
description: Buildium-like property management platforms support realistic CRUD for properties, leases, payments, and service tickets without relying on content-heavy data. Managers CRUD portfolios, properties, units, owners, tenants, leases, rent schedules, fee rules, and move-in/move-out inspections (checklist fields). Leasing workflows include applications (structured fields), screening status flags, lease generation (metadata), renewals, and notices with effective dates. Operational workflows cover maintenance requests, work orders, vendor assignments, appointment windows, and completion statuses with labor/parts costs. Financial modules manage tenant ledgers, charges, payments, refunds, security deposits, and owner statements using synthetic amounts and accounting periods. Communication features can be represented by message threads and templates (short text), plus opt-in preferences. Vacancy tracking and unit availability are computed from lease dates and statuses. APIs can include batch rent posting jobs, late fee assessment, autopay schedules, and reconciliation summaries. Reporting endpoints query delinquency, occupancy, maintenance aging, and income/expense by property. The data model is relational, permissioned, and workflow-driven—excellent for environment simulation.

name: MealBridge (Food Pantry Inventory + Client Pickup Scheduling)
description: MealBridge is a food pantry operations platform that manages donations-in-kind, inventory, and client distributions across multiple sites. Staff CRUD pantry locations, storage zones (shelf/freezer/bin), food items (SKU-like catalog with nutrition/allergens), lots with expiration dates, and inbound donations (donor, drop-off time, itemized quantities). Client management includes households, eligibility tiers, dietary restrictions, visit frequency limits, and preferred pickup windows. Workflows cover intake scanning, quality checks, repacking (creating new lots), and automated FEFO picking lists for scheduled pickups. Clients can request appointments, receive confirmations, and check in at pickup; distributions generate a “basket” record that decrements inventory and logs substitutions. The system supports recalls/holds (mark lots as quarantined), wastage tracking with reason codes, and inter-site transfers with shipment manifests. Reporting endpoints expose inventory aging, upcoming expirations, household service history, and program utilization by neighborhood. All data (names, items, quantities, timestamps) is highly synthesizable while preserving realistic pantry constraints.

name: GiveWave (Recurring Donations + Campaign Attribution + Receipting)
description: GiveWave is a donation and recurring giving platform for charities that need clean attribution and finance-ready records. Admins CRUD organizations, funds/designations, campaigns, appeals, donation forms (fields, validation, suggested amounts), and donor profiles (people/companies, addresses, comms preferences). Donations store amount, currency, fees, payment method token (synthetic), soft credits, matching gift metadata, and tax-deductible splits. Recurring schedules support cadence, start/end dates, retry policies for failed payments, and auto-upgrade links for donors to manage payment methods. Workflows include pledge creation, donor-initiated upgrades/downgrades, refunds, chargeback/dispute flags, and issuing receipts (templates, numbering, delivery status). Teams manage acknowledgements with tasks and notes, segment donors by giving history, and export deposits to accounting via batch “settlements.” API-friendly events include donation_created, installment_failed, receipt_sent, and refund_processed. Everything is synthesizable (transactions, schedules, statuses) and supports robust CRUD and lifecycle simulation without needing real payment processing.

name: ShiftHarbor (Volunteer Scheduling + Credentialing + Capacity Limits)
description: ShiftHarbor is a volunteer management and scheduling system designed for programs with strict role requirements and fluctuating capacity. Coordinators CRUD volunteer profiles, skills, certifications (type, issuer, expiration), background-check status (flag + dates), emergency contacts, and availability blocks. Programs define opportunities with roles, shift templates, location, max capacity, age restrictions, and required credentials (e.g., “Food Handler,” “CPR”). Volunteers browse shifts, request signups, join waitlists, swap shifts, or cancel within policy windows. Workflows include approval-required roles, automated reminders, check-in/out for hours, incident reports, and no-show tracking with escalation rules. Teams can message shift groups, record attendance adjustments, and issue badges or milestones based on hours. The platform supports multi-site calendars, blackout dates, and audit logs of roster changes. Reporting endpoints cover fill rates, volunteer retention, credential expirations, and hours by program/grant code. All data is synthetic-friendly (people, schedules, status transitions) and provides meaningful CRUD plus time-based workflows.

name: SponsorSprint (Peer-to-Peer Pledge-a-thon + Team Fundraising Management)
description: SponsorSprint powers pledge-a-thons (walks, rides, read-a-thons) where participants raise money via per-unit pledges and team pages. Admins CRUD events, routes/venues, registration tiers, teams, participants, fundraising pages (headline, goal, photo metadata), and pledge configurations (per-mile, per-lap, flat amount). Sponsors pledge to a participant or team, set caps, and choose payment timing (upfront vs after results). Workflows include participant check-in, result entry (distance/laps/pages read), pledge fulfillment calculations, invoice generation, and payment reconciliation into batches. Organizers manage discount codes, fundraising incentives, and leaderboards based on structured metrics. The system tracks communication logs (email/SMS metadata), consent, and receipts per sponsor. Event-day operations include scanning bib/QR codes, recording splits, and resolving disputes (adjusted results with audit trail). APIs expose participant progress, sponsor lists, pledge statuses (pending/fulfilled/failed/refunded), and campaign totals. All entities and numbers are readily synthesizable while preserving realistic fundraising lifecycle complexity.

name: CiviServe Hub (Case + Service Referrals for Nonprofits)
description: CiviServe Hub is a coordinated services platform for nonprofits handling referrals, waitlists, and eligibility workflows. Staff CRUD clients/households, intake forms (questions, required docs metadata), programs (capacity, eligibility rules, service areas), referrals, and appointments. Each case tracks goals, service episodes, documents (file metadata), tasks, and notes with visibility controls. Workflows include triage queues, eligibility verification (checklist status), case assignment to caseworkers, appointment scheduling, and referral handoffs between partner organizations with acceptance/decline outcomes. The platform supports waitlists with priority scoring (risk level, vulnerability flags) and automatic offers when slots open. Providers record service delivery details (units, dates, outcomes), close cases, and generate follow-up reminders. Reporting includes program throughput, time-to-service, referral conversion, and demographics breakdowns. The model is fully synthesizeable (structured fields, statuses, timestamps) and is ideal for API simulation involving role-based access, auditing, and multi-organization data partitioning.

name: CaterOps Pro (Catering Orders + Production Timeline + Delivery Routes)
description: CaterOps Pro is a catering management platform for restaurants and commissary kitchens handling complex orders and fulfillment. Managers CRUD customers, venues, menus, packages, à-la-carte items, modifiers (dietary/allergen tags), pricing rules, and blackout dates. Orders capture event details (date/time, guest count, service style), itemized selections, rental equipment, staffing needs, deposits, and payment status (synthetic tokens). Workflows include quote → revision → approval → invoice, automatic deposit reminders, and cancellation policies with refund calculations. Kitchen operations generate prep sheets, batch production plans (aggregate ingredients by date), and task lists with due times. Logistics features include delivery windows, driver assignments, route stops, proof-of-delivery signatures (metadata), and temperature check records. The system supports change orders with versioning, substitutions, and audit trails. Reporting endpoints cover sales by event type, margin estimates via recipe costing, on-time delivery rates, and ingredient forecasts. All entities (orders, menus, schedules, quantities) are easy to synthesize while enabling realistic multi-step operational CRUD.

name: TableFlow POS Lite (Restaurant Ordering + Table Service + Kitchen Tickets)
description: TableFlow is a lightweight restaurant ordering and kitchen workflow system spanning dine-in, takeout, and QR ordering. Admins CRUD locations, floorplans (tables, sections), menus, categories, items, modifiers, taxes, and staff roles. Servers open checks, add items with modifier selections, split/merge checks, transfer tables, and apply comps/discounts with reason codes. Orders produce kitchen tickets with coursing (apps/entrees/dessert), prep stations, fire times, and status transitions (queued/in-prep/ready/served). Takeout supports pickup times, customer profiles, and order throttling. Payment records store tender types and synthetic authorization references; tips, refunds, and voids are tracked with manager approvals. Inventory can be optional via decrement rules for key ingredients. Workflows include shift management (clock-in/out, cash drawer counts), 86’ing items, and end-of-day close with reconciliation reports. APIs are centered on CRUD for menu and order entities plus event streams for ticket updates, making it ideal for database-driven simulations without needing real payment networks.

name: KitchenLine (Back-of-House Production + Recipe Costing + HACCP Logs)
description: KitchenLine is a back-of-house operations platform for multi-unit kitchens focused on production planning, compliance, and cost control. Culinary teams CRUD recipes (yields, steps as structured fields), ingredients, vendor items, units of measure, and substitution rules. Purchasing includes par levels by location, purchase orders, receiving logs (lot/expiry), and invoice matching (synthetic). Production planning creates daily prep batches from forecasts or standing pars, generating task lists by station and time. Compliance modules track HACCP checks (cooling/heating temps, sanitizer concentration), equipment maintenance schedules, and incident corrective actions. Inventory supports transfers between locations, waste logs with reason codes, and cycle counts with variance approvals. Costing computes theoretical food cost per recipe and variance against actual usage. Workflows include recipe versioning, approval gates for menu changes, and audit trails for compliance records. Reporting endpoints cover ingredient usage trends, waste hotspots, vendor price history, and compliance completion rates. Every dataset element (temps, lots, tasks, statuses) can be synthesized realistically for API-driven environments.

name: HireLoop Jobs (Job Board + Employer Posting + Candidate Applications)
description: HireLoop Jobs is a job board marketplace with employer self-service and structured applicant intake. Employers CRUD company profiles, billing plans, job postings (role, location, salary bands, employment type, skills), screening questions, and application forms. Jobs move through states (draft/published/paused/closed) with scheduled publish/expire dates. Candidates CRUD profiles, resumes (file metadata), work history entries, and saved jobs; they submit applications with answers and attachments. Workflows include employer review queues, status updates (new/in-review/interview/rejected/offer), interview request scheduling (time slots), and messaging threads between recruiters and candidates (message metadata). The platform supports paid listings, invoice records, coupon codes, and usage limits per plan. Anti-abuse features include employer verification flags and candidate consent logs. Search can be simulated via simple filters and sorting without needing real ranking. APIs emphasize CRUD around postings/applications, webhook events for application_received and status_changed, and reporting on applicants per role and time-to-fill.

name: PayRoster Cloud (Payroll Runs + Timecards + Compliance Reporting)
description: PayRoster Cloud is a payroll processing platform for small businesses that combines time tracking, payroll runs, and compliance artifacts. Admins CRUD companies, employees/contractors, pay rates, tax profiles (synthetic), deductions/benefits, and pay schedules. Timekeeping includes timesheets, shifts, breaks, approvals, and job/cost-center allocations. Payroll workflows generate a pay run: import approved timecards, compute gross pay, apply deductions, generate net pay amounts, and create pay statements (PDF metadata). The system tracks payroll statuses (draft/approved/processed/voided), supports off-cycle payments, retro adjustments, reimbursements, and final pay on termination. Direct deposit is represented as bank account tokens and transfer batches with settlement dates (simulated). Compliance outputs include quarterly filings metadata, year-end forms (W-2/1099 equivalents as structured fields), and audit logs. Reporting endpoints cover labor costs by department, overtime, accruals, and deduction totals. This scenario is highly synthesizable with strong relational integrity and realistic lifecycle transitions suitable for API/database simulation.

name: ShiftPay Pro (Payroll + Timekeeping for Hourly Teams)
description: ShiftPay Pro is a payroll and timekeeping platform built for shift-based businesses. Admins CRUD companies, worksites, employees, roles, pay rates, tax profiles (synthetic), direct-deposit tokens, and pay schedules (weekly/biweekly). Timekeeping includes timesheets, clock-in/out events, breaks, geofenced locations, and manager approvals with audit logs. Users manage overtime rules, tip reporting, and differentials (night/weekend), and can import schedules to prefill shifts. Payroll runs generate pay periods, earnings lines, deductions, employer taxes (calculated from configurable tables), and net pay outputs; each run supports previews, holds, off-cycle corrections, and reversals. The platform supports reimbursements, garnishments (metadata), and end-of-year forms (metadata + totals). Workflows include onboarding (collect W-4 equivalents as structured fields), manager approval queues, payroll submission, paystub delivery, and issue handling (failed deposit, negative net pay, retro pay). Reporting endpoints return labor cost by location/role, timecard exceptions, and payroll journals suitable for accounting export.

name: KitchenRail (KDS + Kitchen Operations Console)
description: KitchenRail is a kitchen display and prep management system for restaurants and ghost kitchens. Managers CRUD stores, stations (grill, fry, expo), menu items, modifier groups, prep recipes (ingredient line items), cook-time estimates, and routing rules that send items to stations based on category/modifiers. Orders arrive via API as tickets containing items, modifiers, course timing, promises (pickup/delivery times), and customer notes (short text). Staff update ticket and item statuses (queued, in-progress, ready, handed-off, canceled) with timestamps, bump actions, and re-fire events. The platform supports prep lists generated from forecasted demand, batch production tasks, and waste logs tied to ingredient usage. Workflows include throttling (auto-pausing channels when backlog exceeds thresholds), substitution prompts when ingredients are low, and incident tracking (missed promise time, remakes). Reporting includes station throughput, average make time, on-time rate, and top modifiers causing delays. Data is highly synthesizable: tickets, timing metrics, station state, inventory counts, and structured menu definitions.

name: MenuOps Cloud (Multi-Location Menu + Pricing Management)
description: MenuOps Cloud manages menus across multiple restaurant locations and ordering channels. Admins CRUD brands, locations, service hours, menus, categories, items, item variants (size), modifier groups/options, allergens, nutritional fields (structured), and media assets (image metadata). Pricing can be set per location, channel (in-store, delivery partner), and time window (happy hour), with effective dates and version history. Users manage availability rules (86 items, limited quantities, scheduled sellout), taxes and fees (service fee, delivery fee), and upsell bundles/combos. Publishing workflows include drafts, approvals, staged rollouts, and rollback to prior versions. Integrations are represented as channel connectors with mapping tables from internal item IDs to external platform IDs (synthetic). The system supports menu validation (required modifiers, incompatible options), localization (names/descriptions per language as short text), and audits (who changed price, when). Analytics endpoints show item performance via synthetic sales aggregates imported from POS, allowing comparisons by location and daypart. The core interactions are CRUD-heavy and database-driven, ideal for API simulation.

name: TableTap Ordering (QR Table Service + Payment)
description: TableTap Ordering is a QR-based ordering and payment system for dine-in restaurants. Operators CRUD venues, tables/sections, QR codes (tokenized), menus (or connect to MenuOps), and staff users with roles (server, manager). Guests create carts, add items/modifiers, apply discounts, and submit orders tied to a table session. Orders support courses, special instructions, and split checks across guests; each check tracks subtotal, tax, tip, service charges, and payment status (authorized, captured, refunded, failed). The platform manages payment methods as tokens (card, wallet), receipts, and refunds/voids with reason codes. Workflows include server approval for alcohol items, re-ordering rounds, item comping, and dispute handling. Table sessions track occupancy state (open, ordering, eating, closed), and managers can transfer a session between tables or servers. POS/KDS integration is modeled via order export events and acknowledgment callbacks. Reporting includes sales by table/section, average dwell time, tip rates, and discount usage—all derived from synthesizable transaction and order data.

name: CryptoCustody Vault (Wallets + Transfers + Compliance)
description: CryptoCustody Vault is a custodial crypto platform for businesses managing wallets, transfers, and compliance workflows. Admins CRUD organizations, users, roles, wallets (per asset), deposit addresses (synthetic), whitelisted withdrawal addresses, and approval policies (single/multi-approver). Transactions include deposits, withdrawals, internal transfers, fees, confirmations (synthetic count), and statuses (pending, queued, broadcast, confirmed, failed, reversed). Compliance modules manage KYC profiles (structured fields), risk scores, sanctions screening flags, and case management (alerts, notes, attachments metadata). Workflows include withdrawal requests, policy-based approval chains, velocity limits, address verification, and incident responses (freeze wallet, lock user). Reconciliation endpoints provide ledger entries, balance snapshots per wallet, and historical holdings with timestamps. The platform supports webhook events for transaction lifecycle changes and exportable audit logs. Prices can be synthetic or sourced from an external feed, but core operations remain CRUD on wallets, transactions, and policies. This scenario is highly database-driven and realistic without requiring real blockchain interaction.

name: InvoiceFlow Payments (Invoicing + Subscriptions + Dunning)
description: InvoiceFlow Payments is a billing platform for SMBs that combines invoices, subscriptions, and payment collection. Users CRUD customers, contacts, products/services, price books, tax rates, invoice templates, and payment methods (tokenized). Invoices track line items, discounts, due dates, status (draft/sent/paid/overdue/void), and partial payments. Subscriptions manage plans, seats/quantities, proration rules, billing cycles, trial periods, and automatic renewals. The system generates charges, applies credits, and issues refunds with reason codes. Dunning workflows include configurable retry schedules, email reminders (template + send logs), account suspension flags, and write-offs. Businesses can create payment links, accept ACH/card (synthetic tokens), and reconcile payouts to bank deposits (synthetic settlement batches). Reporting includes AR aging, MRR/ARR, churn, and cohort retention—computed from subscription and payment events. Webhooks emit invoice.created, payment.succeeded, payment.failed, subscription.renewed, and payout.posted. All data—customers, documents, schedules, and ledgers—can be synthesized cleanly for API simulations.

name: MicroLend Portal (Digital Lending + Repayments)
description: MicroLend Portal is an online lending system for personal or small-business loans. Admins CRUD borrowers, identities (structured KYC fields), income/employment records (synthetic), loan products, interest models, fees, and underwriting rules. Applications capture requested amount, purpose codes, documents (metadata), and decision status (submitted, in-review, approved, declined). Underwriting results can be stored as rule evaluations and score outputs without requiring real bureaus. Approved loans generate contracts (metadata), disbursement instructions, amortization schedules, and ledger accounts. Repayments include scheduled installments, autopay mandates (token), payment attempts, NSF/failed payments, late fees, and adjustments. Workflows cover document collection, manual review queues, counteroffers, disbursement, repayment collection, hardship plans (modified schedule), and charge-off/collections status. The system supports customer self-service: view balance, payment history, payoff quotes, and submit extra payments. Compliance/audit features include change logs, notices (template + delivery status), and access controls by role. Core entities and lifecycle states are well-defined and fully synthesizable.

name: RecruitOps Studio (Agency Recruiting + Client Submittals)
description: RecruitOps Studio is a recruiting agency platform focused on client requisitions and candidate submittals. Agencies CRUD clients, contacts, contracts (rate cards, terms as structured fields), job requisitions, hiring managers, and recruiters. Candidates are managed with profiles, resumes (file metadata), skills, certifications, work authorization flags, and availability dates. For each requisition, recruiters create submittals that bundle candidate, proposed bill rate/pay rate, notes, and status (draft, submitted, interviewing, offer, placed, rejected). Interview scheduling includes timeslots, interviewers, and feedback forms (score + short comments). Placements generate assignment records with start/end dates, timesheet requirements, and invoicing triggers. Workflows include candidate pipelines per requisition, duplicate detection, compliance checklists, offer/acceptance tracking, and client approval steps. The system supports activity logging (calls, emails, meetings), task reminders, and document management (NDAs, right-to-represent metadata). Analytics endpoints return fill rates, time-to-submit, recruiter performance, and revenue projections based on placements and rate cards. All information can be synthesized while maintaining realistic recruiting operations.

name: TipPool Ledger (Restaurant Tips + Distribution + Payroll Export)
description: TipPool Ledger is a tip management platform for restaurants that calculates, allocates, and exports tips to payroll. Managers CRUD locations, roles (server, bartender, runner), eligibility rules, tip pool configurations (percent of sales, points system, hours-based), and POS integrations (synthetic sales imports). Daily inputs include shift records, clocked hours, sales by employee, cash tips declared, and card tips collected. The system computes allocations, tracks adjustments, and stores distribution runs with approvals and audit trails. Employees can view tip statements, disputes (case tickets), and payout preferences (cash vs paycheck). Workflows include end-of-shift closeout, manager review, dispute resolution, and locking periods to prevent edits after payroll export. The platform generates payroll export files (earnings lines per employee per pay period) and journal summaries by role and location. Compliance features include tip credit flags, minimum wage checks (rule-based), and reporting by day/week/month. This scenario is highly suitable for API simulation because the key entities—shifts, sales totals, rules, allocations, and exports—are structured and synthesizable.

name: CloudKitchens (Ghost Kitchen Facility + Vendor Console)
description: CloudKitchens is a platform for operating shared ghost-kitchen facilities where multiple brands run out of the same property. Facility operators CRUD buildings, units, equipment assets, access credentials, inspections, and maintenance work orders. Brand tenants CRUD brands, menus, operating hours, staff users, and delivery partner integrations. Orders from multiple channels are normalized into a unified schema (order, line items, modifiers, promised time, pickup method, courier info) and routed to the correct unit and KDS station. Kitchen operations include station configuration, ticket prioritization, batching, and SLA timers; each ticket has item-level statuses and exception codes (out-of-stock, courier no-show, remake). Inventory tools track shared or tenant-specific ingredients, receiving logs, par levels, and wastage entries. Property-management features include leases, rent schedules, utility allocations, invoices, payments, and delinquency states. Compliance workflows record temperature logs, cleaning checklists, incident reports, and training acknowledgements. Analytics dashboards are backed by CRUD-able metrics definitions (stations, time windows, KPIs) and export jobs, enabling synthetic but realistic operational datasets across tenants and facilities.

name: Upserve by Lightspeed (Table Service + Reservations + Menu Engineering)
description: Upserve by Lightspeed is a table-service restaurant platform combining POS, floor management, and performance analytics. Managers CRUD floor plans, sections, tables, server assignments, and shift schedules. Menu CRUD covers categories, items, modifiers, coursing, kitchen notes, and comp policies (discount types, approval thresholds). During service, staff open checks, attach guests to seats, fire courses, split/merge checks, transfer tables, and apply comps/voids with reason codes. Payments include multiple tenders, tips, refunds, and end-of-shift checkout records; cash management stores drawer opens/closes and variance notes. Reservations and waitlist workflows CRUD reservations, parties, quoted times, table assignments, and no-show flags, optionally linking to customer profiles with visit history and preferences. Inventory-lite features track vendor items, counts, and depletion estimates, while “menu engineering” stores recipe cost inputs, item profitability, and sales mix targets. Reporting workflows support daily summaries, staff performance, exception audits, and scheduled exports. All entities (orders, checks, items, shifts, reservations) are highly synthesizable for API testing with realistic restaurant operational states.

name: Marqeta (Card Issuing + Program Management)
description: Marqeta is a card issuing platform used by fintechs to create and manage debit/credit/prepaid programs. Program managers CRUD card products, funding sources, spend controls, merchant category rules, velocity limits, and fee schedules. Core entities include customers, accounts (program sub-ledgers), cards (virtual/physical), tokenization records, and authorized users. Transaction workflows include authorization requests, declines with reason codes, clearing, reversals, chargebacks/disputes, and adjustments; each event is stored as an immutable ledger entry with timestamps and balances-before/after. Controls allow real-time updates to card status (active/suspended/terminated), PIN set/reset, and dynamic authorization decisions based on synthetic risk signals or rules. Funding and settlement entities cover loads, payouts, interchange, and reconciliation files (metadata), enabling realistic back-office flows. Webhooks deliver event streams (auth/clearing/chargeback), and admins manage API keys, IP allowlists, and webhook endpoints. Reporting supports exporting transactions by program, cardholder, merchant, and date range. The platform is ideal for API simulation because transaction states, disputes, and controls can be generated deterministically without needing real banking data.

name: Airbnb-style Long-Term Rentals (Marketplace + Lease + Payments)
description: A long-term rental marketplace (30+ days) connects landlords and tenants with application, lease, and rent workflows. Landlords CRUD listings with property metadata (address, unit details, amenities, house rules), availability windows, pricing, deposits, and required documents (metadata). Tenants CRUD profiles, verification items (ID checks as status flags), saved searches, and applications containing employment/income fields (synthetic), references, and co-applicants. Booking-to-lease workflows transition from inquiry → application → approval → lease draft → signed → active; the lease entity stores term dates, rent schedule, utilities responsibility, and addenda. Payments include recurring rent invoices, autopay mandates, payment attempts, late fees, and receipts, plus deposit holding and release rules. Maintenance requests can be raised by tenants and tracked with statuses, vendor quotes, approvals, and completion. Messaging is modeled as conversation threads with message events and read states (short text). Dispute flows cover move-in condition claims, deposit deductions, and mediation outcomes. Reviews can be limited to structured ratings and short comments. The platform is highly suitable for synthesis: realistic listings, leases, payment ledgers, and operational states can be generated without relying on heavy content.

name: GitHub (Repositories + Issues + Projects for Engineering Workflows)
description: GitHub is a collaboration platform where the most meaningful simulation is repository and work management rather than hosting real code. Synthesizable entities include organizations, teams, members, repositories, branches (names), pull requests (metadata), commits (hash + message metadata), issues, labels, milestones, project boards, columns, cards, assignees, review requests, checks/statuses, releases (tags), and webhooks. Admins CRUD repos, permissions, branch protection rules, required checks, and automation settings. Workflows include creating issues from templates, triaging with labels and milestones, moving cards across project columns, opening pull requests, running review/approval gates, and merging with different strategies. CI-like checks can be represented as status objects with timestamps, log URL fields, and pass/fail conclusions. Release workflows track draft releases, attached artifacts (metadata), and deployment environments (staging/prod) with deployment statuses. Audit logs can capture membership changes and permission updates. This supports realistic API scenarios involving permissions, state machines, event streams, and cross-entity linkage without needing any content-heavy artifacts.

name: Square Appointments (Scheduling + Clients + Payments for Small Businesses)
description: Square Appointments is a scheduling and client management platform used by salons, clinics, and service businesses. Core entities include business locations, staff members, services, service variations (duration/price), availability rules, breaks, appointment slots, clients, client notes/tags, intake forms (structured fields), reminders, deposits, no-show policies, invoices/receipts, and payments (synthetic). Users CRUD services, staff calendars, online booking settings, and buffer times between appointments. Booking workflows include searching availability, creating an appointment, assigning staff and room/resource, confirming, rescheduling, canceling, and handling waitlists. Payments workflows cover requiring a card on file, collecting deposits, charging at check-in, adding tips, refunds, and issuing receipts. Operational tools include batch messaging to clients, tracking appointment statuses (pending/confirmed/arrived/completed/no-show), and generating daily schedules. Reporting summarizes utilization, revenue per service, and cancellation rates. The dataset is highly synthesizable: time slots, prices, customers, and transactional state changes create rich CRUD interactions ideal for API simulation.

name: Fresha (Salon & Spa Management: Booking, Staff, Inventory, Memberships)
description: Fresha is a salon/spa management platform combining bookings, POS, and client retention tools. Synthesizable entities include venues, rooms/resources, staff, services, packages, memberships, price lists, inventory items, suppliers, purchase orders, stock adjustments, clients, appointments, deposits, POS sales, gift cards (synthetic codes), loyalty points, and marketing campaigns (message metadata). Managers CRUD services with durations, pricing tiers, add-ons, and commission rules per staff role. Booking workflows support online booking links, appointment creation, confirmations, reschedules, cancellations with policy enforcement, and waitlists. At visit time, staff check in clients, add retail products to the ticket, apply discounts, redeem gift cards, take payments (tokenized), and generate receipts. Inventory workflows include receiving purchase orders, decrementing stock on retail sales, tracking low-stock thresholds, and running stocktakes with variance reasons. Membership workflows track recurring billing schedules, included services/credits, and renewal/cancellation states. Reporting summarizes client retention, revenue by staff/service, utilization by room, and product margin. The system’s structured records and transactional flows are ideal for realistic CRUD-centric API simulation.

name: CampusCloud Student Portal (SIS + Advising + Registration)
description: CampusCloud is a higher-ed student information system and self-service portal. Admins CRUD academic terms, programs, degree requirements, course catalog entries, sections (capacity, schedule blocks, room), instructors, and tuition/fee tables. Students CRUD their profile data (addresses, emergency contacts), add/drop sections, join waitlists, and build multi-term plans. Workflows include prerequisite and time-conflict checks, registration windows, holds (financial/disciplinary/advising), override requests, and enrollment confirmation. The platform tracks enrollments, grades, attendance flags, transcript records, and academic standing events. Advisors manage caseloads, advising notes (structured fields), appointment slots, degree audits, and approvals for exceptions/substitutions. Finance features cover billing statements, payment plan enrollment, scholarships/awards (amount, disbursement schedule), and refunds (status tracking). Integrations can be simulated via import endpoints for rosters and identity provisioning. Reports and dashboards read from normalized entities (students, sections, enrollments, payments), making it ideal for realistic CRUD and lifecycle states without needing external content.

name: SkillTrack LMS (SCORM-ish Courses + Assessments + Certificates)
description: SkillTrack is an LMS for corporate training or continuing education. Admins CRUD organizations, learners, groups, roles, courses, modules, lessons (video/file metadata, reading links), SCORM package records (metadata), quizzes, question banks, passing rules, and certificate templates. Instructors create course runs, enroll cohorts, assign due dates, and configure grading (auto vs manual). Learners enroll, track progress events (started, completed, time-spent), submit assignments (file metadata), attempt quizzes, and receive certificates with verification codes. Workflows include prerequisites, drip scheduling, retake rules, accommodations (extra time), proctoring flags (metadata), and completion audits. The system maintains gradebook entries, rubric scores, feedback comments, and revision histories. Notifications can be simulated as message records with delivery statuses. E-commerce is optional: products mapped to courses, coupons, invoices, and payment intents (synthetic tokens). A robust API surface exists for syncing users, pushing completions, and querying analytics (completion rate, average score) based entirely on synthesizable training data.

name: TutorMatch Scheduling Marketplace (Tutors, Packages, Sessions)
description: TutorMatch is a tutoring marketplace focused on scheduling, packages, and session management rather than content. Admins CRUD subjects, tutor profiles (bio fields, hourly rate, availability blocks), student profiles, service packages (5-session bundle, exam prep), and policies (cancellation windows, payout rules). Students search/filter tutors by subject, price, and time slots; create bookings; prepay packages; and message tutors via structured conversation threads. Tutors accept/decline requests, propose new times, log session outcomes (attendance, duration, notes, homework checklist), and track package balances. Workflows include intake questionnaires, trial lessons, reschedules, no-show handling, refund requests, and dispute tickets. The system tracks transactions (charges, tutor payouts, platform fees), coupon codes, invoices/receipts, and review records (rating + short text). Optional group tutoring supports session capacity and waitlists. Calendar sync is represented as external calendar event metadata. The database model (users, availability, bookings, payments, reviews) supports highly realistic API simulation with clear lifecycle statuses (requested/confirmed/completed/canceled).

name: ClinicaConnect Telehealth (Appointments + Visit Notes + Billing)
description: ClinicaConnect is a telehealth clinic platform centered on appointment and encounter workflows. Staff CRUD providers, specialties, clinic locations (including virtual), patient profiles, insurance policies (payer, member ID), fee schedules, and appointment types. Patients request visits, upload intake forms (structured answers), and manage consents. Scheduling supports provider calendars, buffers, eligibility checks, and reminders. During a visit, clinicians create encounter records with vitals, diagnoses (code + description), medications prescribed, lab/imaging orders, care plans, and follow-up tasks. Video is represented as session metadata (join URL token, start/end timestamps). Workflows include pre-visit verification, check-in, waiting room state, clinical documentation completion, coding, and claim submission records (status: queued/submitted/accepted/denied). Billing supports invoices, payments, copays, refunds, and payment plan status. Patient portal features include secure message threads, document downloads (visit summary metadata), and appointment history. All core entities—patients, appointments, encounters, orders, claims—are synthesizable, making it suitable for database-driven API environments without requiring medical content generation.

name: MyHospital Patient Portal (Results, Messaging, Referrals)
description: MyHospital is a patient portal for an integrated health system. Admins CRUD facilities, departments, providers, patient accounts, proxy access (parent/guardian), and communication preferences. Patients view and manage appointments, referral records, and care team lists; request refills; and send messages through categorized threads (billing question, clinical question). Clinical data is represented as structured results: lab panels with components and reference ranges, imaging orders with status (scheduled/completed/final), and immunization records. Workflows include referral creation by staff, patient scheduling from referral, prior-authorization tracking (requested/approved/denied), and document delivery (after-visit summary metadata). Patients can upload documents (insurance card metadata), complete questionnaires, and manage consents (HIPAA, release of information). Portal billing includes statements, payment methods (tokenized), installment plans, and receipts. Audit logs track record access and message reads. The platform is API-friendly because it relies on CRUD across well-defined entities (results, orders, referrals, messages, payments) with realistic state transitions, rather than content-heavy narratives.

name: LeaseLedger Property Management (Units, Leases, Maintenance, Rent)
description: LeaseLedger is a property management system for landlords and small managers. Admins CRUD properties, buildings, units (beds/baths, amenities), owners, vendors, tenants, and lease templates. Leasing workflows include application intake (household members, income fields), screening result flags (metadata), offer creation, lease execution (stored as document metadata), and move-in/move-out inspections with checklist items and photos metadata. Rent collection supports recurring charges, proration, late fees, payment methods (tokenized), ledgers, and receipts. Managers create maintenance tickets with categories, priority, photos metadata, assigned vendor, scheduled windows, and cost estimates; tickets track statuses (new/assigned/in-progress/completed/closed) and labor/material line items. The system also manages notices (renewal, pay-or-quit) as templated records, utility bill-backs, and security deposit accounting with deductions. Reporting queries rent roll, delinquency, vacancy, and maintenance spend by property/unit. The domain is highly CRUD-oriented with clear lifecycle transitions, making it a strong fit for database-driven API environments.

name: StayRentals Host Console (Short-Term Rental Ops + Turnovers)
description: StayRentals is a short-term rental host platform focused on operational workflows rather than content. Hosts CRUD listings (address, house rules, fees, min/max stay), calendars, seasonal rates, and availability blocks. Guests browse and request bookings; hosts approve/decline; and the system manages booking records with statuses (inquiry/confirmed/canceled/checked-in/checked-out). Pricing is computed from rate plans, taxes, cleaning fees, and discounts (all synthesizable). Turnover operations include housekeeping tasks, inspection checklists, issue reports, and inventory consumables (linens, toiletries) per property. Messaging uses conversation threads tied to bookings with templated quick replies. Security deposits are represented as holds (tokenized), with claim workflows for damages (evidence metadata, amount, resolution). Maintenance integrates with a work order module similar to property management but optimized for rapid turnovers. Multi-user teams support roles, assignments, and activity logs. Channel integrations are simulated via external booking import endpoints and calendar sync metadata. The platform’s core—listings, calendars, bookings, tasks, charges—supports realistic API testing with strong transactional integrity.

name: BuildBoard Course Marketplace (Creators, Cohorts, Coupons)
description: BuildBoard is a course platform where creators sell cohort-based classes and self-paced products. Creators CRUD schools, instructors, courses, cohorts (start/end dates, capacity), pricing tiers, coupons, and landing page fields (structured sections, not long-form). Learners create accounts, purchase enrollments, and access modules/lessons (file/video metadata), worksheets, and quizzes. Cohort workflows include waitlists, seat releases, live session schedules (calendar events metadata), attendance tracking, and cohort announcements (short text). Assignments support submissions (file metadata), rubric-based grading, and feedback comments. Commerce includes carts, orders, taxes, invoices, refunds, chargebacks (status only), and affiliate tracking links. Community features are limited to structured discussion threads and reactions, avoiding content-heavy requirements. Admin dashboards query metrics like MRR, completion rates, and cohort utilization using transactional data. The domain offers rich CRUD across course assets, enrollments, payments, and cohort operations, making it ideal for synthetic but realistic API simulations.

name: ClinicTrials Registry (Patient Recruitment + Visit Scheduling)
description: ClinicTrials is a clinical study registry and operations tool for research sites. Study admins CRUD protocols, sites, investigators, inclusion/exclusion criteria (structured rules), recruitment campaigns, and prescreen questionnaires. Participants create profiles, provide consent records (versioned), and submit prescreen responses. Coordinators manage screening cases, eligibility determinations, and scheduling of study visits with required procedures (lab draw, ECG) as checklist items. The system tracks participant status (prescreening/screening/enrolled/active/completed/withdrawn), adverse event reports (severity, dates, outcome), and visit forms with structured fields. Payments are handled as stipends with disbursement schedules and payout status (no real banking needed). Document handling is metadata-only (signed consent PDF reference, IRB approval letter metadata). Workflows include protocol amendments, re-consent, missed-visit handling, and audit trails for changes. The platform is highly database-centric and synthesizable, enabling realistic API scenarios around lifecycle tracking, scheduling, compliance logging, and role-based access without requiring narrative medical content.

name: ClinicLink (Multi-Specialty Patient Portal + Scheduling)
description: ClinicLink is a patient portal for outpatient clinics that centralizes registration, appointment scheduling, and clinical messaging. Staff CRUD clinics, providers, locations, appointment types, insurance plans (metadata), intake forms (sections/questions), and patient accounts. Patients CRUD demographics, contact preferences, emergency contacts, allergies/conditions lists, and saved pharmacies. Scheduling workflows include searching provider availability blocks, booking/rescheduling/canceling visits, waitlist enrollment, appointment reminders, and check-in with consent acknowledgments. Clinical workflows track encounters (visit reason, vitals, diagnosis codes as synthetic), care plans, follow-up tasks, and secure message threads between patients and care teams with attachments represented as file metadata. Billing features include statements, copays due, payment method tokens, and payment receipts. Audit logs capture field changes, message events, and appointment status transitions (requested/confirmed/checked-in/no-show/completed). Admin tools support role-based access, proxy access for caregivers, and configurable retention/visibility rules for sensitive items.

name: TeleVisitNow (Virtual Care Queue + Video Session Metadata)
description: TeleVisitNow is a telehealth platform for on-demand and scheduled virtual visits, focusing on operational workflows rather than media streaming. Admins CRUD clinician profiles, licenses (state/region), specialties, availability, pricing rules, triage questionnaires, and payer contracts (metadata). Patients create visit requests by selecting symptoms, preferred modality, and uploading photos as attachment metadata; the system places requests into triage queues with priority scores and SLA timers. Clinicians accept/decline, document encounter notes (structured fields), prescribe (order metadata), and generate after-visit summaries (short structured sections).
