Each visit generates a service record with check-in/out timestamps, route distance estimates, potty/feeding checklists, photo/file metadata, and a short visit report. The system tracks visit status (scheduled/en-route/started/completed/canceled/no-access) and supports emergency escalation (incident cases with timeline and contacts). Admin tools include sitter onboarding steps, background-check status (synthetic), messaging threads, and review moderation. APIs can expose availability, booking creation, and webhook updates for visit status changes—ideal for simulation with synthesized pets, schedules, and service logs.

name: VetClinic OS (Appointments + Treatments + Inventory)
description: VetClinic OS is a veterinary practice management portal for appointment scheduling and clinic operations. Staff CRUD clients, pets, species/breed catalogs, appointment types, providers, rooms, and schedules. Clinical workflows include creating visits, capturing vitals (weight, temperature), recording diagnoses (coded lists), treatment plans, administered medications, lab orders (test type, specimen, status), and vaccination records with reminders. Billing is modeled via invoices with line items (services, meds, supplies), payment methods (synthetic), discounts, and balances due. The platform includes pharmacy and inventory management: products, lots, expiration dates, reorder thresholds, purchase orders, and stock adjustments. Follow-up workflows include discharge instructions (short structured templates), recheck appointments, and client communications logged as events. Permissions separate receptionist, tech, vet, and manager roles with audit trails. Reporting dashboards show daily schedule, revenue summaries, vaccine due lists, and inventory turns using synthesizable metrics. APIs can integrate with online booking, reminders, and accounting exports, making it a robust CRUD simulation environment.

name: PawSupply Wholesale (B2B Pet Supplies Ordering Portal)
description: PawSupply Wholesale is a B2B ordering platform for pet stores, groomers, and shelters purchasing supplies in bulk. Admins CRUD supplier catalogs, SKUs, case packs, tiered pricing, minimum order quantities, warehouse locations, tax rules, and shipping methods. Business customers CRUD company profiles, users/roles, delivery addresses, payment terms (net-30, prepaid), and favorites lists. Ordering workflows include building carts, requesting quotes, converting quotes to purchase orders, placing orders, and tracking fulfillment (picked/packed/shipped/backordered/delivered). The system supports substitutions, partial shipments, returns authorizations (RMA), credit memos, and dispute cases for damages/shortages. Inventory is tracked by warehouse with available-to-promise quantities, incoming purchase orders, and allocation to orders. Promotions are structured (buy-X-get-Y, case discounts) and fully synthesizable. Customers can download invoices, view statements, and reconcile payments (synthetic transactions). APIs expose product search/filter, pricing lookup per account, order creation, and shipment status events—ideal for database-driven simulations without content dependencies.

name: HireFlow ATS (Applicant Tracking + Interview Ops)
description: HireFlow ATS is an applicant tracking system for startups and mid-sized companies. Recruiters CRUD companies, departments, jobs, hiring plans, scorecards, interview stages, and candidate sources. Candidates are entities with profiles, resumes (file metadata), structured work history, skills tags, and application records per job. Workflows include application intake, stage transitions (screen/phone/onsite/offer/rejected), scheduling interviews with availability blocks, collecting interviewer feedback forms (ratings + short notes), and generating offer packets (compensation fields, equity, start date) with approvals. The system supports email templates, task queues (reference checks, portfolio review), and compliance fields (EEO data stored separately). Hiring managers can compare candidates, request changes to job requisitions, and manage headcount status. Analytics dashboards track time-to-fill, source effectiveness, stage conversion, and interviewer turnaround using synthesizable metrics. Permissions and audit logs are first-class. APIs support posting jobs to a public board, ingesting applications from forms, and pushing hires to HRIS/payroll, making it an excellent CRUD + workflow simulator.

name: OnboardIQ HR (Onboarding + Training + Policy Acknowledgements)
description: OnboardIQ HR is an HR onboarding platform that combines checklists, required training modules, and policy acknowledgements. HR admins CRUD employee records, departments, managers, onboarding templates, tasks, document requests (file metadata), and training assignments. New hires complete profiles, enter personal/tax fields, choose benefits plans (structured options), and sign acknowledgements (timestamped consent records). Managers assign equipment requests (laptop, badge), schedule orientation sessions, and track completion of tasks across stakeholders (IT, facilities, finance). Training content is modeled as modules with sections, short quizzes, and completion criteria—no long-form content required. The system maintains policy versioning, re-acknowledgement campaigns, and compliance dashboards (who is overdue, expiring certifications). Workflows include automated reminders, escalation rules, and offboarding checklists with access revocation tasks and exit interview forms (structured responses). APIs can provision users via SCIM, sync employee status from payroll, and emit webhook events for task completion. This scenario is highly synthesizable: employees, tasks, documents, training status, and signatures.

name: Upwork (Freelance Marketplace)
description: Upwork is a services marketplace connecting clients and freelancers through postings, proposals, contracts, and milestone payments. In a simulated environment, users can CRUD client companies, freelancer profiles (skills, rates, availability), job posts (title, category, budget, screening questions), proposals (cover note short text, bid amount, estimated duration), interviews/messages (short), and contracts. Workflows include posting a job, receiving proposals, shortlisting, scheduling interviews, issuing an offer, and converting to a contract with milestones or hourly tracking entries (timesheets as synthetic durations). Contracts progress through states (offered/active/paused/ended) and can generate invoices, escrow holds, releases, refunds, and disputes with status timelines. Ratings and reviews are structured entities (score, tags, short feedback). Admin tools can include fraud flags, account verification states, and compliance checks (all synthetic). This produces multi-party interactions, negotiation and approval flows, and ledger-like records while keeping content minimal and fully synthesizable.

name: OpenTable for Restaurants (B2B Guest Management)
description: OpenTable’s core is guest seating management for restaurants, distinct from generic reservation apps by focusing on guest profiles, dining history, and demand controls. A simulation can model CRUD for restaurants/locations, table inventories, service periods, reservation slots, guest profiles (contact info synthetic, tags, allergies notes), and reservation records. Workflows include creating reservations from online channels, confirming/canceling, handling deposits/no-show fees (synthetic charges), and transitioning statuses (booked/confirmed/arrived/seated/completed/no-show). Hosts can assign tables, track wait times, merge/split parties, and record visit outcomes. Demand management includes blackout dates, pacing rules, slot overrides, and capacity constraints by area or shift. Marketing-like features can be modeled with campaigns (offer codes, targeted segments), messaging logs (sent/delivered), and guest segmentation queries (VIPs, frequent diners). Reporting endpoints can return covers per hour, turn times, no-show rate, and server section load. This provides strong scheduling, constraint solving, and high-volume transactional CRUD.

name: Coursera (Learning Management & Assessments)
description: Coursera is an online learning platform that can be simulated as an LMS with structured course administration rather than content hosting. Entities include organizations, instructors, learners, courses, sessions/cohorts, modules, lessons (metadata only), quizzes (questions, options, correct answers), assignments (rubrics, due dates), enrollments, grades, certificates, and discussion threads (short posts). Workflows cover course creation, publishing to a session, learner enrollment, prerequisite checks, progress tracking (lesson completion events), quiz attempts with scoring, assignment submissions as file metadata, peer review allocations, and certificate issuance when requirements are met. Admins manage roles, access controls, paid plans (subscriptions or one-time purchases), and refund eligibility windows. Analytics endpoints can provide completion rates, average scores by module, cohort retention, and engagement metrics (logins, time spent as synthetic durations). This scenario yields rich relational data, rule-based gating, assessment pipelines, and time-based scheduling without needing long-form educational content.

name: Smartsheet (Work Management & Automation)
description: Smartsheet is a spreadsheet-like work management tool combining tables, forms, approvals, and automation. A synthable API can expose CRUD for workspaces, sheets, columns (types, validation rules), rows (cells, attachments metadata), views (grid/card/calendar), forms (field mappings), and users/permissions. Workflows include submitting a form to create a row, assigning owners, updating status fields, and triggering automations: alerts, reminders, approval requests, row moves between sheets, and task creation. Dependencies and dates support Gantt-style scheduling (predecessors, durations, critical path flags). Comments, change history, and activity logs record user actions. Dashboards can aggregate metrics across sheets (counts by status, overdue items, workload by assignee) using synthetic calculations. Integrations can be simulated with webhook listeners and outgoing event payloads on row create/update/delete. This scenario tests flexible schemas, bulk operations, optimistic concurrency, and automation rules—ideal for database-driven API environments with realistic enterprise collaboration patterns.

name: Verkada (Physical Security & Access Control)
description: Verkada is a physical security platform combining device management, access control, and event logs. A synth environment can model CRUD for organizations, sites, doors, access controllers, cameras (metadata), sensors, users, access groups, credentials (badge IDs, mobile tokens), schedules, and policies. Workflows include provisioning a device to a site, assigning doors to controllers, granting users credentials, and defining access rules by schedule and door group. Access events are structured logs (timestamp, door, user/credential, result granted/denied, reason codes) and can trigger alerts or incident cases. Camera functionality can be simulated via clip metadata (start/end times, camera ID, tags) without real video. Admins can create incident reports that collect related access events and device alerts, assign investigators, and track status (open/in review/closed). Health monitoring records device online/offline, firmware versions, and signal metrics. This supports realistic IoT-style fleets, authorization checks, time-window constraints, and high-volume event ingestion while keeping all data synthesizable.

name: EnergyCAP (Utility Bill Management for Enterprises)
description: EnergyCAP is a utility management platform used by organizations to track electricity, gas, and water accounts, bills, meters, and cost allocations. In a simulated API, users can CRUD facilities (sites/buildings), utility accounts, meters, rate plans, vendors, bills, line items (usage, demand, fees, taxes), and payments. Workflows include importing bills (manual entry or batch upload), validating against expected ranges, allocating costs to departments or cost centers, and approving bills for payment with an audit trail. Meter readings can be recorded as time-series entries (start/end dates, kWh/therms/gallons) with computed deltas and anomalies. Budgets and forecasts can store monthly targets and variance calculations. Reporting endpoints can return consumption by facility, peak demand trends, emissions factors (static), and exception queues (missing bills, outliers, estimated reads). This scenario offers strong transactional CRUD, time-series data, reconciliation/approval flows, and finance-style reporting without relying on any non-synthesizable content.

name: HubSpot CRM
description: HubSpot CRM is a sales and marketing database for managing customer relationships and pipeline activity. Users CRUD contacts, companies, deals, pipelines/stages, tasks, meetings, and notes. Workflows include lead capture from forms (structured fields), deduplication/merge, assigning owners, moving deals through stages (qualified/proposal/negotiation/closed won/lost), and logging activities (calls/emails as metadata). Associations between entities (contact ↔ company ↔ deal) are central and can be exercised via API. Teams configure properties (custom fields), lead scoring (rule-based numeric scores), automated workflows (if stage changes then create task), and sequences (scheduled follow-ups). Marketing objects include lists/segments, campaign tags, and email events (sent/opened/clicked as synthetic tracking). Reporting includes pipeline velocity, win rate, activity volume, and forecast by close date. Permissions and audit logs support multi-user simulation. Because the platform is fundamentally structured records, relationships, and status-driven workflows, all datasets can be realistically generated without needing real marketing content or external search/recommendation systems.

name: HireLoop ATS
description: HireLoop ATS is an applicant tracking system for fast-growing companies to manage recruiting pipelines end-to-end. Admins CRUD companies, departments, locations, hiring plans, job requisitions, and scorecard templates (competencies, weighting, pass/fail criteria). Recruiters publish jobs to connected job boards, create candidate records (source, resume file metadata, tags), and move candidates through stages (applied, screened, interview, offer, hired, rejected) with timestamps and reasons. Interview coordination supports CRUD interview plans, interviewer assignments, availability blocks, and scheduled interview events (virtual or onsite) with feedback forms, ratings, and debrief notes. Offer workflows include creating compensation packages (salary, bonus, equity), generating offer letters from templates, collecting e-sign acknowledgments (metadata), and tracking approvals. Compliance features store consent, EEOC/OFCCP optional fields, and retention policies. Integrations can be simulated via API tokens for background checks and assessments, with webhook-style status callbacks (initiated/in-progress/clear/consider). Reporting endpoints summarize funnel conversion, time-to-fill, and recruiter workload—all with fully synthesizable candidate and job data.

name: CredentialCheck Pro (Healthcare Recruiting)
description: CredentialCheck Pro is a healthcare credentialing and onboarding platform used by hospitals and staffing agencies to verify clinicians before placement. Users CRUD facilities, departments, roles (RN, NP, MD), clinician profiles, licenses (state, number, expiration), certifications (BLS/ACLS), education, work history, and required immunizations. Each placement request defines start/end dates, shift patterns, pay package terms, and facility-specific credential checklists. Workflows track credential tasks (requested, received, verified, expired) with due dates, assignees, and audit trails. Document handling is modeled as file metadata (title, type, issue date, expiration) and verification notes rather than actual files. The platform supports primary-source verification events, background screen cases, drug test orders, and references as structured records with statuses. Expiration monitoring generates renewal tasks and notification logs. Placement approvals include multi-step signoff (recruiter, compliance, facility admin) with decision timestamps and comments. APIs allow querying clinician readiness for a specific facility, listing missing items, and exporting a credential packet summary for downstream systems.

name: GigLedger Contractor Payments
description: GigLedger is a contractor onboarding and payouts platform for marketplaces and gig businesses. Operators CRUD clients, projects/gigs, contractor profiles, tax forms (W-9/W-8 metadata), compliance checklists, and payment methods (tokenized bank/card). Workflows start with onboarding invitations, identity verification steps (status only), and contract acceptance (template + acknowledgment metadata). Earnings are tracked as jobs completed with line items (base pay, tips, bonuses, platform fees) and dispute flags. The payouts module batches eligible earnings into payment runs, supports payout schedules (daily/weekly), and records payout transactions with statuses (queued/sent/failed/returned) and failure reasons. Adjustments allow clawbacks, manual credits, and chargebacks, each with references to original jobs. The platform can generate 1099 summaries as structured totals by contractor and tax year, plus consent and delivery status. APIs let clients create jobs, submit completion events, compute net earnings, and initiate payouts. Webhooks simulate processor callbacks for payout success/failure. Everything—jobs, amounts, dates, statuses, and identities—can be synthesized while still matching real operational patterns.

name: CarePortal EHR Lite
description: CarePortal EHR Lite is a patient portal and clinic workflow system for small practices. Staff CRUD patients, insurance profiles, providers, appointments, visit types, clinical notes (structured fields like chief complaint, vitals, ICD/CPT codes), and care plans. Patients can request appointments, update demographics, complete intake questionnaires, and view visit summaries and lab result records (numeric values, reference ranges, flags). Messaging supports CRUD message threads between patient and clinic with categories (billing, clinical, refills) and SLA tracking. Billing workflows create encounters, charges, claims (payer, status, denial codes), patient statements, and payment records (synthetic) with balances. Consent management stores consent artifacts as metadata, with effective dates and revocation. The platform also tracks tasks such as prior authorizations and referrals, each with assignees, due dates, and statuses. APIs provide endpoints for appointment availability, patient record retrieval, posting vitals/labs, and updating claim status, enabling realistic database-driven simulations without requiring actual medical media or long narrative content.

name: VideoVisit Telehealth Suite
description: VideoVisit is a telehealth operations platform for virtual clinics and specialist networks. Admins CRUD clinics, provider profiles, state licenses, availability schedules, appointment slots, visit fees, and triage protocols. Patients create accounts, store preferred pharmacies, and request on-demand or scheduled visits with symptoms selected from controlled vocabularies. Visits are tracked as sessions with statuses (requested, triaged, scheduled, in-waiting-room, in-progress, completed, no-show). Triage nurses manage queues, assign providers, and capture structured intake (allergies, meds list, vitals self-reported, questionnaire responses). Providers document visit outcomes using templates: diagnosis codes, treatment plan, follow-up instructions, and orders (labs, imaging, referrals) as structured entities. Prescriptions are created as eRx records with drug, dosage, quantity, refills, and transmission status (queued/sent/failed). Payments and copays are recorded as synthetic transactions; refunds and charge reversals are tracked with reasons. Communication includes visit chat messages and post-visit survey ratings. APIs cover slot search, visit creation, queue management, documentation updates, and webhook notifications for status changes—ideal for simulating end-to-end telehealth workflows.

name: MediFill Pharmacy Hub
description: MediFill Pharmacy Hub is a pharmacy management and refill coordination platform for independent pharmacies and small chains. Users CRUD patients, prescribers, insurance plans, medication catalogs (NDC, form, strength), prescriptions, refill requests, and inventory lots (quantity on hand, expiration, location). Prescription workflows track intake (eRx/manual), adjudication outcomes (paid/rejected with reject codes), prior authorization tasks, and dispensing events (filled, verified, picked up, delivered). Each prescription has fill history with timestamps, days supply, copay amounts, and pickup method. The inventory module handles purchasing orders, receiving, cycle counts, and automatic reorder rules based on par levels. Delivery workflows include courier batches, route stops, and proof-of-delivery metadata (signature flag, delivered time). Clinical services can be modeled via vaccine appointments and medication therapy management (MTM) cases with action items and outcomes. Billing exports produce claim batches and reconciliation records against payer remittances (synthetic). APIs support creating refills, checking stock availability, reserving inventory for a fill, posting dispensing updates, and generating patient adherence reports.

name: BankOps Digital Banking Sandbox
description: BankOps is a digital banking platform simulator for retail banking operations. Admins CRUD customers, KYC profiles, accounts (checking, savings), cards (tokenized PAN), beneficiaries, and product configurations (fees, interest tiers). Customers can initiate transfers (internal, ACH-like), schedule bill payments to payees, set up recurring transfers, and manage alerts and spending limits. Transaction ledgers store debits/credits with merchant descriptors, categories, posting vs pending states, and dispute flags. Card workflows include virtual card issuance, freeze/unfreeze, replacement orders, and chargeback cases with evidence metadata and status timelines. Compliance features model suspicious activity cases, holds, and enhanced due diligence tasks. Statements are generated as period summaries with line items and delivery status. The platform includes a rules engine for limits (daily transfer caps, velocity checks) and exception queues for manual review. APIs expose endpoints for balance/transaction queries, posting transactions, initiating transfers, and simulating asynchronous settlement via webhooks (accepted/returned/reversed). All financial data, merchants, and events are synthesizable while maintaining realistic banking behavior.

name: PortfolioPilot Investments
description: PortfolioPilot is an investment account and portfolio management platform for brokerages or advisor firms, designed around CRUD and lifecycle operations rather than real market feeds. Users CRUD clients, risk profiles, investment accounts (taxable, IRA), model portfolios, holdings, and watchlists. The system records orders (buy/sell), order types (market/limit), and execution events (submitted, partially filled, filled, canceled) with synthetic prices and timestamps. Corporate actions are modeled as events (dividends, splits) that adjust holdings and create ledger entries. Funding workflows include deposits/withdrawals, transfers between accounts, and cash management sweeps. Advisors can create proposals, rebalance requests, and compliance notes, then route them through approvals. Performance reporting generates time-weighted returns based on stored price snapshots (synthetic) and produces statements as metadata. Suitability and compliance modules store investment policy constraints (restricted tickers, max sector exposure), and each order is validated against rules with reject reasons. APIs cover account creation, placing orders, retrieving positions, generating performance summaries, and posting price snapshots—allowing realistic trading simulations without requiring real-time market data.

name: CryptoCustody & Exchange Ops
description: CryptoCustody & Exchange Ops is a cryptocurrency wallet, custody, and trading operations platform focused on account and transaction lifecycle management. Users CRUD customers, wallets (hot/cold labels), blockchain addresses, whitelisted withdrawal destinations, and supported assets. Deposits and withdrawals are represented as on-chain transaction records with statuses (detected, pending confirmations, confirmed, failed, reversed) and synthetic tx hashes. Trading supports order books per asset pair with limit/market orders, fills, fees, and account-level balances; settlement moves assets between available and locked balances. Compliance features include travel-rule style beneficiary records, risk scores, sanctions screening results (status only), and case management for flagged transactions. Security workflows include 2FA enrollment status, API keys, IP allowlists, and withdrawal holds. The platform supports staking products as positions with rewards accrual entries and unbonding periods. Custody operations model multi-approval withdrawals (request, review, approve, broadcast) with signer roles and audit logs. APIs provide wallet creation, address generation, posting deposit events, placing/canceling orders, and webhooks for confirmation updates—fully synthesizable while remaining operationally realistic.

name: CarePath Patient Portal (Multi-Clinic EHR Lite)
description: CarePath is a patient portal used by outpatient clinics to manage appointments, records, and billing in a structured, API-friendly way. Patients CRUD profiles, contact details, insurance policies, preferred pharmacy, emergency contacts, and communication preferences. Core workflows include requesting/scheduling appointments (provider, location, reason, time slot), completing pre-visit questionnaires, uploading documents (file metadata), and checking in with forms and consent acknowledgements. The portal exposes clinical record objects that are synthesizable: problem list entries, allergies, immunizations, vitals, lab orders/results (numeric ranges, flags), visit summaries, care plans, and referral requests. Messaging is modeled as threads with participants, timestamps, and attachment metadata (no long freeform content required). Billing features include invoices, line items (CPT/HCPCS codes as static catalogs), payments (synthetic transactions), statements, and payment plans. Admin/staff APIs manage providers, clinic locations, schedules, appointment types, capacity rules, and patient panel assignments. Audit logs track record access and updates, enabling realistic compliance-oriented event histories.

name: PulseClinic Telehealth (On-Demand + Scheduled Visits)
description: PulseClinic is a telehealth platform centered on scheduling, eligibility checks, and visit lifecycle tracking rather than media streaming. Patients CRUD accounts, household members (dependents), symptoms/intake forms, state/location for licensure, and preferred communication channels. Visits are created as cases with structured fields: visit type (urgent care, dermatology, behavioral health), triage score, queue position, assigned clinician, and status (requested/queued/assigned/in-session/completed/canceled). The system supports insurance verification (policy, payer, coverage flags), co-pay estimation (synthetic), and payment capture records. Clinicians CRUD encounter notes as templated sections (checkboxes, coded diagnoses, medications) to avoid long narrative content; they can create prescriptions, lab orders, work notes (metadata), and follow-up tasks. Operational entities include clinician profiles, licenses, availability blocks, shift rosters, service regions, and clinical protocols with versioning. Post-visit workflows cover discharge instructions templates, patient satisfaction ratings, refund requests, and incident reporting. APIs naturally simulate webhooks for status changes (visit assigned, visit completed, prescription issued) and SLA metrics (time-to-first-response, abandonment rate).

name: MediDose Pharmacy Hub (Refills, Transfers, Delivery)
description: MediDose is an online pharmacy experience focused on prescription management and fulfillment workflows. Users CRUD patient profiles, addresses, insurance details, allergies, preferred pickup location, and caregiver access. Prescription entities include Rx number, drug (NDC catalog), dosage, quantity, refills remaining, prescriber (directory), directions (short text), and status (new/refill requested/in review/ready/dispensed/shipped/on hold). Workflows include requesting refills, initiating transfers from another pharmacy, setting auto-refill, choosing pickup vs delivery windows, and tracking shipment events. The platform supports prior authorization tasks as structured cases: payer, required forms, requested dates, outcome (approved/denied/needs info). Users can manage medication reminders and adherence logs (taken/skipped/reason). Retail add-ons are modeled as a small catalog (OTC items), carts, orders, coupons, and returns—fully synthesizable. Pharmacy staff APIs manage inventory lots (expiration, on-hand), dispensing queues, substitutions (generic allowed), cold-chain flags, and counseling acknowledgements. Claims/billing uses transaction records, copay amounts, reversals, and receipts (metadata), enabling realistic payment and reconciliation scenarios without needing real clinical content.

name: CardioTrack RPM (Remote Patient Monitoring Dashboard)
description: CardioTrack is a remote patient monitoring platform for chronic-care programs where device data and care-team tasks are first-class entities. Patients are enrolled into programs with start/end dates, monitoring plans, thresholds, and assigned care teams. Devices (BP cuff, scale, pulse oximeter) are CRUDed with serial numbers, pairing tokens, firmware versions, and last-seen timestamps. Readings are time-series records (systolic/diastolic, weight, SpO2, pulse) with flags (normal/high/critical) and provenance (manual/device). Workflows include alert generation from threshold rules, escalation routes (nurse review -> provider), outreach tasks (call/SMS/email as synthetic logs), and resolution notes via structured fields (action taken, outcome code). The platform supports patient check-ins (symptom scores), medication adherence events, and appointment scheduling for follow-ups. Billing is modeled through RPM billing cycles, eligibility checks, time-spent logs (minutes), and claim submissions (codes, statuses). Admin APIs manage clinics, staff roles, patient consent, device inventory pools, threshold templates, and report schedules. This scenario is ideal for API simulation because it mixes CRUD, event streams, role-based access, and analytics-friendly aggregates (weekly averages, adherence rates) from fully synthesizable numeric data.

name: NovaBank Digital (Accounts, Cards, Loans, Alerts)
description: NovaBank Digital is a consumer banking portal emphasizing structured finance objects and lifecycle workflows. Users CRUD customer profiles, KYC documents (metadata), beneficiaries, external payees, linked accounts, and notification rules. Core entities include deposit accounts, credit cards, and personal loans with balances, statements, interest rates, limits, and due dates. Transaction ledgers are fully synthesizable: postings, pending/settled states, categories, merchant descriptors, and dispute flags. Users can initiate transfers (internal/external), bill payments, recurring schedules, and wire requests with approval steps. Card management supports virtual cards, spend controls, travel notices, replacement requests, and tokenized wallets (synthetic tokens). Lending workflows include applications (income, employment, offers), underwriting decisions (rule-based), funding events, repayment schedules, and payoff quotes. The portal includes secure messaging modeled as ticket threads, plus service requests (address change, stop payment, check reorder). Admin/back-office APIs manage products, fees, rate tables, fraud rules, holds, and case management (chargeback/dispute cases with evidence metadata). Audit logs, idempotent transfer endpoints, and webhooks for posting events provide realistic banking-style integration patterns without requiring real market data.

name: IndexForge Investing (Brokerage, Portfolios, Corporate Actions)
description: IndexForge is a brokerage-style investing platform designed for portfolio CRUD and order-lifecycle simulation with synthetic price feeds. Users manage accounts (individual, IRA), cash balances, watchlists, and tax lots. Securities are referenced via a static instrument master (tickers, asset class, exchange) while prices can be generated deterministically for testing. Order workflows cover market/limit/stop orders with states (created/routed/partially filled/filled/canceled/rejected), timestamps, and execution records. Holdings update through fills, dividends, splits, and fees, all captured as ledger entries. The platform includes deposits/withdrawals, transfer-of-assets requests, and recurring investing plans. Risk and compliance can be modeled via suitability profiles, trading permissions, and pattern-day-trader flags. Statements and confirmations are generated as metadata objects with line items rather than PDFs. Corporate actions (dividend, split, symbol change) are stored as event entities applied to holdings. Admin APIs manage instrument onboarding, fee schedules, order routing rules, and customer support tickets. This scenario supports rich database interactions (lots, positions, orders, events) and deterministic replay of market days for integration testing.

name: BlockHarbor Exchange (Spot Crypto + Custody)
description: BlockHarbor is a cryptocurrency exchange and custody platform focused on account, wallet, and compliance workflows rather than real blockchain connectivity. Users CRUD identity/KYC profiles, risk questionnaires, whitelisted withdrawal addresses, API keys, and security settings (2FA devices, recovery codes). Assets are defined in an instrument catalog (BTC, ETH, USDC) with synthetic network metadata. Wallets track available/locked balances; deposits and withdrawals are modeled as transfer records with statuses (initiated/pending/completed/failed), confirmations count (synthetic), and fee breakdowns. Trading supports spot order books via generated quotes, placing/canceling orders, and fill events; all records are persisted for auditability. Compliance workflows include travel-rule information capture (beneficiary, VASP), transaction monitoring alerts (rule-based flags), and case management with dispositions. The platform also supports staking programs as positions with lockups, reward accrual entries, and unstake requests. Reporting entities include trade history exports (metadata), realized P&L summaries, and tax lots. Admin APIs manage asset listings, fee tiers, limits, compliance rules, and incident response (account freeze/unfreeze). The system is highly synthesizable while still reflecting realistic crypto exchange state machines and ledger behavior.

name: PayFlow Merchant Studio (Invoices, Subscriptions, Payouts)
description: PayFlow Merchant Studio is a payments platform for small businesses to create invoices, accept checkout payments, and manage recurring billing. Merchants CRUD business profiles, staff roles, customers, products/services, tax rates, coupons, and branding settings. Invoices include line items, due dates, payment links, reminder schedules, and statuses (draft/sent/viewed/paid/overdue/void). Subscriptions manage plans, seat/usage quantities, proration rules, trial periods, and lifecycle events (activated/paused/canceled/past due). Payment objects are modeled as intents/authorizations/captures/refunds with processor response codes (synthetic), dispute cases, and evidence metadata. Payouts track settlement batches, fees, and reconciliation to invoices and subscriptions. The platform includes a lightweight POS catalog (items, modifiers) and checkout sessions for one-time purchases. Webhooks simulate real integrations: payment_succeeded, invoice_overdue, dispute_opened, payout_paid. Risk controls include velocity limits, customer allow/deny lists, and manual review queues. Admin APIs manage merchant onboarding (KYC fields), pricing, feature flags, and support tickets. This scenario yields rich CRUD plus event-driven flows without needing any non-synthesizable content.

name: ProCircle Network (Professional Profiles + Referrals)
description: ProCircle is a professional networking platform optimized for structured profile data, connections, and referral workflows. Users CRUD profiles (headline, skills tags, locations), employment history, certifications, portfolio links, availability for projects, and contact preferences. Network entities include connection requests, connections, follows, and private groups with membership roles. Instead of long content feeds, the platform focuses on actionable objects: job/project postings (title, rate range, required skills, location/remote, status), applications (answers as short text, attachments metadata), and referrals (referrer, candidate, company, stage). Messaging is represented as conversation threads with timestamps and optional attachments metadata. Reputation is modeled through endorsements (skill + endorser), short recommendations (bounded length), and verified badges (certification checks). Organizations can CRUD company pages, team rosters, open roles, and candidate pipelines with stages (new/screen/interview/offer/hired/closed). Analytics entities include profile views, application funnel counts, and response-time metrics—fully synthetic. Admin features cover moderation actions, abuse reports, and audit trails. This scenario supports complex relational data (users-orgs-roles-postings-applications) and realistic enterprise-style permissions.

name: HeartLink Dating (Matches, Preferences, Safety Tools)
description: HeartLink is a dating platform centered on profile CRUD, matching constraints, and conversation workflows. Users create and manage profiles (photos as file metadata, bio bounded length, interests tags, lifestyle fields), discovery preferences (age range, distance, intent, dealbreakers), and visibility settings. Discovery results can be generated from synthetic user pools and geo-coordinates. Core actions include likes, passes, super-likes, match creation when mutual, and unmatching. Conversations are modeled as threads with message objects, read receipts, and optional media metadata; no AI or content ranking is required. Safety and trust features are structured: identity verification status, selfie checks (metadata), block/report cases with categories and outcomes, and date-check-in plans (location, time, emergency contact) as shareable records. Premium features are easy to simulate: subscriptions, boosts, rewind, and who-liked-you lists. Events include profile updates, match timestamps, and activity indicators. Admin/moderator APIs manage flagged accounts, report queues, evidence metadata, sanctions (warning, shadowban, ban), and appeals. The platform naturally supports rate limiting, privacy controls, and audit logging, making it strong for API testing with realistic state transitions.

name: LedgerLane (Digital Checking + Bills + Shared Budgets)
description: LedgerLane is a digital banking web/app experience centered on everyday money management. Users CRUD customer profiles, KYC verification records (status, timestamps), linked funding sources (cards/bank accounts as tokenized instruments), checking/savings accounts, beneficiaries, and account limits. Core workflows include creating payees, scheduling one-time and recurring bill payments, internal transfers between accounts, and external transfers with pending/posted/failed statuses and reversal handling. Users can manage virtual cards, set spend controls, and create shared “spaces” for couples/roommates with permissions, contribution rules, and transaction categorization. The system stores transactions, merchant metadata, categories, memos, attachments (receipt metadata), disputes/chargebacks, and alerts (low balance, large purchase). Administrative tools manage fee schedules, interest rules, account holds, and audit logs. API simulation is strong: you can synthesize balances, ledger entries, authorization holds, settlement events, statements, and notifications while exercising realistic banking CRUD plus stateful workflows like canceling a scheduled payment, reissuing a virtual card, or freezing an account.

name: InvoiceHarbor (SMB Invoicing + Subscriptions + Payments)
description: InvoiceHarbor is a small-business invoicing and receivables platform. Businesses CRUD organizations, customers, contacts, product/service catalog items, tax rates, invoice templates, and payment terms. Users generate estimates, convert them to invoices, apply discounts, add line items, and manage invoice states (draft/sent/viewed/partially paid/paid/overdue/void). Payment workflows include creating payment links, recording payments (card/ACH/cash), issuing refunds, and handling failed payments with retry schedules. Subscription billing supports plans, metered usage records, proration, renewals, cancellations, and dunning rules. The database tracks payouts, fees, reconciliation batches, and ledger mappings to accounting categories. Users can create recurring invoices, automate reminders, and manage team roles/permissions. Supporting entities include attachments (file metadata), notes, email delivery logs, webhooks, and dispute cases. All data is synthesizable: invoice totals, due dates, line-item quantities, statuses, and timelines can be generated to exercise CRUD-heavy APIs and lifecycle transitions end-to-end.

name: TradeFolio Pro (Brokerage Orders + Portfolio + Tax Lots)
description: TradeFolio Pro is an investment brokerage simulation focused on portfolio operations rather than real market feeds. Users CRUD investor profiles, suitability/risk questionnaires, brokerage accounts (cash/margin), watchlists, and funding instructions. Trading workflows include placing orders (market/limit/stop), modifying/canceling open orders, and tracking order states (queued/routed/partially filled/filled/rejected/canceled). The system stores executions, positions, cost basis lots (FIFO/LIFO), corporate actions (splits/dividends as synthetic events), and realized/unrealized P&L snapshots. Users can create model portfolios, rebalance by target allocations, and generate trade proposals requiring approval. Additional entities include deposits/withdrawals, cash sweeps, statements, tax documents (metadata), and restricted symbol lists. Compliance-style features include trade confirmations, best-execution notes (short text), and audit logs. All numeric values (prices, fills, fees) and timestamps are synthesizable, enabling rich API interactions like partial fills, wash sale adjustments, and portfolio performance queries without needing real-time pricing.

name: CoinCustody Hub (Crypto Wallets + Transfers + Compliance)
description: CoinCustody Hub is a cryptocurrency wallet and custody platform for retail or small institutions. Users CRUD identities, KYC/KYB cases, wallets (hot/cold labels), blockchain addresses, address books, whitelisted withdrawal destinations, and multi-user approval policies. Core workflows include initiating deposits (address assignment), creating withdrawal requests, enforcing approval chains (pending/approved/rejected/expired), and generating on-chain transaction records with confirmations as synthesized status updates. The platform tracks internal transfers, fees, network selection, memos/tags, and travel-rule style counterparties (name, jurisdiction, risk rating). Security operations include setting up MFA devices, creating API keys, rotating secrets, and freezing wallets. Risk/compliance entities include screening hits, case notes, disposition codes, and reporting exports. Asset management covers supported tokens, token metadata, and balance snapshots per wallet. Because the platform is ledger- and status-driven, it’s ideal for API simulation: realistic CRUD on wallets/addresses, state transitions for approvals/confirmations, and auditable event histories without requiring real blockchain connectivity.

name: EscrowSprint (Milestone Escrow for Freelance & B2B Deals)
description: EscrowSprint manages escrowed payments tied to milestones for freelance projects and B2B services. Users CRUD buyer and seller profiles, organizations, contracts, milestones, deliverables (file metadata), and acceptance criteria. Funding workflows include creating an escrow deposit request, recording incoming payments, and allocating funds across milestones with statuses (unfunded/funded/in review/accepted/disputed/released/refunded). Parties can submit deliverables, request changes, approve acceptance, or open disputes with reason codes, evidence items, and mediator assignments. The platform maintains a ledger of holds, releases, fees, and payout instructions, plus tax forms (metadata) and compliance flags. Notifications, messaging threads, and timeline events capture the negotiation and fulfillment process without needing long-form content. Admins can define fee schedules, dispute SLAs, and auto-release rules. Everything is synthesizable: contract amounts, milestone dates, dispute outcomes, and escrow balances make for robust database-driven APIs with clear, testable lifecycle transitions.

name: CircleSquare (Neighborhood Social Groups + Events + Moderation)
description: CircleSquare is a community social platform organized around neighborhoods and interest circles. Users CRUD profiles, verification badges (optional), neighborhood membership, circles/groups, and roles (member/moderator/admin). Content is short-form and structured: posts with categories (lost & found, recommendations, alerts), comments, reactions, and attachments (image/file metadata only). Workflows include creating events, RSVPs, event check-ins, and posting updates. Marketplace-lite features support listing items to give away or sell locally (title, price, condition, pickup window) with reserved/sold statuses and message threads. Moderation tools are first-class: report queues, rule violations, takedown actions, temporary mutes/bans, and appeal tickets. The system tracks notifications, saved posts, and digest subscriptions. This is highly synthesizable because entities are compact and stateful; you can generate realistic users, posts, group permissions, reports, and event attendance while exercising CRUD, pagination, feeds (without ranking complexity), and moderation workflows.

name: ThreadFoundry (Q&A Forum + Tags + Reputation)
description: ThreadFoundry is a structured Q&A forum focused on searchable threads without relying on real web search. Users CRUD accounts, profiles, topic tags, questions, answers, comments, and votes. The platform enforces workflows such as accepting an answer, editing with revision history, closing/reopening questions with reason codes, and awarding reputation points and badges based on synthesized rules. Moderation entities include flags, review tasks, spam actions, and suspension records. Community management includes tag synonyms, tag wikis (short descriptions), and curated topic collections. The database captures activity logs, notification subscriptions, and saved searches (stored queries as text). For API simulation, you can generate realistic thread lifecycles: a question moves from asked to answered, edited, and possibly closed; votes adjust scores; accepted answers change visibility; and review queues process flags. All content can remain short and templated, making data easy to synthesize while still enabling complex CRUD and permission logic.

name: ProLink Atlas (Professional Network + Hiring Pipelines)
description: ProLink Atlas is a professional networking and recruiting platform emphasizing structured data over long posts. Users CRUD profiles (skills, titles, employment history), companies, teams, and connection relationships (requested/accepted/blocked). Recruiters and hiring managers CRUD job postings, screening questions, candidate pipelines, stages (applied/screen/interview/offer/hired/rejected), interview schedules, scorecards, and offer packages (compensation fields as numbers). Messaging threads support candidate outreach with templates and tracking of delivery/open status. Users can create endorsements, recommendations (short text), and project portfolios (links/attachments metadata). Administrative features include role-based access for recruiters, audit logs, and compliance holds for candidate data retention. The platform stores saved searches (structured filters), talent pools, and tagging for candidates. Everything is synthesizable: profiles, skills, job attributes, pipeline events, interview times, and offer amounts provide rich API testing across CRUD, workflow transitions, permissions, and reporting dashboards.

name: MatchHarbor (Dating + Preferences + Safety Controls)
description: MatchHarbor is a dating app built around profiles, preferences, and messaging workflows. Users CRUD profiles (photos as metadata, bio short text), identity verification states, preference filters (age range, distance, interests), and privacy settings. Matching is represented as a state machine users can interact with via APIs: likes, passes, mutual matches, unmatches, and blocks. Conversations include message threads, read receipts, attachments (metadata), and safety tools like report reasons and incident tickets. The platform supports date planning by creating “date cards” (location, time, status: proposed/confirmed/canceled) and sharing limited profile details upon confirmation. Subscription features include tiers, boosts, super-likes, and renewal/cancellation records. Moderation includes flagged accounts, content removal actions, and appeal flows. All data is synthesizable (locations, preferences, timestamps, statuses), and the app provides realistic CRUD plus lifecycle events suitable for simulating rate limits, privacy constraints, and moderation pipelines.

name: BidBarn Exchange (Timed Auctions + Seller Tools + Escrow Checkout)
description: BidBarn Exchange is a marketplace focused on timed auctions and structured seller operations. Sellers CRUD storefronts, payout profiles, product lots, item condition reports, reserve prices, shipping options, and inventory locations. Auction workflows include scheduling listings, bid increments, proxy bids, watchlists, and auction states (draft/scheduled/live/ended/void). The system records bids, bidder eligibility, anti-sniping extensions, winner selection, and post-auction checkout. Buyers manage carts for won lots, shipping addresses, tax exemptions, payment authorizations (synthetic), and order statuses (unpaid/paid/packed/shipped/delivered/returned). Dispute flows cover non-payment, item-not-as-described claims, refunds, and seller penalties. Ratings are structured (star + short tags), and messaging supports buyer-seller coordination. Admin tools include category management, prohibited item flags, fee rules, and fraud holds. Every field is synthesizable—prices, timestamps, bids, inventory counts—making it ideal for API simulations that test concurrency, state transitions, and transactional integrity.

name: Shopify POS (Retail Store Operations)
description: Shopify POS is a retail point-of-sale and inventory system for brick-and-mortar stores. Merchants CRUD products, variants (size/color), barcodes/SKUs, price lists, discounts, tax rules, locations, and stock levels with transfers between stores. Sales workflows include building carts, applying promotions, capturing payments (synthetic), issuing receipts, and handling returns/exchanges with restocking rules. Order records track line items, fulfillment status, customer association, and staff attribution. Merchants also manage customers (profiles, loyalty points as synthetic), staff roles/permissions, cash drawer sessions, and shift reconciliation with cash counts and variances. Inventory workflows include purchase orders to suppliers, receiving stock, cycle counts, and stock adjustments with reasons (damage, shrink, recount). Reporting endpoints summarize sales by day, category, staff, and location, plus inventory valuation and sell-through. API simulation can model barcode scans, offline-to-online sync events, webhooks for order/stock updates, and multi-location constraints, all with synthesizable numeric and status data.

name: Shopify Admin (Store Ops: Products, Inventory, Fulfillment)
description: Shopify Admin is a commerce operations backend focused on catalog, inventory, and fulfillment workflows rather than marketplace browsing. Merchants CRUD products, variants, options, collections, pricing, discount rules, and tax/shipping profiles. Inventory is tracked per location with stock levels, reservations, transfers, and reorder thresholds. Order lifecycles include checkout-created orders, payment status (authorized/paid/refunded), fulfillment status (unfulfilled/partial/fulfilled), and shipment tracking metadata. Customer entities include profiles, addresses, tags, and consent flags; marketing automations can be simulated as campaigns and sent-event logs. Returns and exchanges are represented as return requests with line items, inspection outcomes, restock actions, and refund calculations. Store settings include staff roles, apps (installed integrations as metadata), webhooks, and API tokens. Analytics dashboards summarize sales, AOV, conversion, and inventory aging, all derived from synthetic order lines and timestamps. The platform suits API simulation because it is CRUD-heavy, event-driven, and measurable without needing real content.

name: HireHarbor Recruiting CRM (Sourcing + Pipeline + Talent Pools)
description: HireHarbor is a recruiting CRM designed around structured candidate data and pipeline workflows. Recruiters CRUD candidates (contact info, location, skills tags, comp bands, consent flags), resumes as file metadata, social links, and custom fields. Talent pools and campaigns group candidates by role or segment; users can add/remove candidates, apply labels, and set nurture cadences. The system models jobs/requisitions with hiring team members, interview plans, scorecard templates, and stage definitions. Candidate pipeline objects track stage history (sourced/screen/interview/offer/hired/rejected), disposition reasons, and next steps. Communication is simulated via message records (email/SMS templates, sends, opens, replies) without needing real email delivery. Scheduling entities include interview events, availability slots, attendees, and confirmation status. Notes, tasks, and reminders are first-class records linked to candidates and jobs. Offer management includes offer drafts, approvals, comp components, and acceptance/decline outcomes. Reporting endpoints provide counts by stage, time-in-stage, source effectiveness, and recruiter activity logs—fully synthesizable for realistic QA and API simulations.

name: ShiftMint Workforce Scheduling (Hourly Staff + Shift Trades)
description: ShiftMint is a workforce scheduling platform for hourly teams where schedules, time events, and approvals drive the core CRUD. Managers CRUD locations, departments, roles, employees, pay rates, and skills/credentials (e.g., forklift certified) with expiration dates. Schedules are built from shift templates (start/end, breaks, headcount needs) and published as schedule versions with audit trails. Employees submit availability, time-off requests, and shift-trade offers; managers approve/deny with reasons and timestamps. Timekeeping is modeled through clock-in/out records (device ID, geofence flag, exception codes), timesheets, and corrections. Rule engines are representable as configuration objects: overtime thresholds, meal-break compliance, minor labor rules, and fair scheduling notice windows. Workflows include open-shift bidding, coverage alerts, callouts, and escalation to supervisors. Payroll export is done via pay period summaries and earnings lines (regular, overtime, differential) without needing banking integration. Analytics endpoints can synthesize labor cost vs budget, adherence, and coverage gaps per location and day.

name: PayRoller Pro (Payroll Runs + Deductions + Tax Forms)
description: PayRoller Pro is a payroll system focused on pay runs, employee compensation data, and compliance artifacts that can be fully synthesized. Admins CRUD companies, work sites, pay schedules, earning types, deduction types (benefits, garnishments), and PTO policies. Employees are CRUDed with demographics, addresses, tax withholding elections, direct deposit accounts (tokenized), and pay settings (salary/hourly, rates, overtime eligibility). Payroll runs are modeled as entities with periods, cutoffs, statuses (draft/calculating/approved/submitted/voided), and line-item pay statements. Time input can come from imported timesheets or manual entry records with approvals. The platform tracks employer and employee taxes as calculated ledger entries per run, plus adjustments and retro pay as separate objects. Workflows include multi-step approvals, off-cycle payments, missed payroll corrections, and paycheck reissues. Document endpoints cover W-2/1099 metadata, pay stubs, and quarterly filings as generated PDFs/records (metadata only). Audit logs record who changed what and when. Reporting supports payroll registers, department allocations, and year-to-date totals, all deterministically generatable for testing.

name: UnionWorks Case Desk (HR Cases + Policy Requests + Approvals)
description: UnionWorks is an internal HR case management portal that treats every employee question as a ticket with structured fields and lifecycle state. Employees and HR agents CRUD profiles, org units, and case categories (benefits, leave, conduct, workplace accommodation, policy exception). Cases include severity, due dates, SLA timers, watchers, and linked knowledge-article IDs (metadata references, not long content). Agents can assign, reassign, and escalate cases, add internal notes, request information, and attach documents as file metadata. Workflows support intake forms, triage queues, approvals (e.g., manager sign-off), and resolution codes. A task checklist system breaks a case into steps with owners, deadlines, and completion status. Sensitive data controls are modeled via role-based permissions and redaction flags on fields/attachments. The platform includes scheduled reminders, status updates, and customer satisfaction surveys as short-form ratings and comments. Reporting APIs aggregate volume by category, SLA compliance, reopen rates, and workload per agent. All entities—cases, tasks, statuses, timestamps, and structured fields—are easily synthesized for API simulation.

name: CampusHire Board (Early-Career Job Board + Applications)
description: CampusHire is a job board for internships and graduate roles emphasizing postings, eligibility rules, and application workflows rather than content feeds. Employers CRUD company profiles, recruiters, office locations, and job postings with structured fields: role type, salary range, visa sponsorship, remote/hybrid, required graduation dates, and skills tags. Students CRUD profiles, education records, work history entries, portfolios (links), and resume file metadata. Search can be simulated via filterable fields and saved searches; alerts are modeled as subscription records tied to criteria. Applications are first-class entities with answers to short questions, document attachments, status (submitted/under review/interview/offer/rejected/withdrawn), and stage history. Employers manage screening questions, knockout rules, and interview slots; students book or reschedule interviews with confirmation states. Messaging is represented by conversation threads scoped to an application, including templated outreach and automated updates. Offer objects include compensation components, deadlines, and acceptance outcomes. Compliance controls include consent, data retention settings, and opt-out flags. Analytics endpoints support funnel conversion, time-to-review, and application volume by school or major.

name: ContractorCloud VMS (Freelancer Requests + Timesheets + Rate Cards)
description: ContractorCloud is a vendor management system for contingent workforce procurement with highly structured, synthesizable data. Hiring managers CRUD worker requests (role, skills, location, duration, bill rate range), approval chains, and cost centers. Vendors CRUD candidate submissions tied to a request, with rates, availability dates, and compliance checklists (background check status, certifications, I-9 metadata). Once selected, engagements become assignment records with start/end dates, manager, work location, and status (active/on hold/ended). Timesheets are submitted weekly with daily hours, project codes, and approver status; exceptions and corrections are tracked as separate adjustment objects. Invoicing is modeled via invoice headers and line items derived from approved timesheets, including tax/fee fields and payment status (pending/approved/paid/failed). Rate cards are configurable per role, location, and vendor tier, with effective dates. The system supports onboarding tasks, equipment requests, and access provisioning tickets as linked workflow items. Reporting covers spend by department, vendor performance, aging invoices, and utilization—ideal for deterministic test data and CRUD-heavy API simulations.

name: GuildForum Communities (Groups + Threads + Moderation Tools)
description: GuildForum is a community forum platform optimized for structured discussion objects and moderation workflows without relying on long-form publishing. Admins CRUD communities, categories, tags, and membership roles (member/mod/admin). Users CRUD profiles, preferences, and notification settings. Content objects are threads and replies with bounded-length bodies, attachments as file metadata, and reaction/vote records. Thread lifecycle includes statuses (open/locked/archived), pinning, and category moves with audit history. Moderation is modeled through reports (reason codes, evidence links), queues, and actions (remove/restore, lock, warn, temporary ban) recorded as enforcement events with durations. Automation rules can be configured as synthesizable policies: auto-flag by keyword list, rate limits, or reputation thresholds. Reputation is computed from upvotes, accepted answers, and participation streaks—stored as periodic score snapshots. Users can create polls with options and vote records; events such as AMAs can be represented by scheduled sessions linked to a category and host users. Search can be simulated via tag/category filters and simple full-text indexes. Analytics endpoints return active users, response times, and moderation metrics.

name: MentorMesh Professional Network (Mentorship Matching + Sessions)
description: MentorMesh is a professional networking platform centered on structured profiles and mentorship workflows rather than content feeds. Users CRUD profiles (headline, skills taxonomy, industries, location, years experience), availability windows, and mentoring preferences (topics, meeting cadence, language). Connection objects include invites, accepts, and blocks with timestamps. Matching can be simulated using tags, distance, and availability overlap, producing match recommendations as stored results. Mentorship relationships are tracked as engagements with goals, start/end dates, and satisfaction check-ins. Scheduling is handled through session entities: proposed times, confirmed time, agenda, meeting link (metadata), and attendance status. Users can exchange messages in conversation threads tied to a match or engagement; attachments are file metadata. Organizations can create programs with cohorts, eligibility rules, and assigned coordinators; coordinators can approve participants and monitor engagement health. Feedback forms capture structured ratings and short comments after each session, and issues can be escalated into support tickets. Admin dashboards expose participation rates, session completion, and topic popularity. All objects—profiles, matches, sessions, messages, statuses—are straightforward to synthesize for robust API testing.

name: Heartline Messages (Secure Chat + Teams + Read Receipts)
description: Heartline Messages is a messaging and communication platform designed for CRUD-heavy simulation: users, devices, conversations, and message state. Admins CRUD organizations, teams, channels (public/private), and role permissions. Users CRUD profiles, contact lists, blocking rules, and notification preferences. Conversations can be direct messages or group threads with membership lists, join/leave events, and admin roles. Message objects include sender, timestamps, content (bounded text), attachments as metadata, and delivery state per recipient (sent/delivered/read/failed). The platform models edits, deletes, reactions, and message pinning as separate event records, enabling audit trails. Device management includes device registrations, push tokens (fake), sessions, and multi-factor settings. Presence is represented as status records (online/away/do-not-disturb) with last-seen timestamps. Moderation/compliance features are simulated with retention policies, legal hold flags, export requests, and content reports. Workflows include invite links, workspace switching, and channel discovery via tags and membership. Analytics endpoints return message volume, active users, and response-time stats, all synthesizable without real-time media or AI features.

name: HelpStitch Service Desk (Omnichannel Tickets + SLAs + Macros)
description: HelpStitch is a customer support ticketing system focused on ticket lifecycles, routing, and structured resolution data. Customers CRUD accounts, contact methods, and product registrations; agents CRUD teams, skills, schedules, and permissions. Tickets originate from channels (email/web form/chat transcript metadata) and include category, priority, product, environment, and customer impact. Routing is modeled through queues, assignment rules, and round-robin logic stored as configuration entities. SLA policies are CRUDed with targets per priority and timers that pause/resume based on ticket status. Agent workflows include internal notes, public replies, macros/templates, tagging, linking duplicates, and creating child tickets. Status transitions (new/open/pending/on-hold/solved/closed) are tracked with timestamps and reason codes. Escalations create incident records with stakeholders, timelines, and postmortem tasks. Knowledge base integration is via article metadata references and “suggested article” links (no long content required). CSAT surveys capture ratings and short comments. Reporting APIs deliver backlog, first-response time, reopen rates, and agent productivity. The entire environment is ideal for synthetic, database-driven API simulation.

name: CraftCircle Groups (Local Communities + Events + Member Roles)
description: CraftCircle Groups is a social/community platform for local clubs and interest circles that centers on membership, scheduling, and structured interactions rather than long-form publishing. Users CRUD profiles, interests, home city, and privacy settings. Groups are first-class entities with owners/moderators, membership roles, join questions, dues settings (optional), and house rules. Members can create posts (short text), polls (options + closing time), and announcements, plus attach images as metadata. Event workflows include creating events with venue/address, capacity, RSVP limits, waitlists, ticket price (optional), and attendance check-in. The system tracks RSVP status (going/maybe/not going), waitlist promotion, and reminders. Group admins manage member approvals, invitations via share links, member removals, and incident reports. Direct member-to-member messaging can be enabled per group with opt-in settings. Additional entities include shared resource lists (tools, books), lending records (item, borrower, due date, returned), and volunteer shifts for events. All data (members, RSVPs, venues, dues invoices, check-ins) is easily synthesized for realistic API testing.

name: SparkMatch (Dating + Safety + Date Planning)
description: SparkMatch is a dating app scenario emphasizing profile CRUD, structured preferences, messaging, and safety tooling. Users manage profiles (photos as metadata, bio length-limited, interests tags, lifestyle fields), verification status, and visibility controls. Discovery is driven by synthetic candidate pools filtered by age range, distance radius, intent, and dealbreakers; results are logged as impressions for analytics. Core workflows include likes, passes, match creation on mutual likes, and unmatching. Once matched, users can message via conversation threads with message states (sent/delivered/read), attachments (metadata), and conversation actions (mute, report, block). Safety features are structured: report categories, evidence attachment metadata, case status (open/in review/resolved), and enforcement actions (warning, temporary ban, permanent ban). A date-planning module lets matches create shared plans with proposed time/location, RSVP status, and check-in reminders; users can share a trusted-contact token and set a safety timer. Monetization can be simulated through subscriptions (tier, renewal date, perks like boosts) and consumables (boost count). All records—profiles, preferences, matches, chats, safety cases—are realistic and database-friendly.

name: RelayChat Workspace (Team Messaging + Channels + Admin Policies)
description: RelayChat Workspace is a messaging/communication platform for teams with fully structured objects and admin controls. Users CRUD user accounts, profiles, device sessions, and notification settings. Workspaces contain channels (public/private), membership roles, and channel topics. Messages are stored as bounded text with optional attachments (file metadata), reactions, and threads (parent/child relationships). Workflows include inviting users, joining/leaving channels, pinning messages, bookmarking, and editing/deleting with retention rules. Admins configure policies: message retention windows, external guest access, allowed domains for invitations, and moderation tools. Compliance features include audit logs for admin actions, export requests (workspace/date range), and legal hold flags on channels or users (metadata only). Presence and read receipts are modeled as timestamped states (online/away/last seen; message read at). A simple bot integration framework can be simulated via webhook subscriptions to events (message.created, channel.created, user.invited) and outbound “bot messages” as a distinct actor type. The platform supports searchable message indexes using stored keywords/tags rather than real search ranking, keeping it synthesizable while exercising rich CRUD and event-driven APIs.

name: SupportNexus (Customer Support Helpdesk + SLA + Escalations)
description: SupportNexus is a customer support ticketing system designed for lifecycle simulation and operational CRUD. Customers submit tickets via web forms or email-ingest (simulated), creating cases with category, product, priority, and custom fields. Agents CRUD replies (public/private notes), attachments (metadata), tags, and status transitions (new/open/pending/on-hold/solved/closed). Workflows include assignment rules, round-robin routing, escalation policies, and SLA timers (first response due, resolution due) computed from timestamps and business hours calendars. The platform includes a knowledge base as short articles/templates (title, snippet, steps list) used for canned responses, avoiding long editorial content. Entities include customers, organizations, contacts, agent teams, macros, and automations (if tag X then set priority Y). Integrations can be simulated via webhook events and a minimal CRM sync (account id, contract tier). Reporting endpoints expose synthesizable metrics (backlog, SLA breaches, agent workload, CSAT scores). Role-based access controls govern who can view customer PII fields. All data can be generated deterministically to test queues, SLA behavior, and escalation paths.

name: SeatSnap Tickets (Venue Ticketing + Transfers + Entry Scanning)
description: SeatSnap Tickets is an event ticketing platform focused on inventory, orders, and access control without needing real payments or media. Organizers CRUD venues (sections/rows/seats), events (date/time, doors open), ticket types (GA, reserved), pricing tiers, and sales windows. Buyers create accounts, manage attendee profiles, and purchase tickets (order records with line items, fees, taxes, and status: pending/confirmed/canceled/refunded). Tickets are digital passes with barcode/token metadata, transferability rules, and lifecycle states (issued/transferred/voided/scanned). Workflows include ticket transfers to other users, reclaim/accept transfer, resale listings within price caps, and organizer-issued comps. Entry scanning is modeled with scan events (gate id, device id, timestamp, result: accepted/duplicate/invalid) and offline sync batches. Organizers manage staff roles, scanning devices (registered/disabled), and incident logs (manual entry, denied reasons). Post-event reporting includes attendance counts, scan rate by gate, and fraud flags (multiple scans). All entities—seats, tickets, transfers, scans—are cleanly synthesizable and ideal for API-driven state transitions.

name: ClipVault Collections (Lists + Curation + Collaborative Folders)
description: ClipVault Collections is a lists/collections and curation app for saving links and notes with collaboration features. Users CRUD accounts, browser-extension tokens (simulated), and default privacy settings. Core entities are saved items with URL, title, short description, thumbnail metadata, tags, and created/updated timestamps. Items live in folders/collections with ordering, pinned items, and sharing settings (private/shared/public link). Collaboration supports invites, roles (owner/editor/viewer), comments on items, and activity logs (item added/moved/edited). Workflows include bulk import/export, deduplication (same URL), and item status fields like “to read,” “in progress,” “archived.” Teams can create templates for collections (predefined tag sets, required fields) and moderation rules for public collections (report item, remove item, ban collaborator). A lightweight discovery feed can be synthesized using collection metadata (most-saved tags, trending collections by saves) without requiring real ranking. Optional integrations: webhook on item.created, and an API to embed a public collection as a widget. Everything is metadata-focused and strongly suited for database-backed CRUD and sharing workflows.

name: WishNest Registry (Wishlists + Gift Reservations + Group Funding)
description: WishNest Registry is a wishlist and registry platform for birthdays, weddings, and group gifting with structured commerce-adjacent data but no dependency on real catalogs. Users CRUD registries (event type, date, shipping address), co-organizers, and privacy settings. Wishlist items can be added manually with URL, price, variant notes, priority, and desired quantity; items track status (available/reserved/purchased/hidden). Gift-givers create profiles, browse shared registries, reserve items to avoid duplicates, and mark purchases with optional proof metadata (receipt id, store name). Group funding supports “contribution pools” per item with target amount, contributions, and payout preference (gift card, cash transfer simulated). Messaging is scoped to registry threads (questions, thank-you notes) with bounded text. Workflows include registry updates (address change notifications), item substitutions, and return tracking (return initiated/received/refunded). Admin tools include fraud checks on contribution pools and audit logs. The platform is highly synthesizable: prices, items, contributions, reservations, and timelines can all be generated to test concurrency (two users reserving) and lifecycle transitions.

name: CircleQ Help Community (Q&A + Reputation + Bounties)
description: CircleQ Help Community is a structured support forum blending Q&A and community moderation, optimized for synthesizable interactions. Users CRUD profiles, expertise tags, and notification settings. Questions are objects with title, short body, product/version fields, tags, and status (open/answered/closed/duplicate). Answers and comments are bounded-length posts with votes, accepted-answer flags, and edit histories. Reputation is derived from vote counts, accepted answers, and moderation actions; privileges unlock at thresholds (comment anywhere, close-vote, edit others). Workflows include suggesting duplicates, adding an answer, marking accepted, reopening, and awarding bounties (points escrowed and paid out on accepted answer). Moderation entities include flags, review queues, close reasons, and bans. A lightweight “article” format exists for canonical solutions with a template (problem/steps/expected result) to avoid long editorial content. Admin APIs manage tag synonyms, tag wikis (short descriptions), and anti-spam rules (rate limits, captcha required flag). Reporting covers unanswered backlog, time-to-first-answer, and top contributors by tag. All objects and counters are realistic to synthesize for API simulations.

name: HelpDesk Harbor (Omnichannel Customer Support + SLAs)
description: HelpDesk Harbor is a customer support platform for managing inbound requests across email, web forms, and chat widgets. Admins CRUD channels, business hours, SLA policies, and routing rules (by product, priority, language, or customer tier). Core entities include customers/organizations, tickets, conversations (threaded messages), attachments (file metadata), tags, custom fields, and statuses (new/open/pending/on-hold/solved/closed). Agents manage queues, assign/claim tickets, add internal notes, create macros/canned replies, and set follow-up reminders. Workflows cover triage (auto-categorize + priority), escalation to a specialist group, and SLA breach tracking with timers. The platform supports knowledge-base linkage as structured references (article IDs/titles), plus ticket-to-issue linkage for recurring problems. Reporting is database-driven: volume by channel, first-response time, resolution time, backlog aging, and agent workload. Auditing tracks every state change with timestamps and actor IDs. Everything is synthesizable: customers, tickets, message bodies (short text), timestamps, and status transitions.

name: QueuePilot (Internal IT/Facilities Ticketing + Approvals)
description: QueuePilot is an internal ticketing system for IT and facilities requests (password resets, laptop repairs, badge access, maintenance). Employees CRUD requester profiles, office locations, and assets (laptops, monitors, printers) with serial numbers and warranty dates.
