Shipping label generation and tracking are metadata entities; tax calculation can be rule-based. Returns are typically limited and can be modeled as policy-driven case outcomes. Admin controls include bidder suspensions, item removals, and audit logs. This environment is highly synthesizable: items, bids, timing, status transitions, and fulfillment are all structured and database-friendly.

name: Donorbox (Donations + Recurring Giving)
description: Donorbox is a donation platform for nonprofits that manages donation forms, donor records, and recurring contributions. Organizations CRUD nonprofit profiles, campaigns (goal amount, start/end dates, designation funds), donation forms (fields, suggested amounts, tribute options), and integrations (webhooks, CRM export settings). Donors submit one-time or recurring donations, manage donor profiles, payment methods (token metadata), receipts, and communication preferences. The core workflow includes donation created → payment authorized/captured → receipt issued → funds settlement → acknowledgment email logged, with refunds, failed payments, and retry schedules for recurring gifts. The system maintains a donor CRM: donors, households, notes, tags, soft credits, and interaction history. Additional entities include peer-to-peer fundraising pages, team fundraising, matching gift metadata, and event-linked campaigns (ticket add-ons can be modeled as line items). Admin users manage roles/permissions, tax-deductible receipt templates, and reporting snapshots (monthly totals, retention) that can be synthesized. Everything is structured—amounts, frequency, statuses, timestamps—making it excellent for API CRUD, ledger simulation, and webhook-driven automation testing.

name: GiveCloud Donor CRM
description: GiveCloud is a donor management and fundraising CRM for charities. Staff CRUD constituents (people/organizations), households, contact methods, communication preferences, and relationship links (board member, employer match contact). Fundraising entities include campaigns, funds/designations, appeals, donation forms (fields, suggested amounts, recurrence rules), gift records (one-time/recurring, soft credits, tributes), and pledge schedules. Workflows support donation intake (online/offline), acknowledgement queues (email/letter tasks), recurring payment lifecycle (active/past-due/canceled), and refunds/voids. Finance tools model batches, deposits, GL codes, and reconciliation notes. Volunteer features include interests, availability, shifts, hours logs, and background-check status as structured attributes. Events are optional: create events, ticket types, registrations, check-ins, and seating blocks. Reporting is driven by saved segments (filters on giving history, last touch, geography) and exports. All data is synthesizable: donors, gifts, receipts, statuses, timestamps, and audit logs. APIs can simulate form submissions, webhook-style payment notifications, and automated stewardship tasks.

name: GrantTrack RFP + Grants Management
description: GrantTrack manages the full lifecycle of grantmaking for foundations and corporate giving programs. Admins CRUD programs, eligibility rules, application forms, scoring rubrics, reviewer pools, and funding cycles with deadlines. Applicants CRUD organization profiles (EIN/registration metadata, contacts, service areas), proposals, budgets (line items), attachments as file metadata, and milestone plans. Review workflows include assignment, conflict-of-interest declarations, scoring, comments, panel meetings (agenda items, votes), and decision states (submitted/in-review/clarifications/approved/declined/awarded). Award management models grant agreements, disbursement schedules, payment requests, compliance checklists, and reporting requirements (narrative prompts, metrics tables). Monitoring supports site-visit logs, risk ratings, and change requests (budget reallocation, timeline extension) with approvals. Finance entities include disbursement batches, payment methods metadata, and reconciliation statuses. The platform emphasizes auditability: versioned forms, immutable submission snapshots, and activity logs. Data can be fully synthesized—applications, scores, disbursements, and deadlines—making it ideal for API simulations of form submission, reviewer assignment, and payout workflows.

name: FundSprint Peer-to-Peer Fundraising
description: FundSprint powers peer-to-peer fundraising for runs, school drives, and advocacy campaigns. Organizations CRUD campaigns, goals, thermometers, teams, registration options, and donation settings (matching gifts, fee coverage, recurring). Participants CRUD fundraising pages (short bio, story snippet, goal amount), team membership, offline donation pledges, and reward selections. Donation entities include donor profiles, gifts, dedications, receipts, and anonymity flags. Workflows support participant onboarding, page publishing, social share link tracking (UTM metadata), pledge fulfillment, and matching-gift verification as a status queue. Incentives are modeled with reward tiers, inventory counts, fulfillment addresses, and shipment status metadata. Admin dashboards manage approvals (page moderation states), refund/chargeback records, and payout batches. The platform can also manage event-day check-in with bib numbers as structured identifiers and progress updates (miles, steps) as numeric logs. Everything is synthesizable: participants, donation streams, team leaderboards, and fulfillment. APIs can simulate real-world flows such as creating a page, receiving donations, updating totals, and triggering automated thank-you tasks.

name: BoardBinder Governance & Compliance
description: BoardBinder is a governance portal for nonprofits and associations focused on compliance, board operations, and controlled records. Admins CRUD organizations, committees, board member profiles, terms, roles, and voting rights. Meeting management includes agendas, packet items (documents as metadata + versions), attendance, minutes, and action items. Compliance modules track policies (code of ethics, whistleblower, retention), attestations, conflict-of-interest disclosures, and annual filings with due dates and completion status. Workflows support distributing packets with access windows, collecting RSVPs, recording votes (motion, second, result), and generating follow-up tasks. Document controls include review cycles, required approvers, and audit logs of views and acknowledgements. For grants and restricted funds, the system can store resolutions authorizing budgets and signatories. Integrations can be simulated via webhooks for new meeting events or expiring attestations. All data is structured and synthesizable—members, meetings, votes, compliance statuses—making it suitable for API testing of role-based permissions, versioning, and immutable audit trails.

name: FlowRelay Workflow Automation for Operations
description: FlowRelay is a no-code workflow automation platform focused on CRUD-friendly operational data rather than AI. Users define integrations (API connectors, webhooks), data objects, and automations composed of triggers, conditions, and actions. Entities include workflows, steps, secrets (token metadata), run histories, retries, and error logs. Common actions are create/update records in connected apps, assign tasks, generate approvals, and send notifications. FlowRelay includes an internal work queue: tasks, assignees, SLAs, and statuses (open/in-progress/blocked/done). Approval steps support multi-approver rules, escalations, and comments. Data mapping is modeled as field-level transforms with versioning, enabling realistic simulations of syncing donors to accounting, routing contract requests, or creating volunteer shifts from intake forms. Governance features include environments (dev/stage/prod), role-based access, and audit logs for workflow edits. Everything is synthesizable: connectors, payloads, runs, and outcomes. APIs can test idempotency keys, replaying events, and at-least-once delivery patterns without relying on external real-time datasets.

name: ImpactProject Hub (Programs, Tasks, Outcomes)
description: ImpactProject Hub is a project and program management platform tailored to nonprofits delivering services across multiple initiatives. Teams CRUD programs, projects, tasks, dependencies, checklists, and assignments, with views for boards, timelines, and calendars. Beneficiary/client entities are optional and structured (client ID, eligibility flags, intake dates) without requiring sensitive content. Outcome tracking is built-in: define indicators (numeric targets), collect periodic measurements, and link outcomes to activities and funding sources. Budgeting models line items, approvals, and spend-to-date snapshots; procurement requests create purchase tasks and vendor records. Collaboration features include comments, mentions, attachments as file metadata, and decision logs. Workflows cover intake → plan → execute → report, including milestone approvals and automated reminders when indicators are overdue. Role-based permissions support partner organizations with scoped access to specific programs. All data (tasks, milestones, indicators, budgets) is synthesizable and database-driven, making it strong for API simulations of complex CRUD, state transitions, and reporting queries without content-heavy requirements.

name: SprintLedger (Agile Project Management + Capacity Planning)
description: SprintLedger is an agile work-management platform for product and engineering teams. Users CRUD workspaces, projects, epics, user stories, subtasks, and bugs with fields like priority, story points, labels, due dates, dependencies, and acceptance criteria. Teams manage sprints (start/end dates, sprint goals), capacity plans (per-user availability, holidays), and backlog ordering with drag-and-drop rank stored as an index. Workflow actions include creating tickets from templates, moving items across customizable statuses, assigning owners/reviewers, linking commits/PRs as metadata, and logging time entries against issues. Collaboration features are structured: comments, @mentions, attachments as file metadata, watchers, and notifications with per-project rules. Reporting is database-driven: burndown data, velocity by team, cycle time, SLA breaches, and workload distribution. Admins manage roles/permissions, custom fields, automation rules (e.g., when status changes to “Ready for QA,” assign QA group and set due date), and integrations via webhooks. Everything is synthesizable: users, tickets, timestamps, statuses, and numerical metrics for realistic API simulations.

name: BoardRoom Kanban (Cross-Team Collaboration + Approvals)
description: BoardRoom Kanban is a collaborative kanban and approval hub for operations and shared services (IT, finance, facilities). Users CRUD boards, columns, cards, and swimlanes with structured metadata such as requester, department, cost center, urgency, and target completion date. Cards support checklists, linked assets, and required approvers (role-based). Workflows include request intake → triage → in progress → review → approved/rejected → done, with audit trails for every state change. Teams manage queues, WIP limits, and service-level targets; the system calculates aging and breach flags from timestamps. Collaboration is handled via card comments, internal notes vs. requester-visible updates, and escalation rules. Admins create form templates (e.g., “New Laptop Request,” “Vendor Setup,” “Facility Repair”) that generate cards with predefined fields and validation. Additional entities include recurring tasks, saved filters, assignment rotations, and notification subscriptions. The platform is ideal for API simulation: cards, approvals, statuses, structured forms, and time-based metrics can all be synthesized and exercised through CRUD, search-by-field, and workflow transition endpoints.

name: FlowForge Automations (No-Code Workflow Automation + Webhooks)
description: FlowForge Automations is a no-code workflow automation platform similar to Zap-style tools, focused on database-driven configurations rather than content. Users CRUD connections (apps, credentials metadata, tokens), triggers (webhook, schedule, record-changed), workflows (graphs of steps), and actions (create/update record, send email, post message, create ticket). Each step has structured inputs, mappings, and validation rules, stored as versioned workflow definitions. Execution generates run records: start/end timestamps, status (success/failed/retried), step logs (bounded text), and error codes. Users can replay failed runs, throttle concurrency, and configure retries/backoff. The platform includes a lightweight “data store” where users CRUD tables, records, and schemas to support automation scenarios without external systems. Governance features include environments (dev/stage/prod), role-based access, approval gates for publishing workflows, and audit logs for edits. Monitoring is entity-based: alerts on failure rate thresholds, run duration, and webhook delivery. Because workflows, runs, logs, and records are all structured and synthesizable, FlowForge is highly suitable for API environment simulation involving CRUD plus event-driven interactions.

name: PolicyPilot (Compliance Policy Management + Attestations)
description: PolicyPilot is a compliance platform for managing internal policies and employee attestations (SOC 2/ISO-style readiness). Admins CRUD policy documents as versioned records (title, scope, owner, effective date, review cadence) with attachments as file metadata. Policies have control mappings (framework, control ID, evidence type) and assigned reviewers/approvers. Workflows include draft → review → approved → published → archived, with immutable audit events capturing who changed what and when. Employees receive attestation tasks tied to a policy version (read/acknowledge, due date, reminders), and the system records completion status, timestamps, and optional comments. Evidence collection is structured: evidence requests, upload links, expiration dates, and renewal tasks. Risk and exception tracking is supported via CRUDable risk registers (likelihood/impact scores), mitigation tasks, and exception approvals with expiry and compensating controls. Reporting endpoints summarize coverage by framework, overdue attestations, upcoming reviews, and evidence freshness. All data—policies, versions, tasks, scores, statuses, and timestamps—can be synthesized realistically for testing compliance workflows and auditing APIs.

name: StudioPulse (Boutique Fitness Studio Scheduling + Memberships)
description: StudioPulse is a gym/studio management platform for classes, memberships, and check-ins. Staff CRUD locations, rooms, class types (capacity, duration, level), schedules, instructors, and equipment resources. Members CRUD profiles, waivers, payment methods (token metadata), memberships (plan, billing cycle, freeze status), and class bookings with waitlist support. Workflows cover booking → confirmation → reminders → check-in (QR code token) → attendance → no-show/late-cancel fee assessment. The system supports class packs, promo codes, referrals, and corporate discounts. Operational entities include staff shifts, instructor payroll rules (per-class or per-attendee), and incident reports. Reporting endpoints provide occupancy, revenue by plan, retention cohorts, and instructor utilization. Access control separates member vs. staff actions; audit logs record membership changes and refunds. All data can be synthesized: class schedules, capacities, bookings, payments as ledger entries, and attendance timestamps—ideal for APIs that require realistic transactional behavior without relying on external content.

name: LiftLog Pro (Workout Tracking + Programs + PR Analytics)
description: LiftLog Pro is a strength-training tracker centered on structured workout data. Users CRUD exercise definitions (name, muscle group, equipment), training programs (weeks, days, progression rules), workouts, and sets with metrics (weight, reps, RPE, tempo, rest). Workflows include starting a session → following program prescriptions → logging actual performance → auto-calculating volume, estimated 1RM, and personal records → completing the session with notes. Users manage goals (e.g., squat 140kg by date), deload weeks, and injury flags that adjust recommendations via deterministic rules (not AI). Additional entities include measurement logs (bodyweight, circumferences), mobility routines, and reminders. Social features are optional and structured: following, workout kudos, and shared templates. The platform provides analytics endpoints for trends over time, adherence, muscle-group balance, and fatigue flags based on set counts and intensity. Because everything is numeric/time-series and entity-based, datasets are easy to synthesize while still feeling realistic for API testing (pagination, filtering by date range, aggregation queries, and data integrity constraints).

name: MacroMap Nutrition (Meal Planning + Pantry + Grocery Lists)
description: MacroMap Nutrition is a nutrition tracker and meal-planning platform that avoids content-heavy recipes by focusing on structured food data. Users CRUD foods (name, serving size, calories, macros, allergens), custom recipes as ingredient lists with computed nutrition, and meal plans by day/time slot. Daily logs store consumed items with quantities, timestamps, and notes, enabling totals per meal/day/week. Users manage goals (calorie target, macro ratios), dietary preferences, and exclusions. Pantry management includes items on hand, expiration dates, and reorder thresholds; generating a grocery list is a workflow that compares planned meals vs. pantry inventory and creates purchasable line items (quantity, unit, store category). Integrations can be simulated via barcode scans as lookup events and wearable calories as imported numeric entries. Reporting includes adherence, average intake, micronutrient coverage (if modeled), and streaks. All entities—foods, recipes, logs, quantities, and dates—are fully synthesizable and support rich CRUD interactions, joins, and aggregation endpoints for realistic database-driven simulations.

name: FormRoute (Structured Intake Forms + Task Routing)
description: FormRoute is a workflow-oriented intake platform for internal requests (HR, IT, legal ops) combining forms, routing, and task management. Admins CRUD form templates with fields (text, dropdown, date, file metadata), validation rules, conditional logic, and SLA targets. Submissions create cases with structured data, attachments, and requester identity. Routing rules assign cases to queues or individuals based on field values (department, region, spend amount) and can spawn subtasks (e.g., collect approval, perform review, provision account). Workflows track case status (new/triage/in review/blocked/resolved) and record every transition in an audit trail. Collaboration is structured through comments, internal/private notes, watchers, and notification subscriptions. The platform supports approval steps with required approvers, due dates, reminders, and escalation policies. Reporting endpoints provide queue load, resolution times, SLA compliance, and case volumes by type. Because cases and form fields are strongly typed and bounded, the data can be synthesized easily while enabling meaningful CRUD, filtering, and automation testing in an API environment.

name: Acuity Scheduling (Client Appointments)
description: Acuity Scheduling is an appointment booking platform for service professionals (salons, consultants, clinics without medical records). A simulation can model businesses, staff, services, availability rules, time blocks, locations, clients, appointments, intake forms (structured questions), packages, memberships, and deposits (payment metadata). Providers CRUD service types (duration, price, buffers), configure weekly hours, exceptions/holidays, and capacity limits (e.g., group classes). Clients self-book by selecting service, staff, time slot, and providing contact details; the system creates appointment records and confirmation notifications (email/SMS as delivery status). Workflows include reschedule, cancel with policy windows, no-show tracking, and waitlists that auto-fill from cancellations. Intake forms are submitted as field/value pairs tied to appointments. Multi-location setups support resource constraints (rooms/equipment) as schedulable entities. Admin views include calendars, appointment statuses (pending/confirmed/checked-in/completed), and revenue summaries by service/staff. API simulations can also include recurring appointments and reminder sequences with configurable lead times.

name: Workday HCM (HR + Time Off)
description: Workday HCM is an enterprise HR system centered on employee lifecycle management. A simulation can model companies, workers, positions, job profiles, departments, locations, managers, compensation plans (numbers), benefits enrollments (plan selections), time-off balances, time-off requests, and approvals. HR admins CRUD worker profiles (contact info, employment status), hire/terminate actions, job changes (promotions, transfers), and position management (open/fill/freeze). Employees submit time-off requests specifying type, dates, and partial days; workflows route approvals to managers with states submitted → approved/denied/canceled, and balances update deterministically. Onboarding tasks can be represented as checklists with due dates and completion statuses. Payroll can be simulated at a metadata level: pay periods, earnings codes, deductions, and payslip summary numbers without needing bank integrations. Security roles define who can view/edit compensation or personal data. Reporting endpoints cover headcount by department, turnover, open positions, PTO liability, and approval aging—fully synthesizable, CRUD-heavy, and suitable for complex workflow testing.

name: QuickBooks Online (Small Business Accounting)
description: QuickBooks Online is an accounting platform for small businesses managing books, invoices, and expenses. A synthetic simulation can model companies, chart of accounts, customers, vendors, items/services, invoices, payments, bills, bill payments, bank transactions (imported feed as synthetic), journals, tax rates, and reports. Users CRUD customers/vendors, create invoices with line items, apply taxes/discounts, send (delivery status), record payments, and track invoice states (draft/sent/paid/overdue/void). Expense workflows include creating bills, scheduling payments, categorizing bank-feed transactions, attaching receipts as file metadata, and reconciling accounts by statement period. Inventory-lite can track quantity on hand per item with purchase/sale adjustments. Audit logs and user roles (admin/accountant/clerk) control access. Reporting APIs can generate profit & loss, balance sheet, cash flow, AR/AP aging, and sales by customer—derived deterministically from transactions. This scenario provides rich relational data, constraints (double-entry accounting), and realistic edge cases (refunds, credit memos, write-offs).

name: StreamShelf (Watchlists + Multi-Service Library)
description: StreamShelf is a streaming-library organizer that lets users track what they want to watch across multiple services without hosting any video. Users CRUD profiles, household members, and connected services (as tokens/metadata). Core entities include titles (movies/series) with synthesizable metadata (genre, year, runtime, cast list, maturity rating), availability records (service, plan tier, region, start/end dates), and user lists (watchlist, favorites, “up next”, custom collections). Workflows support adding a title to a list, setting reminders for releases, marking episodes watched, rating with stars, and attaching notes/tags (e.g., “family night”, “needs subtitles”). Social features are structured: users can follow friends, share lists, and create group queues with voting and scheduling (date/time, host, participants). Admin tooling supports importing catalog data, de-duplicating titles, managing region catalogs, and enforcing parental controls. Notifications are driven by CRUDable rules (new season available, title leaving service, friend recommendation). Data is fully synthesizable: titles, seasons/episodes, availability windows, user activity events, and list membership.

name: ArcadeVault (Virtual Items + Game Wallet)
description: ArcadeVault is a virtual-goods inventory and wallet platform for multiple games. Users CRUD accounts, linked game identities, and an item vault containing skins, emotes, boosters, crafting materials, and cosmetics represented via structured metadata (rarity, series, tradable flag, expiration). The marketplace module supports listing creation (price, quantity, duration), offers/bids, and escrowed trades with statuses (created/accepted/shipped/confirmed/disputed/canceled). A wallet ledger tracks balances, credits, debits, fees, and refunds in multiple currencies. Users can build loadouts per game and per character, with validation rules (slot type, class restrictions). Gifting workflows include selecting recipients, scheduling delivery, and applying promo codes. Admins manage item catalogs, drop tables (probabilities), bundles, and seasonal rotations; users purchase bundles and open packs (pack-open events + item grants). Risk controls are modeled via rate limits, KYC status metadata, suspicious-activity flags, and dispute tickets. Everything is database-driven and synthesizable: inventories, transactions, listings, trade events, and audit logs.

name: GuildOps (Clan Management + Raids + Loot)
description: GuildOps is a companion platform for gaming clans focused on structured operations rather than chat content. Users CRUD player profiles (roles, time zone, platform, preferred classes), guilds, ranks/permissions, and rosters. Event planning covers raids, scrims, and practice sessions with entities for events, time slots, sign-ups, substitutes, and attendance outcomes. Teams can define raid templates (required roles, minimum power level), then generate events from templates and track readiness via checklists (consumables, gear score, assignments). Loot and rewards are modeled as items, loot drops, point systems (DKP/EPGP), and distribution records with approvals and disputes. Recruitment is structured: applications, interview steps, trial periods, and promotion/denial decisions. Integrations are represented as webhook subscriptions and imports of match results (as structured stats), but all data can be synthetic. Moderation tools include warnings, strikes, and bans. Analytics dashboards summarize attendance rates, role coverage, and loot distribution fairness using purely numeric and categorical data. The platform supports multi-guild organizations and seasonal resets with archiving of events and ledgers.

name: HomePulse Hub (Smart Home Automation + Scenes)
description: HomePulse Hub is a home automation controller that manages devices and automations through a unified API. Users CRUD homes, rooms, devices (lights, thermostats, locks, cameras as metadata-only), and capabilities (on/off, brightness, temperature setpoint, lock state). Device telemetry is stored as timestamped readings (battery, temperature, motion events) that can be synthesized. Automation entities include scenes, schedules, and rules built from triggers (time, geofence enter/exit, sensor threshold), conditions (presence, mode, device state), and actions (set brightness, arm system, adjust setpoint). Workflows cover onboarding devices (pairing token, firmware version), assigning to rooms, and testing automations with simulated events. Access control supports household members, roles, guest access windows, and per-device permissions. Energy tracking is represented as per-device consumption estimates and billing periods. Admin features include device templates, firmware rollout campaigns, and incident logs. Audit trails capture every command issued and the resulting state transitions, enabling deterministic replay. The platform is ideal for CRUD-heavy simulations: device registries, rule engines, event logs, schedules, and permissions.

name: DeviceFleet Console (Enterprise Device Management)
description: DeviceFleet Console is an MDM-style platform for managing fleets of smart displays, kiosks, and set-top boxes used in venues. Admins CRUD organizations, sites, device groups, and individual devices with attributes (serial, model, OS version, last check-in, tags). Policies are first-class records: Wi-Fi profiles (metadata), allowed apps list, update windows, reboot schedules, and compliance rules (min OS version, encryption required). Workflows include enrolling a device (enrollment code → claimed → active), assigning it to a site, applying policies, and tracking command execution (queued/sent/acknowledged/failed). App deployment is modeled via app packages as metadata (name, version, checksum) and install/uninstall commands. Telemetry includes heartbeat pings, storage/cpu metrics, crash reports as structured fields, and location coordinates for mobile units. A ticketing module logs incidents, maintenance actions, and RMA shipments. Role-based access enables site managers vs global admins. Reporting summarizes compliance rates, update progress, and device health over time. All records are synthesizable and support realistic API interactions: bulk operations, filtering, pagination, and audit logs.

name: PlaylistFoundry (Collaborative Playlists + Rights Metadata)
description: PlaylistFoundry is a playlist-building platform that focuses on library management rather than streaming audio. Users CRUD profiles, libraries, playlists, and playlist items (track references with metadata like artist, duration, BPM, mood tags). Tracks are represented by catalog records or external IDs; no audio is stored. Collaborative workflows allow inviting editors, setting permissions, tracking revisions, and approving changes through a lightweight review queue (proposed/approved/rejected). Playlists support ordering, sections, rules (max explicit tracks, target duration, energy curve), and scheduling (publish at time, rotate weekly). For creators and venues, the platform manages usage logs (when/where playlist played), licensing metadata (territory, expiry, allowed use), and reporting exports. Users can create “radio sets” by defining constraints and generating a draft list (deterministic rule-based generation, not AI). Social features include following curators, saving copies (“forks”), and structured recommendations via tags and similarity scores computed from metadata. The API surface is CRUD-heavy: playlist membership, collaboration invites, version history, publishing states, and analytics counters—fully synthesizable.

name: Collectory (Collections + Wishlists for Pop Culture)
description: Collectory is a lists-and-collections app for tracking collectibles such as trading cards, figures, comics, and limited-edition merch. Users CRUD collections, items, and variants (edition, condition grade, serial number, signed flag), plus photos as file metadata. Each item has structured fields: brand/franchise, release date, rarity tier, estimated value, purchase price, and storage location (shelf/bin). Workflows include importing a checklist set, marking items owned/wanted, recording acquisitions (purchase, trade, gift), and logging sales with profit/loss calculations. Wishlists support priorities, target price alerts, and notes. Trading is modeled via trade proposals (offered items, requested items, cash adjustment), negotiation messages (short), and statuses (proposed/countered/accepted/completed/canceled). Inventory audits allow scanning barcodes/QR codes (synthetic identifiers) and reconciling discrepancies. Community features are structured: public showcases, follows, and swap meets as events with attendee lists. Admins maintain catalogs, set lists, and variant definitions. Everything is database-driven and realistic to synthesize: items, ownership, valuations, transactions, and locations.

name: GameKey Library (Digital Game Codes + Entitlements)
description: GameKey Library is a platform for managing digital game purchases, license keys, and entitlements across PC and console ecosystems (metadata only). Users CRUD accounts, linked platform identities, and a library of entitlements (game, edition, region lock, activation status). Key management supports vault entries (key code tokenized), redemption attempts, and redemption results (success/already-used/invalid/region-blocked) stored as structured events. Purchases are modeled with orders, line items, taxes, discounts, refunds, and chargebacks. Subscriptions create recurring entitlements with renewal schedules and grace periods. Family sharing is handled via household groups, share permissions, and device limits. Download/install isn’t performed; instead, the platform tracks install state as user-reported records (installed on device X, last played timestamp). Gifting workflows support scheduled gifts, recipient acceptance, and fallback refunds. Admin features include catalog management (SKUs, editions, bundles), pricing rules, fraud flags, and reconciliation reports. This scenario is highly suitable for API simulation: entitlement lifecycles, order workflows, key redemption logs, access control, and audit trails are all synthesizable.

name: SceneBoard (Smart Lighting + Venue Cues)
description: SceneBoard is a cue-based lighting and effects controller for streamers and small venues using smart bulbs, LED strips, and plug relays. Users CRUD projects, device rigs, fixture groups, and presets (color, intensity, pattern, duration). Timelines are built from cues that reference presets and include triggers (hotkey, MIDI note as metadata, stream event webhook, schedule). Cue execution is stored as runs with statuses (queued/running/completed/failed) and per-device command logs. Users can create show templates, duplicate them per event, and maintain versioned revisions. Device discovery and pairing are modeled with pairing sessions, device capabilities, and firmware metadata. A permissions layer supports collaborators (operator vs designer) and shared asset libraries. Monitoring dashboards show synthesized device health (signal strength, last seen, temperature) and alert rules for offline fixtures. Integrations are represented as subscriptions and event payload schemas; no real streaming is needed. This environment is excellent for database-driven simulation: projects, cues, schedules, execution history, device registries, and role-based collaboration all provide rich CRUD and workflow testing.

name: ToyBox Arcade (Mini-Games + Profiles + Season Pass)
description: ToyBox Arcade is a casual game platform hosting multiple mini-games where the core system is accounts, progression, and virtual rewards rather than content creation. Users CRUD profiles, avatars, friends, and privacy settings. Game sessions generate match records (game type, score, duration, inputs summary), leaderboards (daily/weekly/seasonal), and achievements (unlock conditions, timestamps). A season pass module manages tiers, XP events, claimable rewards, and purchase status. Virtual currency is tracked via wallet ledgers and item grants; users spend currency on cosmetics and emotes stored in inventories and equipped via loadouts. Challenges are structured tasks (play X matches, reach score Y) with progress counters and expiration dates. Moderation includes reports for usernames and basic conduct flags, plus ban states. Admin tooling manages game definitions, reward tables, XP multipliers, store rotations, and A/B test cohorts. All data is synthesizable: users, session stats, progression, currencies, store catalogs, and purchase records. The APIs support realistic flows like login → start session → submit results → grant rewards → update leaderboards → claim pass rewards.

name: Coursera (Course Administration + Learner Progress)
description: Coursera is an online learning platform that can be simulated primarily through its structured catalog, enrollment, and progress-tracking features rather than long-form lectures. Providers and admins CRUD courses, sessions/cohorts, instructors, modules, assignments (quizzes, peer reviews as rubric metadata), grading policies, and certificate rules. Learners CRUD profiles, enrollments, payment/subscription status, and learning preferences. Workflows include: browse catalog → enroll (single course or subscription) → start session → complete items with timestamps → submit assignments → receive grades → pass/fail outcomes → certificate issuance. Discussion forums can be reduced to short posts and moderation actions without emphasizing content depth. Progress is modeled as completion percentages, item attempts, due dates, late penalties, and mastery thresholds, all synthesizable. Billing can be represented as orders, invoices, refunds, and subscription renewals. Notifications (deadline reminders, grade posted, certificate available) are event-driven and can be replayed via webhooks. Reporting includes course completion rate, average time-to-complete, and drop-off by module. The emphasis is on CRUD and lifecycle states of enrollments, attempts, grades, and credentials, which map cleanly to database interactions.

name: Brightwheel (Childcare Center Management)
description: Brightwheel is a childcare management app that handles enrollment, attendance, messaging, billing, and daily activity tracking for daycare centers and preschools. Centers CRUD classrooms, staff, children, guardians, authorized pickup lists, immunization/waiver status flags, and schedules. Daily operations include check-in/check-out events with timestamps and pickup verification, plus incident reports (type, severity, guardian acknowledgment). Activity logs are structured entries (meals, naps, diapers, learning activities) with time ranges and notes, suitable for synthetic generation. Messaging is modeled as conversations, participants, attachments as metadata, and read receipts. Billing supports tuition plans, subsidies/discounts, invoices, autopay token metadata, failed payment handling, and account balances. Enrollment workflows include application → waitlist → offer → acceptance → onboarding checklist (forms submitted, documents verified) → active enrollment. Staff management includes ratios by classroom, shift schedules, and timeclock events. Reports cover attendance rates, late pickups, staffing compliance, and receivables aging. The domain offers rich CRUD patterns across people, schedules, logs, invoices, and compliance states without relying on content-heavy media.

name: SeedlyFund (Crowdfunding + Backer Rewards Platform)
description: SeedlyFund is a crowdfunding platform centered on project creation, pledge management, reward fulfillment, and creator updates as short structured posts. Creators CRUD campaigns (goal amount, duration, categories), reward tiers (price, quantity limits, shipping regions), stretch goals, and FAQs (bounded text). Backers CRUD profiles, shipping addresses, pledge carts, add-ons, and payment token metadata. Workflows include: campaign draft → compliance review → launch → pledges collected with status (authorized/captured/refunded) → campaign success/failure → funds disbursed → surveys sent → reward production milestones → fulfillment with tracking numbers. Inventory for limited rewards is tracked with reservations and oversell protection. Disputes and refunds are managed as cases with reason codes and approval steps. Creator communications can be represented as update entities (title, short body, attachments metadata) and comments/reactions without being content-centric. Analytics include conversion rate, pledge distribution by tier, funding velocity, and fulfillment backlog. Moderation tools manage reported campaigns, identity verification states, and prohibited-category flags. All key entities—campaigns, tiers, pledges, payments, surveys, shipments, and statuses—are synthesizable and drive meaningful API interactions.

name: WishForge (Multi-Store Wishlists + Price Watch)
description: WishForge helps shoppers build wishlists across many stores and manage gift planning without needing a full e-commerce checkout system. Users CRUD products as “saved items” (URL, store, title, variant metadata like color/size, target price, current price snapshot, availability flag, image URL metadata). They organize items into wishlists (public/private), add collaborators, and assign intended recipients for gifting. Workflows include: capture item → choose list → set priority and desired quantity → enable price/stock alerts → optionally mark purchased (with purchaser identity hidden for surprise gifts). For group gifting, a list can have contribution pledges (amount, status) and reservation locks to prevent duplicates. The platform supports structured comments per item (e.g., “prefer navy”) and messaging between collaborators using threads tied to a wishlist. A simple subscription tier gates features such as number of lists, alerts frequency, and collaborators; entities include plans, entitlements, invoices (metadata), and renewal status. APIs cover CRUD for users, lists, items, alerts, contributions, and webhooks for price-change events (synthetic) and reservation state transitions.

name: TasteTrail (Curated Recipe Box + Grocery List Builder)
description: TasteTrail is a digital recipe-box and curation app centered on structured recipe metadata rather than long editorial content. Users CRUD recipes with bounded fields: title, servings, time, cuisine/diet tags, ingredients (name, quantity, unit), steps (short ordered strings), and nutrition numbers (optional). They save recipes into collections (weeknight, meal prep, holidays), rate them, and attach notes/substitutions. The core workflow is planning: users build a meal plan calendar (date, meal slot, recipe reference, servings) which generates a consolidated grocery list. Grocery lists are editable: items can be grouped by store/aisle, checked off, substituted, or split into multiple trips. Users can share a plan or list with household members with role-based access; changes create an activity feed and conflict resolution (last-write-wins or per-item locks). Messaging is lightweight and task-oriented: comments on a grocery list item (e.g., “get lactose-free”) and assignment of list items to a person. Optional subscriptions manage premium features like unlimited collections, household seats, and export formats. APIs support CRUD for recipes, collections, meal plans, grocery lists, list items, shares, assignments, and audit events.

name: CollectibleVault (Digital Collection Catalog + Trading DMs)
description: CollectibleVault is a cataloging and curation platform for collectibles (TCG cards, comics, sneakers, vinyl, watches) focused on inventory management and structured trading. Users CRUD collection items (category, brand/set, identifiers like SKU/series, condition grade, purchase price, estimated value, photos metadata, storage location), plus custom attributes per category. Items can be organized into sets, showcases (curated galleries), and “for trade/sale” lists with asking price and trade preferences. The trading workflow is fully modeled: a user can create an offer referencing one or more items, specify cash adjustments, set expiration, and exchange messages within the offer thread. Offers progress through statuses (draft/sent/countered/accepted/declined/expired) and can generate a shipping task (carrier, label metadata, tracking number, insured value) without needing real shipping APIs. Watchlists allow monitoring of specific sets or attributes (e.g., “mint, size 10”) and trigger synthetic price-change alerts. A membership subscription can unlock valuation history, additional showcases, and advanced export. APIs include CRUD for items, sets, showcases, listings, offers, messages, watchlists, and shipment records.

name: SupportHub Desk (Customer Support Tickets + Knowledge Snippets)
description: SupportHub Desk is a customer support platform for small businesses that emphasizes tickets, messaging, and subscription-based SLAs. Customers submit tickets via email/web form/chat; agents CRUD tickets (subject, category, priority, requester, product, custom fields), comments, internal notes, and attachments metadata. Workflows include triage queues, assignment, status transitions (new/open/pending/on-hold/solved), escalation rules, and SLA timers that can be simulated deterministically. Conversations are threaded with channel metadata (email, chat, portal) and support structured macros (predefined replies) and canned knowledge snippets (short articles, tags, related links) rather than long documentation. Organizations CRUD customer accounts, contacts, entitlements (plan, seats, response-time tiers), and satisfaction ratings (CSAT per ticket). Automation entities include triggers (when status changes), actions (assign, tag, notify), and webhook events. Reporting dashboards derive from ticket events: first-response time, resolution time, reopen rates, agent workload. APIs cover CRUD for users/roles, customers, tickets, messages, tags, macros, SLAs, and audit logs—ideal for database-driven simulation with synthetic tickets and timelines.

name: CampusLoop (Membership Clubs + Announcements + Group Chat)
description: CampusLoop is a membership and communication platform for university clubs, associations, and chapters. Admins CRUD clubs, officers, membership tiers (student/alumni/sponsor), dues schedules, and application forms (fields, approvals, statuses). Members CRUD profiles (major, grad year, interests tags), notification preferences, and roles within each club. Communication is organized into channels: announcements (read receipts, pinned posts), event threads, and group chat with moderation tools (muted users, message deletion, report queue). The platform supports structured events: create event → RSVP → check-in roster → follow-up survey, with capacity limits and waitlists. Ticketing can be enabled per event with tiered pricing and promo codes, but payments are represented as transaction metadata for simulation. Club content is primarily structured: resource links, shared documents metadata, and curated link libraries per topic. Workflows include onboarding (invite link, approval), renewals (dues paid/unpaid), and member offboarding. APIs provide CRUD for clubs, memberships, dues invoices, channels, messages, events, RSVPs, check-ins, and moderation actions, enabling realistic multi-tenant, role-based simulations.

name: StreamPerks (Subscription Bundles + Loyalty + Rewards Wallet)
description: StreamPerks is a subscription management and loyalty platform for digital services (streaming, newsletters, online communities) that bundles memberships and tracks rewards. Users CRUD subscriptions (service, plan, start date, renewal cadence, status), payment methods (token metadata), and preferences (billing reminders, auto-renew on/off). Providers CRUD plans, bundle offers, coupon codes, trials, and entitlement rules (features unlocked, usage limits). A loyalty layer issues points and badges for actions (renewals, referrals, streaks, content completion as synthetic events), stored as ledger entries with reason codes. Users redeem rewards in a wallet: coupons, partner discounts, and perks with expiration dates. Referral workflows are structured: referral codes, invites, conversion statuses, and reward issuance. Customer support is integrated: users can open billing/support tickets tied to a subscription, with dispute statuses and escalation. The system produces invoices/receipts metadata and maintains audit logs for compliance. APIs cover CRUD for users, providers, plans, bundles, subscriptions, invoices, coupons, referral programs, points ledger, redemptions, and webhooks for renewal, cancellation, and reward-earned events.

name: PodShelf (Podcast Library + Playlists + Episode Bookmarks)
description: PodShelf is a podcast organization platform focused on library management, curation, and messaging around shared playlists, without needing actual audio hosting. Users CRUD show subscriptions, episode library entries (episode id, title, duration, publish date, description snippet), and playback progress (position seconds, completed flag). Key curation features include playlists/queues, smart filters (unplayed under 20 minutes, downloaded tag), and episode bookmarks with notes and timestamps. Users can create shareable playlists for friends or teams, manage collaborators, and discuss episodes via comments tied to an episode or bookmark. A “listen later” inbox supports triage: add → prioritize → archive. The platform models downloads as file metadata (device, size, status) to support realistic sync workflows. Notifications are based on structured events: new episode in a subscribed show, playlist updated, comment mention. Optional premium subscriptions unlock additional devices, collaborative playlist limits, and export. APIs cover CRUD for users, shows, episodes metadata, subscriptions, playlists, playlist items, progress records, bookmarks/notes, comments, devices, and notification events—highly synthesizable from stored metadata and timestamps.

name: ArtBoard Curator (Digital Gallery Curation + Client Messaging)
description: ArtBoard Curator is a platform for curating digital art selections for clients (interior designers, galleries, corporate buyers) using metadata rather than large media. Curators CRUD artworks (artist, title, year, medium, dimensions, edition info, price, availability, image/file metadata), collections, and presentation “boards” (layout order, theme tags, room context). Boards can be shared with clients with permissions and watermark settings (metadata). Client feedback is structured: like/dislike, rating, comments, and change requests (e.g., “swap frame,” “lower budget”) tracked as tasks with statuses. A messaging thread exists per board and per artwork, enabling negotiation without needing real payment processing. Workflow: curator drafts board → shares for review → iterates revisions (version snapshots) → client approves shortlist → generates a quote (line items, taxes/shipping estimates as numbers) → marks items reserved/sold. Inventory holds and expiration timers can be simulated. Subscription/membership supports multi-client seats, board limits, and brand customization. APIs include CRUD for artworks, artists, clients, boards, versions, feedback, messages, quotes, holds, and audit events.

name: MicroSurvey Vault (Forms + Panels + Incentive Tracking)
description: MicroSurvey Vault is a lightweight forms and survey platform optimized for recurring micro-polls and panel management. Creators CRUD surveys (title, status, schedule), questions (type, options, validation rules), logic (branch conditions), and distribution links. Respondents are modeled as panelists with profiles (demographics, tags, consent flags) and invitation statuses (invited/opened/started/completed/disqualified). Responses are stored as structured records with timestamps, device metadata, and score calculations. Workflows include: draft → test → publish → collect → close → export, with quota rules by segment and fraud checks modeled via flags (duplicate IP, too-fast completion). Incentives are tracked as ledger entries (points/cash equivalents), redemption requests, and payout statuses (pending/approved/paid) represented as metadata. Messaging/communication includes invite email templates, reminder schedules, and support inbox for respondent issues (ticket CRUD tied to a survey session). Dashboards aggregate completion rates, drop-off per question, and panel engagement—fully synthesizable. APIs cover CRUD for surveys, questions, logic, panels, invitations, responses, quotas, incentives ledger, redemptions, and support tickets/webhooks.

name: PulseChat Team Messaging (Channels + Approvals + Compliance)
description: PulseChat is a team messaging platform for companies that need structured conversations and auditable workflows. Users CRUD workspaces, profiles, devices, notification settings, and contact directories. Communication entities include channels (public/private), channel memberships and roles, threads, messages, reactions, attachments (file metadata), mentions, and bookmarks. Admins manage retention policies, eDiscovery holds, keyword rules, and export jobs. Workflow features are first-class: approval requests (e.g., “approve copy,” “approve discount,” “approve payout”) are created inside chats as structured objects with assignees, due dates, status (draft/submitted/approved/rejected/expired), and an immutable decision log. Integrations are modeled as connected apps with OAuth tokens (metadata), event subscriptions, and webhooks; message events can create tasks or tickets in external systems. Moderation includes message edits/deletes with audit records, user suspensions, and channel archiving. Typical API scenarios: post messages, fetch history with pagination, manage channel membership, create approval objects from a message, update approval status, and run compliance exports over a date range.

name: RelayDesk Customer Support (Omnichannel Inbox + SLA + Knowledge Base Metadata)
description: RelayDesk is a customer support platform centered on a unified ticket inbox across email, web forms, chat widgets, and social DMs (stored as message metadata, not media content). Core entities include customers, contacts, organizations, tickets, ticket comments, internal notes, attachments (metadata), tags, custom fields, and status (new/open/pending/on-hold/solved). Agents CRUD macros, canned responses, views/queues, and personal workload settings. Workflow entities include SLAs (targets by priority), business hours calendars, escalation rules, and automations that transition ticket state based on timers or events (e.g., auto-close after 7 days). The platform supports assignments, watcher lists, @mentions, collision detection, and audit logs. A lightweight knowledge base is modeled as articles with title/summary, category, visibility, and version metadata (no long-form content requirement), plus feedback votes. Reporting is fully synthesizable: handle time, first response time, reopen rate, and CSAT surveys (rating + short comment). APIs cover ticket creation, threading, merges/splits, SLA timers, assignment changes, and event webhooks.

name: MemberNest Subscriptions (Plans + Entitlements + Pauses + Billing)
description: MemberNest is a subscription/membership management platform for digital services, clubs, and SaaS add-ons. Admins CRUD products, plans (monthly/annual), pricing, trial rules, coupons, and feature entitlements (limits, roles, access flags). Customers CRUD accounts, payment methods (token metadata), subscriptions, add-ons, and billing addresses. The billing ledger is modeled with invoices, line items, taxes, credits, proration adjustments, and payment attempts with retry schedules. Lifecycle workflows include signup → trial → active → past-due → grace-period → canceled, plus pause/resume, plan upgrades/downgrades with proration, and reactivation. Entitlements are computed as records tied to a subscription and can be queried by downstream apps (e.g., “max_projects,” “premium_support,” “gym_access_level”). The platform supports seat-based memberships: organizations CRUD teams, seats, invites, and seat assignments. Dunning communications are represented as message logs (channel, template, send status). APIs cover subscription creation, schedule changes, invoice generation, payment webhooks, entitlement checks, and admin overrides with full audit history.

name: PerkPoints Loyalty Wallet (Earn/Burn + Tiers + Offers)
description: PerkPoints is a loyalty program platform for multi-location retailers and service businesses. Merchants CRUD locations, registers (POS IDs), staff users, earning rules (points per dollar, category multipliers), redemption rules, and tier thresholds (Silver/Gold/Platinum). Customers CRUD profiles, linked identifiers (phone, email, membership card number), consent flags, and communication preferences. The points system is modeled as a ledger: earn events, redeem events, adjustments, expirations, and reversals, each tied to a transaction reference and timestamp to prevent double-posting. Offers and campaigns are structured objects with targeting filters (tier, location, date range), coupon codes, and redemption limits; redemptions create records with status (reserved/redeemed/voided). Receipt uploads are represented as file metadata plus extracted totals entered manually (no OCR dependency). The platform supports referrals (referrer/referee, reward status), birthday bonuses, and customer service tools to issue goodwill credits with reason codes. APIs simulate POS posting, points balance queries, tier recalculation jobs, offer eligibility checks, and monthly statements.

name: StreamShelf Digital Library (Licenses + Playlists + Access Windows)
description: StreamShelf is a digital content access platform focused on managing licensed catalogs rather than generating content. Providers CRUD content items as metadata (title, series, season/episode numbers, duration, rating, genres, cover-art file references), license windows (start/end), and regional availability flags. Users CRUD profiles, watchlists, playlists, parental controls, and playback progress markers (position seconds, last played timestamp) for resume functionality. Subscription entitlements integrate with plan data: ads/no-ads, max devices, and offline download limits (downloads represented as device-bound records with expiry timestamps). Social features remain lightweight and synthesizable: short reviews/ratings, content reactions, and “continue watching” rows. Operational workflows include catalog ingestion jobs, availability audits, takedown requests, and reporting on views (event logs), completion rate, and device concurrency violations. Search can be limited to deterministic filtering over metadata fields (no web-scale ranking). APIs cover catalog browsing by filters, entitlement checks, progress updates, playlist CRUD, license window enforcement, and event ingestion for analytics dashboards.

name: WellSpring Coaching (Wellness Programs + Habits + Check-ins)
description: WellSpring is a wellness coaching platform for individuals and employer-sponsored programs. Users CRUD health profiles (goals, constraints, preferences), habit plans, reminders, and daily check-ins (mood, stress, sleep quality scores, short notes). Coaches CRUD client rosters, program templates (weeks, modules), assignments, and session schedules. Program content is represented as structured modules with titles, estimated time, and resource links (metadata) rather than long articles. Workflows include onboarding assessments → goal setting → weekly plans → adherence tracking → program completion. Messaging is included as secure chat threads between client and coach with message logs and attachments (metadata). Measurements are modeled as time-series entries (weight, steps, hydration, blood pressure values if needed), all synthesize-friendly. Employers can CRUD cohorts, eligibility, incentives, and aggregated reporting views with privacy controls. API simulations include creating program enrollments, assigning modules, posting check-ins, generating adherence summaries, scheduling sessions, and exporting progress reports. The system supports alerts when check-ins indicate risk thresholds, creating a “follow-up task” for a coach.

name: LiftLedger Workout Tracker (Routines + Sets + PRs + Wearables Metadata)
description: LiftLedger is a workout tracking app focused on structured training data. Users CRUD exercise libraries (name, muscle groups, equipment), routines, scheduled training days, and workout logs. A workout log contains sets with weight, reps, RPE, rest time, tempo, and notes, plus timestamps for start/end and location (optional gym ID). The platform computes personal records (PRs) as derived entities: best 1RM estimate, max reps at weight, volume PR, and streaks, all reproducible from synthetic logs. Program workflows support progressive overload rules: increase weight when reps hit target for N sessions, deload weeks, and autoregulation adjustments based on RPE. Social features stay structured: follow relationships, workout “kudos,” and short comments on logs. Wearable integrations are modeled as device connections (token metadata) and imported summaries (heart rate avg/max, calories, duration) without needing raw sensor streams. APIs cover routine CRUD, workout creation, set updates, PR queries, calendar scheduling, and exporting training history to CSV-like records.

name: GymFlow Studio Management (Classes + Memberships + Check-ins + Staff)
description: GymFlow is a gym/studio management system for memberships, classes, and front-desk operations. Owners CRUD locations, rooms, equipment resources, staff roles, instructors, and member accounts. Offerings include memberships (plans, billing cadence, freeze rules), class packs, and drop-in passes, each producing entitlements with visit limits and expiration. Scheduling entities include class templates, sessions, instructor assignments, capacity, waitlists, and cancellation policies. Member workflows include signup → waiver signing (signature metadata) → booking → waitlist promotion → check-in; no-shows and late cancels generate penalties or strikes. Check-ins are modeled as scan events via QR/barcode tokens, front-desk override reasons, and attendance records. The platform supports lead intake (trials), sales tasks, and simple CRM pipelines for conversions. Payment data can be simulated with invoices, receipts, refunds, and failed payments; integrations with door access are represented as access grants per member with start/end dates. APIs cover booking, waitlist operations, membership freezes, attendance exports, instructor payroll summaries (hours taught), and capacity utilization reporting.

name: MacroMate Nutrition Planner (Meals + Pantry + Grocery Lists + Targets)
description: MacroMate is a nutrition tracking and meal planning platform where all data can be synthesized from structured nutrition entries. Users CRUD dietary profiles (calorie/macro targets, allergens, preferences), custom foods (nutrition per serving), recipes (ingredients + quantities), meals, and daily logs. A pantry module tracks inventory items (quantity, unit, expiration date) and supports depletion rules when recipes are logged. Meal plans are weekly schedules with planned vs. actual adherence, plus leftover handling as a structured quantity. Grocery lists are generated as entities with line items, store categories, and purchased flags; barcode scans can be represented as product IDs without needing real images. The system supports goals (cut/bulk/maintenance), check-in measurements (weight, waist), and compliance scores. Social or coaching add-ons are structured: share a meal plan with a coach, receive comments, and approve plan revisions with version history. APIs cover food/recipe CRUD, daily log posting, target calculations, pantry adjustments, grocery list generation, and exporting nutrition summaries (averages, micronutrient totals if included as numeric fields).

name: Google Workspace Admin Console
description: Google Workspace Admin Console is an identity, device, and policy management portal for organizations using Gmail/Drive/Meet. Admins CRUD users, groups, organizational units, roles, and access policies. Directory entities include aliases, shared mailboxes, and group memberships with role (member/manager/owner). Device management covers endpoints as records (serial, model, OS, last check-in), compliance status, and actions (lock, wipe, require passcode). Security workflows include SSO/SAML settings, MFA enrollment enforcement, login challenges, and audit log review. Admins manage licenses and subscriptions, tracking assigned seats and billing cycles. Drive governance can be simulated as shared drive metadata, sharing policies, and external access exceptions, without requiring actual file contents (only file/folder metadata, ownership, and permissions). Lifecycle workflows include onboarding (create user, assign license, add to groups, provision device) and offboarding (suspend, transfer ownership, revoke tokens, archive). Data is synthesizable: directory records, policy states, token/session logs, device posture, and admin actions, enabling realistic API simulations for provisioning, compliance checks, and audit reporting.

name: FundTrackr (Personal Portfolio + Dividend Calendar)
description: FundTrackr is a personal investing organizer for ETFs, mutual funds, and individual stocks focused on portfolio records rather than live market data. Users CRUD portfolios, holdings (ticker, quantity, cost basis lots, tax lot method), cash balances, and manual price snapshots (date, price, source tag). A dividend module lets users CRUD dividend schedules (ex-date, pay date, amount per share), dividend receipts, and reinvestment rules, generating a forecast calendar and payout history. Workflows include: import/create transactions (buy/sell/dividend/fee/transfer) → reconcile positions → generate performance summaries (time-weighted/ money-weighted) using stored snapshots. Users can tag assets (sector, strategy), define allocation targets, and set alerts for drift thresholds and upcoming dividend events. A “rebalance plan” feature creates proposed trades (not executed) with approval and status tracking. Reports are exportable (CSV/PDF metadata), and accounts can be shared with an advisor role for read-only access and comment threads on holdings and planned trades.

name: CryptoVault Ledger (Wallet Watchlists + On-Chain Journal)
description: CryptoVault Ledger is a crypto tracking and bookkeeping app that simulates wallet activity without requiring real chain connectivity. Users CRUD wallets (chain, address label, custody type), tokens (symbol, contract id, decimals), and transactions (hash placeholder, from/to wallet, token, amount, fees, timestamp, status). A watchlist module lets users follow token sets and maintain manual price points and volatility bands for alerts. Users can categorize transactions (swap, transfer, staking reward, airdrop, mint) and attach notes, counterparties, and evidence metadata (receipt links, screenshots). Workflows include: create wallet → add tokens → record transactions → reconcile balances → generate taxable events (realized gains, income) using stored cost basis lots and synthetic price snapshots. A “staking” area models validator positions, lockups, reward accrual schedules, and claim events with status transitions (pending/claimable/claimed). Teams can manage permissions, requiring approvals for edits to transactions and cost basis, with an audit log for every CRUD change.

name: SplitNest (Group Expenses + Settlement Requests)
description: SplitNest is a group payments and expense-splitting platform for roommates, trips, and clubs. Users CRUD groups, members, payment methods (token metadata), and expenses (amount, currency, merchant, date, category, receipt metadata). Each expense contains line-item splits with rules (equal, percentages, shares, custom amounts) and supports exclusions. Workflows include: create group → invite members → add expenses → compute balances → create settlement requests. Settlements are modeled as payment intents with statuses (draft/sent/accepted/paid/failed/expired) and can be bundled into a single “settle up” batch. Users can issue IOUs, create recurring expenses (rent, utilities), and set due dates with reminder schedules. A disputes module supports raising an issue on an expense line (reason code, comments, resolution status) and tracks edits with version history. Reporting endpoints provide per-member totals, category breakdowns, and monthly statements. The platform supports multiple groups per user, per-group roles (admin/treasurer/member), and exportable ledgers suitable for API-driven simulations of realistic peer-to-peer money workflows.

name: InvoiceFlow Pay (Freelancer Invoicing + Client Portal)
description: InvoiceFlow Pay is a lightweight invoicing and payments portal for freelancers and small agencies. Users CRUD clients, projects, rate cards, invoices (line items, taxes, discounts, due dates), and estimates that can be converted into invoices with versioning. Payments are represented as payment records tied to invoices with method metadata and statuses (initiated/authorized/captured/failed/refunded). Workflows include: create client → create estimate → approve → issue invoice → send reminders → record payment → reconcile and close. The client portal supports viewing invoices, downloading PDFs (metadata), saving payment details, and submitting billing questions via threaded messages attached to an invoice. Subscriptions/retainers are modeled as recurring invoices with pause/resume and proration rules. A disputes and adjustments module lets users issue credit notes, partial refunds, and write-offs with reason codes and audit trails. Reporting includes aging summaries, cashflow by month, and outstanding balances. Webhooks can simulate events like invoice viewed, payment succeeded, and overdue reminders sent.

name: LinkStack Collections (Bookmarks + Team Curation Boards)
description: LinkStack Collections is a bookmarking and curation platform for saving links, files-as-metadata, and structured snippets. Users CRUD bookmarks (URL, title, description, preview metadata, tags), collections/boards, and collaborators with permissions (owner/editor/viewer). Bookmarks can include custom fields (rating, read status, priority, source) and attachments metadata (PDF link, thumbnail URL). Workflows include: capture link → enrich metadata → assign to collection → annotate → share to team. Teams can create “curation pipelines” where bookmarks move through statuses (inbox/triaged/approved/published) and require review before appearing on a public board. Discussion is structured via comments and reactions on each bookmark, plus change logs for edits to titles/tags. Users can create smart collections based on filters (tag contains, domain, last updated, read status). Export/import endpoints support JSON/CSV for migration. The platform is API-friendly for CRUD-heavy simulations: link creation, tagging, access control, moderation, and analytics counters (views, saves, shares) that can be synthesized.

name: OutfitVault (Fashion Wishlists + Closet Inventory)
description: OutfitVault is a fashion wishlist and digital closet organizer focused on structured product and wardrobe data rather than checkout. Users CRUD closet items (brand, category, size, color, season tags, purchase date, price, condition, photo metadata) and wishlist items (store URL, target price, current price snapshot, availability flag). Items can be grouped into outfits (ordered components, occasion tags) and packing lists for trips. Workflows include: add closet item → create outfit combinations → schedule outfits on a calendar → track wears and cost-per-wear metrics using synthesized counters. A price-watch module supports thresholds and notification rules per wishlist item, plus history of price snapshots. Users can share wishlists with friends or stylists with comment permissions and can mark items as gifted/purchased with provenance metadata. A resale prep flow generates a listing draft (title, attributes, condition notes, asking price) without requiring a marketplace. The platform supports multiple closets per user (personal/work), collaboration on shared suitcases, and bulk tag editing—ideal for CRUD and relational database simulations.

name: ForumForge (Moderated Community Forums + Reputation)
description: ForumForge is a classic forum platform optimized for API-driven CRUD operations and moderation workflows. Users CRUD accounts, profiles, forum categories, threads, posts (short text, attachments metadata), and reactions. Threads support labels, status (open/answered/locked/archived), and accepted answer selection. Moderation entities include reports (reason code, reporter, target post), actions (remove, edit, warn, suspend), ban records, and appeal tickets with timelines. Workflows include: create thread → receive replies → mark accepted answer → close or keep open; or report content → moderator reviews queue → action recorded → user notified → appeal resolved. A reputation system tracks points for upvotes, accepted answers, and rule violations, unlocking roles (member, trusted, moderator). Admins manage rule sets, auto-moderation filters (keyword lists, rate limits), and category-level permissions. Analytics endpoints provide counts by category, response times, and top contributors, all synthesizable. The platform is suitable for simulations of relational data (users↔posts↔moderation logs), state transitions, and role-based access control.

name: DateLoop (Dating Profiles + Matches + Safety Checks)
description: DateLoop is a dating app scenario focused on profile management and match workflows without requiring AI-based recommendations. Users CRUD dating profiles (bio, age, gender, preferences, photos metadata, interests tags), privacy settings, and verification artifacts metadata (ID check status, selfie check status). Discovery is modeled via deterministic filters (distance range, age range, interests overlap), with users generating likes, passes, and blocks as separate entities. Workflows include: create profile → set preferences → browse results → like/pass → match created when mutual → open chat thread → schedule date plan. The date planning module lets matched users CRUD date ideas (venue name, time, budget range, location coordinates) and confirmations (proposed/accepted/canceled). Safety features include reporting a user, sharing a “date itinerary” with a trusted contact (contact entity, share status), and check-in timers (scheduled, confirmed, missed) that trigger notifications. Messaging is bounded to short text with delivery/read statuses. Admin tools cover content review queues, sanctions, and audit logs—ideal for API simulation of lifecycle states and trust/safety CRUD.

name: CharityCircle Wallet (Donations + Recurring Giving + Receipts)
description: CharityCircle Wallet is a donation and recurring giving platform combining payment records with curated nonprofit lists. Users CRUD donor profiles, saved nonprofits (cause tags, regions), donation campaigns (goal amount, timeframe), and donations (amount, currency, designation, anonymity flag, timestamp). Recurring giving is modeled as subscriptions with cadence, next charge date, status (active/paused/canceled/past_due), and retry rules. Workflows include: discover nonprofit list → add to giving plan → set recurring amount → process charges → issue receipts → year-end summary. Receipts are entities with tax fields, PDF metadata links, and delivery status (sent/opened/bounced). Donors can create personal fundraising pages with structured updates (short fields, milestones) and manage supporter lists and thank-you messages templates. Nonprofit admins CRUD organization profiles, bank payout accounts (token metadata), payout schedules, and acknowledgement templates. A compliance module tracks donor consent flags, refund requests, and dispute statuses. The system supports role-based access (donor, nonprofit admin, platform admin) and fully synthesizable financial and engagement data.

name: CareCircle Patient Portal
description: CareCircle is a patient portal for a multi-clinic health system focused on structured record access and self-service workflows. Patients CRUD their profile (demographics, preferred pharmacy, emergency contacts), insurance policies (payer, member ID, coverage dates), communication preferences, and consent forms (versioned acknowledgements). Clinical data is modeled as read-only summaries plus user-managed additions: problem list confirmations, allergies, medications (active/inactive, dose, start/stop dates), and home vitals logs (BP, glucose, weight). Appointment workflows include searching provider locations, requesting/scheduling visits, completing pre-visit questionnaires, uploading document metadata, and checking in with arrival status. Secure messaging supports threads tied to a department or visit, with message status (sent/received/read) and attachment metadata. Results and documents are organized by encounters (labs, imaging reports as structured fields, discharge instructions), and patients can request records exports. Billing features include statement line items, payment plans, card token metadata, receipts, and dispute tickets. APIs simulate realistic state transitions: appointment requested → confirmed → checked-in → completed; message triaged → answered; bill issued → partially paid → settled.

name: TeleMedNow Virtual Clinic
description: TeleMedNow is a telehealth platform for on-demand and scheduled virtual visits without needing actual video. Patients CRUD accounts, dependents, preferred providers, symptoms/intake forms (structured answers), and visit requests. Providers CRUD availability blocks, visit types (urgent care, dermatology, mental health follow-up), service regions, and templates for clinical notes (SOAP sections as short text fields). A visit record contains statuses (requested, waiting room, in-session, completed, canceled), triage priority, assigned clinician, and timestamps. During a visit, clinicians create structured encounter artifacts: diagnoses (codes), prescriptions (drug, dose, quantity, refills, instructions), lab orders (test, priority, collection window), and follow-up tasks. Messaging is tied to a visit for asynchronous care, with escalation rules (e.g., unanswered within 24h). Payments are modeled as invoices with line items (visit fee, add-ons), coupons, insurance copay estimates, and refunds. Post-visit workflows include patient satisfaction ratings, care plan checklists, and automated reminders. The system supports audit logs, clinician licensing verification metadata, and role-based access for coordinators who can reschedule, reassign, and manage queues.

name: RxRelay Pharmacy & Refills
description: RxRelay is a digital pharmacy portal centered on prescription lifecycle management and fulfillment logistics. Patients CRUD profiles, delivery addresses, insurance cards (metadata), and preferred pickup locations. They manage prescriptions as structured entities: medication, prescriber, dosage, days supply, remaining refills, substitution allowed, and status (new, processing, ready, shipped, delivered, on-hold). Refill workflows include eligibility checks (too soon, no refills left), refill requests, prior authorization tasks, and pharmacist clarification messages to prescribers (modeled as request/response tickets). Orders are created from one or more prescriptions with shipping method, cold-chain flag, package tracking numbers, and delivery time windows. Patients can set adherence reminders and manage medication schedules (times per day, start/end), plus record side effects as coded events. Pharmacists CRUD inventory lots (NDC, quantity, expiration), dispense events, substitutions, and counseling notes. Payments include copay estimates, coupons, HSA/FSA card token metadata, invoices, and refunds. The platform supports controlled-substance constraints via additional verification statuses and required signature flags, all fully synthesizable through deterministic state transitions.

name: MediClaims Benefits & Claims Hub
