description: MediClaims is a healthcare insurance member portal and claims tracker emphasizing predictable, database-driven processes. Members CRUD their household (dependents), plan selections (effective dates, tier), PCP selection, and benefit preferences (paperless, reimbursement method). Claims are modeled as structured records with provider, service date, procedure codes, billed amount, allowed amount, member responsibility, and adjudication status (received, pending info, processed, denied, appealed). Users submit reimbursement claims by CRUD-ing claim forms, attaching receipt metadata, and tracking requests for additional documentation. Prior authorization is handled as a workflow entity: request, clinical criteria checklist, decision, and expiration. A directory module supports managing saved providers and facilities (IDs, specialties, locations) and scheduling callbacks. Payments and reimbursements include EFT details (tokenized bank info), check issuance, and remittance advice. Appeals are ticket-like objects with deadlines, statuses, and decision reasons (coded). The system generates explanations of benefits as structured line items rather than long narrative. Admin roles can manage plan documents versions, benefit tables, provider contracts metadata, and member communications campaigns with delivery status and read acknowledgments.

name: HeartBridge Remote Monitoring
description: HeartBridge is a remote patient monitoring platform for chronic care programs that focuses on devices, readings, and care-team workflows. Clinics CRUD programs (hypertension, diabetes), enrollment rules, and threshold policies (e.g., systolic > 160 triggers alert). Patients CRUD device pairings (BP cuff, scale, glucometer; serial, last sync), measurement schedules, and manual entries. Readings are structured time-series entities with units, device source, and validation flags. Alerts are generated as records with severity, reason codes, assigned nurse, and status (new, acknowledged, contacted, resolved). Care teams CRUD outreach attempts (call, message), care plans (goals, interventions, target dates), and tasks (review readings, schedule follow-up). A messaging module supports secure threads per patient with templated check-ins. Billing is modeled as monthly monitoring statements with billable minutes logs, modifiers, and claim submission statuses (draft, submitted, paid, rejected). The platform supports audit logs, role-based access, and export jobs for EHR integration. All data is synthesizable: devices, readings, thresholds, alert outcomes, and time-based workflows like missed-measurement reminders and escalation after repeated abnormal values.

name: ProLink Network (Professional Profiles & Referrals)
description: ProLink Network is a professional networking platform optimized for structured profiles, referrals, and recruiting pipelines rather than content feeds. Users CRUD profiles (headline, skills tags, certifications, locations), employment history, education, and availability preferences (open to work, contract-only). Connections are managed via requests (pending/accepted/blocked) and contact labels. Companies CRUD organization pages, teams, and job requisitions with structured fields (title, level, salary range, location/remote, required skills, status). Candidates CRUD applications, resumes as file metadata, questionnaires, and interview availability. Hiring managers manage pipelines with stages (applied, screened, interview, offer, hired, rejected), assign interviewers, capture scorecards (numeric ratings + short notes), and send templated messages. Referrals are first-class entities linking referrer, candidate, job, and reward status (eligible, submitted, paid). The platform includes a lightweight events module for webinars/meetups (RSVPs, attendance, follow-up tasks) and analytics dashboards (conversion rates, time-to-hire) based on stored metrics. APIs are rich in CRUD and workflow transitions while remaining fully synthesizable.

name: MatchLane Dating (Profiles, Preferences, Safety)
description: MatchLane is a dating app scenario emphasizing structured profiles, matchmaking preferences, and moderated interaction workflows. Users CRUD profiles (bio short text, age, location, interests tags, lifestyle attributes), photo metadata, and discovery settings (distance radius, age range, dealbreakers). Swipe actions create interaction records (like, pass, super-like) with timestamps and limits. When two likes occur, a match entity is created with status (active, paused, unmatched) and conversation permissions. Messaging is modeled as threads per match with message objects, delivery/read states, and attachment metadata (no actual media required). Safety features are key entities: identity verification status (unverified, pending, verified), block lists, report tickets (reason codes, evidence metadata), and moderator actions (warning, temporary suspension, ban). Date planning can be simulated via “plans” objects: venue suggestion (place name, category, coordinates), proposed time slots, confirmations, and cancellations. Subscription tiers manage entitlements (daily likes limit, advanced filters) and billing records (renewal cadence, invoices, payment token metadata). The platform supports audit logs and deterministic rate limiting—ideal for API-driven CRUD and state transitions without needing AI matching or content-heavy feeds.

name: ChainWallet Crypto Portfolio & Transfers
description: ChainWallet is a cryptocurrency wallet and portfolio platform that simulates on-chain activity through ledger-style records rather than real blockchain access. Users CRUD wallets (addresses, labels), token holdings, watchlists, and contact books (trusted recipient addresses with whitelisting). Transfers are modeled as transactions with fields (from, to, asset, amount, network, fee, nonce, status: created, signed, broadcast, confirmed, failed). Users can create recurring buys as scheduled orders (asset, fiat amount, cadence) and manage limits, KYC verification status, and withdrawal whitelists with cool-down timers. The platform includes staking entities (validator, amount, lock-up, rewards accrual) and DeFi-like positions (pool, deposited amounts, APR snapshots) represented as structured records. Security workflows include 2FA devices, session tokens, risk flags, and manual review cases for unusual activity. Statements and tax lots are generated from stored transactions (cost basis lots, realized gains) without requiring external price feeds beyond synthesizable price snapshots. Admin APIs manage asset catalogs (symbol, decimals, network support), fee tables, and compliance holds—highly suitable for deterministic API simulations.

name: BillFlow Payments & Invoicing
description: BillFlow is a payments platform for freelancers and small businesses centered on invoicing, payouts, and dispute workflows. Merchants CRUD customers, products/services (rate, tax category), invoices (line items, due dates, discounts), and recurring subscriptions (plan, cadence, proration rules, status). Payment methods are stored as token metadata; payments generate transaction records with authorization/capture/refund states, fees, and settlement dates. Payouts are modeled as batches to bank accounts with statuses (queued, sent, failed) and reconciliation fields. Disputes and chargebacks are handled as case entities with evidence checklists, deadlines, and outcomes. The platform supports multi-currency balances, exchange rate snapshots (synthesizable), and bookkeeping exports (journal entries). Team features include roles/permissions, approval workflows for refunds, and audit trails. Customer-facing portals allow clients to view invoices, update billing details, download receipts, and manage subscription cancellations. Webhooks/event logs are first-class objects for developers to test integrations (invoice.created, payment.succeeded, dispute.opened). The focus remains on CRUD-able entities and predictable lifecycle transitions rather than fraud AI or external network dependencies.

name: CareForum (Patient Communities & Moderation)
description: CareForum is a health-focused community and forum platform designed around short, structured posts and rigorous moderation rather than long-form publishing. Users CRUD profiles (conditions tags, treatment interests, anonymity settings), follow topics, and create posts with bounded fields (title, body length limits, condition/category tags). Replies and reactions (upvote, helpful, support) are stored as entities with timestamps. Threads support status controls (open, locked, resolved) and pinned resources (link metadata). A symptom tracker add-on lets users log daily entries (pain score, mood scale, medication adherence yes/no) and optionally attach them to posts as structured context. Moderation is workflow-heavy: reports (reason codes, severity), automated holds (new user rate limits), moderator reviews, actions (remove, edit request, suspend), and appeal tickets. Private groups for cohort programs (e.g., post-op recovery) include membership requests, roles, and scheduled check-in prompts. Clinician or verified-coach accounts can publish “verified answers” as short responses with credential metadata. The platform includes notification preferences, digest subscriptions, and analytics on engagement—all fully synthesizable and well-suited to API/database interaction without relying on external content or AI inference.

name: CardWise Issuing (Virtual & Physical Card Program Manager)
description: CardWise Issuing is a card-issuing management platform for fintechs and SMBs to create and control virtual/physical debit or prepaid cards. Admins CRUD programs (BIN/config metadata), cardholders (KYC fields, limits, status), funding accounts, and card products (tiers, fee tables, controls). Core objects include cards (PAN token references, activation state, shipping address), spend controls (MCC blocks, merchant allowlists, velocity limits), and authorizations/transactions (amount, merchant metadata, timestamps, status lifecycle: authorized/cleared/reversed/chargeback). Workflows: onboard cardholder → verify identity → issue virtual card instantly → optionally order physical card → set limits → fund account → monitor spend and disputes. The platform supports card freeze/unfreeze, reissue, PIN set/reset metadata, and webhook-driven event logs for auth decisions and settlements. Reporting features CRUD scheduled exports, reconciliation batches, and accounting mappings (GL codes per transaction type). Support agents manage disputes (reason codes, evidence attachments metadata, deadlines), refunds, and card replacement requests. All data is synthesizable: merchants, authorizations, limits, and settlement files can be generated deterministically for testing API integrations.

name: BillFlow Payables (AP Automation + Vendor Payments)
description: BillFlow Payables is an accounts-payable automation tool for small businesses that centralizes vendor records, bills, approvals, and outbound payments. Users CRUD vendors (addresses, tax IDs, payment preferences), bills/invoices (line items, due dates, currency, attachments metadata), purchase orders, and approval policies (roles, thresholds). Payments are modeled as payment intents (ACH/check/virtual card), funding sources, and execution batches with statuses (draft/queued/sent/failed/settled). Workflows: capture bill → match to PO/receipt → route for approval → schedule payment → run payment batch → sync settlement results → post to ledger. The platform also manages vendor onboarding tasks (W-9 request status, bank account verification status), early-pay discounts, and recurring bills. Admins can define spend categories and accounting mappings; exports can be generated per period. Audit trails store immutable events (who approved, when fields changed). Test environments can synthesize vendors, invoices, and settlement outcomes to validate idempotency, retries, webhooks, and role-based access across endpoints.

name: NestEgg Robo (Goal-Based Investing & Rebalancing)
description: NestEgg Robo is a goal-based investment platform that simulates brokerage-like portfolios without relying on live market feeds. Users CRUD goals (retirement, house, emergency fund), risk profiles, contribution schedules, and linked funding accounts. The system models portfolios as target allocations across model funds/ETFs (symbols, expense ratios, asset classes), holdings, cash balances, and trade orders. Workflows: create goal → complete risk questionnaire → generate portfolio proposal → accept IPS settings (constraints, ESG exclusions) → fund account → place recurring buys → periodic rebalancing trades. Orders move through statuses (created/submitted/partially_filled/filled/canceled) with fills generated from synthetic price series and timestamps. Tax features include lots (cost basis, acquisition date), realized gains reports, and tax-loss harvesting rules that can be simulated deterministically. Notifications and documents are stored as statements (period, PDF metadata), confirmations, and alerts. Admins CRUD model portfolios and drift thresholds. The API surface supports backtesting endpoints with generated historical returns, enabling realistic integration tests around order lifecycle, portfolio math, and statement delivery.

name: ChainCustody Vault (Crypto Custody + Policy Approvals)
description: ChainCustody Vault is an institutional crypto custody platform centered on wallet governance, approvals, and auditability rather than on-chain complexity. Orgs CRUD entities (departments, users, roles), assets (BTC/ETH/stablecoins as symbols), vault wallets (addresses, network, labels), and policy rules (quorum, spending limits, allowlisted destination addresses). Transactions are modeled as transfer requests with metadata (asset, amount, from/to, fee tier, purpose tag) and lifecycle statuses (draft/pending_approval/approved/signed/broadcasted/confirmed/rejected/expired). Workflows: request transfer → collect approvals (per role, timeouts) → generate signing session records (signer devices metadata) → broadcast event → confirmations simulated with block height counters. The platform also manages address books, deposit monitoring (incoming transfer records), and reconciliation reports by period. Security features include mandatory travel-rule fields, risk flags, and incident cases. All objects are synthesizable: addresses, confirmations, fees, and approval outcomes can be generated to test policy enforcement, multi-user concurrency, webhooks, and immutable audit logs.

name: ClaimBridge Clearing (Healthcare Claims & Eligibility)
description: ClaimBridge Clearing is a claims and eligibility management portal for clinics and billing services. Staff CRUD patients (demographics, coverage), payers/plans, providers (NPI metadata), appointments/encounters, diagnoses/procedures (codes), and claims (837-like structured fields, line items, modifiers, amounts). Workflows: verify eligibility → create encounter → build claim from charge capture → run validations (missing fields, code conflicts) → submit → track responses (accepted/rejected/denied/paid) with remittance advice records (EOB line details, allowed amounts, adjustments, reason codes). Users manage claim corrections, resubmissions, and appeals (attachments metadata, deadlines, status). Posting payments creates payment batches tied to remittances, updating patient responsibility and account balances. The platform supports prior authorization records (service, units, validity window) and coordination of benefits. Reports CRUD run configurations (date ranges, payer grouping) and export jobs. For API simulation, payers, responses, denial reason codes, and payment timelines can be synthesized to test end-to-end revenue-cycle workflows without requiring real PHI.

name: TeleVisit Connect (Telehealth Scheduling + Visit Notes)
description: TeleVisit Connect is a telehealth platform focused on appointment logistics, documentation, and billing-ready artifacts rather than real video streaming. Patients CRUD profiles, insurance details, preferred pharmacy, intake forms (structured answers), and appointment requests. Clinics CRUD providers, availability templates, appointment types (duration, price, eligibility rules), and care teams. Visits are objects with status transitions (requested/confirmed/checked_in/in_session/completed/no_show), join links (token metadata), and consent records. Clinicians create structured notes (SOAP sections with bounded text), problem lists, vitals, and orders (labs, imaging, referrals) as discrete entities. Prescriptions are stored as eRx drafts (drug, dosage, quantity, refills, pharmacy routing metadata) with approval/signing status. Workflows: patient requests visit → eligibility check → schedule and reminders → collect pre-visit forms → clinician documents encounter → generate superbill/claim draft → patient invoice and payment. Admins manage templates, coding suggestions as rule-based mappings, and audit logs. All data—schedules, notes snippets, orders, and payment statuses—can be synthesized for realistic API testing.

name: MediRefill Portal (Pharmacy Refill & Inventory Operations)
description: MediRefill Portal is a pharmacy operations and patient refill system that models dispensing workflows without requiring actual controlled substance handling. Patients CRUD profiles, addresses, insurance, allergies, and medication lists; they submit refill requests tied to prescriptions. Pharmacy staff CRUD prescribers, prescriptions (drug identifiers, directions, days supply, refills remaining), prior authorizations, and fulfillment tasks. Inventory is tracked via NDC-like items, lots (expiration), on-hand counts, reorder points, and supplier purchase orders. Workflows: receive refill request → verify eligibility and refills → check inventory → queue for fill → label/pack status → pickup/delivery scheduling → completion with counseling acknowledgment. Delivery features include courier assignments, route stops, and proof-of-delivery metadata. The portal stores communications as message threads with templates and opt-in flags, plus clinical interventions (substitution allowed, drug utilization review flags). Billing objects include copay estimates, claims submissions (status only), and patient invoices. Synthetic data can generate prescriptions, inventory movements, and fulfillment timelines to test concurrency, idempotent updates, and webhook notifications.

name: GiveLedger Grants (Nonprofit Grantmaking & Disbursements)
description: GiveLedger Grants is a grantmaking platform for foundations and nonprofits to manage the full lifecycle of applications, reviews, awards, and disbursements. Applicants CRUD organizations, profiles, programs, budgets (line items), and applications with structured narratives (bounded fields, not long articles), attachments metadata, and compliance attestations. Funders CRUD grant programs (eligibility rules, cycles, scoring rubrics), reviewers/panels, and review assignments. Applications move through statuses (draft/submitted/in_review/clarification/approved/declined) with scorecards stored as structured criteria and comments. Award management includes grant agreements (versioned templates, e-sign metadata), payment schedules (milestones, due dates), and disbursement records (amount, method, status, reference IDs). Grantees submit reporting deliverables (KPIs, outcomes metrics, expenditures) as structured forms; funders track overdue items and renewals. Finance features include budget vs actual tracking, restricted fund tagging, and audit logs. The system can synthesize applicants, scores, awards, and payment statuses to validate workflows, permissions, and reporting APIs.

name: DonorLoop Recurring (Donations + Pledges + Matching Campaigns)
description: DonorLoop Recurring is a fundraising and donation operations platform optimized for recurring gifts, pledge drives, and corporate matching. Nonprofits CRUD campaigns (goals, date windows), donation forms (fields, suggested amounts), donor profiles, and fundraising pages for teams/individuals. Donations are stored as payment intents and transactions with statuses (created/authorized/succeeded/failed/refunded) and receipts (tax fields, email delivery metadata). Recurring giving uses subscription objects (cadence, next charge date, retry rules) plus pledge schedules and installment tracking. Matching programs model matchers (company/foundation), eligibility rules, match ratios, and match claim records with verification status. The system also manages soft credits, donor segmentation tags, and acknowledgments as tasks (call/email/mail) with completion state. Workflows: donor gives once → opts into monthly → payment retries on failure → receipt issuance → campaign progress updates → match claim submitted → match disbursement reconciled. Admins CRUD webhooks, export jobs for accounting/CRM, and fraud/risk flags. Amounts, donors, and transaction timelines can be synthesized for realistic API-driven simulations.

name: DoseWise Specialty Pharmacy Hub (High-Cost Therapies + Outcomes)
description: DoseWise is a specialty pharmacy coordination platform for complex therapies (e.g., biologics) emphasizing case management and outcomes tracking. Patients CRUD profiles, caregiver delegates, delivery preferences, and financial assistance applications. Each therapy is a “program enrollment” entity linking diagnosis, prescribing provider, dose schedule, labs required, and monitoring frequency. Case managers CRUD tasks (benefits investigation, cold-chain shipment, injection training), outreach attempts, and structured check-in surveys (side effects, adherence, quality-of-life scores). The platform manages shipment plans with recurring delivery dates, temperature-control requirements, and hold/release approvals. It also stores lab prerequisites as structured requirements (test type, due date, completed flag, result value ranges) gating refill eligibility. Financial workflows include copay cards, foundation grants, and claim statuses with amounts, approvals, and renewal dates. Status models support: referral received → onboarding → benefits cleared → first fill scheduled → ongoing fills → therapy discontinued/paused. Providers can receive generated adherence summaries and refill status updates as structured notifications. This scenario enables rich database interactions across enrollments, tasks, shipments, lab gates, and financial assistance—ideal for realistic synthesized environments.

name: HopeBridge Donor CRM (Non-Profit Fundraising + Receipts)
description: HopeBridge is a donor management and fundraising CRM for non-profits that tracks constituents, campaigns, and gift processing. Staff CRUD donor profiles (contact info, household links, communication preferences), relationships, segmentation tags, and consent flags. Fundraising objects include campaigns, appeals, events, and funds with goals, date ranges, and attribution rules. Gifts are structured records with amount, payment method token, designation, soft credits, matching gift status, and acknowledgement workflow state. The platform supports pledges and recurring donations (cadence, next charge date, failed payment status), in-kind gifts (item, estimated value), and sponsorship packages. Communication workflows are modeled as email/SMS touches with templates, send jobs, opens/clicks placeholders, and opt-out enforcement. Receipting is a deterministic workflow: gift posted → receipt queued → receipt delivered → thank-you task assigned → follow-up completed. Reporting endpoints summarize campaign progress, donor retention, LYBUNT/SYBUNT segments, and forecasted pledge revenue using synthesizable metrics. Admin controls include role-based access (finance vs development), audit logs for edits, and imports/exports for migrations, making it excellent for API-driven simulations.

name: VolunteerFlow (Volunteer Scheduling + Credentialing)
description: VolunteerFlow is a volunteer management platform for charities and community organizations that need scheduling, compliance, and hour tracking. Organizations CRUD programs, locations, volunteer roles, shift templates, and capacity limits. Volunteers CRUD profiles, availability calendars, skills, interests, emergency contacts, and required documents metadata (ID, waivers, background check status). Each shift is a bookable entity with start/end times, required headcount, check-in rules, and cancellation policy. The system supports applications and onboarding pipelines: applied → screened → accepted → trained → active, with training modules tracked as completions. Coordinators can assign volunteers, approve swap requests, mark attendance, and log hours with supervisor verification. Communication is organized into announcements and shift messages with delivery status and read receipts. Impact tracking is modeled via program metrics attached to shifts (meals served, calls made, kits assembled) with numeric entries and timestamps. Workflows include waitlists, automatic reminders, incident reports, and recognition (badges, milestones, volunteer-of-month nominations as structured records). This creates a realistic CRUD-heavy environment covering people, schedules, compliance, and operational metrics.

name: ShelterAid Rescue Network (Foster + Intake + Adoption Pipeline)
description: ShelterAid is an operations platform for animal rescues coordinating intake, fosters, veterinary care, and adoptions. Staff CRUD animal records (species, breed, age estimate, microchip id, behavior tags), intake events (source, date, condition score), photos metadata, and shelter/foster placement history. Foster homes CRUD profiles (capacity, pet restrictions, availability dates), foster agreements, and supply requests. Medical tracking includes vaccinations, deworming, spay/neuter scheduling, medications, and visit notes as structured entries with due dates and completion statuses. Adoption workflows are a pipeline: application submitted → references checked → meet-and-greet scheduled → trial period → finalized/returned. Applicants CRUD household info, landlord approval flag, existing pets, and preferred animals; coordinators CRUD screening tasks and decisions. The platform also manages fundraising tied to animals (sponsor-a-pet, medical fundraiser goals) and inventories (food, crates, medications) with stock movements. Event endpoints handle adoption events (venue, time slots, attendees, animals present) and outcomes. The entire system is synthesize-friendly: animals, statuses, dates, costs, and tasks can be generated while supporting realistic multi-entity operations.

name: PawPro Vet Clinic Portal (Appointments + Vaccines + Reminders)
description: PawPro is a veterinary clinic portal for pet owners and clinic staff, focused on appointment and preventive-care management. Pet owners CRUD accounts, pets (species, breed, weight history, allergies), insurance info, and preferred communication channels. Appointment requests capture pet, reason, urgency level, and preferred times; clinics CRUD provider schedules, exam rooms, service codes, and pricing tables. Visit records store structured SOAP notes, diagnostics ordered, vaccination administration (vaccine type, lot, expiration), prescriptions, and follow-up tasks with due dates. A reminder engine generates scheduled items (annual exam, rabies booster, heartworm test) and logs reminder deliveries (sent/opened placeholder) and owner actions (booked, snoozed). Payment flows can simulate invoices, line items, discounts, deposits, and refund statuses without real processing. The platform supports secure messaging threads per pet, attachment metadata (photo of symptoms), and triage tags for routing. Multi-pet households, consent forms, and medical record export jobs are included as CRUD entities. This scenario provides rich relational data (owners ↔ pets ↔ visits ↔ vaccines) ideal for API environment simulation.

name: SitPaws Marketplace (Pet Sitting + Walks + Service Requests)
description: SitPaws is a pet care marketplace for booking pet sitting, dog walking, and drop-in visits, emphasizing scheduling and transactional CRUD rather than content. Pet owners CRUD pets (temperament tags, feeding instructions, meds schedule), home access notes, and emergency contacts. Sitters CRUD profiles, service offerings (rate, radius, availability), credentials (certifications metadata), and blackout dates. Bookings are structured entities with service type, start/end times, recurrence rules, address, pet list, and pricing breakdown (base, add-ons, holiday rate). The workflow includes request → sitter accepts/declines → payment authorization token → scheduled → in-progress → completed → review. In-progress care is modeled via check-in events (timestamp, GPS coordinates, potty/feeding/water flags, photo metadata), enabling realistic timeline APIs. Cancellations and refunds follow rule-based policies with statuses and computed fees. Messaging threads link to bookings and store read receipts and moderation flags. Dispute handling captures issue type, evidence attachments metadata, and resolution outcomes. This setup supports robust simulations of marketplace mechanics: availability search, booking lifecycle, payments metadata, and operational logs.

name: PetSupply Co-Op (Subscription Pet Supplies + Auto-Ship)
description: PetSupply Co-Op is an e-commerce and subscription platform for consumable pet supplies (food, litter, treats) built around catalog, orders, and auto-ship plans. Admins CRUD products (SKU, brand, size, species, dietary tags), pricing, inventory per warehouse, and promotions (coupons, tiered discounts). Customers CRUD carts, shipping addresses, pets (to drive size/species matching), and subscriptions (items, quantity, cadence, next ship date, skip/pause, swap item). Orders track fulfillment statuses (picked/packed/shipped/delivered), shipment splits, carrier label metadata, and returns with reason codes and restock outcomes. The system supports product bundles (kit builder), loyalty points, and reorder reminders. A customer service module manages tickets tied to orders/subscriptions with status, tags, and resolution codes. Forecasting endpoints compute upcoming subscription demand by SKU and warehouse using synthesizable quantities. Workflows include: browse → add to cart → checkout → fulfillment → delivery confirmation → return/exchange; plus: create subscription → upcoming order preview → edit/skip → charge token → ship. This scenario is highly suitable for database-driven API simulations without any content-heavy dependencies.

name: ChargePoint (EV Charging Network + Fleet Accounts)
description: ChargePoint is an EV charging platform that manages charging stations, driver accounts, and session billing. A simulation can model CRUD for charging stations (location, connectors, power rating, status), site hosts, pricing rules (per kWh/per minute/idle fees), and maintenance tickets. Driver entities include accounts, vehicles (make/model/battery size), RFID cards, and payment token metadata. The core workflow is a charging session: authorize → start → energy readings streamed as periodic records → stop → cost calculated → receipt generated, with states like available/in_use/out_of_service. Fleet features can add organizations, driver groups, station access policies, and consolidated billing invoices. Reservations and queues can be modeled with holds, expirations, and no-show handling. Operational data includes meter readings, uptime/downtime events, fault codes, and firmware versions, all of which are numeric/status-driven and synthesize well. Admin endpoints can change station pricing, schedule maintenance windows, and update station status. Analytics endpoints can aggregate energy dispensed by site, peak usage hours, and average session length. This scenario supports rich state machines, time-series records, and role-based access without requiring real maps, live traffic, or media content.

name: NetSuite ERP (Order-to-Cash + Purchasing)
description: NetSuite is a cloud ERP used for finance, inventory, procurement, and order management. A simulation can model CRUD for customers, vendors, items (SKUs, units, pricing), warehouses/locations, and accounts (chart of accounts). Order-to-cash workflows include quotes → sales orders → allocations/fulfillment shipments → invoices → payments and credit memos, with status transitions and partial shipments. Procurement workflows include purchase requisitions → purchase orders → receipts → vendor bills → payments, with approvals and three-way match (PO/receipt/bill) represented as linked records. Inventory operations cover on-hand quantities, bin locations, transfers, adjustments, and lot/serial tracking. Accounting entries can be simulated as journal entries generated from transactions with posting periods, tax codes, and currency conversions. Permissions and subsidiaries support multi-entity testing. Reporting endpoints can produce AR/AP aging, inventory valuation, and P&L by department. Because the system is essentially a network of relational records with deterministic calculations and timestamps, it’s ideal for API environment simulations that stress CRUD, referential integrity, and complex workflows without requiring any non-synthesizable content.

name: Upwork (Freelance Marketplace + Contracts + Milestones)
description: Upwork-like marketplaces can be simulated by focusing on structured profiles, job posts, proposals, and contract states rather than content-heavy messaging. Entities include clients, freelancers, agencies, skills, portfolios (metadata), job posts, screening questions (short), proposals, shortlists, interviews (scheduled events), contracts, milestones, hourly work logs (time blocks), escrow transactions (status-only), disputes, reviews/ratings, and compliance flags. Clients CRUD job posts with budget, category, required skills, and visibility; receive proposals with bid amounts, availability dates, and attachments metadata; then hire to create a contract. Contract workflows include milestone creation → funded → submitted → approved/rejected → paid, and for hourly: weekly timesheets with activity levels as numbers, manual adjustments, and approvals. Dispute workflow can be modeled as statuses, evidence attachments metadata, mediator assignment, and resolution outcomes. Platform operations include identity verification flags, account holds, and limit rules. APIs can simulate search/filter on skills and rates using synthetic catalogs, pagination over proposals, webhooks for milestone status changes, and analytics like hire rate, average time to fill, and freelancer responsiveness.

name: OpenTable (Restaurant Reservations + Waitlist + Table Rules)
description: OpenTable-style reservation platforms support rich CRUD and scheduling constraints with fully synthesizable data. Entities include restaurants, dining areas, tables, table combinations, reservation slots, blackout periods, policies (deposit/no-show), guests, reservations, waitlist entries, seating assignments, notes/tags (allergies as tags), and review ratings (numeric + short text). Restaurants CRUD floor plans, table capacities, operating hours, and pacing rules (max covers per 15 minutes). Guest workflow: search availability by party size/date (generated from slot rules) → create reservation → modify/cancel → check-in → seated → completed/no-show. Waitlist workflow: add walk-in → quote time → notify → seat or drop. Policies can drive deterministic outcomes: late arrival grace period, deposit required for large parties, cancellation windows with fee status. Restaurants can manage special events (prix fixe seatings) as separate inventory. APIs can model availability queries, atomic booking creation with conflict handling, and idempotent cancellation. Reporting can aggregate covers by daypart, no-show rate, average turn time, and table utilization, all derived from timestamps and statuses.

name: DocuSign (eSignature + Templates + Agreement Workflows)
description: DocuSign is ideal for simulation because the core value is a structured agreement workflow and audit trail, not the document content itself. Entities include users, organizations, templates, documents (file metadata + placeholder fields), envelopes, recipients, routing orders, tabs/fields (sign, date, initials, text), authentication methods (SMS/email flags), reminders, expirations, signing events, and completion certificates (metadata). Admins CRUD templates with predefined recipient roles and required fields; users create envelopes from templates, attach document references, assign recipients, and send. Workflow: envelope created → sent → viewed → signed/declined → completed/voided/expired, with an immutable event log capturing timestamps, IP/device metadata, and recipient actions. Corrections can be modeled as “correct” operations producing a new envelope version. Bulk send supports lists of recipients and merge fields. Access control includes shared templates, delegated signing, and group-based sending permissions. APIs can simulate embedded signing sessions, webhook callbacks for status transitions, retrieval of audit trail entries, and storage of signed document URLs (synthetic). Data remains realistic via deterministic routing rules and compliance-friendly logs.

name: ShiftNest (Workforce Scheduling + Time-Off)
description: ShiftNest is a workforce scheduling platform for hourly teams (retail, clinics, hospitality) focused on calendar-driven CRUD. Managers create locations, departments, roles, and employees (skills, availability windows, labor rules). They build schedules by creating shifts (start/end, role, break rules, headcount, pay code) and assigning employees; shifts support status changes (draft/published/locked) and swap requests. Employees manage profiles, preferred hours, unavailability blocks, and time-off requests (type, dates, accrual bucket, approval status). Workflows include: schedule template → generate weekly roster → publish → employee acknowledgements → swap/cover requests → manager approval → audit log. The system tracks timesheets via clock-in/out records (device metadata, rounding rules), exceptions (late, missed break), and manager edits with reason codes. APIs cover conflict checks (overtime, overlapping shifts), notifications (publish, swap approved), and exports (payroll batches, cost center summaries). All data (people, shifts, approvals, timestamps) is synthesizable and supports realistic multi-tenant operations.

name: VenuePulse (Event Management + Ticketing Ops)
description: VenuePulse is an event operations platform for venues and promoters that emphasizes structured event, inventory, and attendee workflows. Organizers CRUD venues (sections, seat maps as coordinates/rows, capacity rules), events (dates, doors time, lineup as short names), ticket products (tiers, price, fees, on-sale windows), and allocations (comp holds, partner allotments). Attendees CRUD accounts, payment tokens, orders, and transfers; orders contain line items, discounts, tax, delivery method, and status (pending/paid/refunded/chargeback). Check-in is modeled via scannable tickets (barcode value, check-in status, scan device, timestamp) with rules for re-entry and invalidation. Workflows include: event draft → approval → on-sale → order management → ticket delivery → day-of scanning → post-event settlement. Admin tools manage refunds, exchanges, voids, seat changes, and incident logs (denied entry, duplicate scan). Reporting endpoints summarize sales by tier, attendance counts, and settlement statements—all based on synthesizeable entities and deterministic status transitions.

name: ToolDock (Resource Booking for Equipment + Rooms)
description: ToolDock is a resource booking system for shared assets (meeting rooms, cameras, vehicles, lab equipment) with availability and checkout tracking. Admins CRUD resources (type, location, capacity/specs, maintenance intervals), operating hours, blackout periods, and pricing rules (hourly/daily, deposits, late fees). Users CRUD booking requests (resource, start/end, purpose, attendees, required accessories) and receive approval/denial with reasons. The core workflow is: request → conflict check → approval → reservation confirmed → check-out → check-in → fee assessment → receipt. Inventory-like sub-entities include accessory bundles, consumables, and condition checklists (before/after states, damage flags, photos metadata). The platform tracks maintenance tickets (issue type, severity, status), scheduled servicing, and utilization metrics. APIs support recurring bookings, waitlists, buffer times between reservations, and role-based permissions (staff can override holds, block resources). Everything—resources, schedules, statuses, fees, and timestamps—can be generated realistically for simulation and load testing.

name: HarborLane TMS (Freight Logistics + Shipment Lifecycle)
description: HarborLane TMS is a transportation management system for shippers and 3PLs that models end-to-end shipments without content-heavy data. Users CRUD customers, lanes (origin/destination, equipment type), carriers, and rate cards (base, fuel surcharge tables, accessorials). Shipments are created as orders with stops (pickup/drop, appointments, reference numbers), commodities (weight, pallets, hazmat flags), documents metadata, and status events (tendered/accepted/in-transit/delivered/closed). Dispatchers tender loads to carriers, manage acceptance, assign drivers/tractor-trailer, and schedule appointments. Tracking is event-driven: check-calls, geofence pings, ETA updates, exceptions (delay, detention) with timestamps and notes. Billing is structured via invoices (line items, taxes, currencies), matching to carrier bills, and disputes (reason codes, resolution status). Workflows: quote → book → tender → track → POD upload metadata → invoice → audit → pay. Reporting endpoints provide on-time performance, cost per mile, and carrier scorecards—all based on synthesizable numbers and entities.

name: DropLine (Last-Mile Delivery Tracking + Proof of Delivery)
description: DropLine is a last-mile delivery platform for local couriers and retailers, centered on orders, stops, and status events. Merchants CRUD customers, delivery orders (items, weight, service level, time windows), pickup/dropoff addresses, and special instructions (short text). Dispatchers group orders into routes, assign couriers, and sequence stops; each stop records planned vs actual times, attempt count, and outcome (delivered/failed/returned). Couriers use a driver app to update statuses (picked up, en route, arrived, delivered), capture proof-of-delivery metadata (signature flag, recipient name, photo url metadata), and collect payments on delivery (amount, method, tip). Exceptions are first-class entities: delays, address issues, damaged package, customer not available—each with codes, notes, and resolution actions. Workflows: order created → dispatch → pickup scan → in-transit updates → delivery attempt(s) → POD → settlement. Settlement endpoints produce courier payouts and merchant invoices with fees, surcharges, and adjustments. All fields are easy to synthesize while supporting realistic event streams and database interactions.

name: LedgerSpring (Digital Banking + Bill Pay + Transfers)
description: LedgerSpring is a consumer digital banking portal designed for account-centric CRUD and transaction workflows. Customers open and manage accounts (checking, savings), beneficiaries, external bank links (token metadata), and debit cards (freeze/unfreeze, limits). Core entities include transactions (posted/pending, merchant name, category, amount), statements, and alerts. Users create billers and schedule payments (one-time/recurring), set up internal transfers, and initiate ACH transfers to linked accounts; each transfer has states (created/submitted/processing/settled/returned) with return codes. The platform supports budgeting buckets (envelopes), goals, and rules to auto-categorize transactions based on merchant patterns (deterministic rules, not AI). Disputes are handled via case records (transaction id, reason, evidence metadata, status). Workflows include: onboarding → KYC status (simulated) → funding → card activation → payment schedules → statement close. Admin APIs allow holds, account locks, fee assessments, interest accrual runs, and audit trails. All data is structured and synthesizable, enabling realistic simulations of balances, ledger postings, and user actions.

name: AlphaLot (Paper Trading + Portfolio + Orders)
description: AlphaLot is an investment platform for simulated trading that emphasizes order/portfolio CRUD without needing real market feeds. Users create watchlists, portfolios, and trading accounts (base currency, buying power). They place orders (market/limit/stop), set quantities, time-in-force, and attach risk controls (take-profit/stop-loss). Orders progress through deterministic statuses (new/queued/partially filled/filled/canceled/rejected) based on a synthetic price series stored as OHLC bars per symbol and timestamp. Holdings track lots, cost basis, realized/unrealized P&L, dividends (cash events), and corporate actions (splits) as structured events. The platform also supports scheduled contributions, rebalancing plans (target weights), and trade journals (short notes, tags). Workflows include: funding → place order → fill events → settlement → monthly statement generation. Admin endpoints manage symbol master data (tickers, exchange, trading hours), fee schedules, and account restrictions. Reporting includes performance over time, allocations, and tax-lot summaries, all derived from synthesizable numeric series and transactional records.

name: ChainVault (Crypto Wallets + Transfers + Compliance Flags)
description: ChainVault is a crypto account and wallet management platform suitable for simulation with synthetic ledgers. Users CRUD wallets (per asset), addresses (whitelist, labels), contacts, and API keys. Transfers are modeled as on-platform and on-chain withdrawals/deposits; each transaction includes asset, amount, fee, destination, tx hash (synthetic), confirmations count, and state (created/pending/broadcast/confirmed/failed/reversed). The platform supports internal swaps between assets using configurable rate tables and spreads, generating trade records and updated balances. Security features include withdrawal limits, 2FA status flags, device sessions, and approval workflows for large withdrawals (maker/checker). Compliance is represented through structured risk flags: high-risk address, velocity limit exceeded, sanctions match (simulated boolean), and case management records (review notes, decision, status). Workflows: onboarding → address whitelisting → deposit credited after confirmations → trade/swap → withdrawal request → review → broadcast → confirm. Admin tools manage asset listings, maintenance windows, fee schedules, and incident banners (metadata). No real blockchain access is required; all events and numbers can be synthesized realistically.

name: PayRibbon (Payments + Invoicing + Subscriptions for SMBs)
description: PayRibbon is a payments platform for small businesses that combines invoicing, checkout links, and recurring billing. Merchants CRUD customers, products/services, tax rates, and invoice templates. Invoices contain line items, discounts, due dates, payment terms, and status (draft/sent/partially paid/paid/overdue/void). The system supports payment links and hosted checkout sessions with payment method token metadata, refunds (full/partial), and disputes (chargebacks) with reason codes and evidence attachments metadata. Subscriptions are modeled via plans (amount, cadence, trial days), subscriptions (start, renewal, cancel_at_period_end), and invoices generated per cycle. Payouts to merchants are tracked as batches with settlement dates, fees, and reconciliation reports. Workflows include: create customer → issue invoice → reminders → payment captured → receipt → payout → accounting export. Admin APIs manage risk holds, manual capture, webhook event logs, and idempotency keys. All entities are structured and synthesizable, enabling realistic simulations of billing lifecycles, payment states, and ledger reconciliation without requiring real processor integrations.

name: RouteDock (Carrier Dispatch + Proof-of-Delivery)
description: RouteDock is a carrier-facing dispatch and delivery tracking platform for local and regional shippers. Dispatchers CRUD customers, pickup/delivery stops, shipments (pieces, weight, dimensions, service level), and driver assignments. They build daily routes from orders, reorder stops, set time windows, and publish manifests to a driver app. Drivers CRUD trip events (arrived, loaded, departed, delivered, failed attempt), capture proof-of-delivery (signature name, photo metadata, geotag, timestamp), and record exceptions (damaged, missing, refused) with standardized reason codes. The system tracks vehicle capacity (weight/volume), driver hours, and stop-level ETAs that can be deterministically synthesized from distance tables and planned durations. Billing workflows include rate cards, accessorial charges (liftgate, residential, wait time), invoice drafts, approvals, and payment status. Customers use a portal to CRUD shipment requests, addresses, and notification preferences; they can query tracking history and download POD artifacts. Admin tools include user roles, depot locations, equipment types, and audit logs for status transitions.

name: YardStack (Warehouse Yard + Trailer & Gate Management)
description: YardStack manages the “yard” outside distribution centers: trailers, dock doors, appointments, and gate transactions. Users CRUD facilities, yards, dock doors, carriers, tractors, trailers, and container assets (IDs, ownership, maintenance status). Inbound/outbound loads are modeled as moves with references to purchase orders/shipments, seal numbers, temperature requirements, and priority. Gate staff CRUD check-in/check-out records (driver, tractor, trailer, appointment, seal verification) and print badges. Yard jockeys receive move tasks (spot to door, pull from door, stage in row/slot), update task statuses, and record timestamps for dwell-time analytics. Dock schedulers CRUD appointments with time windows, load types, and required equipment; they can approve, reschedule, or cancel requests and enforce capacity rules per door/shift. Exception handling includes “no show,” “late,” “seal broken,” and “trailer not found.” Reporting endpoints expose dwell time by carrier, door utilization, and trailer inventory snapshots by row/slot. All data (IDs, timestamps, statuses, temperature readings) is synthesizable and supports realistic event-driven APIs.

name: FleetPulse (Vehicle Fleet Maintenance + Compliance)
description: FleetPulse is a fleet management system for service vans, trucks, or municipal vehicles. Fleet admins CRUD vehicles (VIN, make/model, odometer, fuel type), drivers, assignments, and depots. Maintenance teams CRUD service schedules (intervals by miles/hours/dates), work orders (diagnosis codes, labor items, parts used), vendor invoices, and inspection checklists. Drivers submit DVIR-style inspections with defect flags, photos metadata, and “safe/unsafe” status; defects automatically generate work orders and require sign-off to close. Compliance workflows cover registration/insurance expirations, emissions tests, and policy acknowledgments, with configurable reminders and escalation rules. Optional telematics-like data can be synthesized: trip logs (start/end, distance), fuel purchases, and sensor readings (engine hours, battery voltage) to drive alerts such as “maintenance due” or “idling high.” Role-based access controls separate drivers, mechanics, and admins. Analytics endpoints provide cost per mile, downtime by vehicle, and maintenance backlog by priority. The platform is database-heavy and supports CRUD plus state transitions across assets, tasks, and compliance artifacts without needing real-time maps.

name: PayRail (SMB Payments + Invoicing + Payouts)
description: PayRail is a payments and invoicing platform for small businesses that need receivables and controlled payouts. Merchants CRUD customers, invoices (line items, taxes, discounts), payment links, and recurring billing plans. They can issue refunds, void invoices, and track statuses (draft/sent/paid/overdue/void). Payment methods are stored as token metadata, with support for bank transfer and card-like instruments. A payouts module lets businesses CRUD vendors/contractors, payout batches, and approval workflows (created → approved → processing → paid/failed) with remittance notes. Risk and disputes are modeled with synthesizable entities: chargebacks, evidence checklists, deadlines, and outcomes. The platform includes a lightweight ledger: balance movements, fees, and settlement events, enabling realistic reconciliation APIs and statement exports. Users manage webhooks, API keys, and idempotency keys for safe integrations. Admins set business profiles, KYC checklist statuses, and transaction limits. The core workflows—invoice creation, customer payment, settlement, payout approvals, and dispute lifecycle—are well-suited to synthetic but realistic datasets.

name: BrickBank (Digital Banking Sandbox for Consumers)
description: BrickBank is a consumer digital banking portal focused on account management and transaction workflows. Users CRUD profiles, beneficiaries, external bank links (token metadata), and multiple account types (checking, savings, goal buckets). They can initiate transfers (internal, ACH-like external), schedule recurring transfers, and manage billers and bill payments with payee directories and delivery dates. Transactions are stored with categories, merchant names, pending/posted states, and memo fields; users can add tags, split transactions, and attach receipt metadata. Card management includes CRUD cards, freeze/unfreeze, spending limits, and travel notices; disputes can be filed with reason codes, temporary credit flags, and status tracking. Alerts and rules are configurable (low balance, large purchase, paycheck detected). Statements, tax documents, and secure messages are modeled as downloadable document metadata and thread entities. Admin APIs support onboarding checklists, identity verification status, and fraud holds with audit logs. All balances, transactions, and statuses can be synthesized while preserving realistic constraints (available vs current balance, posting delays, cutoff times).

name: IndexNest (Portfolio Tracking + Rebalancing Workflows)
description: IndexNest is an investment portfolio tracker that models holdings, trades, and planned rebalancing without needing real market feeds. Users CRUD brokerage accounts, positions (symbol, quantity, cost basis), and transactions (buy/sell, dividend, split) with timestamps and fees. They can define target allocations by asset class or symbol, set drift thresholds, and generate “rebalance plans” that produce proposed orders with estimated impacts. Watchlists and price snapshots are stored as periodic synthetic quotes, allowing performance charts and time-weighted returns to be computed deterministically. Tax lots are first-class entities: users choose lot selection methods (FIFO/specific ID), simulate capital gains, and export reports. The platform supports goals (retirement, house down payment) with contribution schedules and projected scenarios using configurable return assumptions. Compliance-style controls include trading permissions, approval steps for advisor-managed accounts, and audit trails. Workflows cover importing a CSV of transactions, reconciling holdings, creating a rebalance draft, approving it, and recording executed trades with partial fills and cancellations. The database structure (accounts, holdings, lots, orders, snapshots) is highly synthesizable.

name: ParcelPicks (Last-Mile Delivery Tracking for Retailers)
description: ParcelPicks is a retailer-integrated last-mile delivery tracking platform for same-day and next-day orders. Merchants CRUD stores, service zones, customers, and delivery orders (items, value, special instructions, age verification flag). Orders are batched into runs; dispatchers assign runs to couriers and set pickup readiness times. Couriers update stop statuses (accepted, en route, arrived, picked up, delivered, failed) and submit proof artifacts (signature, photo metadata, ID check result) with standardized failure reasons (customer unavailable, unsafe location, address issue). ETA calculations can be synthesized from zone-based travel times and courier capacity. Customers receive tracking links and can CRUD delivery preferences (safe drop location, contactless, alternate recipient). Returns are modeled as reverse pickups with their own status lifecycle and labels metadata. The platform supports service-level rules, cancellation windows, tipping, and incident reporting. Retail analytics endpoints provide on-time rate, average stop duration, and exception rates by zone or courier. The emphasis is on CRUD for orders, runs, events, and evidence—ideal for database-driven simulation.

name: ClipKeep (Research Bookmarks + Tagging + Collections)
description: ClipKeep is a bookmarking and curation workspace for teams collecting web resources and notes. Users CRUD bookmarks (URL, title, source, favicon metadata), short annotations, and extracted highlights as bounded text snippets. They organize bookmarks into collections and nested folders, apply tags, and set visibility (private/team/public link). A reading queue supports statuses (inbox, reading, archived) and reminders. Teams CRUD workspaces, members, roles, and shared collections; collaboration includes comments on bookmarks, mention notifications, and change history. Deduplication and canonicalization are modeled with link fingerprints and merge workflows (merge duplicates, keep fields). Import/export workflows include CSV/JSON imports, browser extension-like “save” events, and API endpoints to list, search by tag, filter by domain, and retrieve recent saves. Optional scoring fields (relevance 1–5, confidence) enable curated lists without content-heavy requirements. Because all stored data is structured metadata plus short notes, datasets are easy to synthesize while still feeling realistic for CRUD-heavy API testing.

name: WishMint Registry (Wishlists + Gift Planning + Price Targets)
description: WishMint Registry is a wishlist and gifting registry platform for birthdays, weddings, and group gifting—focused on structured item tracking rather than full checkout. Users CRUD profiles, events (date, shipping address preferences), and wishlists with collaborators. Wishlist items store product metadata (name, store, URL, variant attributes like size/color, priority, quantity desired, and price target/current price snapshot). Purchasers can reserve items, mark as bought, contribute to group-fund goals, and attach purchase confirmation metadata (store order number optional). The system enforces workflows to prevent duplicate gifting: item status transitions (available → reserved → purchased → received/returned) with expiration timers for reservations. Hosts can manage thank-you note tasks and track gift receipts, exchanges, and return deadlines. Notifications and privacy controls are first-class entities: who can view, who can purchase, and whether purchased items are hidden from the host until event date. Admin APIs support merchant/store directories and affiliate attribution fields (campaign, referrer). All entities—events, lists, items, reservations, contributions—are synthesizable and suitable for database-driven API simulations.

name: LedgerNest (Personal Finance + Budgeting + Goals)
description: LedgerNest is a personal finance manager that consolidates accounts, budgets, and goals into a structured ledger. Users CRUD financial accounts (checking, savings, credit card, cash), categories, merchants, and transactions (amount, date, payee, notes, tags, attachments metadata). Import workflows can be simulated via uploaded CSVs or “bank connection” tokens with deterministic sync runs that create pending/posted transactions and reconciliation states. Budgeting supports monthly envelopes, rollover rules, and alerts (overspend, unusual spend, low balance) with configurable thresholds. Users can create savings goals (target amount/date, funding account, auto-transfer rules) and track progress using scheduled allocations. Shared households are supported via members, permissions, and split transactions. Reporting is dashboard-style with aggregations (spend by category, net cash flow, recurring bills), all derived from stored records rather than external content. Admin APIs manage data sources, sync jobs, and audit logs (who edited what, when). Suitable for synthesis because all entities are numeric/time-based or short text, and workflows revolve around CRUD plus deterministic calculations.

name: BillFlow Pro (B2B Invoicing + Receivables + Payment Links)
description: BillFlow Pro is a small-business invoicing and accounts receivable platform. Businesses CRUD customers, contacts, addresses, products/services (SKU, unit price, tax code), invoices (line items, due dates, discounts), and payment links (token, expiry, allowed methods). Invoice lifecycle is modeled with statuses (draft/sent/viewed/partial/paid/void/overdue) and automated reminders (schedule rules, templates with bounded fields). Users can record payments (amount, method, reference), issue credit notes, and reconcile to a cash account. Teams CRUD users, roles, approval rules (e.g., invoices over $5k require manager), and branding settings (logo URL metadata, email sender). Disputes are tracked as structured cases tied to an invoice (reason, evidence metadata, outcome). Reporting endpoints summarize AR aging, customer balances, and tax collected. Integrations can be simulated via webhooks for invoice.created, payment.succeeded, and reminder.sent. All data is synthesizable: monetary amounts, dates, IDs, short descriptions, and status transitions.

name: CoinVault Exchange (Crypto Wallet + Transfers + Compliance)
description: CoinVault Exchange is a custodial crypto wallet and lightweight exchange simulator centered on ledger accuracy and compliance workflows. Users CRUD wallets per asset (BTC/ETH/USDC), blockchain addresses (label, whitelisted flag), and transfer requests (asset, amount, destination, fee, memo). Transfers move through statuses (created → AML_check → queued → broadcast → confirmed/failed) with confirmation counts simulated deterministically. Users can manage fiat on/off-ramp instructions (bank accounts, payout methods) and view a unified transaction ledger with fees and balance snapshots. Security features include CRUD of API keys (scopes, IP allowlist), device sessions, 2FA methods, and withdrawal limits. Compliance is first-class: KYC profiles (identity fields, document metadata, verification status), risk flags, and SAR cases with structured notes and outcomes. Trading can be modeled as simple market/limit orders against a synthetic order book, producing fills, trade records, and fee tiers. Admin tools manage asset listings, fee schedules, and incident holds. No real market data is required; all prices/spreads can be generated.

name: AutoInvest Pilot (Robo-Portfolios + Rebalancing + Tax Lots)
description: AutoInvest Pilot is an investment platform for model portfolios and automated rebalancing. Users CRUD investment accounts (taxable/IRA), funding sources, risk profiles, and target portfolios (asset allocations, eligible instruments). Holdings are derived from trades but can also be imported as starting positions. The system generates recommended actions (buy/sell lists) based on drift thresholds and cash flows, then users approve to create orders. Orders progress through statuses (queued/routed/partially_filled/filled/canceled) and create executions with prices and timestamps. Tax-aware investing is represented via lots (purchase date, cost basis, quantity) and realized gains calculations; tax-loss harvesting can be simulated via rule-based triggers and wash-sale windows. Users can schedule recurring deposits, enable auto-rebalance cadence, and set constraints (exclude tickers, max position size). Statements, performance snapshots, and fee billing (AUM tiers) are produced from stored valuations using synthetic prices. Admin APIs manage model versions, suitability questionnaires, and audit trails.

name: RoutePay Gateway (Payment Orchestration + Refunds + Chargebacks)
description: RoutePay Gateway is a payment orchestration platform that routes transactions to multiple processors while tracking the full payment lifecycle. Merchants CRUD stores, API credentials, payment methods (token metadata), customers, and payment intents (amount, currency, capture mode). Intents create charges that transition (authorized/captured/voided/refunded/failed) and support partial captures and multiple refunds. Settlement is modeled via payouts (batch id, fees, net amount, scheduled date) with ledger entries and reconciliation reports. Disputes/chargebacks are managed as cases (reason code, evidence checklist, deadlines, status) with attachments metadata and outcome tracking. Routing rules are configurable (processor priority, currency support, risk threshold, failover) and are logged per attempt. Webhooks notify merchants of payment_succeeded, refund_created, dispute_opened, and payout_paid. A rules engine can simulate fraud screening via deterministic scores and allow/deny decisions without ML. Everything is CRUD-friendly and synthesizable: amounts, IDs, timestamps, short metadata, and state machines.

name: Pinboard Collections (Bookmarks + Tagging + Shared Curation)
description: Pinboard Collections is a bookmarking and curation platform focused on structured organization rather than content hosting. Users CRUD bookmarks (URL, title, short description, favicon/image URL metadata), tags, folders/collections, and reading states (unread/archived/favorite). Imports from browser exports are modeled as batch jobs with progress and deduplication rules. Collections can be shared with collaborators via invites and roles (owner/editor/viewer), and each bookmark can have comments and highlights stored as short snippets with source offsets (start/end) and timestamps. Users can create smart collections using saved filters (tag includes, domain equals, date range, unread) and schedule weekly digests. Link health checks are simulated via periodic jobs that update status (reachable/redirected/404) and last_checked timestamps. A lightweight activity feed tracks adds/edits/moves and supports undo operations via revision history. The platform includes a “save from mobile” inbox and an API for programmatic saves. All data is synthesizable: URLs, tags, short text, permissions, and job statuses.

name: MarketWatchlists (Multi-Asset Watchlists + Alerts + Notes)
description: MarketWatchlists is a watchlist and research-notes tool for stocks, ETFs, crypto pairs, and FX—without needing real-time feeds. Users CRUD instruments (symbol, exchange, asset type), watchlists, and watchlist entries (target price, priority, position intent). Price history and quotes are generated or uploaded as time series, enabling deterministic alerting (crossed_above/crossed_below, percent_change, volatility threshold) with notification preferences. Users can attach structured notes to instruments (thesis, catalysts, risk flags) and maintain a checklist workflow (research steps with statuses). Collaboration supports shared watchlists, mentions in comments, and role-based permissions. Corporate actions can be simulated as events (split, dividend, symbol change) that update instrument metadata and derived charts. API endpoints support batch updates, exporting to CSV, and audit logs of edits. This scenario is database-driven (time series, alerts, notes, permissions) and suitable for synthesis because all market data can be fake yet consistent.

name: ChatServe Inbox (Omnichannel Messaging + Assignments + Macros)
description: ChatServe Inbox is a team messaging platform that centralizes customer conversations from email, web chat, and social DMs as unified threads. Admins CRUD channels, routing rules, business hours, and user roles. Agents CRUD conversations (status: open/snoozed/pending/closed), assignments, tags, and internal notes. Messages are structured events with direction (inbound/outbound), attachments metadata, and delivery/read states. Workflows include triage queues, SLA timers (first response, resolution), collision prevention (agent viewing/typing indicators), and canned responses/macros with variables. Automation rules can be configured (if VIP tag + keyword, escalate; if no reply in 48h, auto-close) and executed deterministically. Customer profiles store contact info, custom fields, consent flags, and relationship to orders or subscriptions (linked IDs). Reporting endpoints summarize volume, response times, and agent workload. Webhooks fire on conversation.created, message.received, and status.changed. No AI is required; everything is CRUD, state transitions, and timestamped events.

name: OpsTicket Forge (ITSM Ticketing + Change Requests + Assets)
description: OpsTicket Forge is an IT service management ticketing system with incidents, service requests, problems, and change management. Users CRUD tickets with categories, priority, impact/urgency, requester, assignee, watchers, and custom fields. Tickets follow configurable workflows (new → in_progress → waiting_on_user/vendor → resolved → closed) with SLA policies and escalation rules. The platform includes a CMDB: CRUD assets (devices, servers, applications), relationships (depends_on, hosted_on), and maintenance windows. Change requests are first-class objects with risk level, implementation plan (short steps), approvals, and scheduled start/end; they can be linked to incidents and assets. A knowledge base is limited to short “runbook snippets” and structured checklists to avoid content-heavy articles. Integrations are simulated via inbound email parsing, webhook triggers, and API tokens. Audit logs, comments, attachments metadata, and time entries support compliance. This is highly synthesizable: IDs, statuses, timestamps, small text fields, and relational links drive realistic workflows.

name: DisputeDesk (Payments Disputes + Case Management + Evidence)
description: DisputeDesk is a specialized case-management platform for merchants handling payment disputes across processors. Users CRUD merchants, processor connections (token metadata), transactions (amount, date, card brand metadata), and disputes (reason code, stage, deadline, disputed amount). Each dispute is a case with tasks (collect receipt, provide shipping proof, respond to inquiry), evidence items (file metadata, document type), and communications log entries. The lifecycle is modeled across stages (inquiry → chargeback → pre-arbitration → arbitration → won/lost/accepted), with configurable time limits and reminders. Users can define playbooks: rule-based templates that generate required evidence lists and recommended responses based on reason codes and transaction attributes (digital goods vs physical shipment). Outcomes create ledger adjustments and metrics (win rate, representment ROI, average days to resolve). Role-based access supports internal teams and external BPO partners with scoped permissions. All data can be synthesized—case statuses, deadlines, amounts, and structured evidence—making it ideal for API simulation.

name: ClipStack (Team Web Clipper + Knowledge Collections)
description: ClipStack is a web-clipper and curation platform for teams to save, organize, and share links and page snapshots as structured items. Users CRUD saved clips (URL, title, source, favicon/image metadata, excerpt, tags, read-status, importance score), plus annotations (highlight ranges, short notes) and relationships (duplicate-of, related-to). Clips are organized into collections and nested folders with permissions (private, team, public link). Workflows include: capture via extension → auto-fill metadata → tag & file → assign to a teammate for review → mark verified/needs-update. Teams can create projects with curated “briefs” (ordered clip lists), add collaborators, and maintain an audit log of edits. Messaging is lightweight: item-level comments, @mentions, and resolution states (open/resolved). Admins manage workspaces, roles, retention policies, and domain allow/deny lists. Export/import supports JSON/CSV for portability, and integrations can be simulated via webhook subscriptions for clip.created, clip.updated, and comment.added events.

name: ShelfMark (Research Reading List + Citation Library)
description: ShelfMark helps students and researchers manage reading lists and citations without hosting full texts. Users CRUD library items (type: book/paper/report/webpage; title; authors; publication year; DOI/ISBN; venue; abstract snippet; keywords; URL; attached file metadata), then group items into reading lists (course, thesis chapter, literature review). Workflows include: add item manually or via identifier → de-duplicate → attach notes and highlights (short, bounded strings) → assign reading status (to-read/reading/finished) → rate relevance. Users can create citation projects with styles (APA/MLA/Chicago) and generate formatted references from stored fields (deterministic). Collaboration features include shared folders, roles (owner/editor/viewer), and comment threads on items. A task layer supports follow-ups (request PDF, email author, check replication) with due dates and reminders. Admins can manage organizations, templates for metadata fields, and compliance flags (copyrighted file present: yes/no). Everything is database-friendly: items, authors, lists, notes, statuses, and activity logs.

name: BrandBoard (Moodboard Curation + Client Approvals)
description: BrandBoard is a moodboard and asset curation tool for creative teams and clients, focused on metadata and approvals rather than heavy media editing. Users CRUD boards (project, objective, audience, palette tags) and board items (image/video URL metadata, thumbnail, supplier link, category, color tags, usage rights flags, cost estimate). Boards support sections (typography, imagery, UI references) and ordered layouts (position indices). Workflows: create board draft → invite client reviewers → collect structured feedback (approve/reject, reason codes, short comment) → iterate versions with diffable change logs. Teams can maintain an asset library with reusable items, licensing dates, and expiration reminders. Messaging includes board-level chat, item-level threads, and @mentions with notification preferences. Account admins manage client organizations, access windows, watermark settings (metadata), and export packages (CSV/JSON plus a manifest of asset URLs). The system is ideal for API simulation: boards, items, versions, approvals, comments, permissions, and lifecycle states (draft/in-review/approved/archived).

name: GiftCircle (Group Wishlists + Event-Based Gifting)
description: GiftCircle supports group gifting for birthdays, weddings, and office exchanges without running a full storefront. Users CRUD profiles, shipping addresses, and event registries (event type, date, host, privacy). Each registry contains wishlist items (title, store URL, variant fields like size/color, target price, priority, quantity wanted, reservation status). Friends can claim/reserve an item, contribute amounts to a pooled gift, or propose alternatives (structured suggestion records linked to an item). Workflows include: create registry → invite guests → guests reserve/contribute → host confirms purchased/received → send thank-you notes (short templates). The platform tracks budgets, contribution transactions (synthetic), refunds/cancellations, and reminders (RSVP deadlines, shipping cutoff). Messaging includes guest chat per event and direct questions to the registrant with moderation tools. Admins can manage fraud rules (duplicate reservations, suspicious contribution patterns) and reporting (top reserved items, fulfillment rates). Entities are clean CRUD: events, invites, items, reservations, contributions, messages, and statuses.

name: CommunityInbox (Member Messaging + Announcements + Moderation)
description: CommunityInbox is a communication hub for online communities and membership groups, centered on structured messaging and moderation rather than long-form content. Admins CRUD communities, roles (owner/mod/member), channels (announcements, Q&A, support, social), and posting policies (approval required, rate limits). Members CRUD profiles (bio snippet, tags, timezone), conversation threads, and direct messages. Workflows include: new member onboarding → welcome sequence messages → posting → moderation queue (flagged items) → enforcement actions (warn/mute/ban with durations). Messages are stored as bounded text with attachments metadata, reactions, and read receipts. Announcement posts support scheduled publishing, pinning, and targeted delivery by tags/segments. A ticket-like “ask a mod” feature creates private threads with statuses (new/triaged/closed) and assignments. Analytics can be simulated via event logs (message.sent, reaction.added, user.muted). The API surface includes CRUD for users, channels, threads, messages, flags, moderation actions, schedules, and notification preferences.

name: RepairDesk Lite (Repair Shop Tickets + Customer Updates)
description: RepairDesk Lite is a ticketing and communication system for device repair businesses (phones, laptops, appliances). Staff CRUD customers, devices (brand, model, serial/IMEI, condition), repair tickets (issue codes, intake checklist, estimated cost, SLA due date), and parts usage (part SKU, quantity, cost). Workflows: intake → diagnostics → quote approval → repair in progress → quality check → ready for pickup/shipped → closed. Each stage changes status and triggers templated notifications (SMS/email metadata) to the customer. Messaging is threaded per ticket, with internal notes vs customer-visible messages, plus attachments metadata (photos, invoices). The system supports deposits, payments, refunds (synthetic transactions), and warranty periods with reopen rules. Staff can assign tickets to technicians, track time logs, and manage queues by priority. Admins manage store locations, business hours, pricing templates, and custom fields. All data is synthesizable and CRUD-heavy: tickets, statuses, estimates, approvals, parts, payments, messages, and audit logs.

name: MemberPass (Membership Subscriptions + Entitlements)
description: MemberPass is a subscription and membership management platform for gyms, coworking spaces, newsletters, and clubs. Admins CRUD membership plans (price, billing cadence, trial rules, capacity limits), perks/entitlements (guest passes, class credits, discount percentages), and policies (freeze, cancellation, late fees). Members CRUD profiles, payment method tokens (metadata only), subscriptions (start/renewal dates, status), and benefit usage records (credit consumption, guest check-ins). Workflows include: sign-up → trial → active → renewal failed (dunning sequence) → grace period → canceled/paused. The platform supports coupon codes, upgrades/downgrades with proration rules (simulated), and invoicing. A check-in module records visits by location and time, and can enforce limits (e.g., 10 visits/month) deterministically.
