Workflows include pledge tracking (pledged → partially_paid → fulfilled), offline gifts entry (cash/check), and refund/void operations with audit trails. The platform includes task queues for stewardship (call donor, send thank-you) and exports for accounting. All data is synthesizable: donation amounts, donor addresses, receipt numbers, campaign metrics, and recurring schedules, making it ideal for API simulations and database-driven interactions.

name: CatalogForge PIM (Product Catalog + Attributes + Syndication)
description: CatalogForge PIM is a product information management system for brands managing large catalogs across channels. Teams CRUD products, variants, SKUs, categories, attribute definitions (size, material, compliance flags), and media references (URLs/metadata only). Workflows include data completeness checks, approval stages (draft → review → approved → published), and channel-specific mappings (Amazon/Shopify/B2B portal) with transformation rules (attribute rename, unit conversion). Pricing is managed as price lists with effective dates, customer segments, and currency; inventory is optional and can be synced as stock snapshots. The platform supports bulk imports as jobs (file_id, progress, row errors) and versioning for auditability. Users can manage related products (accessories, substitutes), compliance documents metadata (MSDS links), and localized fields (title, short description) with validation constraints. Syndication endpoints push “published” products to downstream systems via webhooks. All data is synthesizable and CRUD-heavy—ideal for simulating complex relational schemas, state transitions, and batch operations without needing real reviews or long-form content.

name: WarehouseWarden WMS (Bins + Pick/Pack + Cycle Counts)
description: WarehouseWarden WMS is a warehouse management system for small to mid-sized operations. Admins CRUD warehouses, zones, bins, items (SKU, lot/serial rules), suppliers, and customers. Core transactions include receiving (ASN → receipt → putaway tasks), inventory movements (transfer, adjustment, quarantine), and outbound fulfillment (sales orders → waves → pick tasks → pack → ship). Each step updates inventory balances by bin, lot, and status (available/reserved/damaged). The system supports barcode scan events (timestamp, user, location) and exception workflows (short pick, overage, substitution approvals). Cycle counting is modeled with count plans, assigned counters, counted quantities, variance review, and recount steps. Shipping supports carrier service selection and label metadata generation (tracking numbers can be synthetic) plus shipment status events (manifested/in_transit/delivered). Role-based permissions and audit logs provide realistic operational controls. Everything is based on structured entities and numeric quantities, making it highly suitable for API simulation and deterministic database-driven interactions.

name: AssetTrail Tracker (Equipment + Maintenance + Chain-of-Custody)
description: AssetTrail Tracker is an asset tracking and maintenance platform for organizations managing equipment, tools, or IT peripherals. Admins CRUD asset types, individual assets (serial, tag, purchase date, depreciation fields), locations, and custodians (employees/contractors). Chain-of-custody is modeled via check-out/check-in transactions with due dates, condition reports (enumerated values + short notes), and signature metadata. Maintenance workflows include preventive maintenance schedules, work orders (priority, tasks checklist, parts used), and status transitions (open → in_progress → awaiting_parts → completed → closed). Assets can have warranties, vendor contracts, and attachments metadata (manual URLs, photos links). The platform supports audits: inventory scans that reconcile “expected vs found” and generate discrepancy cases (missing, unexpected, damaged). Integrations include webhook events for asset_assigned, work_order_completed, and audit_variance_detected. Reporting endpoints summarize utilization, downtime, maintenance costs, and asset lifecycle. Data is fully synthesizable—assets, locations, dates, statuses, and numeric costs—providing rich CRUD operations and realistic workflows for API environment simulation.

name: CauseCamp Manager
description: CauseCamp Manager is a fundraising event platform for nonprofits running walks, galas, and online campaigns. Admins CRUD organizations, campaigns, events (date, venue, capacity), ticket types, sponsorship tiers, and fundraising pages for individuals/teams. Donor records include contacts, communication preferences, tax receipt profiles, and employer matching metadata. Donations are modeled as pledges and payments with statuses (initiated/authorized/settled/failed/refunded), plus soft credits and tribute gifts. Workflows include participant registration, team creation, goal setting, discount codes, check-in lists, and badge/QR generation metadata. Finance tools support batch reconciliation, export jobs, and receipt issuance queues. Campaign managers create email/SMS segments, scheduled reminders, and thank-you tasks tied to donation milestones. A public API can simulate checkout sessions, webhook-driven payment status updates, and real-time leaderboards derived from stored totals (without needing live feeds). Audit logs and role-based permissions (org admin, event manager, volunteer captain) provide realistic multi-tenant CRUD interactions.

name: FoodBank Inventory Hub
description: FoodBank Inventory Hub is a warehouse-style system for food pantries and regional food banks. Staff CRUD donors/suppliers, incoming donations, purchase orders, items (UPC/SKU, category, allergens, unit size), lots (expiry, best-by, temperature class), and storage locations (warehouse, zone, bin). Inventory is tracked by quantity and unit of measure with adjustment reasons (cycle count, spoilage, recall, transfer). Workflows include receiving (scan items → create lots → put-away tasks), picking/packing for agency orders, inter-warehouse transfers, and distribution events with allocations by household size. The platform supports kitting (assemble standard boxes), substitution rules, and reservation of stock for upcoming distributions. Compliance features include recall notices, lot holds, and temperature excursion incident records. Reports are database-driven (turnover, shrink, near-expiry lists) and can be simulated via stored aggregates. APIs cover scan events, task queues, and integration tokens for scales/handhelds, all using synthesizable inventory and timestamp data.

name: ShelterSupply Asset Tracker
description: ShelterSupply Asset Tracker manages durable assets and supplies for homeless shelters and outreach teams. Admins CRUD sites (shelters, drop-in centers), rooms, storage lockers, asset categories, and individual assets (serial number, condition, acquisition cost, funding source grant). Consumables (blankets, hygiene kits) are tracked as stock items with minimum thresholds and reorder points. Workflows include check-out/check-in of assets to staff or clients, scheduled maintenance, damage/loss reporting, and replacement approvals. Each transaction records timestamps, custodian, expected return, and status (issued/overdue/returned/retired). For outreach, mobile-friendly “distribution sessions” capture batches issued by kit type, location, and team members, with optional signature metadata and incident notes. The system supports barcode/QR label generation, audit logs, and periodic inventory counts with discrepancy reconciliation. APIs allow creating assets, moving locations, posting scan events, and generating alerts when items are overdue or below par levels. All data is realistic to synthesize and supports complex CRUD plus lifecycle state transitions.

name: GrantGoods Catalog & Fulfillment
description: GrantGoods Catalog & Fulfillment is a catalog-based ordering portal where nonprofits request approved supplies funded by grants. Program admins CRUD grant programs, eligible organizations, budgets, product catalogs (items, variants, restricted categories), and pricing rules (subsidized, fully covered, co-pay). Organizations browse and build carts, then submit requisitions that flow through approvals (draft → submitted → reviewer_changes → approved/rejected). Approved requisitions generate warehouse pick tickets, shipment records, and budget encumbrances that later convert to actual spend when marked shipped. Inventory can be internal (stock on hand by warehouse) or drop-ship vendors with purchase orders and expected delivery dates. The platform stores shipping addresses, delivery windows, and proof-of-delivery metadata. Reporting includes budget utilization, item distribution by program, and backorder queues. APIs focus on CRUD for catalog items, requisitions, approvals, and fulfillment status updates—ideal for simulation because products, budgets, and shipment statuses are all deterministic database entities.

name: AdoptLink Donation & Sponsorships
description: AdoptLink is a donation and sponsorship platform for animal rescues and sanctuaries. Staff CRUD animals (intake date, medical flags, foster/home status), sponsorship packages (monthly amount, benefits metadata), donors, and recurring giving plans. Donations are stored with allocation rules (general fund, medical fund, specific animal), receipts, and acknowledgement workflows. Recurring plans create scheduled invoices/charges with statuses (scheduled/processing/paid/failed/paused/canceled) and retry policies. The system tracks in-kind donations (food, crates, medicine) as item records with quantities and expiry dates, linking them to inventory locations and usage logs. Case workflows include intake → quarantine → treatment → adoptable, with tasks and appointment records (vet visits) as structured entities. Donor portals let users update payment methods metadata, manage communication preferences, and download receipts. APIs can simulate payment webhooks, renewal events, and allocation reports derived from stored transactions. The model is fully synthesizable and offers realistic CRUD around donors, animals, and recurring financial lifecycles.

name: SmartShelter IoT Console
description: SmartShelter IoT Console manages connected devices in nonprofit facilities (shelters, clinics, community centers). Admins CRUD sites, rooms, device types (thermostat, door sensor, smart lock, water leak sensor), individual devices (serial, firmware, connectivity), and access policies. Telemetry is stored as time-series readings (temperature, humidity, battery, open/closed, leak detected) that can be synthesized deterministically. Workflows include onboarding devices (provisioning tokens), assigning to rooms, configuring thresholds, and creating automation rules (if door_open after hours → create alert; if leak_detected → open incident ticket). Alerts become incidents with statuses (new/acknowledged/in_progress/resolved) and assignments to staff. Maintenance features track firmware updates, health checks, and device retirement/replacement history. The system supports role-based access (facility manager vs. technician) and audit logs for configuration changes. APIs emphasize device CRUD, telemetry ingestion endpoints, rules management, and incident lifecycle updates, making it ideal for environment simulation without relying on real hardware or live data feeds.

name: CommunitySolar Meter & Billing
description: CommunitySolar Meter & Billing is a utility-style platform for nonprofits running community solar or energy assistance programs. Operators CRUD participant accounts, service addresses, meters, rate plans, and billing cycles. Meter readings are imported as periodic records (kWh, timestamps, quality flags) that can be synthesized or uploaded via CSV batch jobs. Bills are generated from rules (base charges, tiered rates, credits), producing invoices with due dates, line items, and statuses (draft/issued/paid/overdue/void). Payment tracking includes payment intents, settlements, refunds, and allocations across outstanding invoices. Assistance programs can apply subsidies or one-time grants as credit transactions with eligibility periods and documentation metadata. Workflows include enrollment approvals, meter swaps, dispute tickets, and statement delivery preferences. Reporting covers arrears, consumption trends, and program impact metrics derived from stored readings. APIs suit simulation: CRUD for accounts/meters/rates, ingestion of readings, invoice generation runs, and webhook-like payment updates—no need for real grid integration.

name: ClinicColdChain Warehouse
description: ClinicColdChain Warehouse is an inventory and cold-chain compliance system for nonprofits distributing vaccines or temperature-sensitive medicines. Staff CRUD products (NDC-like codes, storage range, diluents), lots (expiry, manufacturer, recall status), storage units (fridge/freezer/cooler), and temperature loggers (device id, calibration date). Inventory is tracked by lot and location with reservation for appointments or outreach events. Workflows include receiving shipments (verify → quarantine hold → released), continuous temperature logging (time-stamped readings), excursion events (trigger → investigation → disposition: usable/quarantined/wasted), and wastage reporting with reason codes. Dispensing creates administration records linking patient identifiers (synthetic), dose, lot, and consent metadata, decrementing stock and updating lot status. Cycle counts reconcile expected vs. actual, producing adjustment transactions and audit trails. APIs cover lot CRUD, temperature ingestion, excursion/incident creation, and dispense endpoints—highly suitable for simulation because all readings, statuses, and timestamps can be generated while preserving realistic operational constraints.

name: ReliefFleet Dispatch & Asset Control
description: ReliefFleet Dispatch & Asset Control is a fleet and asset tracking platform for disaster-response nonprofits. Admins CRUD vehicles (VIN, type, capacity, maintenance schedule), drivers, equipment assets (generators, chainsaws, satellite phones), depots, and missions (incident, area, priority). Dispatch workflows create routes and assignments, track check-out of equipment to vehicles/teams, and record mission progress statuses (planned/en_route/on_scene/completed/canceled). GPS pings can be synthesized as coordinate/time events, enabling geofenced alerts (entered zone, idle too long) without real tracking. Maintenance modules manage service tickets, inspections, fuel logs, and odometer readings, plus downtime reasons. Inventory of consumables (fuel cans, tarps) can be attached to missions with issued/returned quantities. After-action reports are derived from mission logs, assets used, and time-on-task. APIs include CRUD for missions, assignments, pings, equipment custody transfers, and maintenance records, supporting realistic multi-entity interactions and stateful workflows in an API simulation environment.

name: Calendly Scheduling & Routing
description: Calendly is a scheduling platform that automates booking meetings based on availability rules and booking links. Core entities include users, teams, event types (duration, buffers, location type), availability schedules, booking pages, invitees, bookings, reschedule/cancel events, routing forms, and reminders/notifications. CRUD operations cover creating event types, updating availability windows, setting minimum notice and max bookings per day, and managing invitee data and custom questions. The primary workflow is: a host publishes an event type → an invitee selects a time slot → the system creates a booking, reserves the time, and triggers confirmations and reminders → either party can reschedule or cancel, updating booking status and timestamps. Teams can set round-robin or priority assignment rules, which creates additional interactions for routing (e.g., assigning based on region, department, or responses). Admins manage organizations, user seats, SSO settings, and group event types. Data is easily synthesized: calendars can be represented as time blocks and busy slots; bookings are records with participants, time zones, and status transitions (scheduled/rescheduled/canceled/no_show), enabling realistic API simulation without needing real calendar provider integrations.

name: Motive (KeepTruckin) Fleet Maintenance & Driver Logs
description: Motive is a fleet management platform combining vehicle records, driver profiles, maintenance tracking, and trip/log data. Entities include fleets, vehicles (VIN, make/model), devices (telematics units), drivers, assignments (driver ↔ vehicle), trips, odometer readings, fault codes (synthetic), inspections (DVIR), maintenance schedules, work orders, parts, vendors, and compliance statuses. CRUD operations include onboarding vehicles and drivers, pairing devices, creating maintenance plans, logging inspections, and opening/closing work orders with line items and costs. Workflows include: a trip is created from start/end events → mileage accumulates → maintenance due thresholds trigger alerts → a manager creates a work order, assigns a vendor, tracks status (open/in_progress/waiting_parts/completed), and records invoices (metadata). Driver workflows include daily logs, inspection submissions, issue reporting, and acknowledgments of repairs. Dashboards query vehicle uptime, cost per mile, overdue maintenance, and driver compliance. Data is synthesizable: GPS points can be approximated, mileage and timestamps are numeric, and fault/inspection statuses are structured. The platform yields rich API interactions across time-series events, relational entities, and stateful workflows.

name: LeaseRunner (Rental Applications + Screening)
description: LeaseRunner is a rental application and tenant-screening platform used by independent landlords and small property managers. Landlords CRUD properties, units, rent schedules, lease terms, and application requirements (income rules, pet policy, required documents). Prospective tenants create profiles, upload ID/income document metadata (file references), and submit applications to specific units with co-applicants. Applications move through a configurable workflow (draft → submitted → in_review → screening_requested → approved/denied/withdrawn) with timestamps, notes, and decision reasons. The system tracks screening orders (credit/criminal/eviction checks as request/response metadata), application fees, and refunds (status only, tokenized payment references). Landlords can schedule showings, message applicants, issue conditional approvals, and generate lease packets from templates (field-based merge variables). Once approved, an application can convert into a lease record, creating a tenant ledger with charges (rent, deposit) and a move-in checklist. Reporting endpoints provide vacancy, application funnel metrics, and lease conversion rates. All data is synthesizable: applicants, properties, screening outcomes, fees, and lifecycle statuses.

name: Buildium Lite (Small-Portfolio Property Management)
description: Buildium Lite is a property management portal centered on operational CRUD for small residential portfolios. Managers CRUD owners, properties, buildings, units, tenants, leases, rent rules, and fee schedules. A lease produces a recurring charge calendar and a tenant ledger; managers can post charges, record payments (cash/check/online token metadata), issue credits, and track delinquencies with dunning steps (reminder → late_notice → final_notice). Maintenance workflows include work orders (category, priority, photos metadata, entry instructions), assignment to vendors, quotes, approvals, and completion verification. The platform supports inspections (templates, itemized findings, pass/fail, follow-up tasks) and move-in/move-out checklists that generate deposit disposition items (charge lines + reasons). For owners, there are statements (period, income/expense summaries) and distribution rules; for tenants, a portal handles requests, announcements, and document library metadata (lease PDFs, addenda). Core statuses (occupied/vacant/notice, open/in_progress/on_hold/closed, paid/partial/overdue) make it ideal for API-driven simulations.

name: CozyNest Coliving (Rooms + House Rules + Billing)
description: CozyNest Coliving is a coliving operator platform that manages room inventory, member onboarding, and monthly billing across shared homes. Operators CRUD houses, rooms (availability windows, pricing, amenities), house rules, deposits, and membership plans (month-to-month, fixed term, utilities included). Applicants create profiles, identity verification metadata, preferred move-in dates, and roommate preferences (structured tags), then submit room requests. The workflow covers application review, interview scheduling, offer issuance, e-sign acceptance, and conversion into a member contract. Once active, the system generates recurring invoices (rent, utilities, cleaning fees) with proration, tracks payments and refunds (status + payment token references), and maintains a member ledger. Operational modules include incident tickets (noise, repairs, policy violations), house chores schedules, key/lock assignments, and asset inventory (furniture, appliances) with check-in/check-out logs. Move-in and move-out flows manage checklists, condition reports, and deposit deductions. Analytics endpoints summarize occupancy, churn, AR aging, and revenue by house/room. All entities—members, rooms, invoices, tickets, schedules—are easily synthesized for realistic CRUD testing.

name: SpaceFlex Self-Storage (Units + Reservations + Access Codes)
description: SpaceFlex is a self-storage facility management and online reservation platform. Operators CRUD facilities, unit types (size, climate control, drive-up), individual units, rate tables, promotions, and access schedules. Customers can search availability, reserve a unit for a date range, and convert reservations into rental agreements. The system tracks reservation and rental statuses (reserved → pending_payment → active → delinquent → lien → closed), with timestamps and reason codes. Billing includes recurring monthly rent, insurance add-ons, admin fees, and late fees; invoices, payments, credits, and refunds are recorded in a customer ledger (tokenized payment metadata only). Access control is modeled with gate codes and door lock credentials (code value/valid_from/valid_to, last_used timestamp), plus event logs for entries/exits. Move-in workflows capture ID verification metadata, unit inspection checklist, and lock assignment; move-out workflows compute proration, schedule vacate inspections, and close access credentials. Customer service tools include tickets, notes, and call-log metadata. Reporting endpoints provide occupancy by unit type, delinquency, revenue per available unit, and promotion performance—ideal for database-driven simulation.

name: Workday Payroll Sandbox (Pay Runs + Deductions + Taxes)
description: Workday Payroll Sandbox is a payroll operations simulator focused on pay cycles, employee setup, and calculation artifacts. Payroll admins CRUD companies, pay groups (weekly/biweekly/monthly), employees (employment status, pay rate, tax profile), bank accounts (tokenized), and earnings/deduction codes (overtime, bonuses, benefits, garnishments). Timesheets and salary changes feed into pay runs that move through statuses (draft → calculated → approved → paid → voided). Each pay run produces pay statements with line items (gross, pre-tax deductions, taxable wages, tax withholdings, employer taxes, net pay) and audit logs capturing who approved and when. Adjustments are modeled as off-cycle payments, retro pay, and corrections with reason codes. The platform supports benefit enrollments (plan, coverage tier, effective dates), PTO accrual rules, and year-to-date summaries. Bank files and tax filings are represented as generated report metadata (file_id, period, totals) rather than real submissions. APIs expose endpoints for employee changes, time import, pay run execution, and reconciliations (GL export mapping codes to accounts). All values—wages, deductions, tax rates, dates—are numeric/structured and highly synthesizable.

name: BambooHR Onboarding + Time Off (Employee Lifecycle)
description: BambooHR Onboarding + Time Off is an HRIS module set centered on employee records, onboarding tasks, and leave management. HR teams CRUD employees, departments, locations, job titles, compensation history, manager relationships, and document metadata (handbooks, signed forms). Onboarding workflows create task lists by role/location (I-9 steps, equipment requests, orientation sessions), assign owners, due dates, and completion states. Time-off management defines policies (PTO, sick, parental), accrual rules, carryover caps, and approval chains. Employees submit time-off requests that move through statuses (requested → approved/denied → cancelled) and automatically update balances; the system records absence calendar entries and optional coverage notes. Performance and training elements can be simulated via review cycles (templates, rating scales, goals) and course assignments (metadata only). Access control is role-based (admin/manager/employee) with field-level visibility. Offboarding workflows manage resignation dates, last-day checklists, account deprovision tasks, and exit interview responses (structured). Reporting endpoints provide headcount, turnover, PTO liability, and onboarding completion metrics. The platform is ideal for CRUD-heavy API simulations because the core data is structured, timestamped, and doesn’t depend on long-form content.

name: Indeed Employer Hub (Job Board + Applications Inbox)
description: Indeed Employer Hub is a job board employer console that manages postings, budgets, and inbound applicants. Employers CRUD company profiles, job postings (title, location, salary range, employment type, requirements as structured bullet fields), screening questions (multiple choice/short answers), and applicant routing rules. Posting workflows include draft → published → paused → closed, with optional sponsored budget settings and pacing parameters (daily cap, CPC bids as numeric fields). Candidates submit applications containing profile data, work history entries, availability, and resume file metadata; applications land in an inbox with statuses (new → reviewed → contacted → interview → offer → rejected) plus tags and notes. Scheduling features record interview slots, interviewer assignments, and event metadata, while communication is modeled as message threads with short templates and delivery states (queued/sent/failed). Employers can export applicant lists, create talent pools, and track simple funnel analytics (views, clicks, applies, conversion rate) using synthesized counters. Compliance controls include consent capture, data retention windows, and audit logs. No real search ranking is required; the simulation focuses on CRUD, pipeline transitions, and reporting around postings and applications.

name: Chargebee Growth (Subscriptions + Invoicing + Dunning)
description: Chargebee Growth is a subscription billing platform for SaaS and services businesses. Admins CRUD products, plans, add-ons, coupons, tax rules, and customer accounts. Subscriptions track lifecycle states (trialing → active → past_due → canceled) with billing cycles, proration, upgrades/downgrades, and scheduled changes. The invoicing engine generates invoices, credit notes, and refunds (status + payment token metadata), and maintains a ledger of transactions. Dunning workflows configure retry schedules, grace periods, and email steps; each failed payment creates an event timeline with attempt counts and outcomes. The platform supports usage-based billing via metered events (timestamp, quantity, metric), generating overage line items at period end. Revenue operations features include subscription churn reasons, cancellations with end-of-term vs immediate, and reactivation flows. Customer portal modules let users update billing addresses, payment methods (tokenized), and view invoices/receipts. Integrations are representable through webhooks (event type, payload) and API keys. Reporting endpoints cover MRR/ARR, cohort churn, AR aging, and coupon performance. All entities—plans, invoices, events, statuses, quantities—are structured and easy to synthesize for realistic API/database simulations.

name: Vimeo OTT Admin (Catalog Metadata + Entitlements)
description: Vimeo OTT Admin is a digital video subscription platform focused on content metadata management and access entitlements rather than video hosting itself. Operators CRUD channels, series, seasons, episodes (titles, durations, release dates, ratings, genre tags), artwork metadata, and availability rules (regions, start/end windows). Monetization includes subscription plans, TVOD rentals, bundles, and promotional codes; purchases create entitlements tied to users, plans, devices, and expiration dates. Users are represented as accounts with profiles, household members, and registered devices (device_id, platform, last_seen), with limits per plan. Playback is modeled as session logs and progress markers (watched_seconds, completion percent) without storing actual media. Moderation workflows cover comments/reviews (short text), flags, and visibility states. Operations can manage customer support tickets, refunds (status only), and chargeback cases (metadata). Release workflows allow draft → scheduled → published, with audit trails and webhook events for app clients. Analytics endpoints provide views, completion rates, subscriber counts, churn, and revenue by plan/title. The system is highly suitable for synthesis because it relies on structured catalog fields, transactional billing records, and entitlement lifecycles—not long-form content.

name: BambooHR
description: BambooHR is an HRIS for managing employee records and HR workflows from onboarding through offboarding. HR admins CRUD employee profiles (personal info, job details, compensation history metadata, emergency contacts), departments, locations, and organizational structure (manager relationships). Onboarding workflows include templates for checklists, assigned tasks (IT setup, paperwork, training), e-sign document placeholders (file metadata), and due dates with completion states. Time-off management can be simulated with policies (PTO/sick), accrual rules, requests, approvals, and balances with audit logs. Performance workflows include goals, review cycles, questions, ratings, and manager/peer feedback submissions. The system also tracks assets (laptops, badges), training records (course metadata, completion dates), and announcements. Employee self-service CRUD includes updating profile fields, submitting time-off requests, and acknowledging handbook items (stateful acknowledgments). Reporting entities include headcount, tenure, turnover, and absence trends. All core data (employees, tasks, requests, approvals, statuses, timestamps) is easily synthesized and supports realistic API simulations like create_employee, update_job, request_time_off, approve_request, and complete_onboarding_task.

name: Deel
description: Deel is a global payroll and contractor management platform that supports cross-border hiring through contracts, invoicing, and payments. Teams CRUD workers (contractors/employees), engagements (country, role, start/end dates), contracts (template metadata, clauses as structured fields), and compliance documents (file metadata, expiration dates). Payment workflows include creating invoices or payroll statements, adding expense items, applying approvals, and tracking statuses (draft → submitted → approved → paid/failed). The system can model multi-currency amounts, exchange-rate fields (synthetic), and payout methods as tokenized accounts. HR operations include onboarding checklists, equipment requests (items, shipping address fields), and offboarding steps with exit dates and access revocation tasks. Admins manage entities like legal entities, departments, cost centers, and permissions. Dispute handling can be simulated with cases tied to invoices (reason codes, messages, resolution outcomes). API simulation is rich: create_contractor, create_contract, submit_invoice, approve_payment, update_worker_status, and webhook events for payment_status_changed or document_expiring. Data is primarily structured and synthesizable: identities, dates, amounts, statuses, and task lists.

name: Indeed Employer Dashboard
description: Indeed Employer Dashboard is a job posting and applicant intake platform for companies advertising openings and managing inbound applicants. Employers CRUD job posts (title, location, salary range, employment type, screening questions), company profiles, and hiring team users. Candidate intake creates application records with resume metadata, answers to screening questions, source attribution, and consent flags. Employers can triage applications with states (new → reviewed → shortlisted → rejected) and add internal notes, tags, and tasks for follow-up. Communication workflows can be modeled as message threads (metadata, timestamps, templates) and interview invitations with scheduled times and confirmation states. The platform supports budgeting/paid promotion as campaigns (daily budget, spend to date, status paused/active), and performance analytics (views, clicks, apply rate) as synthesized metrics. Integrations can be represented via exportable applicant feeds and webhook-like events on application_created or application_status_updated. This scenario stays content-light: the primary objects are postings, applicants, and workflow states. CRUD operations map cleanly to APIs for creating jobs, listing applicants, updating dispositions, and generating reporting aggregates.

name: AngelList Talent (Wellfound)
description: AngelList Talent (Wellfound) is a job marketplace focused on startups and candidate matching through structured profiles and application workflows. Startups CRUD company pages (industry tags, stage, size), roles (requirements, compensation bands, remote options), and hiring team permissions. Candidates CRUD profiles (skills, role preferences, salary expectations, location, work authorization fields), applications, and saved jobs. Employers review applicant pipelines, request intro calls, and move candidates through stages with outcome reasons. Communication can be simulated via in-platform message threads and scheduling links (metadata). The platform supports talent pools, shortlists, and notes, plus structured interview feedback forms and scorecards. Offer flows include generating offer records (equity/bonus fields), approvals, and acceptance/decline statuses. Marketplace governance can be modeled with moderation queues (flagged profiles/jobs, review outcomes) and account verification states. Reporting entities include role fill metrics, response rates, and pipeline conversion—synthesizable counters and timestamps. This scenario is API-friendly: create_job, search_candidates (filters over structured fields), apply_to_job, update_application_stage, send_message, and webhook events for new_application or offer_accepted.

name: Slack (Workspace Administration + Workflows)
description: Slack can be simulated as a collaboration hub emphasizing workspace administration, channels, memberships, and workflow automation rather than heavy content. Admins CRUD workspaces, users, user groups, roles, and channel configurations (public/private, retention policy metadata). Users CRUD channels, membership lists, message objects (short text), threads, reactions (emoji codes), and bookmarks. Workflow Builder-style automation can be modeled with triggers (scheduled, webhook, form submission) and steps (post message, create channel, request approval, update a record). Enterprise-style features include audit logs, data exports (metadata), and compliance holds as structured records. Integrations can be represented as apps with OAuth installs, scopes, and event subscriptions; events include message_posted, channel_created, member_joined, and workflow_started. Operational workflows that fit well include incident coordination channels (incident record, severity, status), onboarding channels (checklist tasks), and request queues (forms create ticket objects posted to a channel). While message content exists, it can remain short and synthetic; the value is in entity relationships and event-driven APIs such as users.list, conversations.create, chat.postMessage, and events callbacks.

name: ServiceNow Lite (IT Service Desk + Asset & Incident Tracking)
description: ServiceNow-style ITSM portals manage internal IT requests, incidents, and assets. Employees CRUD service requests (category, urgency, description), incident tickets, and knowledge article feedback (ratings, short comments). IT agents CRUD ticket assignments, prioritization, SLAs, and resolution notes; they can link related items like affected services, configuration items (CIs), and change records. Core workflows include ticket lifecycle (new → triaged → in_progress → pending_user → resolved → closed), escalation based on SLA timers, and approvals for access or purchases. Asset management supports CRUD on hardware/software assets (serial, model, owner, location, warranty dates), inventory stock, and check-in/check-out transactions. A CMDB can store servers, applications, dependencies, and maintenance windows. Reporting dashboards aggregate metrics (MTTR, backlog, SLA compliance) and allow exporting. APIs can simulate realistic enterprise data: user directories, queue routing, repeating incidents, scheduled maintenance, and audit trails—entirely synthesizable structured records with timestamps and status transitions.

name: Jira Work Management
description: Jira Work Management is an issue- and project-tracking platform used beyond software teams for operations and business workflows. Users CRUD projects, issue types (task/request/incident), issues, epics, components, labels, and custom fields. Each issue holds structured attributes: summary, description (short text), priority, status, assignee, reporter, due date, SLA timers, linked issues, and attachments metadata. Teams configure workflows as state machines (To Do → In Progress → Waiting → Done) with transition rules, validators, and post-functions (e.g., auto-assign on transition, require fields before approval). Boards and backlogs are derived views from issue queries and can be represented via saved filters. Automation rules (when issue created, then set component; if priority=High, then notify channel and escalate) are first-class entities. Service-style intake is supported via request forms that map to issue fields and queues. Reporting entities include dashboards, gadgets, and saved reports referencing filters and time ranges. Everything is API-friendly for synthesis: issues, statuses, transitions, comments, and audit events.

name: Miro
description: Miro is a collaborative whiteboard platform where teams manage boards as shared work artifacts. For API simulation, the focus is on board and collaboration metadata rather than heavy content. Users CRUD organizations, teams, boards, board members, invitations, and access roles (viewer/commenter/editor). Boards contain structured objects that can be synthesized as lightweight entities: frames, sticky notes (short text), shapes, connectors, checklists, and kanban cards, each with position coordinates, size, color, tags, and timestamps. Version history and change events are modeled as snapshots and deltas (object.created, object.moved, object.updated, object.deleted). Comment threads attach to objects with resolved/unresolved states, mentions, and notifications. Templates are reusable board blueprints with predefined objects and frames. Governance features include retention rules, export job metadata (PDF/PNG export requests), and audit logs. Workflows include board creation from templates, invitation acceptance, approval of board sharing, and archiving. This is synthesizable because the “content” is short text plus structured shapes and coordinates, enabling realistic CRUD interactions without needing media or long-form documents.

name: Skedda
description: Skedda is a resource booking system for spaces and shared assets (rooms, desks, studios, equipment). Admins CRUD locations, spaces/resources, booking rules (opening hours, minimum/maximum duration, lead time), user groups, permissions, and pricing rules (hourly rates, member vs guest pricing). Users CRUD bookings with fields like title, purpose category, attendees count, recurrence, required equipment, and notes (short text). Booking lifecycles include requested → approved → confirmed → checked_in → completed/canceled/no_show, with optional approval workflows for certain spaces or time windows. The system supports conflict detection, buffer times, and maintenance blocks as first-class entities. Payments/invoicing can be modeled as charges tied to bookings with statuses (draft/issued/paid/void). Access features include door access integrations represented as access grants (start/end time, credential id metadata). Audit logs capture rule changes and booking edits. This scenario is ideal for API simulation: it’s CRUD-heavy with clear constraints, scheduling logic, and realistic operational workflows using entirely synthesizable entities and timestamps.

name: Square for Retail
description: Square for Retail is a POS and inventory platform for small retailers with online/offline sales. Entities include locations, registers, products, variants/SKUs, barcodes, categories, price books, inventory counts by location, purchase orders, suppliers, customers, carts, orders, payments metadata, returns, and employee permissions. Retailers CRUD catalogs, set pricing and sale rules, and manage stock movements (receive, transfer, adjust, recount) with reasons and audit logs. Selling workflows include building carts, applying discounts/taxes, completing payment, and issuing receipts; orders transition through states (open → completed → refunded/partially_refunded). Returns and exchanges are modeled as return orders linked to original transactions, updating inventory and generating refund events. Purchase order workflows cover draft → sent → partially_received → received/closed, with expected vs. received quantities and cost updates. Customer profiles track purchase history, notes, and marketing preferences. Integrations can simulate real-time inventory sync between store and online channels, as well as webhooks for order updates. All data—SKUs, quantities, prices, statuses, timestamps, store locations—is easy to synthesize and supports robust CRUD and event-driven testing.

name: Splunk Observability / Monitoring (Metrics & Alerts)
description: Splunk Observability (and similar monitoring suites) provides instrumentation, dashboards, and alerting for systems and applications. Key entities include organizations, users/teams, services, environments, metric time series (names, tags, values), log sources metadata, detectors/alert rules, dashboards, SLOs, incidents, on-call schedules, and notification channels. Admins CRUD dashboards (charts, queries, thresholds), define detectors with conditions (static thresholds, anomaly rules using precomputed flags, or rate-of-change), and route alerts to email/webhook/PagerDuty connectors (modeled as destinations). Incident workflows create incident records when alerts fire, attach related alerts, assign responders, and transition states (triggered → acknowledged → mitigated → resolved) with timelines and postmortem metadata. On-call schedules define rotations, overrides, and escalation policies. Although real monitoring involves live streams, the API simulation can use synthesized metric points and alert events with timestamps and tags, enabling realistic interactions like backfilling data, muting rules, and testing incident automation. The platform is suitable because the core operations are structured configuration and event records rather than content consumption.

name: RelayRoute Linehaul & Cross-Dock TMS
description: RelayRoute is a transportation management system for carriers and 3PLs coordinating linehaul and cross-dock operations. Dispatchers CRUD lanes, terminals, customers, rate agreements, and loads with stops (pickup, cross-dock, delivery) and required appointment windows. Each load tracks status (tendered/accepted/arrived/loaded/in_transit/at_terminal/out_for_delivery/delivered/exception) with timestamps, location pings (synthetic GPS), and document metadata (BOL, POD). Planners build trips by assigning tractors, trailers, and drivers; the system enforces constraints like hours-of-service limits, equipment type, and terminal cutoffs. Cross-dock workflows include inbound trailer check-in, unload tasks, sort-to-outbound, and re-seal events, each generating scan logs and handling units (pallet_id, piece_count, weight). Billing supports accessorials (detention, lumper, fuel surcharge), automated invoice generation, and dispute/adjustment records. Customers can log in to create shipment requests, view ETAs, and receive exception alerts. APIs simulate tendering, status updates, and EDI-like events.

name: ParcelPilot Last-Mile Delivery Tracker
description: ParcelPilot is a last-mile delivery platform for local couriers and retailers offering customer-facing tracking. Merchants CRUD customers, delivery orders, pickup/dropoff addresses, service levels (same-day/two-hour/standard), and delivery windows. Dispatchers batch orders into routes and assign them to drivers and vehicles; each stop records proof-of-delivery metadata (signature flag, photo URL metadata, recipient name, delivered_at) and status transitions (created/assigned/picked_up/en_route/attempted/delivered/returned). Drivers use a mobile workflow to scan packages (barcode_id), capture event codes (address_not_found, customer_not_home, damaged_package), and send standardized notes. Real-time location can be simulated via periodic GPS pings tied to route_id and timestamp. Returns and redelivery are modeled as linked orders with reason codes and scheduled windows. Merchants can set notification rules (SMS/email) and view dashboards for on-time rate, average drop time, and failed delivery reasons. APIs cover order creation, route optimization requests (mock), event posting, ETA updates, and webhook subscriptions for tracking events.

name: DealerDesk Automotive Sales & F&I CRM
description: DealerDesk is a dealership platform for managing vehicle inventory, leads, deals, and finance-and-insurance workflows. Staff CRUD vehicle records (VIN, trim, mileage, options, acquisition cost), photos metadata, and pricing history. Sales teams manage leads and opportunities with stages (new/contacted/test_drive/negotiation/closed_won/closed_lost), tasks, notes, and appointment scheduling. Deal worksheets model trade-ins (appraisal, payoff), fees, taxes, incentives, and lender offers; approvals and manager overrides are tracked as audit events. F&I modules CRUD lender profiles, rate sheets, credit application submissions (metadata only), product add-ons (warranty, GAP, maintenance plan), and contract packets (document metadata, signature status). Delivery workflows include vehicle prep checklists, final paperwork steps, and post-sale follow-ups. Customer service can initiate addendum requests, refunds, or contract corrections with reason codes. APIs enable synthetic simulations: inventory updates, lead ingestion, quote generation, lender decision responses (approved/conditional/declined), and deal status webhooks.

name: PartsShelf Multi-Location Auto Parts Inventory
description: PartsShelf is a parts inventory and procurement system for dealerships, repair chains, or municipal garages. Users CRUD parts master data (SKU, OEM number, interchange groups), suppliers, price lists, and store locations with bins. Stock is tracked by location, bin, lot (optional), and status (available/reserved/defective/returned). Core workflows include purchasing (POs → receipts → putaway), internal transfers between stores, reservations for repair orders, and returns to vendor with RMA numbers. The system supports cycle counts with count sessions, variances, and approval logs. Demand planning features generate suggested reorders based on min/max levels and recent usage; users can override and create POs. Sales/counter tickets can be created for walk-in customers or internal departments, producing invoices and tax calculations (synthetic). Reporting endpoints show fill rate, aging inventory, and stockouts. APIs provide a strong CRUD surface for simulating scanning events, inventory movements, and procurement lifecycles without any content-heavy dependencies.

name: GiveHarbor Donations & Campaign Operations
description: GiveHarbor is a nonprofit donation and campaign operations platform focused on structured fundraising data. Staff CRUD donor profiles, households, communication preferences, and consent flags. Fundraising teams CRUD campaigns, goals, appeal codes, and giving forms (fields, suggested amounts, matching gift flags). Donations can be one-time or recurring with schedules, soft credits, designations (general, program-specific), and statuses (initiated/authorized/settled/failed/refunded). Receipting is automated: tax receipt records include issue date, deductible amount, and delivery status. Peer-to-peer fundraising supports fundraisers (participant profiles), teams, and pledged amounts with progress tracking. The platform manages in-kind gifts as separate entities (item, estimated value, restriction) and produces acknowledgment tasks. Operations workflows include donation reconciliations, batch exports to accounting, and dispute/chargeback records. APIs simulate webhook payment events, recurring renewals, refunds, donor merges, and campaign performance queries—highly suitable for database-driven testing with fully synthesizeable numbers, timestamps, and short text.

name: ReliefStock Disaster Supply Distribution Tracker
description: ReliefStock supports charities and emergency response teams distributing supplies during disaster relief. Admins CRUD warehouses, mobile distribution sites, item catalogs (water, meals, hygiene kits), and kits (bill of materials). Inventory is tracked by lot and expiration date where applicable, with statuses (available/reserved/packed/distributed/damaged). Request workflows allow partner organizations to submit supply requests (items, quantities, delivery method, priority); coordinators approve, allocate stock, and create pick/pack tasks. Distribution events record recipient type (household/shelter/community center), quantities issued, and optional anonymized recipient tokens for repeat visits—avoiding content-heavy personal data while staying realistic. Logistics features include shipment records to field sites, vehicle assignments, and route stops with check-in/out timestamps. Accountability includes audit logs, variance reports, and donation-in-kind receipts for inbound supplies. APIs support request submission, allocation, inventory movements, distribution posting, and dashboard queries for burn rate and days-of-supply, making it ideal for synthesized, database-driven environments.

name: Yardi / AppFolio Property Management (Rentals)
description: Yardi/AppFolio-style property management software supports rental operations for landlords and property managers. Admins CRUD owners, properties, buildings, units, unit amenities, rent schedules, and availability. Applicant and tenant portals CRUD applications, household members, documents metadata, and communication preferences. Leasing workflows cover listing → application intake → screening result (status only) → lease offer → e-sign metadata → move-in. Lease records include term dates, recurring charges, deposits, late-fee rules, and renewals. Maintenance workflows include work orders (category, priority, unit, access instructions) → vendor assignment → scheduling → in_progress → completed with parts/labor line items and invoice records. Accounting entities include ledgers, charges, payments, credits, and owner distributions; payments store method metadata (ACH/card token), status (pending/settled/failed/returned), and reconciliation batches. Inspections can be modeled as checklists with photo metadata, condition ratings, and follow-up tasks. Notices (pay-or-quit, renewal offers) are structured templates with delivery logs. This scenario is ideal for synthesized CRUD and lifecycle events without requiring real documents or sensitive financial details.

name: PagerDuty (On-Call + Incident Response)
description: PagerDuty is an incident management platform for alerting and coordinating operational response. Teams CRUD services, integrations (event sources), escalation policies, on-call schedules, users, teams, and notification rules. Incoming events create incidents with severity, deduplication keys, and statuses (triggered/acknowledged/in_progress/resolved). Workflows include alert ingestion → incident triggered → assignment/escalation → acknowledgements → conference bridge/war room links (metadata) → status updates → resolution and post-incident review. Incidents can spawn tasks, notes, timeline events, and stakeholder notifications. Users manage overrides (swap shifts), maintenance windows (suppress alerts), and service dependencies. Analytics entities include MTTA/MTTR metrics, incident counts by service, on-call load, and noise reduction via event rules. Access control and auditing track who acknowledged, reassigned, or resolved incidents with timestamps. The entire model is highly synthesizable: services, alerts, schedules, escalation events, and incident timelines can be generated realistically for API simulations of monitoring integrations and operational workflows without any need for real-time external data.

name: ServiceTitan (Field Service Management)
description: ServiceTitan is a field service management platform for HVAC, plumbing, and electrical contractors. Core entities are customers, service locations, assets/equipment (model, serial, install date, warranty), technicians, job types, pricebooks, work orders, and invoices. Dispatchers CRUD jobs, assign technicians, set appointment windows, and manage status workflows (new → scheduled → enroute → onsite → completed → invoiced → paid). Technicians use a mobile app to view schedules, capture notes/photos (metadata), record labor time, add line items from the pricebook, collect signatures, and take payments (tokenized payment metadata). Inventory can be modeled via truck stock, parts, and purchase orders, with job-level part reservations and adjustments. The platform supports estimates, approvals, change orders, membership plans, and follow-up tasks. Reporting endpoints can summarize revenue, close rates, technician utilization, and outstanding AR. Integrations include customer notifications (SMS/email metadata), call tracking (call records metadata), and accounting exports, all driven by synthesizeable records and timestamps.

name: Freshdesk (Customer Support Ticketing)
description: Freshdesk is a helpdesk platform for managing customer support across email, chat, and web forms (message content can be short and synthetic). Key entities include contacts, accounts/companies, agents, groups, tickets, conversations, tags, SLAs, canned responses (short templates), knowledge base articles metadata (title/category/status), and satisfaction ratings. Workflows center on ticket lifecycle states (new → open → pending_customer → resolved → closed), assignment rules, priority and impact fields, and SLA timers with breach tracking. Agents CRUD tickets, add internal notes, change statuses, link related tickets, and create tasks/follow-ups. Automation rules can be modeled as triggers (when status changes, when overdue) that set fields or notify agents (notification records). The system supports custom fields (order_id, device_serial), time tracking for billable hours, and escalations to supervisors. Reports aggregate volumes by channel, response times, agent performance, backlog, and CSAT, all derived from structured ticket events and timestamps. This scenario is highly synthesizable because it’s centered on workflow state transitions, assignments, and audit logs rather than long-form content.

name: Apple Health / HealthKit-Style Wellness Logger
description: A HealthKit-style mobile health platform aggregates user-entered and device-sourced wellness metrics without requiring real sensors. Entities include user profiles, connected devices (metadata), data sources, metric types (steps, heart rate, sleep, weight, blood pressure), samples (value, unit, start/end timestamps), workouts (type, duration, calories, route coordinates optional), goals, and notifications. Users CRUD profiles, set privacy/consent flags, connect/disconnect devices, and authorize apps as data writers/readers. Workflows include daily metric ingestion (create batches of samples), deduplication by source and time window, goal progress updates, and anomaly flags (e.g., unusually high resting heart rate) recorded as simple events. Users can create plans (weekly activity targets), log workouts, edit/delete incorrect entries, and export summaries. Clinician-sharing can be simulated with share invitations, access scopes, and audit logs. Dashboards and APIs expose aggregates (daily totals, rolling averages) generated from synthetic samples. This scenario provides rich time-series CRUD patterns, permissions, and data normalization workflows while keeping all values realistically synthesizable.

name: OpenTable for Business (Restaurant Reservations Management)
description: OpenTable for Business is a reservation and table management system centered on structured bookings rather than content. Entities include restaurants, dining areas, tables (seats, joinable groups), shifts, availability rules, customers, reservations, waitlist entries, special requests (short text), guest notes/tags, and notification logs. Hosts and managers CRUD floor plans, table configurations, and shift schedules, then open inventory for specific time blocks with pacing rules (max covers per 15 minutes). Reservation workflows include states (requested → confirmed → seated → completed) and exceptions (cancelled/no_show), with timestamps for seat time and turn time. Walk-ins can be added to a waitlist and converted into seated parties, assigning tables and tracking quoted vs actual waits. Customer profiles accumulate visit history, spend estimates (synthetic), no-show counts, and preferences (allergies as tags). The platform can support deposit holds (payment token metadata) and automated reminders. Reporting includes occupancy, table turn times, no-show rates, and demand by time slot—derived entirely from structured reservation events, making it highly suitable for API/database simulation.

name: ThreadHarbor Community Groups
description: ThreadHarbor is a community platform for local and interest-based groups (neighborhoods, hobby clubs, alumni circles). Users CRUD profiles (bio, location, privacy), group memberships, and notification preferences. Group admins CRUD groups (name, description, rules, join questions), roles (owner/mod/member), and moderation settings. Core entities include posts (text, tags, attachments metadata), comments, reactions, polls (options, close time), and events (time, venue/address, capacity, RSVP limits). Workflows support join requests (pending/approved/denied), post review queues, reporting/appeals (report reason, status, moderator notes), and member discipline (warnings, temporary mutes, bans). Events support RSVP lists, waitlists, check-in status, and reminder scheduling. A lightweight marketplace module can be enabled per group: listings (title, category, price), inquiries, and reservation holds with expiry. APIs naturally cover feed retrieval by group, CRUD for content and membership, moderation actions, and audit logs (who changed what, when). All data is synthesizable: members, groups, posts, timestamps, locations, and status fields.

name: MatchCraft Dating & Safety Profiles
description: MatchCraft is a dating app centered on structured matchmaking inputs and clear consent/safety workflows. Users CRUD profiles (photos metadata, prompts, interests, dealbreakers), preference settings (age range, distance, intent), and visibility controls. Core entities include swipes/likes, matches, chat threads (message metadata, read receipts), and date plans (proposed time/location, confirmation status). The platform models safety features as first-class records: verification checks (selfie/doc metadata, status), block lists, report tickets (category, description, evidence metadata), and consent check-ins (pre-date checklist, post-date feedback). Matching can be simulated with deterministic rules (shared interests, distance, activity recency) rather than AI inference. Workflow states include like → match → chat → plan_proposed → confirmed/canceled, plus account states (active/paused/deactivated). Users can schedule “availability windows” and set auto-expiring invites. Monetization is modeled via subscriptions (tier, renewal date, entitlements like unlimited likes) and in-app purchases (boosts, super-like bundles) with receipts and entitlement history. APIs cover CRUD for profiles, preferences, interactions, moderation/safety actions, and subscription lifecycle events, all using synthesizable entities and timestamps.

name: FormStacker Builder (Forms + Workflows)
description: FormStacker Builder is a form and workflow platform for teams collecting structured data (intakes, inspections, incident reports). Admins CRUD workspaces, form templates, sections, fields (type, validation rules, conditional logic), and versions (draft/published). Users submit responses that create submission records with field values, attachments metadata, geolocation/time captured, and signature metadata (no actual biometric). Workflows route submissions into queues with steps (review, approve, assign, complete), SLA deadlines, and status transitions. Assignment entities include assignees, due dates, and task comments. Notification rules are configurable (email/webhook triggers on create/update/overdue). Access control is role-based: form editors, reviewers, submitters, and external respondents via tokenized share links. Reporting is modeled as saved views (filters, columns) and export jobs (format, status, download URL metadata). Integrations are represented by connector configs (endpoint, auth metadata) and delivery logs (attempt count, response code). APIs naturally cover form CRUD, field validation schemas, submission ingestion, workflow actions (approve/reject/return), and audit logs. Data is easy to synthesize: organizations, forms, responses, statuses, timestamps, and numeric/text fields.

name: PulsePanel Product Feedback & Roadmap
description: PulsePanel is a product feedback portal where customers submit ideas, vote, and track roadmap progress. Admins CRUD products, feedback boards, categories/tags, and visibility settings (public/private, SSO-only). Users CRUD feedback posts (title, short description, attachments metadata), comments, and votes. Duplicates are handled via merge workflows: link duplicates to a canonical item, carry over voters, and post update notices. Product teams manage status pipelines (new/under_review/planned/in_progress/shipped/declined) with public changelog entries (short notes, release version, date). Internal triage entities include severity, effort estimates, impact scores, and linked customer accounts. A lightweight survey module can be attached to a feedback item to collect structured follow-up (use case, willingness to pay, priority ranking). Notification subscriptions let users follow items and receive status-change events. Moderation includes spam flags, user bans, and content hiding with reason codes. APIs cover CRUD for feedback, voting, commenting, status transitions, changelog publishing, and customer segmentation fields—fully synthesizable without needing long-form content, recommendations, or external data feeds.

name: ApplyFlow Admissions (Applications + Review)
description: ApplyFlow is an application management system for programs (bootcamps, scholarships, fellowships, internships). Applicants CRUD profiles, contact info, education history entries, short answers, references (referee contact + submission status), and document uploads metadata. Programs are entities with eligibility rules, deadlines, cohorts, and required form sections. Submissions move through a configurable pipeline (draft/submitted/in_review/interview/decision/accepted/declined/waitlisted) with timestamps and automated reminders. Reviewers CRUD evaluation rubrics (criteria, scoring scales), scorecards per applicant, interview notes, and recommendation flags. Scheduling supports interview slots, invites, reschedules, and attendance status. Decision workflows include offer letters (template + merge fields), acceptance confirmations, deposits (invoice metadata), and onboarding checklists (forms, ID verification metadata, agreement acknowledgments). Admins manage reviewer assignments, blind review settings, and conflict-of-interest declarations. Analytics is modeled as aggregate counts and export jobs rather than heavy BI. APIs cover applicant intake, file metadata, reference collection, reviewer scoring, status updates, and cohort enrollment—highly suitable for synthesized datasets (applicants, applications, scores, decisions, deadlines).

name: RegiDesk Event Registrations & Check-in
description: RegiDesk manages registrations for conferences, workshops, and webinars with structured attendee data. Organizers CRUD events (venue, sessions, capacity), ticket types (price, quotas, refund rules), registration forms (custom fields), and promo codes. Attendees CRUD registrations (ticket selection, add-ons, dietary/accessibility fields), payment records metadata, and badge details. Session enrollment is modeled separately: session choices, waitlists, and seat holds with expiration. Check-in supports QR code tokens, scan logs (time, device_id), and attendance status per session. Organizer workflows include approval-required registrations, group registrations (company/team), transfer tickets, and partial refunds/cancellations with state transitions. Communication tools are templated: confirmation emails, schedule updates, and reminder campaigns with send logs. Exhibitor module (optional) includes booths, staff passes, lead scans (contact fields), and follow-up tasks. Post-event feedback can be captured with short surveys linked to sessions. APIs cover CRUD for events, tickets, attendees, check-in, and reporting exports (attendance lists, revenue summaries). All data is synthesizable (names, tickets, amounts, capacities, timestamps) without requiring content-heavy materials.

name: CourseSpring LMS (Courses + Assessments)
description: CourseSpring is an LMS for self-paced courses and cohorts emphasizing structured learning objects. Instructors CRUD courses, modules, lessons (short text + resource links metadata), quizzes (questions, options, correct answers), assignments (prompt, rubric), and gradebook settings. Learners CRUD enrollments, lesson progress (started/completed timestamps), quiz attempts (responses, score), assignment submissions (file metadata), and discussion replies (short text). Cohorts add schedules (release dates, live session slots), attendance logs, and announcements. Grading workflows support auto-graded quizzes and manual review queues for assignments with rubric scoring, feedback comments, and resubmission cycles. Certificates are generated as records (issue date, certificate_id, status) tied to completion rules. Access control includes instructor, TA, learner, and guest preview roles. Integrations are represented by LTI-like external tool configs (URL, key metadata) and launch logs. APIs can simulate realistic course catalogs, enrollment spikes, assessment results distributions, and progress tracking. The platform stays away from content-heavy lecture hosting by treating media as URLs/metadata while focusing on CRUD and stateful learning workflows.

name: TutorRoster Scheduling & Lesson Notes
description: TutorRoster connects students with tutors for recurring sessions and package-based billing. Tutors CRUD profiles (subjects, rates, availability), service offerings (1:1, group, exam prep), and cancellation policies. Students CRUD profiles, learning goals, preferred times, and saved tutors. Bookings are core entities: session requests, confirmed sessions, recurring series, location (online/in-person address), and status (requested/confirmed/completed/no_show/canceled) with reason codes. Scheduling includes availability slots, buffer times, reschedules, and conflict detection. After sessions, tutors create lesson notes (short summary, homework items), skill assessments (rating scales), and next-session plans. Packages model prepaid credits (quantity, expiry), credit ledger entries, and invoices/receipts metadata; refunds and adjustments are tracked as transactions with audit trails. Messaging is modeled as threads tied to bookings with read states. Admin workflows include dispute tickets, tutor verification status, and marketplace rules enforcement. APIs support CRUD for availability, bookings, recurring schedules, notes, billing artifacts, and ratings—ideal for synthesizing realistic calendars, attendance patterns, and payment states without relying on AI tutoring or content generation.

name: LabForum Q&A (Technical Forums)
description: LabForum is a structured Q&A and discussion forum for technical communities (IT, science labs, makers). Users CRUD accounts, topic subscriptions, and reputation profiles. Content entities include questions (title, body short text, tags), answers, comments, and votes. Moderation entities include flags (reason, status), edit suggestions (proposed diff metadata, approvals), and rate limits/penalties. Knowledge organization is handled via tag management (synonyms, descriptions), collections (curated lists of threads), and accepted answers. Workflows include question lifecycle (open/answered/accepted/closed/duplicate) and escalation paths (auto-close after inactivity, reopen requests). Community roles (new user, trusted, moderator) are derived from synthesizable metrics like reputation points, badges, and activity counts. A lightweight “bounties” feature can be modeled as point escrow records with start/end times and award transactions. Search can be implemented as basic tag/title filtering without simulating web-scale ranking. APIs cover CRUD for threads, tagging, voting, moderation actions, user reputation events, and audit logs. The platform remains suitable because it focuses on structured interactions and short-form content rather than long articles or recommendation engines.

name: Trainerize-Style Personal Training Coaching Portal
description: A coaching portal for personal trainers and clients focuses on structured program delivery and progress tracking. Entities include trainers, clients, health profiles (goals, injuries flags), training plans, workout templates, exercise library items (name, muscle group, equipment), scheduled workouts, sets/reps targets, client check-ins, progress metrics (weight, measurements), habit trackers, message threads (short text), and billing items (packages, invoices, payments status). Trainers CRUD clients, assign plans, build workout templates, schedule sessions, and set progression rules (e.g., increase load after completion). Clients CRUD workout logs (actual reps/weight, RPE, completion status), upload before/after photo metadata (URL only), submit weekly check-in forms, and acknowledge plan updates. Workflows include onboarding questionnaire → plan assignment → daily workout completion → weekly review with trainer notes → plan revision. The system can generate compliance reports and streaks from logged timestamps, support session booking (availability blocks), and manage package usage (sessions_remaining). Everything is database-driven and can be synthesized without needing real sensor data.

name: MyFitnessPal-Style Nutrition & Meal Logging
description: A nutrition tracker enables users to log meals and monitor macros without relying on real barcode databases. Entities include users, nutrition goals (calories/macros), food items (name, brand optional, serving sizes, macro numbers), recipes (ingredients, servings), meal entries (timestamp, meal type), daily diaries, water logs, weigh-ins, and short notes. Users CRUD custom foods, recipes, and diary entries; they can copy prior days, edit serving quantities, and set reminders. Workflows include onboarding goals → daily logging → nutrient totals computation → weekly summaries and adherence stats. The platform supports meal plans (templated menus per day), grocery lists derived from recipes, and “quick add” macro entries for fast logging. Social features can be limited to structured sharing: friend lists, visibility settings, and simple reactions. Admin endpoints manage food categories, unit definitions, and validation rules. All nutrition numbers, food catalogs, and timestamps are easily synthesized, making this a clean CRUD-heavy domain suitable for database-driven API environments.

name: Strava-Style Workout Journal & Challenge Hub (No Real GPS Required)
description: A workout journal and challenge platform tracks activities and friendly competitions using synthetic routes and metrics. Entities include users, activities (run/ride/swim), metrics (distance, duration, pace, elevation_gain, calories), optional route coordinates (polyline metadata), gear items (shoes/bike), segments (named route snippets), challenges (date window, goal rules), leaderboards, kudos (likes), and short comments. Users CRUD activities (manual entry or file metadata), gear assignments, privacy settings, and participation in challenges. Workflows include activity creation → metrics validation → leaderboard recomputation → challenge completion status updates → monthly recap generation. Clubs/groups can be modeled with membership lists, scheduled group events, RSVP statuses, and attendance. Safety features can be represented as simple flags (hide_start/end, follower-only). The platform avoids real sensor integrations by treating activity metrics and routes as user-provided structured data. This enables realistic API simulations with time-series queries (weekly totals), pagination, filtering by sport/date, and derived stats while keeping content requirements minimal.

name: Asana-Style Work Management for Marketing Ops
description: A work management app for marketing operations organizes campaigns as projects with tasks and approvals. Entities include organizations, teams, users, projects, sections/boards, tasks, subtasks, custom fields (budget, channel, priority), assignees, dependencies, due dates, status values, comments (short), attachments (file metadata), and activity logs. Users CRUD projects and tasks, assign owners, set deadlines, define templates for recurring campaigns, and automate status transitions (e.g., “Ready for Review” → “Approved”). Workflows cover request intake → task triage → execution with dependencies → stakeholder approval → launch checklist → post-launch retro tasks. Approvals can be modeled as structured decisions (approved/rejected, decided_at, reason tag). Views include kanban, calendar, and workload (computed from due dates and estimates). Integrations can be simulated via webhook events and external IDs (e.g., “ad_platform_campaign_id”). This scenario is strongly API-driven: permissions, membership, filtering, and audit trails are central and fully synthesizable.

name: SurveyMonkey-Style Feedback & NPS Program Manager
description: A feedback platform manages surveys, recurring NPS programs, and structured reporting without relying on long-form content. Entities include customers/contacts, contact lists, surveys, question banks, response options, distribution campaigns (email/SMS metadata), collectors (links), responses, NPS scores, tags, segments, and dashboards (saved filters). Users CRUD surveys, reuse templates, schedule recurring sends, and manage opt-out preferences and consent flags. Workflows include audience selection → distribution scheduling → response collection → auto-scoring (NPS, CSAT) → alert rules (e.g., score ≤ 6 creates a follow-up ticket record) → periodic reporting. Responses are structured (ratings, multiple-choice, short comments) and easy to synthesize. The system supports deduplication (one response per contact per campaign), reminders to non-respondents, and anonymization settings. Reporting endpoints provide time-series trends, segment comparisons, and driver analysis based on numeric correlations (all computed from synthetic numbers). This scenario emphasizes CRUD, segmentation, and automation—excellent for database-driven simulations.

name: Eventbrite-Style Fitness Event Registration & Check-In
description: A registration platform for races, workshops, and fitness meetups manages tickets, attendees, and on-site check-in. Entities include organizers, venues, events, sessions (multi-day schedules), ticket types (price, capacity, sales window), discount codes, add-ons (t-shirt sizes), orders, attendees, transfers, refunds (status), check-in logs, and email notifications (metadata). Organizers CRUD events, agendas, ticket inventories, waiver requirements, and custom registration questions. Buyers CRUD carts and orders, assign tickets to attendees, update attendee details, and request refunds or transfers subject to policy rules. Workflows include event creation → ticket sales → order confirmation → attendee export → day-of check-in (scan token) → post-event attendance and revenue reporting. Capacity controls support waitlists, reserved blocks, and per-session limits. Financial reporting tracks fees, payouts, and settlement batches with statuses (pending/paid/failed). All event, ticket, and attendee data is structured and synthesizable, enabling realistic API interactions around inventory, order lifecycles, and check-in operations.

name: Airtable (No-Code Database + Views)
description: Airtable is a no-code database platform where users build bases (workspaces) containing tables with customizable fields and relational links. Admins CRUD workspaces, users, permissions, and API keys. Builders CRUD bases, tables, fields (types like text, number, single select, multi select, date, attachment metadata, linked record, formula), views (grid, kanban, calendar), and automations. End users CRUD records, including bulk import/export, filtering, sorting, grouping, and rollups across linked tables. Workflow patterns include: intake form submission → record created → assigned owner → status transitions → automation triggers webhook or sends notification → record archived. This scenario supports realistic synthesis: record schemas can be generated, along with relation graphs (e.g., projects → tasks → assignees), attachment placeholders (file name/type/size/URL), and activity logs (who changed what, when). API simulation can include optimistic concurrency (revision numbers), rate limits, pagination, and formula recalculation. It offers varied interaction patterns (schema design + data CRUD + automation runs) while keeping content short and structured.

name: Zenoti (Salon/Spa Appointment + Memberships)
