description: Zenoti is a platform for salons and spas handling appointments, services, memberships, and retail add-ons. Operators CRUD locations, staff providers, service catalogs (duration, price, required resources), rooms/resources, hours, and client profiles (contact info, preferences, consent). Booking workflow: client searches availability → selects service/provider → reserves slot → optional deposit → check-in → service completion → add products → checkout → receipt and rebook. Appointments track status (requested/confirmed/checked_in/in_service/completed/no_show/canceled) plus reschedule history. Membership entities include plans, benefits (discount %, included services), billing cycles, and member status (active/past_due/canceled). Gift cards and packages can be simulated as balance records with redemption transactions. Staff scheduling includes shifts, breaks, time-off requests, and commission rules (per service/product). Reporting can generate synthetic metrics such as utilization, rebooking rate, no-show rate, and revenue by provider. The domain provides a rich mix of calendar-based operations, transactional records, and policy-driven pricing—all easily synthesized for API testing.

name: Schoology (K-12 LMS + Gradebook)
description: Schoology is a learning management system focused on structured course administration, assignments, and grading. District admins CRUD schools, terms, courses, sections, teachers, students, guardians, and roles/permissions. Teachers CRUD course materials (titles, categories), assignments, quizzes (question banks, points), rubrics, and gradebook categories/weights. Workflow: create course → enroll students → publish assignments with due dates → students submit (submission metadata, file URL placeholder) → teacher grades → feedback (short) → final grades calculated → report cards exported. Attendance can be simulated via per-session records (present/absent/tardy) and notes. Discussion posts can be limited to short text and counts, avoiding content-heavy requirements. Communication features include announcements, messaging threads metadata, and notification preferences. The system naturally supports roster changes, late submissions, extensions, and regrade events. Analytics endpoints can return synthetic progress metrics (missing work count, average score by standard, login frequency) without needing real learning content. This scenario offers strong relational data modeling, role-based access, and lifecycle states suitable for API simulation.

name: FormForge Intake & Workflow Forms
description: FormForge is a forms-and-intake platform for collecting structured data and routing it through review workflows. Admins CRUD workspaces, form templates, sections, fields (types, validation rules, conditional logic), file-upload slots (metadata only), and branding settings. Teams publish forms via links/embeds and manage submissions with statuses (new/in_review/needs_info/approved/rejected/archived). Each submission stores respondent profile data, answers, timestamps, source (web/kiosk/API), and consent flags. Workflow features include assignment to reviewers, comments, internal notes, SLA due dates, and task checklists. FormForge supports reusable question libraries, versioning (draft/published/retired), and change logs so existing submissions retain the schema used at submission time. Automation rules can create follow-up forms, trigger webhooks, or generate “case” records when certain answers appear (e.g., high-risk flags). Reporting endpoints expose counts, funnel metrics, and exports (CSV/JSON) with filters by date range, form version, status, and tags. Everything is synthesizable: respondents, answers, attachments metadata, timestamps, reviewer actions, and audit events.

name: SurveyPulse NPS & CSAT Feedback Hub
description: SurveyPulse is a customer feedback platform centered on short surveys (NPS/CSAT/CES) and structured issue tagging. Admins CRUD organizations, projects, survey templates, questions, answer choices/scales, distribution lists, and delivery channels (email/SMS/in-app link). Each response captures respondent identifiers (customer_id/account_id), rating values, short comments, tags, and timestamps. Workflows include response triage (new/triaged/follow_up/closed), assignment to owners, and creation of follow-up tickets or tasks linked back to the original response. Teams manage tag taxonomies (product area, reason codes), sentiment labels (manual), and escalation rules (e.g., NPS <= 6 creates an escalation record with priority and due date). The platform provides suppression lists, consent/opt-out tracking, and throttling rules for how often a customer can be surveyed. Analytics endpoints return aggregated scores by segment, trend lines, and cohort comparisons, without needing real content. Integrations are modeled as CRUD-managed connectors and webhook subscriptions that receive events like response.created, response.updated, and escalation.triggered.

name: GrantApply Application Portal
description: GrantApply is an application and registration portal for programs such as grants, scholarships, or community initiatives. Program admins CRUD programs, eligibility rules (structured criteria), application forms, required documents (metadata), scoring rubrics, reviewer pools, and submission windows. Applicants create profiles, manage household/organization details, upload required files (metadata), and submit applications that move through states (draft/submitted/incomplete/under_review/awarded/declined/withdrawn). Reviewers record scores per rubric category, add structured notes, request additional information, and recommend decisions. The platform supports multi-round cycles with phases (eligibility screening → panel review → final approval), conflict-of-interest flags, and assignment logic (random, load-balanced, or by expertise tags). Award management includes award amounts, disbursement schedules, compliance checklists, and reporting deadlines with reminders. Every action is auditable via event logs (who changed what/when), and admins can export applicant lists, scoring summaries, and decision letters (template metadata + merge fields). Data is fully synthesizable: applicants, organizations, amounts, scores, statuses, timelines, and document references.

name: ClinicConnect Patient Portal
description: ClinicConnect is a patient portal for clinics to manage demographics, scheduling, and communications without requiring real clinical narratives. Staff CRUD patients, guardians, insurance policies (payer, member IDs), care teams, locations, appointment types, and appointment slots. Patients CRUD profiles, contact preferences, consents, and appointment requests; staff confirm and manage appointment statuses (requested/scheduled/checked_in/seen/canceled/no_show) with reminders. The portal supports secure messaging threads (short, synthetic messages), inbound questionnaires, and document delivery (visit summaries and lab result metadata only). Billing features include invoices, line items (service codes), payments, and statements with balances and due dates. Clinical data can be modeled as structured items: problem list codes, allergy flags, immunization records, vitals entries, and medication lists (name, dose, frequency, start/stop dates) without deep free-text. Workflows include new patient registration, insurance verification status tracking, pre-visit forms, check-in, and follow-up task creation. APIs expose patient timelines, appointment management, document indexes, and audit trails for access and edits, enabling realistic database-driven simulations.

name: RxBridge Pharmacy Refill & Inventory
description: RxBridge is a pharmacy management and patient-facing refill portal designed for synthetic yet realistic medication workflows. Pharmacy admins CRUD stores, staff users, patient profiles, prescribers, drug catalog entries (NDC, strength, form), and insurance plans (BIN/PCN metadata). Prescriptions are modeled with directions (structured sig), quantity, refills remaining, fill history, and statuses (active/on_hold/expired/transferred/canceled). Patients request refills, choose pickup/delivery, manage notification preferences, and update insurance information. The dispensing workflow tracks fill tickets through stages (queued/processing/ready/picked_up/delivered/returned_to_stock) with timestamps and responsible staff. Inventory is tracked by drug, lot (optional), on-hand, reserved, reorder thresholds, and supplier purchase orders; receiving updates stock and creates audit entries. The platform supports prior-authorization tracking as a separate record type (initiated/pending/approved/denied) and claims submission metadata (no real adjudication) with claim statuses and rejection codes. Reporting includes controlled substance logs (metadata), refill adherence metrics, and shrinkage counts, all fully synthesizable for API testing.

name: GlucoHome Connected Glucose Device Manager
description: GlucoHome is an IoT device management platform for connected glucose meters and related sensors, emphasizing device state and readings rather than real medical interpretation. Admins CRUD tenants (clinics/programs), users, device models, firmware versions, and provisioning batches. Patients (or caregivers) CRUD device pairings, connectivity settings (Wi‑Fi/cellular metadata), and data-sharing consents. Devices generate synthetic telemetry: readings (value, unit, timestamp), battery level, signal strength, error codes, and sync sessions. Workflows include device enrollment (claim code → activation), firmware rollout (staged deployments, success/failure outcomes), and alert rules (thresholds, missing-data windows) that create alert records with severity and acknowledgment status. Care teams view dashboards of enrolled patients, last-seen timestamps, and adherence summaries, and can open “cases” when alerts persist. The platform supports data correction flags (duplicate/invalid) and audit trails for edited/deleted readings. APIs cover device commands (ping, reboot, start_sync), configuration profiles, telemetry queries by time range, and event streams, making it ideal for database-driven simulation with synthesizable sensor data.

name: HomeGrid Smart Home Automation Console
description: HomeGrid is a smart home platform for managing devices, rooms, automations, and event histories without needing real hardware. Users CRUD homes, rooms, members/roles, and device records (type: thermostat, lock, light, camera metadata-only, leak sensor). Each device has capabilities and state attributes (on/off, temperature setpoint, lock_state, battery, connectivity). Users create scenes and automation rules with triggers (time schedules, geofence enter/exit, device state change) and actions (set device state, send notification, run scene). Workflows include onboarding (hub pairing, device discovery), sharing access (guest codes, time-limited permissions), and troubleshooting (connectivity checks, device logs). Event history stores state transitions with timestamps and actor (user/automation/system). The platform supports energy-style summaries using synthetic metrics (kWh estimates per device, runtime minutes) and maintenance reminders (filter change, low battery). APIs allow querying current state, issuing commands, managing automation definitions, and subscribing to event webhooks (device.state_changed, automation.executed). All entities and data are synthesizable while still matching realistic smart home CRUD and orchestration patterns.

name: MedEquip Fleet Device Service & Compliance
description: MedEquip is a device fleet management system for medical equipment used in clinics (infusion pumps, monitors, portable ultrasound), focusing on inventory, maintenance, and compliance artifacts. Admins CRUD facilities, departments, devices (serial, model, purchase date), calibration schedules, service vendors, and parts catalogs. Devices move through lifecycle statuses (in_service/available/assigned/out_for_repair/decommissioned) and can be assigned to rooms or patients (assignment metadata only). Work orders track issues, priority, diagnostic codes, labor entries, parts used, and timestamps from opened → dispatched → in_progress → completed → verified. Preventive maintenance creates recurring tasks with due dates and pass/fail outcomes, plus certificates (document metadata) stored per device. The platform tracks software/firmware baselines, patch campaigns, and completion rates across sites. Compliance features include inspection checklists, incident reports, and audit logs of who edited device records. Reporting endpoints cover uptime, MTTR, overdue maintenance, and asset utilization. This scenario is fully synthesize-friendly: device inventories, maintenance events, parts usage, schedules, and status transitions.

name: ImmuniReg Vaccination Registration & Clinic Events
description: ImmuniReg is a registration platform for vaccination clinics and public health events. Organizers CRUD events, locations, capacity rules, appointment slots, eligibility groups, consent forms, and screening questionnaires. Registrants CRUD profiles, guardianship links, demographic fields, and appointment bookings; bookings include confirmation codes, check-in states (scheduled/checked_in/completed/canceled/no_show), and reminder preferences. At the clinic, staff manage check-in queues, verify eligibility (status only), record administered doses as structured records (product, lot, site, dose number, timestamp), and schedule follow-up appointments with recommended date windows. Inventory is tracked per location by product and lot with on-hand, reserved, wasted, and transferred quantities; dose administration decrements stock and writes an audit entry. The system supports adverse event reports as structured forms (symptom list, severity, onset time) and post-visit surveys. APIs cover public slot search, registration submission, QR-based check-in, dose recording, inventory adjustments, and exports for reporting. All data—people, appointments, lots, doses, and questionnaires—is realistic yet fully synthesizable.

name: GitHub Issues-Style Project Tracker (Code Hosting Metadata Only)
description: A GitHub-like platform focused on repository metadata and work tracking (not hosting real code content) is highly suitable for synthesis. Organizations CRUD orgs, teams, members, repositories, permission levels, and branch protection rules (as configuration records). Work management centers on issues, pull requests (PR metadata), milestones, labels, assignees, project boards, and automation rules. Users create issues with short titles/descriptions, set priority, link to milestones, add labels, and track status (open/in_progress/blocked/closed). PR workflows can be modeled with commits as metadata objects (hash, author, timestamp), checks (CI status: queued/running/passed/failed), reviews (approved/changes_requested/commented), and merge states (mergeable/conflict). Additional entities include releases (version tags), changelog entries (short text), and webhooks for event delivery. Audit logs capture permission changes and sensitive operations. Analytics endpoints summarize cycle time, lead time, throughput, and contributor activity. This scenario exercises complex relationships (many-to-many labels, assignments, reviewers), state transitions, and event-driven integration testing without requiring real code, diffs, or long-form content.

name: NetSuite-Style Procurement (Purchase Orders & Supplier Management)
description: A NetSuite-like procurement module focuses on sourcing and purchasing workflows across suppliers and inventory—highly synthesizable. Organizations CRUD vendors, vendor contacts, payment terms, currencies, item masters (SKUs, units, preferred vendors), warehouses, and approval policies. Buyers create purchase requisitions that route for approvals (requester → manager → finance) and convert approved requisitions into purchase orders (POs) with line items, negotiated prices, expected delivery dates, and incoterms. Receiving workflows include goods receipts, partial deliveries, backorders, and discrepancies (short/over/damaged) with reason codes. Three-way matching can be modeled: PO ↔ receipt ↔ vendor bill, producing exception records for quantity/price variance. Vendor bills (invoices) move through statuses (entered/pending_approval/approved/paid) and connect to payment batches. Optional entities include RFQs, supplier scorecards (on-time rate, defect rate), and contracts metadata (start/end, renewal). Inventory updates are transactional: on-order, received, available, reserved. Reporting includes spend by category, open PO aging, vendor performance, and approval cycle time. This scenario exercises complex relational integrity and approval workflows without needing content-heavy documents.

name: Acuity Scheduling-Style Appointments (Services, Staff & Payments Metadata)
description: An Acuity-like scheduling platform supports rich CRUD around services, calendars, and booking flows. Businesses CRUD locations, staff members, services (duration, buffers, price), service categories, add-ons, packages, and availability rules (working hours, time-off, holiday calendars). Clients CRUD profiles, intake forms (field definitions), and appointment requests. Appointment entities include service, provider, location, start/end, status (requested/confirmed/checked_in/completed/canceled/no_show), and reminders. Workflows include client self-booking with rules (lead time, max future booking), approvals for requested appointments, rescheduling, and cancellation policies with fees. Payments can be modeled via invoices and payment records (amount, method, status), including deposits and gift certificates (codes, balances). The system supports group classes with capacity, waitlists, and attendance lists. Automation includes email/SMS templates (short), recurring appointment series, and webhook events for appointment.created/updated/canceled. Reporting summarizes utilization by staff, revenue by service, cancellation rates, and upcoming schedules. This scenario emphasizes time-based constraints, resource allocation, and transactional records—excellent for API simulation and database testing.

name: Stripe Billing (Subscriptions, Invoices, Credits, Dunning)
description: Stripe Billing-style subscription management is highly synthesizable because it revolves around structured financial objects and lifecycle states. Businesses CRUD customers, payment methods (token metadata), products, prices, coupons, tax rates, and subscription schedules. Subscriptions reference items (price, quantity), billing anchors, proration behavior, and statuses (trialing/active/past_due/canceled/unpaid). Invoicing workflows include invoice drafts → finalized → paid/void/uncollectible, with line items, discounts, taxes, and credits. Dunning can be modeled with retry rules, payment failure codes, and notifications sent. The platform supports usage-based billing via meter events (customer, metric, quantity, timestamp) that roll up into invoices. Credit notes and refunds are separate entities with reasons and allocations. Webhooks drive integrations (invoice.created, payment_failed, subscription.updated). Reporting endpoints return MRR, churn, AR aging, and cohort retention. Disputes can be included as structured cases (status, evidence metadata links, deadlines). Every field—amounts, timestamps, states, IDs—can be fabricated realistically, enabling comprehensive API simulations involving idempotency, event ordering, and reconciliation-like queries.

name: Google Calendar (Scheduling, Invites, Resource Booking)
description: A Google Calendar-like scheduling platform is suitable for synthesis because events are structured records with predictable workflows. Users CRUD calendars, event templates, time zones, availability settings, and sharing permissions. Events include title, location (short text), start/end timestamps, recurrence rules, attendees, reminders, conferencing link metadata, and visibility settings. Invite workflows track RSVP statuses (needs_action/accepted/declined/tentative), updates, cancellations, and organizer changes. Resource booking adds entities for rooms/equipment with capacities, features, and approval rules; events may require resource holds with conflict checking. Users manage working hours, out-of-office blocks, and focus time categories. A basic free/busy API returns time ranges per user/resource, enabling scheduling assistants without AI inference. Notifications are modeled as queued deliveries (email/push flags) with delivery status. Audit logs capture who created/edited events and when. Search can be limited to filtering by date range, attendee, or calendar ID (no web search ranking). This scenario yields rich CRUD, concurrency/conflict cases, and event-driven integrations while remaining fully synthesizable with timestamps, statuses, and attendee lists.

name: UtilityConnect (Electricity/Water Billing & Meter Management)
description: A municipal utility billing platform is ideal for synthesized APIs because it relies on structured accounts, meters, readings, and invoices. Staff CRUD customers, service addresses, meter devices (type, serial, install date), rate plans, and service agreements. Meter readings can be imported as batches (meter_id, read_at, value) with validation statuses; estimated reads can be flagged separately. Billing workflows generate bills per cycle: draft → issued → paid/partial/overdue/void, with line items (usage tiers, fixed charges, taxes, fees) and due dates. Payments include channels (ACH/card/cash), allocations across bills, reversals, and NSF events. The platform supports move-in/move-out orders, service connects/disconnects, and field appointments with work order statuses. Adjustments include credits, re-bills, and dispute cases with reason codes and deadlines. Notifications cover bill-ready, overdue, and outage alerts (status-only, not real-time grid data). Reporting endpoints provide aging, consumption trends per premise, high-usage flags, and delinquency rates. Every entity—meters, reads, bills, payments, work orders—can be realistically synthesized for database and workflow simulation.

name: PolicyHub (Insurance Policy Administration & Claims Intake)
description: An insurance policy administration system can be simulated effectively using structured policy, billing, and claims metadata. Agents and underwriters CRUD customers, households, vehicles/properties (insured assets), coverage options, deductibles, endorsements, and policy terms. Quotes become policies through workflows: quote → under_review → issued → active → lapsed/canceled/renewed, with versioning for mid-term changes. Billing includes installments, invoices, payments, and cancellations for non-pay. Claims intake is structured: claim notice with loss date, loss type, location, involved parties, and attachments metadata; then claim statuses (open/investigating/approved/denied/closed) and reserves/payments. Adjuster assignments, tasks, and diary notes can be short text. Providers (repair shops, appraisers) are entities with networks and service regions. Regulatory fields (state, form number) and audit logs fit well for API testing. Reporting endpoints summarize loss ratios, claim cycle time, cancellation reasons, and renewal retention. This scenario avoids needing real actuarial models or narrative-heavy content while still offering complex CRUD, state machines, and relational data across customers, assets, coverages, policies, and claims.

name: LabFlow (Laboratory LIMS: Samples, Tests, Chain-of-Custody)
description: A Laboratory Information Management System (LIMS) is highly suitable for synthetic environments because it centers on sample tracking and structured results. Labs CRUD clients, projects, sample types, collection kits, locations, and test methods (analytes, units, detection limits). Sample records include barcode, collected_at, received_at, condition flags, storage location, and chain-of-custody events (transfers, signatures metadata, timestamps). Workflows move samples through accessioning → queued → in_testing → results_ready → QA_review → reported, with holds and re-tests. Test runs group samples into batches with instrument metadata (model, run_id) and calibration records; results are numeric or categorical with qualifiers (pass/fail, below_LOD). Nonconformance events capture deviations, corrective actions, and closure status. Reports can be represented as generated report metadata (format, version, issued_at) without long narrative. Inventory modules track reagents and consumables with lot numbers and expirations. Billing can be per test or per project with invoices and payment status. This platform offers rich relational CRUD, auditability, and lifecycle state transitions, all fully synthesizable and valuable for API/database simulations.

name: Calendly (Scheduling & Appointment Booking)
description: Calendly-style scheduling is ideal for API simulation because it centers on structured availability, booking rules, and event records. Users CRUD profiles, connected calendars (provider metadata), event types (duration, location type, buffer times), availability schedules (weekly rules, exceptions), booking questions (form fields), and notification templates (short text). Invitees create bookings by selecting time slots; the system generates scheduled events with status (scheduled/rescheduled/canceled/no_show) and stores participant details, time zones, meeting links (metadata), and notes. Workflows include: publish booking link → compute available slots → confirm booking → send reminders → reschedule/cancel with policy enforcement. Teams can manage round-robin routing and collective availability by CRUDing team members, routing rules, priorities, and max bookings per day. Payment-enabled event types can model invoices and transactions as structured records (amount, currency, status). Admin functions include organization-wide settings, domain restrictions, role-based access, and audit logs of changes. Reporting endpoints can query bookings by event type, host, date range, and conversion rates. All data—times, people, event metadata, and policies—can be synthesized while still producing realistic edge cases like time-zone conflicts, double-booking prevention, and last-minute cancellations.

name: GitHub (Repository & DevOps Collaboration Metadata)
description: GitHub can be simulated effectively by focusing on structured collaboration metadata rather than actual code content. Organizations CRUD users, teams, repositories, branches (names only), permissions, secrets metadata, and webhooks. Developers CRUD issues, labels, milestones, projects/boards, pull requests, reviews, and status checks, with short titles/descriptions and timestamps. Workflows include: open issue → assign → link to branch/PR → PR review approvals → merge → close issue, capturing events in an audit log. CI/CD can be modeled as workflow runs and jobs with statuses (queued/in_progress/succeeded/failed/canceled) and artifact metadata (name, size, checksum) without needing real binaries. Release management can CRUD releases, tags, changelog snippets (short), and deployment environments with gates/approvals. Security features can be represented via vulnerability alerts metadata, dependabot PR records, and access logs. API interactions cover listing repos, creating PRs, commenting, updating statuses, and receiving webhooks for push/PR events. Analytics are straightforward queries: cycle time, PR throughput, reviewer load, and incident counts per repo. This scenario exercises permissions, event streams, and lifecycle transitions across many related entities.

name: Slack (Team Messaging Admin + Channel Operations)
description: Slack-like platforms are suitable when scoped to workspace administration and structured messaging metadata (short text). Admins CRUD workspaces, users, user groups, roles, apps/integrations, OAuth tokens metadata, and retention policies. Teams CRUD channels (public/private), membership lists, channel topics/purpose, and settings (posting permissions, approvals). Users create messages (short), threads, reactions, pins, and file metadata (filename/size/type), plus scheduled messages with send_at timestamps. Workflows include onboarding (invite → join → assign to channels), moderation (message flagged → review queue → delete/retain), and governance (export requests, retention holds). You can model huddles/calls as session records (participants, start/end, status) without media. Automation patterns include slash commands and workflow builder steps as structured rules triggering notifications, task creation, or webhook calls. Search can be limited to simple filtering by channel/user/date rather than full relevance ranking. The API surface supports event subscriptions for message.created, member.joined, channel.archived, etc., enabling event-driven simulations. Reporting queries can cover active users, message volume by channel, response times, and app usage. This yields realistic multi-tenant access control, rate limiting, and audit logging scenarios.

name: Toast (Restaurant POS Back Office & Menu/Inventory Ops)
description: Toast-style restaurant POS back-office systems are highly structured and can be simulated without payment rails or real receipts content. Operators CRUD restaurant locations, terminals/devices (metadata), staff, roles, and shift schedules. Menu management includes CRUDing menu groups, items, modifiers, modifier groups, pricing by location/daypart, taxes, and discounts. Order workflows can be modeled as: create check → add items/modifiers → send to kitchen (KDS ticket metadata) → update statuses (open/fired/ready/served/closed) → apply discounts → tender types (cash/card/gift) with synthetic transaction records. Inventory modules CRUD ingredients, recipes (bill of materials), vendors, purchase orders, deliveries, and stock counts with variance reasons. Labor modules CRUD time punches, breaks, overtime rules, and tip pools. Gift cards and loyalty can be modeled as accounts, balances, earn/burn events, and reward tiers. The system can support refunds, voids, and manager approvals as structured events with reason codes. Reporting endpoints query sales by category, item popularity, comp/void rates, labor cost percentage, and inventory depletion. Integrations can be simulated with webhooks for order created/closed, menu updates, and employee changes—providing realistic event-driven testing across operations, finance, and staffing.

name: Zenefits (HR Benefits Enrollment & Employee Lifecycle)
description: Zenefits-style HR platforms offer complex but synthesizable employee lifecycle data. HR admins CRUD companies, departments, locations, job titles, employees, compensation records, employment statuses (active/leave/terminated), and required documents metadata. Onboarding workflows include tasks/checklists, equipment assignments metadata, policy acknowledgments, and e-signature links (metadata). Benefits administration can model plan catalogs, eligibility rules, open enrollment windows, employee elections (medical/dental/vision/FSA), dependents, and carrier connections as structured configurations. Time-off tracking includes PTO policies, accrual rules, balances, and requests with approval chains and statuses (requested/approved/denied/canceled). Payroll can be represented as pay runs, earnings, deductions, taxes (as computed fields), and pay stubs metadata without needing real bank transfers. Compliance workflows include I-9/W-4 status flags, training assignments, incident reports (short), and audit logs of changes. Employee self-service CRUDs profile fields, emergency contacts, and benefit changes after life events (marriage/move). Reporting queries can cover headcount, turnover, PTO liability, and enrollment rates. This scenario stresses permissions (employee vs manager vs HR), effective-dated records, approvals, and period-based calculations—excellent for realistic API simulations.

name: Indeed Employer Job Posting & Sponsorship Console
description: An Indeed-style employer console lets companies create and manage job ads and applicant inflow at scale. Employers CRUD company profiles (locations, billing contacts), job posts (title, category, salary range, remote flag, screening questions), and application forms (required fields, knockout criteria). Posting workflows include draft -> pending_review -> active -> paused -> closed with publish windows and expiration dates. Paid promotion features CRUD sponsorship budgets (daily cap, start/end), bid settings, and billing line items, while performance metrics are exposed as aggregations (impressions, clicks, applies, cost) that are fully synthesizable. Applicant management supports lightweight pipeline statuses (new/reviewed/interview/requested/rejected/hired) plus short notes and tags. Employers can message applicants using templated replies (short text) and schedule interview requests (available slots, location/video metadata). Multi-location hiring is supported through job distribution rules and role-based access for recruiters vs. hiring managers. Audit logs track changes to postings and budgets. APIs can simulate webhook events like “application_received” and “job_closed,” enabling integration testing for downstream ATS imports, billing reconciliation, and reporting dashboards.

name: Workday Recruiting + Core HR
description: A Workday-style HR platform combines recruiting with employee lifecycle management. HR admins CRUD organizational structures (companies, cost centers, supervisory orgs), positions, job profiles, and compensation grades. Recruiting entities include requisitions (position, budget, approvals), candidates, interview events, and offers. Once a candidate is hired, a workflow converts them into a worker record with onboarding tasks. Core HR supports CRUD worker profiles (personal info, addresses, emergency contacts), employment events (hire/transfer/promotion/termination), job assignments, and manager hierarchies. Time-off and absence modules CRUD accrual policies, balances, requests, approvals, and calendars. Document management is metadata-driven: document types, required checklists, and storage references (file IDs, not content). Security features include role-based permissions, delegated admins, and effective-dated changes. Approval workflows are central: requisition approvals, compensation changes, and job changes route through configurable steps with statuses (submitted/approved/denied/returned). Reporting APIs query headcount, turnover, req aging, and comp distributions with synthetic numeric results. The model is ideal for API simulations because nearly all fields are structured, timestamped, and auditable.

name: ADP Workforce Now Payroll + Time & Attendance
description: ADP Workforce Now–style software supports mid-market payroll integrated with timekeeping, scheduling, and HR compliance. Admins CRUD employee master records, earning codes, deduction codes, tax profiles, and pay groups with multiple schedules. Time & attendance modules manage time clocks (device metadata), punches (in/out timestamps), timecards (daily totals, exceptions), and approval workflows. Scheduling supports shifts, labor rules, overtime thresholds, and manager approvals. Payroll processing imports approved timecards to generate pay statements with itemized lines and payment methods (direct deposit vs. check). Compliance features include I-9 and policy acknowledgments as trackable tasks with document metadata and expiration dates. HR can manage disciplinary actions, performance review cycles (ratings, goals, short comments), and training assignments. Audit logs record every update to pay rates, bank accounts, and deductions. Reporting APIs provide labor distribution, overtime spend, attendance points, and payroll register exports with synthetic aggregates. This scenario is ideal for API simulation because it involves heavy CRUD, effective dating, approvals, and reconciliations without relying on content-heavy artifacts.

name: Blackbaud Raiser's Edge NXT Fundraising CRM
description: Raiser’s Edge–style fundraising CRM models donors, relationships, campaigns, and gift processing. Staff CRUD constituent profiles (individual/organization, addresses, communication preferences, consent flags), relationships (households, employer matching, board affiliations), and moves-management portfolios (assigned fundraiser, next action date). Gift workflows include creating donations (one-time/recurring/pledge), allocating to funds/appeals, applying soft credits, and tracking payment statuses (initiated/settled/failed/refunded). Campaign setup CRUD campaigns, goals, segments, and solicitation codes for attribution. Events can be modeled as fundraising dinners or galas with tickets, tables, attendees, and sponsorship packages; revenue is linked back to constituents and allocations. Receipting workflows generate receipt records (template ID, send method, sent_at) and handle acknowledgement tasks. Import tools CRUD batch jobs for offline gifts with validation errors and review queues. Analytics endpoints summarize donor retention, LYBUNT/SYBUNT lists, average gift, and pipeline by fundraiser using synthesizable metrics. Permissions separate gift entry from finance review, and audit trails capture changes for compliance and internal controls.

name: PledgePilot Charity CRM & Donor Stewardship
description: PledgePilot is a nonprofit donor management and stewardship platform designed for repeatable fundraising workflows. Staff CRUD constituent profiles (donors, households, corporate sponsors), communication preferences/consents, relationships, and engagement notes. Fundraising teams create campaigns and appeals with goals, segments, suggested ask amounts, and attribution codes; then record gifts as one-time or recurring pledges with schedules, payment methods (token metadata), soft credits, and designations (restricted funds). Workflows include pledge creation → payment attempts → settlement/failed statuses → receipts/acknowledgements (template metadata) → year-end summaries. Users manage events as fundraising touchpoints (tables, tickets, sponsorship levels) and track attendance and pledge fulfillment. The platform supports basic grant tracking: grantmakers, submissions, requested/awarded amounts, reporting deadlines, and status stages. Admins configure custom fields, import/export batches, deduplication rules, and role-based access. Reporting endpoints expose totals by campaign, donor cohorts, retention, and open pledges. All records are synthesizable (names, amounts, timestamps, statuses), making it ideal for API simulations of financial transactions without requiring real payment processing.

name: GrantLedger Compliance & Reporting Tracker
description: GrantLedger helps nonprofits and municipal programs manage grant compliance using structured records rather than narrative-heavy content. Users CRUD funders, grants, budgets (line items, allowable cost categories), reporting schedules, and performance metrics (target vs actual). Program managers create activities and expenditures with attachments metadata (receipt IDs, file URLs), allocate costs to budget lines, and mark items as reimbursable/nonreimbursable. Compliance officers define requirements as checklists (policy acknowledgements, procurement thresholds, subrecipient monitoring tasks) with due dates, assignees, and evidence links. Workflows include grant award → budget approval → spend tracking → drawdown request (amount, period, status) → supporting documentation → submission status. The platform tracks subrecipients as entities with agreements, risk ratings, site visit schedules, findings, and corrective action plans (CAPs) with statuses and deadlines. APIs provide variance reports, overdue requirement alerts, audit trails, and exportable ledgers by grant period. All data—amounts, dates, checklists, statuses—can be synthesized for realistic compliance simulations.

name: K9Care Veterinary Practice & Appointment Manager
description: K9Care is a veterinary clinic management platform that handles scheduling, patient records, and billing without requiring real medical narratives. Clinics CRUD clients, pets (species, breed, age, microchip ID), vaccinations (type, due dates), allergies flags, and visit histories (reason codes, diagnosis codes, short notes). Front-desk users manage appointment slots by provider and room, create visits, and handle statuses (requested/confirmed/checked_in/in_exam/complete/canceled/no_show). The platform tracks treatment plans as structured items (medication name, dosage, frequency, duration), lab orders (test type, sample collected timestamp, result status), and inventory consumption for administered items. Billing includes invoices, line items, taxes, discounts, payment methods metadata, and refunds. Workflows include new patient intake → reminder notifications (vaccines, annual exams) → appointment → checkout → follow-up task. Staff can upload documents as metadata (rabies certificate IDs, lab report file IDs) and manage consent forms. APIs provide scheduling, patient lookup, due-soon vaccine reports, and inventory reorder thresholds.

name: RescueRoster Foster Network & Animal Placement
description: RescueRoster is an animal rescue operations system for intakes, fosters, and adoptions. Staff CRUD animal profiles (species, breed, intake date, temperament tags), medical checkpoints (vaccines due, spay/neuter status flag), and location statuses (shelter, foster home, medical boarding). Foster coordinators CRUD foster households, capacity limits, pet restrictions, and availability; then create placements with start/end dates and status (requested/approved/active/ended). Adoption workflows include adopter applications (household members, landlord approval flag, references metadata), screening steps, meet-and-greet appointments, and adoption contracts (document metadata) leading to finalized adoption records and fees. The system tracks transports between locations, scheduled vet appointments, and supply distributions (food, crates) as inventory transactions. Communication is modeled via notes and task assignments rather than long stories. APIs support matching animals to foster capacity constraints, tracking days in care, generating follow-up schedules, and reporting outcomes (adopted, transferred, returned) with timestamps and reasons.

name: PetSupplyPro B2B Wholesale Ordering for Shelters & Clinics
description: PetSupplyPro is a B2B e-commerce platform for shelters, rescues, and veterinary clinics purchasing supplies in bulk. Buyers CRUD organization accounts, shipping locations, tax exemption certificates metadata, and user roles/approvals. Catalog entities include products (SKU, brand, unit size), case packs, tiered pricing, and subscription reorder options. Procurement workflows include cart building → quote request (optional) → approval routing (draft/submitted/approved/rejected) → purchase order → fulfillment statuses (picked/packed/shipped/backordered) → invoice → payment status. Inventory is tracked at warehouses with available/reserved/on_order counts; allocations and substitutions can be recorded when items are out of stock. Returns and credits are modeled with RMA numbers, reason codes, and inspection outcomes. The platform supports donations-in-kind from manufacturers as special orders with $0 pricing but tracked fair market value. APIs expose product search by category, reorder endpoints, order tracking, spend analytics by department, and contract pricing lists for member organizations—fully synthesizable with realistic commerce behavior.

name: PolicyProof Ethics Hotline & Compliance Case Manager
description: PolicyProof is a compliance case management platform for organizations and nonprofits to track reports, investigations, and corrective actions. Users submit reports via web form with categories (harassment, fraud, safety), anonymity flag, involved parties (structured entities), and attachments metadata. Compliance teams CRUD cases, assign investigators, set severity and confidentiality levels, and track case status (new/triage/investigating/awaiting_response/closed/substantiated/unsubstantiated). Evidence is modeled as logged items (type, source, timestamp) with file references, not heavy content. The system includes interview schedules, action items, and corrective action plans with owners and due dates. Policies and trainings are managed as acknowledgements: assign a policy to employees/volunteers, record acceptance timestamps, and track overdue attestations. Audit trails capture every status change and access event. APIs provide dashboards for open cases by category, time-to-close metrics, recurring issue tagging, and exportable compliance logs for auditors. All datasets (people, dates, statuses, categories) can be synthesized for realistic legal/compliance simulations without requiring sensitive real data.

name: DealDock Contract Lifecycle Manager (CLM)
description: DealDock is a contract management system for drafting, negotiating, and renewing agreements with structured clause and obligation tracking. Legal ops CRUD counterparties, contacts, contract records, templates, clause library entries, and negotiation versions. Each contract stores key terms (effective_date, term_length, auto_renew, governing_law, payment_terms), linked products/services, and approval routing (requester → legal → finance → exec). Users create redline versions with change metadata (version_number, editor, summary) and track negotiation statuses (draft/in_review/negotiating/approved/executed/terminated). Obligations are modeled as tasks with owners, due dates, recurrence, and evidence links; renewals generate scheduled events with notice periods and renewal options. Repository features include tagging, custom fields, and retention/archival rules. Integrations can be simulated via endpoints for “send to eSignature” (returns envelope_id) and “sync to CRM” (creates account/opportunity references). Reporting endpoints cover contract value by counterparty, upcoming renewals, and obligation completion. All data is synthetic-friendly while exercising complex workflows and relational data.

name: K9Stay Pet Sitting & Boarding Marketplace (Ops-First)
description: K9Stay is a pet sitting and boarding operations platform that manages bookings and care schedules without requiring real media content. Pet owners CRUD profiles, pets (species, breed, age, weight), vaccination records (type, expires_at), feeding instructions, medications (dosage, schedule), and emergency contacts. Sitters CRUD availability calendars, service offerings (drop-in, overnight, boarding), service areas, and pricing rules (base_rate, holiday_multiplier, extra_pet_fee). Booking workflow includes request → accepted/declined → confirmed → in_progress → completed/canceled, with payments modeled as invoices and payout records (status: pending/paid/failed). During stays, sitters log care events (walk, feed, med_administered) with timestamps, short notes, and optional location coordinates. Disputes and refunds are tracked with cases, reasons, and resolution statuses. Admin APIs cover background-check status flags, policy enforcement, and review/ratings entities. This supports realistic CRUD across users, pets, bookings, schedules, and time-series care logs—ideal for synthesizing datasets and testing routing, availability checks, and status transitions.

name: MacroMart Nutrition Coaching & Meal Planning Studio
description: MacroMart is a nutrition coaching platform for dietitians and clients with structured meal plans and adherence tracking. Coaches CRUD clients, health questionnaires (structured responses), goals, dietary preferences/allergies, and plan periods. Meal planning uses a food database (synthetic entries) and recipes with ingredients, servings, macros, and tags (vegetarian, low_sodium). Coaches build meal plans as calendars of meals/snacks, generate grocery lists, and set macro targets per day. Clients log adherence by marking meals eaten, swapping items (with substitution rules), and recording weigh-ins and measurements. Messaging is modeled as threaded conversations with short messages and attachments metadata. Billing includes coaching packages, subscriptions, invoices, and session scheduling. Compliance features track consent forms, data-sharing preferences, and audit logs of plan changes. Reporting includes macro averages, adherence percentage, weight trend charts, and flagged days (missed logs, low protein). All information can be synthesized—foods, macros, plans, timestamps—and supports rich CRUD and workflow testing (draft → published plan, client acknowledgment, revisions, and exports) without content-heavy requirements.

name: PolicyPact Vendor Due Diligence & Contract Compliance
description: PolicyPact is a vendor risk and contract compliance platform that connects due diligence tasks to contract obligations. Procurement and compliance teams CRUD vendors, contacts, services provided, risk tiers, questionnaires, and evidence requests. Vendors respond with structured answers, policy attestations, and document metadata (insurance_certificate file_id, expires_at). Reviews produce risk findings with severity and remediation plans. Contract records link to vendors and include required controls (e.g., encryption_at_rest, breach_notification_days) as obligation items with due dates and verification cycles. Workflows include vendor onboarding → due diligence → approval → contract executed → periodic reassessment, with statuses and SLAs for each stage. The system tracks insurance policies (coverage limits, renewal dates), security reviews, and access approvals (systems_requested, granted_at, revoked_at). Notifications and webhooks can be triggered on upcoming expirations or overdue remediation. Reporting provides vendor risk distribution, upcoming renewals, and compliance completion rates by department. This scenario is highly synthesizable and API-friendly, emphasizing CRUD across vendors, contracts, evidence, obligations, and recurring review schedules without relying on long-form content.

name: Coupa Procurement
description: Coupa is a B2B procurement and spend management platform used by enterprises to control purchasing. Entities are highly synthesizable: companies, users, roles/approvals, suppliers, supplier contacts, catalogs (items, pricing, UOM), requisitions, approval chains, purchase orders, receipts, invoices, budgets, cost centers, projects, and policy rules. Core workflows: requester creates cart from catalog or free-text item → submits requisition → approvals applied by threshold/cost center → PO issued to supplier → goods receipt recorded (partial receipts, backorders) → supplier invoice matched (2-way/3-way match flags) → payment status updated. Admins manage supplier onboarding tasks (forms, compliance statuses), contract metadata (start/end dates, renewal flags), and blocked supplier lists. APIs can model budget checks, encumbrances, split accounting, tax/fee lines, and dispute handling (invoice on hold, mismatch reasons, resolution notes). Spend analytics endpoints can return synthetic aggregation by supplier/category/month, exception counts, and cycle times, without requiring any real content beyond structured line-item data.

name: Epic MyChart (Patient Portal)
description: MyChart-style patient portals center on structured clinical and administrative records that can be synthesized for API simulation. Patients CRUD profile details (addresses, insurance, preferred pharmacy), communication preferences/consents, and dependents/proxy access. Core workflows include: search providers (directory metadata) → request/confirm appointments → complete pre-visit questionnaires → receive check-in tasks (forms, copays as invoice metadata) → view after-visit summaries (short text + coded fields). Patients view and download test results (labs with numeric values and reference ranges), vitals history, medications (Rx list, dose, refills remaining), immunizations, allergies, and care plans. Secure messaging can be modeled as threaded conversations with categories (billing/clinical), attachments metadata, and triage routing to pools. Billing features CRUD guarantors, payment methods token metadata, statements, payment plans, and transaction records. Clinics/admin users CRUD provider schedules, appointment types, visit statuses (requested/scheduled/arrived/completed), and portal content templates (education handouts metadata). Everything is database-driven, with realistic timestamps, status transitions, and audit logs.

name: Kaiser Permanente (Integrated Care Portal)
description: An integrated care portal like Kaiser Permanente can be simulated as a multi-module healthcare platform where members manage coverage and care in one place. Members CRUD household members, insurance plans (effective dates, deductibles, copays), ID cards metadata, and primary care assignments. Appointment workflows include selecting department/location → choosing visit type (in-person/video/phone) → picking a slot → rescheduling/canceling with reason codes and waitlist entries. Clinical record views cover diagnoses/problem lists (coded), lab orders/results, imaging orders (report metadata), medication lists, refill requests, and vaccination history. Pharmacy flows CRUD preferred pickup location, auto-refill settings, refill orders, shipment tracking metadata, and copay invoices. Care teams CRUD member panels, tasks (follow-up calls, labs due), care gaps (preventive services due), and referrals/authorizations with statuses (submitted/approved/denied/expired). Additional member services include symptom questionnaires (structured answers), secure message threads, and case management notes. Data is synthesizable as structured entities and events without requiring long-form medical content.

name: Teladoc (Direct-to-Consumer Telehealth)
description: A Teladoc-style telehealth platform is ideal for CRUD-heavy simulation around encounters, scheduling, and clinical documentation metadata. Patients CRUD profiles, medical history fields (conditions, allergies, current meds), preferred pharmacies, and payment/insurance details. They create visit requests by selecting specialty (general, dermatology, behavioral), symptoms (structured tags), and availability windows; the system matches to provider schedules and generates appointments with join links metadata. Visit lifecycle is modeled with statuses (requested/triaged/scheduled/in_session/completed) and artifacts: intake forms, vitals (optional), provider notes (short structured sections), diagnoses codes, and prescriptions (drug, dose, quantity, refills, eRx status). Messaging supports pre-visit clarifications and post-visit follow-ups as ticket-like threads. Providers CRUD licenses by state, availability blocks, visit templates, and clinical orders (labs/referrals as metadata). Admin workflows include eligibility checks, refunds, visit audits, and quality ratings. The platform can generate realistic synthetic timelines, cancellations, no-shows, and documentation completeness checks without any AI inference.

name: Zocdoc (Provider Directory + Appointment Marketplace)
description: A Zocdoc-style marketplace can be simulated focusing on structured provider listings and booking workflows rather than content. Patients CRUD accounts, insurance plans, saved providers, and appointment preferences (distance, telehealth flag, time-of-day). They search a provider directory (specialty, location, in-network) and create booking requests for open slots. Workflows include: request → provider confirmation → reminders → reschedule/cancel with policy rules (cutoff windows, fees as invoice metadata). Providers/clinics CRUD practice profiles (locations, hours, services), appointment types, slot inventory (availability blocks), staff users, and intake forms. Reviews can be modeled as ratings + short comments with moderation status (pending/approved/rejected). Insurance verification is representable as eligibility checks with outcomes (verified/needs_info/out_of_network) and documentation metadata. The system tracks referral sources, conversion metrics, and patient retention cohorts as analytics entities. All key data—providers, slots, bookings, insurers, and reviews—is fully synthesizable, enabling realistic database interactions and state transitions.

name: GoodRx (Pharmacy Price + Coupon + Medication Manager)
description: A GoodRx-like platform can be simulated as a medication and pharmacy shopping tool where all pricing and inventory can be synthetic yet realistic. Users CRUD medication lists (drug, strength, form, quantity), refill reminders, preferred pharmacies, and household members. They query synthetic price quotes by NDC/medication and zip code across pharmacies, generating coupon offers with terms (BIN/PCN/Group/ID fields as strings), expiration timestamps, and eligibility constraints. Workflows include: select medication → compare prices → save coupon → mark as used → track savings history. A prescription transfer flow can CRUD transfer requests (from_pharmacy, to_pharmacy, Rx identifiers metadata) with statuses (submitted/processing/ready/failed). Pharmacies CRUD store profiles, hours, contact info, and synthetic price tables per medication/quantity. The platform can include membership subscriptions (plan tiers, renewals), notifications, and audit logs. No real drug content is required beyond short descriptions and standardized codes, making it well-suited for API simulation.

name: Airbnb (Long-Term Rentals / Sublets Marketplace Variant)
description: A rentals marketplace like Airbnb (scoped to long-term stays/sublets) is highly synthesizable around listings, availability, and bookings. Hosts CRUD listings (address metadata, unit type, house rules, pricing, fees, photos metadata), calendars (availability blocks, minimum stays), and booking settings (cancellation policy, instant book). Guests CRUD profiles, verification metadata, saved listings, and trip preferences. Core workflow: search/filter listings → request to book (dates, guest count) → host accepts/declines → payment authorization metadata → booking confirmed → check-in/out → review and dispute flows. Messaging can be modeled as short-text threads attached to bookings. Additional operations include security deposits (holds/releases), damage claims (case records), and cleaning tasks (task assignments, schedules). Admin tools can CRUD trust/safety flags, listing suspensions, refund cases, and policy violations with audit trails. The platform avoids content-heavy requirements while still enabling realistic state machines and transactional records.

name: Nextdoor (Neighborhood Community Platform)
description: A Nextdoor-style community app can be simulated by focusing on structured neighborhood membership and short-form interactions. Users CRUD profiles (name, address verification metadata, neighborhood), privacy settings, and notification preferences. Posts are short text with categories (recommendation, safety, lost & found, event, for-sale), optional location pins, and attachments metadata. Workflows include creating posts → comments/replies → reactions → edits/deletes → reporting/moderation decisions (open/under_review/removed). Marketplace features CRUD items for sale (price, condition, pickup location), buyer inquiries, and transaction status (available/pending/sold). Events CRUD titles, times, venues, RSVP lists, and reminders. Local business pages CRUD hours, service categories, and promotional posts; residents can leave ratings and short reviews. Moderators/admins manage neighborhood boundaries, member approvals, flagged content queues, and ban/suspension actions. All entities are database-first and fully synthesizable without requiring long articles or recommendation algorithms.

name: Bumble (Dating + Social Connections)
description: A Bumble-like dating platform can be simulated with profile CRUD, matching, and conversation state transitions using entirely synthetic data. Users CRUD profiles (bio short text, interests tags, photos metadata, prompts, location coordinates, age range), verification status, and privacy controls. Discovery settings CRUD distance, gender preferences, and filters (education, lifestyle tags). The swipe workflow generates actions (like/pass/superlike), which create matches when mutual; matches have timers/expiration rules and states (active/expired/unmatched/blocked). Messaging can be modeled as short-text threads with read receipts, attachments metadata, and reporting reasons. Safety features CRUD block lists, report cases, and moderation outcomes. Premium subscriptions CRUD plan tiers, renewals, boosts, and spotlight sessions with usage counters. Optional friend/network modes can CRUD groups, events, and RSVP lists. Analytics entities (daily swipes, match rate, retention cohorts) can be derived from event logs. The platform is highly suitable for API simulation because it’s dominated by structured user, match, and message records rather than content-heavy media.

name: VRBO / Vacation Rental Manager (Family & Group Stays)
description: A VRBO-like vacation rental platform can be simulated with structured inventory, traveler inquiries, and booking lifecycles. Property managers CRUD property profiles (sleeps, bedrooms, bathrooms, pet policy), rate tables by season, fee schedules (cleaning, resort, pet), and tax rules by jurisdiction (static tables). Calendar management CRUDs availability, changeover days, and minimum stay rules. Travelers create inquiries (dates, group size, questions), which managers respond to with quotes (line items, expiration timestamps). Booking workflows include quote accepted → reservation created → deposit collected → remaining balance schedule → check-in/out → damage claims and refund processing (numeric fields). Managers can CRUD guest profiles, identity verification status flags, rental agreements (document metadata), and special requests. Channel management can be modeled by syncing external calendar blocks and mapping listing IDs across channels. Operational features include assigning cleaners, generating task lists per reservation, and tracking completion statuses. Reporting endpoints can aggregate occupancy, ADR, revenue by property, and inquiry-to-book conversion. The platform remains realistic without requiring any non-synthesizable content beyond short descriptions and metadata.

name: Mindbody (Wellness Studio Class & Appointment Booking)
description: A Mindbody-like platform fits API simulation by focusing on schedules, inventory (classes), and client accounts. Studios CRUD locations, instructors, class types (duration, capacity), recurring class schedules, appointment services (massage, coaching), and resource constraints (rooms, equipment). Clients CRUD profiles, memberships, packages, credit balances, waivers metadata, and payment methods token metadata. Booking workflows include browsing schedules → reserving a class spot or appointment slot → waitlisting → cancellation with policy windows and fee rules. Attendance tracking CRUDs check-ins, late-cancel flags, and no-show statuses. Studios can manage staff schedules, substitute assignments, and payroll-friendly session logs (counts and timestamps). Promotions CRUDs discount codes, intro offers, and referral credits. Communication features include automated reminders, short message templates, and notification preferences. Reporting endpoints can summarize utilization, revenue by service, instructor performance metrics, and retention by membership. All essential data—times, capacities, prices, statuses, and short notes—can be synthesized realistically while enabling complex CRUD and state transitions.

name: Meetup (Local Community Groups & Event RSVPs)
description: A Meetup-style community platform is suitable when modeled around group and event metadata rather than long-form content. Organizers CRUD groups (topics/tags, location, membership rules), member roles (organizer/co-organizer), dues (price and billing period), and group settings (approval required, question prompts). Events are core entities: organizers CRUD event records (title, short description, venue, capacity, start/end times), attendee limits, waitlists, and check-in lists. Members CRUD RSVPs (going/not going), plus visibility preferences and notification settings. The platform supports workflows like: create group → publish event → collect RSVPs → manage waitlist promotions → day-of check-ins → post-event feedback ratings and short comments. Messaging can be scoped to short announcements and direct messages tied to a group or event. Safety and moderation features CRUD reported content flags, member warnings, and bans. Optional ticketing can be simulated with ticket types, order records, refunds, and promo codes (numeric and status fields). Analytics endpoints can aggregate attendance rates, churn, topic popularity, and organizer activity without requiring content-heavy posts.

name: Discourse (Modern Forum Communities)
description: A Discourse-like forum is API-friendly when centered on structured discussion metadata and moderation workflows using short text. Admins CRUD sites, categories, tags, groups, trust-level rules, and user roles. Users CRUD topics (titles, short body), posts/replies, edits with revision history, and reactions/likes. Moderation workflows include flagging posts, reviewing a queue, applying actions (hide, delete, suspend user), and logging staff notes. Additional entities include polls (options and vote counts), bookmarks, notifications, and subscriptions (watching/muting categories). Access control can be modeled through private categories and group-based permissions. Workflows often include: create topic → replies → mark solution/accepted answer → close/archive topic; or: user posts → community flags → moderator reviews → resolution. Rate limits and anti-spam can be synthesized via throttling rules and automated state flags (needs_approval, silenced). Reporting endpoints can summarize active users, posts per category, response times, and moderation volume. The platform avoids any requirement for long articles or media while still producing rich CRUD interactions and state transitions.

name: LinkedIn (Professional Network & Recruiting Metadata)
description: A LinkedIn-style professional network can be simulated by focusing on profile, connection, and recruiting workflows rather than feed ranking. Users CRUD profiles (headline, roles, skills, education, locations), endorsements (counts), certifications, and short recommendations. Network features CRUD connection requests, follow relationships, and messaging threads (short text). Company pages CRUD organizations, locations, employees (relationships), and job postings (title, level, salary range, remote flag, required skills). Recruiting workflows include candidate pipelines: applications, source, stages (new/screen/interview/offer/hired), interview events, interviewer assignments, and feedback scores. Sales-style modules can CRUD leads, accounts, notes, tasks, and reminders. Groups and events can be modeled with membership, invitations, and RSVP tracking. Compliance and privacy settings CRUD consent flags, profile visibility, and data export requests. Analytics endpoints can aggregate profile views (counts), applicant conversion rates, and hiring funnel metrics. All fields are structured and synthesizable (names, titles, timestamps, statuses), enabling realistic database interactions without needing authentic content feeds or recommendation ML.

name: Hinge / Bumble (Dating Profiles, Matches, and Date Planning)
description: A Hinge- or Bumble-style dating app is well-suited to synthesized data because it relies on structured profiles, preference filters, and match states. Users CRUD profiles (photos metadata, bio prompts with short answers, age, gender, orientation, location coordinates, interests), verification status, and discovery preferences (distance, age range, dealbreakers). Discovery workflows generate candidate cards from stored profiles; actions CRUD likes, passes, and “super like” style boosts with quotas. When mutual likes occur, the system creates a match entity with messaging threads (short text), read receipts, and safety controls (block/report). Date-planning features can CRUD proposed date ideas (venue type, time windows), RSVP acceptance, and calendar reminders. Subscriptions can be modeled via plan tiers, entitlements (daily likes), renewal dates, and receipts metadata. Safety and moderation workflows include reports with categories, evidence metadata, and resolution statuses. Analytics endpoints can track match rates, response times, and churn. The app remains realistic without requiring any AI-generated compatibility scores; matching can be a deterministic rules-based filter over synthesizable fields.

name: ServiceNow (ITSM Ticketing & Service Catalog)
description: ServiceNow-style IT service management portals are highly suitable for API/database simulation because they revolve around structured records and repeatable workflows. Admins CRUD organizations, departments, users, roles, assignment groups, SLAs, and notification rules. The service catalog supports CRUDing catalog items, request forms (fields, validation, conditional logic), pricing metadata, approval chains, and fulfillment tasks. End users create incidents and service requests with categories, impact/urgency, attachments metadata, and comments; tickets move through statuses (new/assigned/in_progress/on_hold/resolved/closed) with timestamps, assignees, and resolution codes. Change management workflows CRUD change requests, risk levels, implementation plans (short text), CAB approvals, maintenance windows, and linked configuration items. A CMDB module models configuration items (servers, apps, endpoints), relationships, and lifecycle states. Reporting can be simulated via saved filters, queue views, and dashboard widgets computed from ticket data. Integrations can be modeled with webhooks and inbound email parsing metadata, without needing any real infrastructure.

name: Jira Service Management (Customer Support + Internal Helpdesk)
description: A Jira Service Management–style platform can be simulated as a customer portal plus internal triage system. Projects (service desks) contain request types, form fields, and automation rules. Admins CRUD customers, agents, teams, queues, SLAs, and knowledge-base article metadata (titles, tags, visibility) without generating long content. Users submit requests with short summaries, categories, priority, environment fields, and attachment metadata. Workflows model status transitions (open → waiting_for_customer → in_progress → done) with required fields on transitions. Agents CRUD comments (public/internal), linked issues, watchers, and time logs, and can create child tasks for fulfillment. Approvals are structured: request requires manager approval, then procurement approval, then fulfillment steps. Asset/CMDB-lite features manage assets (laptops, licenses) with owners, serial numbers, warranty dates, and assignment history. Operational patterns include queue-based assignment, escalation via SLA breaches, bulk actions, canned responses, and post-resolution CSAT surveys (rating + short text). All entities are well-structured and synthesize cleanly for API testing.

name: NetSuite (ERP Purchasing, Vendors, and Inventory Receiving)
description: A NetSuite-style ERP procurement module is suitable for synthesis because it is driven by master data and transactional records with auditability. Admins CRUD subsidiaries, locations, departments, chart of accounts, items/SKUs, units of measure, tax codes, and vendor records (contacts, payment terms). Purchasing workflows include: create purchase requisition → approvals → convert to purchase order → send to vendor (status metadata) → receive items → generate vendor bill → pay bill. Entities include purchase orders, line items, expected receipt dates, partial receipts, backorders, landed cost allocations (numbers), and three-way match status (PO/receipt/bill). Inventory interactions model on-hand quantities by location/bin, reorder points, transfers, and adjustments with reason codes. Vendor management supports price lists, lead times, performance ratings, and compliance document metadata. Role-based permissions for requesters, approvers, buyers, and AP clerks are central. Reporting endpoints can return open PO aging, fill rates, inventory turns, and spend by vendor/category. This scenario emphasizes complex but fully synthesizable relational data and multi-step workflows common in enterprise systems.

name: Propertyware (Property Management for Rentals)
description: Propertyware-style property management systems are database-centric and synthesize well with structured leasing and accounting records. Managers CRUD property portfolios, buildings/units, owners, tenants, vendors, and lease agreements (terms, rent amount, deposits, start/end dates). Listing and applicant workflows can be simplified to managing applications (income numbers, screening status flags), approvals, and move-in scheduling. Core operations include rent charges, recurring charges, payments metadata, late fees, and ledgers per tenant and property. Maintenance workflows CRUD work orders, categories, priorities, vendor assignments, estimated/actual costs, and status transitions (new/assigned/scheduled/completed/invoiced). Inspections can be modeled with checklist items, condition ratings, and photo metadata. Vacancy management tracks unit availability, turn tasks, and marketing status without generating long descriptions. Owner reporting includes statements, distributions, and reserve balances. Communication features can be represented via message threads and templates (short text). This scenario offers rich relationships (owners→properties→units→leases→tenants) and multi-party workflows across accounting, maintenance, and occupancy.

name: Ticketmaster (Event Ticketing + Entry Management)
description: A Ticketmaster-style platform supports high-volume event discovery and ticket fulfillment with highly structured, synthesizable data. Organizers CRUD venues (sections, rows, seat maps as coordinates/labels), events (dates, doors time, age rules), ticket types/price tiers, holds/allocations, promo codes, and sales windows. Inventory workflows include creating seat blocks, releasing holds, dynamic price rules (rule metadata), and tracking remaining capacity per section. Customers CRUD profiles, saved payment methods (token metadata), delivery methods (mobile/print), and carts; then purchase orders containing line items, fees, taxes, and delivery status. Post-purchase flows include transfer tickets to other users, resell listings (price, quantity, expiration), refunds/chargebacks, and event cancellation handling. Entry operations simulate scanning/validation: create check-in devices, scan attempts, access decisions (valid/duplicate/void), and attendance analytics. Support teams manage disputes, exceptions, and manual comping with audit logs. All data (events, seats, orders, barcodes as strings, scan timestamps) can be faked while remaining realistic for API/database testing.

name: Steamworks Market (PC Game Library + Virtual Item Marketplace)
description: A Steam-like platform can be simulated by focusing on account, library, entitlement, and virtual goods trading rather than game content. Users CRUD accounts, profiles, device sessions, and security settings; purchase games/DLC as products with licenses (entitlements) tied to the user. The catalog supports CRUD apps (name, genre tags, age rating), editions, regional pricing tables, and bundles. Virtual goods features include inventories (items with rarity, attributes, tradable flags), crafting/consumption events, and marketplace listings (ask price, quantity, expiration, status). Transaction workflows include wallet top-ups (synthetic balances), checkout → order → fulfillment → entitlement grant, plus refunds with eligibility rules. Trading workflows include trade offers (items/currency, counterparty, state machine: created/accepted/canceled/expired) and escrow/hold states. Social/community can be limited to structured metadata: friends, groups, achievements (counters), playtime logs, and review ratings (short text). Admin APIs manage fraud flags, chargeback cases, and item bans with full audit trails.

name: Airbnb Experiences (Activities Booking + Host Scheduling)
description: An Airbnb Experiences-style platform models bookable activities with host-controlled capacity and schedules. Hosts CRUD profiles, payout preferences (token metadata), experience listings (title, category, language, location coordinates, meeting point), requirements (age, fitness level), pricing per guest, add-ons, and cancellation policies. Availability is managed via time slots, blackout dates, capacity limits, and minimum/maximum lead time rules. Guests CRUD profiles, saved travelers, wishlists, and payment methods; then browse experiences and create bookings with guest counts, selected add-ons, and special requests (short text). Booking workflows include request-to-book vs instant book, confirmation, reschedule, cancellation, refunds, and no-show handling. Messaging can be simulated as short messages and templates. Post-activity flows include check-in (host marks attendees present), issue reporting, and two-sided reviews/ratings with tags. Operational entities include support cases, payout batches, tax forms metadata, and dispute states. All core objects—listings, slots, bookings, prices, refunds, attendance—are structured and synthesizable for realistic API simulation.

name: OpenTable for Events (Restaurant Reservations + Prepaid Menus)
description: An OpenTable-like system for standard reservations plus special events is well-suited for CRUD-heavy simulations. Restaurants CRUD locations, floor plans (tables, capacity, join rules), service periods, turn times, reservation policies, and blackout dates. They also create special events (prix fixe menus as items, seating times, deposit requirements, ticketed seats) and manage inventory by time slot/table. Guests CRUD profiles, dining preferences, allergies (tags), saved payment methods (token metadata), and favorite restaurants; then create reservations with party size, time, and notes. Workflows include waitlist join, confirmation via code, modification, cancellation, no-show fees, and table assignment at check-in. For prepaid events, the flow includes checkout → order → reservation linkage → receipt metadata → refund/credit issuance. Restaurants manage staff assignments, shift notes, and status boards (pending/confirmed/seated/closed). Post-meal, guests leave ratings, tags, and short reviews; restaurants respond and flag issues. Reporting endpoints provide covers, turn times, revenue estimates, and no-show rates—all synthesizable numeric data.

name: Marriott Bonvoy (Hotel Booking + Loyalty Program)
description: A Marriott-style hospitality platform combines hotel inventory, rate management, and loyalty workflows with fully synthesizable records. Properties CRUD room types, amenities, photos metadata, rate plans (refundable/nonrefundable), packages, and taxes/fees. Inventory can be modeled as allotments per date and room type, with restrictions (min stay, close-to-arrival, advance purchase). Guests CRUD profiles, preferences (bed type, accessibility), saved travelers, and payment methods (token metadata).
